description:
New Mexican green chili may be the best food on earth. Green Chili Kitchen does a great job of staying true to the New Mexican tradition and classing it up a bit, as is the San Francisco way. I was born and raised in the Land of Enchantment (New Mexico) and I really love this place for bringing home to me. 

I've never met anyone who didn't like green chili. Give it a go! 

(p.s. this place deserves a better rating than it has. The food is fantastic and the space is lovely)
author: Shaun L.

description:
I live close by and have gone to green Chile kitchen frequently. I have very mixed feelings about it at this stage.

 I really like the space (large and airy with windows on two sides), the decor and the communal table. I also like that it's just off Divis. Some of the menu is good (I like the burittos) But I've also had some eating experiences there which range from mediocre (empanadas) through the bad (meagre flat quesadilla with cheese and nothing else for $11) to the appalling (violent food poisoning).

This is my local restaurant: I wish I could like it more.
author: William M.

description:
Was not impressed.

Just moved to the neighborhood and tried this spot out with my sister who had been in the past. She wanted the frito pie and we split that with a salad. We also ordered an agua fresca.

The person who took our order had no clue what she was doing. She could not answer any questions about the menu and we had to wait for her to ask someone else.

As for the food, it was good but, like others have mentioned, not worth the price. The frito pie was kind of small and it was really something you'd make at home, no restaurant twist to it at all. The veggie salad was good but it was $16 without any meat. I did not leave the restaurant feeling full.

Overall, this place is OK. I wouldn't necessarily recommend it, but I won't tell you not to go if you were in the mood for some New Mexican cuisine.
author: Roya B.

description: I came here to watch the Warriors game with a friend. They said it was New Mexican food which I never had experienced. To me, it seems like regular Mexican food. Maybe a little fancier. I ordered the Chile Rellenos combination and that was above average. I enjoyed the fried stuff peppers the most. The taco, rice and the rest of the plate was average. The Racer 5 IPA was amazing. The experience was nice. Not bad. Maybe overpriced?
author: Kay T.

description:
I stopped by Green Chile Kitchen with some friends for brunch because we were ravenous and there was absolutely no line. In hindsight, that would have been a good indication of what was in store for us, but we went in anyway. 

You order at a counter and then they give you a number and you sit down. Maybe the cashier was new, because I asked for a side of roasted potatoes (which is listed on the menu...) and he was confused and asked me if I meant mashed potatoes. It also took about 10 minutes for three people to order- it was very slow. 

We sat down and my friends' food arrived immediately. My food was nowhere to be seen 15 minutes later, and they were almost done. We had ordered the exact same thing, so it shouldn't have taken that long for my food to come out. Finally, my food arrived. The food was good- the healthy breakfast bowl and roasted potatoes were filling and flavorful, and they didn't feel heavy or greasy. It was expensive though, at around $20 for both of them. 

Overall, it was an extremely mediocre experience with good food. I will probably return to try the dinner menu, which looked like it had potential. I would recommend it to someone who is looking for healthy food, but don't expect fantastic or fast service.
author: Ayushi A.

description:
Really confusing restaurant. You order/pay at counter, then seat yourself---but there's no way of figuring that out. Employees themselves look confused when asked.

Food was mediocre. Extremely informal/casual environment but the prices indicated formal setting...confusing.

Friday night, 6+ kids running around wild while their parents ate dinner gave this a Chuck-E-Cheese ambience.

Not going back.
author: Priya S.

description: If the service is bad the food is not far behind. Best eating experiences employ a holistic approach to the process. Read the reviews. Can everyone be wrong?  Sometimes it's impulse that takes you to a restaurant and sometimes expectations. Let's get serious. Is this NEE Mexican fusion or New Mexican cuisine. Big difference.  As someone who went to college and had plenty of great food in Santa Fe be wary of the titles. If it's the real thing you wouldn't have the negative reviews. Always is amazing that someone can invest big money in a eatery and under deliver. Ah well there's a sucker born every minute!
author: Jhb R.

description:
Crappy service. So much so that my friend asked them if they were stoned.

I ordered the Chile releno with a beef taco plate and a horchata and they gave me a watermelon juice and just the Chile releno.

After talking to them about it they fixed it, but not after a lot of blame gaming.

They also forgot my friends drink and her pie.

Horrible, crappy, cold food. I'd rather have a taco from taco Bell and the Chile releno was dry. As was the rice and crappy beans.

Just plain awful and a waste of $20 for one plate of food.
author: Jack R.

description:
Really good representation of legit NM food. 

Although, I always regret getting combo plates. Still, sopaipillas are amazing with honey, butter, and anything else you can cram in there.

Will try the Frito pie in-a-bag one day.
author: Aren A.

description:
This restaurant is super unclear on the way they conduct themselves. 
When I arrived I waited at the door to be seated for nearly 2 minutes (long enough to send a text to my boyfriend) and was still not given notice that I wasn't following protocol. After asking the person who I locked eyes with ("April")  if I was going to be seated they condescendingly told me that I must place my order to be seated. 
After expressing my frustration I asked who the owner/management was and to my surprise it was the person who she was chatting it up with. I then left to the car to write this review.
author: Dafahlia M.

description: Are you craving delicious corn to be delivered to your office? You're in luck because caviar delivers from the Green Chile Kitchen! However, you should be willing to wait hours, or have the order be canceled at the last minute. The Green Chile is so slow you might die from hunger before it arrives.
author: Jillian M.

description: If you love New Mexican food and green chili this place is for you!! With red chili honey from Monroe's!!!!!
author: Kristi K.

description: This is a great burrito place, though you can get a lot more than a burrito. Very friendly staff, as well.  I highly recommend this place for authentic tasting, good quality food. They also have good beers on tap, and wine and soju drinks.
author: Doug A.

description:
The food here is very high quality, and reminiscent of the better run of indigenous restaurants I've eaten at in New Mexico itself.  But 5 out of 5 people at our table agreed that the food was too spicy.  I had the signature dish, a bowl of green chile stew.  The added meat was adequate in quality and quantity, but it floated in an enormous bowl of green chiles in soup.  I like green chiles, I thought I liked them a whole lot, but not this much, and the spiciness of it got to me, even though I like spicy food.  I could only finish about half of it.

Even basic things like the enchilada plate had sauce which was too spicy, even though they were ordered mild.

Service a little bit on the spacey side.  Good food, but watch it!
author: David B.

description:
I was honestly worried about trying Green Chile Kitchen for Brunch based on other reviews. I'm originally from New Mexico, so I'm pretty picky when it comes to restaurants outside of NM serving our cuisine. But....I'm happy to report this was AWESOME! We came here craving a breakfast burrito...and we were impressed.  You get alot of options in building your breakfast burrito platter...meat (several options), Chile (red or green, hot or mild), type of beans. I ordered green Chile with beef, my daughter ordered bacon with green. I kicked myself later for not getting the bacon. The bacon breakfast burrito is my definite recommendation. The side of roasted potatoes are simple but the red chile sauce on them was very tasty. Pinto beans, which I read per review are made vegetarian style (zero lard), worried me. But they were good. Tortillas were great...not the weird sweet tasting ones I've had in taquerias. All in all, I was satisfied with the food and service. I didn't have bad service at all, everyone was nice and polite. My only small complaint might be the "heat" of the green chile. I ordered "hot", but it wasn't too hot for me. But, that's just because I'm accustomed to very HOT chile and I understand not alot of people would appreciate that kind of heat. Still, both the red and green chile had lots of flavor.
Maybe its just low in reviews because it is not the local Mexican food flavor. New Mexican  food is neither Tex Mex nor taqueria style. It was a taste of home...one I surely miss since moving to CA. I'm so happy to find a place that warms my heart and my tummy. :)
author: Jenn H.

description:
Excellent food and reasonable prices. It was my first time and didn't know the servers don't come to the table to take your order. I'm not upset about that at all. I learned about this place from Check Please Bay Area and I'll definitely be back.

I'm on my second visit today and now I know the routine. I ordered the same thing as my last visit because the sopapillas were so awesome! Highly recommend!
author: John S.

description: We love Hatch Green Chile, the kind that makes you work up a sweat. They have regular and hot. Did not expect this in SFO
author: Terry B.

description: 3 and a half stars seems so so little for this place. It is so pretty and cute inside and their burrito is the best. I would put it up there with Don Pistos in the Marina. It is neatly wrapped and just great. I have had nothing but amazing experiences with their delivery as well.
author: Jazlyn H.

description: I only give this place one star for the food, which is great.  However, there was a lackadiaical-disintersted cabal of trophy-Millenials barely trying to achieve a basic work ethic, who couldn"t be bother to lift a finger (all the while, having no idea who Robert Smith really is). The service is pretty shockingly poor--where's my trophy?
author: Glendon R.

description:
I honestly admire how this place does not use lard in their beans. It is a huge win for us vegetarians.
I came in here with my boyfriend for our anniversary. The chef answered our questions with confidence that there was not any meat. (Paranoia of meat lol). Anyways, I ordered a vegetarian nachos. Trust me I'm a nacho enthusiast. And these were really good. Only wish there was more sourcream. 
My boyfriend has GERD so he is on a special diet and he had beans and the mashed potatoes. He really loved both of them. The mashed potatoes were off the hook.
author: Disha B.

description: I'm a huge fan of green chile, having lived with several folks who are from, and love, NM. Ordered the stuffed sopapilla, but was a little disappointed as everything was soggy and mostly very salty and minimally green chile - and overall there was a pretty high price premium.
author: Heidi L.

description:
I ordered a vegan burrito and it was disgusting. The worst burrito I've ever had cost me the most I've ever paid. No burrito should cost $12 and no burrito should be this gross.Sauce was very bland and some of the rice was hard.
I regret coming here.
author: Gökhan S.

description:
Enjoyable ambiance, decent service, and high quality posole.  It was exciting to find New Mexican food in San Francisco, especially since I haven't had any since moved out here from Texas.

I had the posole (red chile, plenty of hominy), migas, and got to try my friend's open faced enchiladas.  The blue corn tortillas were fluffy and flavorful.  I was mildly disappointed by their green chile, but it had a good kick and was awesome when mixed with the red chile.

Overall - delicious and not overly expensive.
author: Colin P.

description: Came here with a New Mexico native when we were in SF for brunch so he could compare it to home. I thought the food and drinks were okay, but nothing to brag about and he wasn't too thrilled with it either. In theory, the menu sounds pretty good but it was executed poorly and there wasn't too much flavor unless you added extras on top. We tried the watermelon and green Chile margaritas as well and they tasted so watered down and nonalcoholic so it wasn't really worth it in our opinion. The Yerba mate  sangria tasted more interesting, but still not that great and I expect fruit in my sangria, which that one did not have. I did like that they had somewhat healthy options and it was easy to avoid gluten and dairy if you need to, which isn't easy to do in actual New Mexico...
author: Samira I.

description: Smothered calabasitas burrito at $17 was underwhelming. Tortilla not grilled enough. Veg chopped too big and poorly grilled. Side of guac is extra $$ and the serving size laughable. At $20 is it too much to ask for a damn good burrito?
author: Justin G.

description: As a native New Mexican I'm really disappointed. I've tried many times over the years and it gets worse each visit. The green Chile stew...which should be their perfection...was a bowl of tasteless green chili...not at all a stew. I seriously wondered if they ran out and just threw some hot water and roasted chili in a bowl. Chicken taquitos were made with scraps...not New Mexican at all. Queso tasted like cheap cheese! And all this is pricey food! guess it's time to stop trying; place is always empty I guess for a reason. Do yourself a favor and try Nopalito close by or go to the mission!
author: Jon H.

description:
My terrible dining experience here has caused me to write my first restaurant review on yelp. Vegetarians and vegans STAY AWAY! This place is not for you.

After adding meat to my vegetarian dish (the tofu and black bean quinoa bowl) I sent it back for a new serving. It came back twice (quickly) and was obviously the same dish with the meat removed - the first time there were still pieces of meat in it. It frustrates me that the kitchen neither acknowledged nor respected my request for a vegetarian meal.

They did reimburse me for the dish, but the lack of concern/awareness of the kitchen is extremely shocking, given that they market many of their meals as vegan/vegetarian friendly.
author: Kirsten M.

description:
Slow service.

I was in a hurry but wanted something quick to go, so I asked the cashier for something quick and asked them to expedite it. I waited 25 min for a burrito.

Would not recommend if you are in a hurry.
author: Angel P.

description: I only go for the green chile stew. Everything else pales in comparison. Food is definitely pricey, too pricey for what you're getting- specially regards to appetizer and common Mexican dishes. But I'm a sucker for the green chile stew. Add an extra side of the blue corn tortillas. The shrubs are a nice touch too.
author: Freddy G.

description: Food is delicious. There was a time where my wife and I ate in, carried out, or got Caviar delivery from GCK two or more times a week. We love New Mexican food and it is not easy to come by. We've brought so many family members and out of town visitors in the past. However, no less than 90% of our orders were wrong in one way or another. One time we visited it took three tries to get the right order. Not easy with a young child to say the least. After a while it just stopped being worth it, esp for the price. We might go back sometime, but we are in no hurry to do so. The people are really nice, food is great, just a bit more expensive and difficult than we would like to deal with.
author: Robert M.

description:
I ate at Green Chile this weekend and was very impressed. I'll start with the food, it was fantastic. I got their burrito with the spicy salsa verde on top.. Arguably the best salsa verde I've ever had. I would bathe in it if I could. 

Not sure how long the special will be going, but they had a great IPA for $2. You just don't find that in sf (that deal itself would get me to be a regular). 

Lastly, their ambiance was great. It was classy while still being fun. I will definitely be back and would recommend this spot to anyone.
author: Trevor C.

description:
Order at the counter then find a place to sit down and enjoy New Mexican cuisine. 

Came here for brunch with a few friends on a Saturday morning. There was adequate space to sit in without having to wait. I ordered a breakfast flat enchilada plate. I chose the chorizo. The blue tortilla was flat and stacked with eggs, cheese and chorizo with another tortilla on top. It came with a little bit of lettuce and pico, posole and green salsa. I replaced my beans with rice. The plate was large and very delicious! It was flavorful! I'm not the biggest fan of blue tortillas but everything seemed like it was blue (even the tamales) so this must be reflective of New Mexican cuisine. 

They had kombucha on tap so I also grabbed one of these. 

Overall, the food was really good for a casual dining experience.
author: Courtney O.

description: I love their 7 layer dip and their rotisserie chicken dinner is amazing. But I have just learned that management is now charging $1 for extra salsa-- $1 for this tiny tub of salsa. They're also charging $1 for an extra flour tortilla.  I felt nickel-and-dimed, especially as in the past, I was able to get an extra serving of the tiny tub of salsa for free.  I had ordered a half chicken dinner-- how do they expect you to use just one little tub?! What's next?  Charging per napkin or utilizing a coin operated bathroom?!
author: Lily D.

description:
Expensive and just ok tasting. Got sangria and their new mexico enchilada, which I guess is pre-made (meaning who knows how long it was sitting under a heating lamp). Maybe if I tried something else...but still it was pretty expensive for  a walk up to the counter place.

$9 guac
$14 for enchilada plate, which is 3/4's rice, beans, & lettuce. 
$16 carafe of sangria
author: Kelly G.

description: The food is not good, plain and simple. It is an overpriced restaurant that bills itself as healthy but really is just boring, not even a step above whole foods salad bar status. There are SO many good options nearby so just pass this one up.
author: Anna S.

description: The presentation and atmosphere were great... unfortunately the drinks were Weak!! Bad sangria and margaritas, couldn't taste or feel the tequila. Made me think they didn't put any in!  The chicken in the enchilada was boiled and flavorless.  In New Mexico they would have roasted or grilled the chicken.  The staff and service were great just think they could step up the food and drinks.
author: Jason S.

description:
Slow service in afternoons/evenings.

The past few times I've been here for a dinner I've waited a long time for my order. On my most recent visit around 7pm on a Thursday, I ordered to-go and waited 30 minutes for my order to be ready. There were a few people who ordered to dine-in after me and no one else waiting in person for a to-go order. As I was waiting, quite a few couriers came in to pick up food for some food-delivery app/service.

At least when there is a long line or a lot of people waiting for their orders I can set my expectations that I will have to wait. It's frustrating that in-person customers aren't more of a priority. I try to call ahead for to-go orders but often they are too busy to answer the phone so I'm not able to place my order until I arrive.

I've been coming to Green Chile since they first opened at their old location down the street. With the increased prevalence of food delivery services it seems like customer service for in-person customers has gone downhill.
author: Lindsay E.

description:
Have you ever bathed yourself with the innards of a burrito? Me neither. But if I did it, it would probably be a green chili kitchen breakfast burrito, we could go into the why but that works would be creepy.  Instead, please copy and paste this order, if there are leftovers (there will be) I expect an invite. 1, super nacho (I got ground beef, weird I know but trust me), breakfast burrito (go chorizo unless you're a...) if it's past 2pm shame on you. 

So why not 5 stars?  I'm a burrito snob and while good, there are no french fries in said burrito. After many years in Southern California there are, umm, expectations.  

That said. Eat here!
author: Matt H.

description: The green Chile stew was the bomb! I don't eat spicy food but had heard it was so delicious I had to try it. No regrets the flavor was so good with a side of blue corn tortillas was the perfect lunch!! I also tried the pork tamales and those were also very tasty
author: Heydee M.

description: Really loved the vibe here Saturday morning. The girl who took our order was really sweet, and the chorizo bfast burrito with green sauce we ordered was awesome. We asked for them to heat up the burrito when it came out, expecting they'd just throw it under the salamander for a couple minutes, but they brought out a whole new burrito. Totally over the top, and we really appreciated the gesture. Will be back soon to try other items.
author: Ellie S.

description:
I placed an order for take out which took slightly longer than the estimate provided. The steak salad was a sizeable portion and flavorful.  The quesadilla, despite its  simplicity,  tasted great. Their take out containers kept the food warm for quite some time which was nice. 

This place is definitely a bit pricey for Mexican food but it's noticeable in the quality of their meals.
author: Daniel R.

description: Finally the only cuisine that I hadn't been able to find is dropped into my SF lap. Any decent mild green Chile is a friend of mine and they did not disappoint. The heouvos rancheros were perfect. Plus they have on tap kombucha. Great options for gluten free and vegan people.
author: Jazmin H.

description:
Only went here for a quick lunch, so it's a short review, but this place made an impression. You walk in, the menus are to your right and you order at the counter. I like that they had an area so you can get as much water as you want plus utensils, napkins, etc.

 So awesome that they have quinoa bowls. Had the pulled pork quinoa bowl and it had so much flavor! A good portion of meat too. The vegetables were cooked perfectly, not mushy at all. I also liked the crunchy red cabbage that added texture and cut through the richness of the pork. A quinoa bowl might sound boring, but this had so much flavor, and I loved that it was a healthier option. Only negative was that it was pricey ($16).

Have to come here again to try other items on the menu.
author: Sherille S.

description: This place is a hidden gem. Absolutely delicious - got the smothered burrito with red chile tofu and my friend got the quinoa red chile tofu. Both were five stars. The watermelon juice felt like I was on the beach in Bali and the horchata wasn't too sweet and very refreshing. I'll be coming here again soon.
author: George R.

description:
The day after our holiday staff party, my company buys us breakfast. This year, on Friday, December 11th, we got delivery through Caviar. Our company placed it a day or so prior for a scheduled delivery at 10am. Unfortunately, 10am came and went and we still didn't have our food. Not sure who messed up, but Caviar comped half of our order. We didn't get breakfast until 11am and everyone was starving!

Prices below are what Caviar charges. Looking online, their tacos are listed at $4 each and adding Guacamole is $0.75, so prices aren't that much more on Caviar.

Breakfast soft or crispy taco: housemade corn tortilla with eggs, cheese, pico de gallo ($4.10 each)
*Chorizo, crispy, add Jalapeno (+$0.80), Guacamole (+$0.80)
*Steak, soft, add Jalapeno (+$0.80), Guacamole (+$0.80)

I don't like beans or tortillas, so I decided tacos were the best thing to order. I adored the crunchy taco. The chorizo was spicy and flavorful. Sooo good! The steak taco was disappointing. The meat was mushy for steak and didn't have much flavor. I'd definitely stay away from steak anything here if mine was any indication of what it tastes like.

The crunchy taco was delish, but the steak fell flat. With each taco being almost $6, I expected a little more from the steak taco. I know prices are inflated by Caviar, but still, why was the steak so mushy? I kind of wish I had the chorizo taco last so I could have ended breakfast on a better note.
author: Elena N.

description: I was there today 8/12/18 around 2:45pm and the guy behind the counter taking orders did not even acknowledge my presence to take my order. I literally stood there waiting while he began to make drinks. There was no one else in line but me. What a different experience from last week when I met the owner.
author: Marcus C.

description:
I feel the need to update this review by mentioning that one of owners, or one of their friends or partners, Greg, attacked me in a personal message through Yelp in the most unprofessional, angry, and even violent fashion. When I expressed my outrage he concluded with, 

"I'd love to suck your d*** because as you know I only suck the tiny ones."

He then called me a "disgruntled Asian" who only writes deplorable reviews and I blocked him. 

Unreal. I gave a one-star review because I had a couple one-star experiences. I understand that might make a business-owner angry as my truthful review might hurt his business- but then to attack me with homophobic and racial slurs??? 

I literally can't believe this terrible experience happened to me. -100 stars.
author: Grizzle J.

description: Phenomenal place. Have the quesadillas, the guac and the veggie burrito bowl. Also, take a chance and go for a special... you won't regret it.
author: Alex G.

description: Tasty vegetarian choices! I got the tofu enchilada, sweet potato tamale, and calabasitas crispy taco. They were all perfect and good. The queso dip was good as well! Come here if you want good and alot of food.
author: Lena P.

description: Awesome cuisine and the waiter was so cool! Loved it. Second time going there. Will be back soon.
author: Jose L.

description: Really delicious food. A little pricy for what I would like, but given it is in SF it is acceptable. I personally love their breakfast dishes.
author: Paterson W.

description: Very good food today for a late lunch at the Green Chile Kitchen. While the food is very flavorful and fairly priced, the general ambiance of the restaurant negatively affected our experience.  The tables and booths seemed quite dirty and worn.  Additionally, all of the restaurant windows and doors were open and there were a number of flies in the dining room that can easily travel into the food prep area.  The music in the dining room became a little grating too.  Oh well, at least the food tasted good!
author: Francie N.

description:
I've been here a few times and each time, I've enjoyed my meal. First, let me say, I like the location. I'm a sucker for a corner restaurant with huge windows so you can enjoy people watching. I mean, the theater of street life is free entertainment, right? (Ideal too if you're dining alone.) Anyway, I recently went in for lunch and ordered their grilled fish tacos. It was delicious and served in presumably a stone-ground blue corn tortilla. It was sturdy and held the nicely grilled tacos well. If I recall, the fish was cod. It was bright, fresh, and extra delicious with the accompanying salsa. The two tacos were served with rice and a wedge of lime. The rice though was a bit more al dente than I'd like it to be. In other words, it needed an extra minute or two to get to the desired fluffiness. In past visits, I've also had their green chile stew which is tasty and satisfying. They also have a pretty solid horchata, a perfect drink for warm autumn San Francisco days. (I'll never understand why our summers are chilly and why our autumns are hot. [Not. About. The. Heat.])

The service is efficient and deserves high marks. You order on a menu at the register, they give you a number, and the food is brought out to your table. The food runners are friendly and attentive. For example, one of the runners not only brought our orders but automatically refilled our chips when we ran out from the chips+guacamole appetizer. And by the way, their tortilla chips are everything! I love thick tortilla chips. Thin chips are good too but I'm partial to these thicker cuts *and* they don't under-salt like some places.

Green Chile has been open for years and clearly they know how to keep their clientele.
author: James Z.

description: Nice place for lunch. A Mexican restaurant, not your regular taqueria. The Margaritas are delicious, so is their lemonades. Lots of food is served in every dish.
author: Gali S.

description: Been going to Green Chile Kitchen for years. Always been a fan, but let down by my experience tonight. Asked for a vegetarian recommendation, as I'm vegetarian, and was advised on a dish that ended up having chicken in it, which I accidentally ate due to trusting staff's recommendation. Disappointed the staff does not know menu, especially when you're paying $30+ for an entree and drink. Brought up issue with another staff member and there were no apologies or attempts to rectify. Expect more from GCK.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Had the grilled steak burrito and it was pretty decent. I love the chile and chips. Filling was pretty generous and portion was okay. I shared the burrito with my friend and the portion was just nice.

We also ordered 1/4 rotisserie chicken. It was very well seasoned and very juicy. Yum!
author: Christina N.

description:
For someone that lives in Dublin, Ireland, going somewhere to have an as close-to-as-it-gets Mexican meal this is the spot to go. Had a delicious fish taco with tons of spicy sauce and veggies. They were accommodating when I wanted to swop the rice to salad, which was a big plus. Sometimes I find it gets too heavy with all that rice AND bread.

Had a couple of bottles with white sangria to go with it which meant that yes we were rolling out of the restaurant his Sunday afternoon. But it didn't really matter as I was going straight on a plane back to Dublin... I'll be back next I'm in down. And oh, regarding prices very affordable. Only downside was they were out of avocado this day. I survived it. :)
author: Linn L.

description: I've been here several times as I live nearby. It's been very consistent but unfortunately that's been consistently mediocre. Space doesn't feel as clean as it could be, the food doesn't taste as good as I'd want, and it's not a good value for the price. Plenty of better Mexican options nearby.
author: Ryan B.

description: Great food all around. The spicy margarita is the best I have ever had. The staff is very friendly. Can't go wrong at happy hour either
author: Emile K.

description: Don't know why I come back here for lunch or dinner, probably because I forget the food taste like nothing and never comes warm enough. Too pricey for the small portions. Silverware and glasses aren't clean. Atmosphere is good and kids friendly though.
author: André F.

description: Great food, easy/low key place. We had two toddlers and space worked for them, and I don't think we bothered others. Will be back. Great neighborhood spot!
author: Christina L.

description: Great restaurant  good food however, they could at least let you know there are no servers and that you don't have to stand there for 15 minutes before you realize it! Had the fish tacos really tasty however you could barely see the fish on the two tacos for $16.00?
author: Curtis L.

description: My wife and I used to looooove this place when Mark was the manager. He always made sure your dinner was awesome, never got a wrong order and the beer selection was always awesome. Since he left there's a noticeable change, wrong orders are common, frequently out of staple beers (Pacifico at a Mexican restaurant shouldn't be out of stock but 11am on Labor Day Weekend), used to love watching local teams on the tv and lately it's always soccer or even the news which is a downer when you're out to dinner. The food (when right) is still great but we really miss Mark and the neighborhood vibe and dependability of GCK. Apparently he's at the new north bay location, we will definitely make a trip out to that GCK asap!
author: Matt S.

description: Prices do not reflect portions. Ordered two taco plate for $15. Came with cafeteria quality rice and beans and a taco that wasn't even filled up with meat. Don't pay the %30 hipster surcharge here
author: Colby C.

description: Come here fairly often, very inconsistent and service is below average. And insane the cooks counting money and not washing their hands
author: Joe R.

description:
I really love the food here. The smothered burrito and taco salad are our go to dishes. I love the atmosphere too because it's causal enough to have kids but still seems nice for like a date. 

The quality of the food always seems fresh and with family we always seem to stop by here since the kids love it too.
author: John-Mark I.

description:
This place is a bit pricey but the portions are sizable. I would describe the food as "fresh or new" Mexican. I'm vegetarian, and the options available to me were plentiful. The actual taste of the veggie tofu is not phenomenal but the fresh veggies and guacamole made up for it. Next time I am going to get calabacitas (grilled veggies) in my burrito because the zucchini in my friends burrito was very well prepared. My favorite menu item so far has to be the 7 layer dip. It's delicious and somehow doesn't make me feel as guilty as a normal 7 layer dip. The ingredients are definitely fresher than any taqueria. 

All in all, I would return to this spot and definitely bring friends. The food was good enough and the ambience is great for groups. With large tables and cool decor, I could see a small party coming together here. In fact, there were two birthdays going on here on a Wednesday night!
author: Shruti S.

description:
I went here on a Sunday for a quick brunch. The place was recommended by a friend and since I like to try new places and I decided it was time to check it out. 

I loved the decor of the place! the high ceilings and the windows that allow you to sit by and people watch while you eat. 

I ordered the Navajo Tacos, which are 3 "fry bread" tacos. One comes with pinto beans, one with calabacitas &  the last one with ground beef. Then they are topped with lettuce, chile, cheese & pico. 

They were delicious! 

Except... they were too small. Seriously. I was still hungry afterwards and I'm not even a big eater. 

I will definitely go back but next time I'll try to order something bigger.
author: Ezekiel G.

description:
I only wish that my review could have been better. The food is okay but the service has gone down...And considering that the place is a "bistro" with a pay first then sit that's not reassuring. Went with the family, ordered two kids meals three adult meals, one app and the bill came to more than $100. I was kind of surprised for somewhat mediocre new Mexican food. 

They messed up our appetizer, never mind that it took ~20 minutes for guacamole and chips. Then on top of that they forgot one of the kids meals. The eldest had to share portions from the adults. I brought it up immediately, but we didn't get that meal until after the rest of the meals were all finished. ~30 minutes later for rice, beans, and cheese burrito.
author: Kira G.

description: This place is right by our school so we want to love, but the last 5 times (seriously) they have messed up our orders or it has taken more than 30 minutes to get a kids bean cheese and rice burrito.  Sometimes food comes out cold (like the quinoa tofu bowl I just got) too. Overpriced for so many mistakes and they are so used to making mistakes, they feel no need to make things better.
author: Nina S.

description: Had their steak nachos and all I can say is they were the best I have had in SF. Came here because we were in the neighbourhood. Haven't had anything else on the menu but I am definitely coming back for the steak nachos
author: Shanzay H.

description:
The steak tacos were juicy and delicious. My friend ordered the burrito and had a big smile on her face when she was done eating. They have a summer menu with corn on the cob and the quinoa bowls look really good. I loved the housemade watermelon drink, it was fresh and summery.

It has a pretty laid back but cool ambience. You can sit outside or at the window seats, good for people watching!
author: Suna L.

description:
The homestyle New Mexican stacked chicken enchiladas, with mild green chile. So heavenly. Also the red chile tofu burrito bowl is another favorite (add cheese and lettuce)!

Don't forget the gluten free pie next door, in the to-go area (they only have one gluten free flavor but it's always good).
author: Shannon Z.

description:
We're big fans of Green Chili Kitchen. The meals can range from light to hearty. They use wonderful ingredients and serve a creative mix of classics and creative takes on New Mexican cuisine. 

One little thing they do that kicks it up one small notch is that everything is served on Heath serving ware. It's a small but really well received touch.

Lastly, this is a vegetarian diner's haven. It's got good stuff and multiple options.
author: A.J. T.

description: I live in the neighborhood but ate here for the first time just this weekend. It is high-quality and delicious but sooo pricey! If you're down for that, then I think you'll be quite satisfied with the meal, but if not, you may cry upon seeing the receipt.
author: Shendi X.

description:
I moved to San Francisco from central New Mexico, and over time I've built up a serious craving for anything New Mexico. I was excited to try this place out with a few friends, two of whom were also New Mexico expatriates. 

The good was generally pretty okay. I know that doesn't sound super positive, and I kind of don't mean for it to. It was definitely authentic New Mexican, but it wasn't as good as any of my favorite New Mexico outfits, and I felt that it was a bit overpriced for what it was. The sopapillas were particularly disappointing, which was a big letdown since that's one of the things I was most looking forward to.

That said, the restaurant is nicely decorated and generally well kept, although it was quite busy when I went on a Saturday afternoon.
author: Jesse C.

description: Very good authentic food! I got the new homemade Mexican chicken enchilada....amazing !!
author: Asia G.

description: They make outstanding burritos. I typically get the veggie burrito with hot green chile, tofu, brown rice, black beans, and sometimes with guacamole. It comes with chips (which are amazing) and salsa. Thankfully I'm able to exhibit some self-control and not go there every day, as I live right next door.
author: D R.

description: So my boss told me to come here for lunch and was a short bus ride  away from work.  So I went in there and looked around and  like the atmosphere. I ordered a Chicken Naked Burrito it was different then I thought but I'm trying to step outside my box so I tried it and loved it.  This my be my new favorite spot. The green chile was just the right amount of  spicy I  needed  to make my meal right. Never knew about this place until now.
author: Elizabeth G.

description: So I have been here twice and both times the food is great.. The place is clean. The price is good for the amount you get.. I recomend coming here..
author: Famous F.

description:
Wasn't a huge fan. It's has such a cute theme and nice people but the food is mediocre therefore felt overpriced. I had the enchilada which was definitely not made to order and was dry. My guy had the burrito and that was better with a lot more flavor but still underwhelming. 
Good beer selection. Not sure I'd go back.
author: Katie S.

description:
I love that I was able to take BART in from the East Bay, and then hop onto the 21 MUNI all the way until it hit McAllister & Baker, to get to Green Chili Kitchen (GCK).  It certainly beat driving across the Bay Bridge, and then around and around in the neighborhood in order to find street parking.

GCK is set up so that you place and pay for your order up at the front counter, and then also find your own seating.  There are a couple of outdoor tables, and lots of different types of seating indoors.  There are two large communal tables, some tables for four, tables for two, some seats at the bar, and a few booths off to the right when you first walk in.  I'm glad that I came a bit earlier than my friend so I could scope out and claim a table for the two of us.  Don't worry about plopping down into a seat at a table with dishes on it.  Someone will be by to ferry it all away and wipe it down.  I'm not sure if GCK is normally filled on Saturday evenings, or if San Franciscans were just out in full force to watch game four of the World Series.  

The have a lot of great things to choose from on their menu, but I opted for two homemade tamales (one chicken, one pork) - $12.  They also have cheese and vegan sweet potato options, too.  The tamales came with chile, beans, rice, and salad.  I chose black beans, but they also have pinto and refried.  As for the chile, they have hot green, mild green or red.  My friend, who has been here before, told me that you could opt for "Christmas," and get both green and red.  I went with that so I could sample both chiles.  :)

After we received a table number, I went to this little station that's to the right once you enter the restaurant, for napkins, cutlery, and mason jars for water.

After about ten minutes or so, a waiter came by with our food.  I thought that the rice and beans were really good, but the tamales were a little on the bland side.  I feel like the meat could have received a bit more seasoning.  On the other hand, once I added on some of the green and red chile, it had plenty of flavor.

If you have a sweet tooth, I would recommend taking your receipt down the block to Chili Pies and Ice Cream for some dessert.  My friend and I split a pie milkshake (Mexican hot chocolate pecan w/ vanilla ice cream), and it was magical.  

I'm not in the Western Addition/NOPA neighborhood a whole lot, but I would definitely stop here again and check out their nachos and some of their housemade lemonades.
author: Iona C.

description:
It's a rainy day, we're on our way home from the dog park and suddenly realize we're starving. My friend navigates us to Green Chile and we park, leave the dogs in the car (knowing they'll be everywhere they're not supposed to be) and walk to the restaurant. It's in between lunch and dinner so not very busy. It feels like a converted warehouse in there. Very tall ceilings, huge windows, chunky and industrial decor. There's a heavy Mexican theme which reminds me of living in Seattle in the 1990s when we decorated with a lot of wrought iron and Catholic iconography. I love it. 

The menu is great -- lots of tamales and sopas and combinations -- prices are reasonable and there's a lot to choose from. Inexplicably, I order a burrito. It was good but is not the best example of what this place is capable of. I had a bite of my friend's food and it was much better. My advice, skip the burrito, get out of your comfort zone and try something new. Ingredients are responsibly sourced, the presentation is fabulous and the dishes have a unique twist on them. I would definitely like to come back when I'm feeling more adventurous.
author: Angelique L.

description: Good, fresh food. I loved the Navajo tacos. And if you come for weekend brunch, it seems like you have tons of options. Lots of healthy options. This is a place I'd love to come back. If you're looking for cheese covered, greasy food (OK, sometimes I am looking for that), don't come to this place.
author: Jason P.

description: Very nice atmosphere.  I hand the chile rellenos.  Very good flavorZ. The pozole was a nice alternative to beans.  It had a great flavor with just the right amount of spiciness.
author: Martha L.

description:
I spent a large part of my youth vacationing in the land of enchantment where a huge chunk of my extended family lives. The result of this being that I get the occasional craving for New Mexican style food smothered in green chile.

I had no idea that such a place could be found in the heart of SF until we ended up trying Green Chile Kitchen. Finding this place brings me a lot of happiness because now I don't have to travel thousands of miles to get delicious stuffed sopaipillas. 

To top it off, when we reached down to grab the honey for our extra order of sopaipillas, we saw that they bring in red chile honey from Monroe's, one of our favorite New Mexico restaurants! 

Everything we ordered here was great. Super nachos with pork belly, green chile roasted pork burritos, enchiladas, stuffed chiles and most importantly, the carne adovada stuffed sopaipillas... it all hits the spot in just the right way.

As an added bonus, if you take the receipt down the block to their partner store Green Chile Pies & Ice cream, you get a discount on some very delicious dessert options. 

This place is a definite winner and I will without a doubt be returning here for more in the future.
author: Mark O.

description:
Green Chile Kitchen the perfect spot to grab something quick and casual. I've been there multiple times for breakfast and lunch. I really enjoy the Healthy Breakfast Bowl, and they have good salads. It's a little pricey for what you get, but it's convenient, fast and healthy. 
Their horchata is delicious as well!
author: Rebecca O.

description: Omg the portions are huge! came for brunch with a friend. It's a mix of Mexican and american brunch style. I got the breakfast burrito with tofu(I think) that came with side of beans and veggies. It was to die for. They have horchata!!!!
author: Jackie N.

description: Clean (New) Mexican food, whhhhhaaaaa!!!! I havent tried the full menu but so far so good. Also, service has been great every time!
author: Fredo L.

description: Native New Mexican very pleased with this home style meal. I've recommended it to all my friends and will be back next time I'm in the city.
author: Toni N.

description:
It took over 45 min to revive two soft tacos and a burrito. We saw groups of people come in, order, sit, eat, and leave before we were served. When asked about the wait and when our food would be up, they said they were backed up and busy... Finally there food arrived and what was hot tasted great. My tacos were cold and soggy. Also paid for guac, didn't receive it. Also something else to note, the windows were open so you could smell cigarette smoke wafting in due to people smoking in the street. 

Only reason I'm giving this two stars and not one is because the food that was hot tasted very good but I still won't be going back there
author: Jessica C.

description: This place has the best food Ive ever eaten! The best dish is the stuffed sopapillas with carne adovada. Ive been coming here like 2 to 3 times a week because I live close by, cant get enough of the food haha. You can never go wrong with a burrito or enchilada either. If you are in the area this is the place to go!
author: Dakota G.

description: Nice atmosphere, gracious staff, and the fare is delicious! Tried tamales made with blue corn masa, one with pork another with sweet potato, also tried the green chile posole with pork, and the "Hangover Stew" --- SABROSO!
author: Laura F.

description: Staff has no idea about what items contain gluten. If you are celiac, I'd be careful here - lots of cross contamination. Also take-out orders take way longer than what they tell you at the time of your order. Expect 30+ mins. Great margaritas though!
author: Jason M.

description:
The New Mexican Smothered Burrito I had here was underwhelming. 14.00 for flavorless meat, +75 for pico +75 for a teaspoon of guacamole. Ay dios mio. You're kidding me right? 


The redemption was the red chile chicken posole had an excellent mix of hominy, cilantro & onion. Despite the cup being an anemic portion for a six dollar price point, it was still pretty good. 

I'd come back for the posole.
author: Liss T.

description: The food menu is great. Though somehow requests for "mild" make no difference which is maddening. The space is very family friendly. My family and I have been eating here for years. The service varies and it has seems to be declining. Super looooong waits for food that feel so frustrating. I wonder if they are having a hard time balancing orders for delivery with orders for folks that actually made the trip to eat there.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: I like this location and food (the Mexican stuff) better than their location in San Rafael. It's a great place for lunch in the neighborhood.
author: O K.

description: Another SF establishment that's all about the ambience and way too less about the overpriced food . I get the references to a monastery or some religious building ... that was cool. But that's pretty much where the cool ended . Dry sickly green tamales , under whelming chile relleno burritos and sangria that tasted like cheap wine and 7 up... Really ?! With all the Mexican options one has in the city this can easily be avoided and you'll thank your taste buds and your wallet
author: Umar G.

description:
I went here twice in 3 days, so that should say how much I liked it. Located within walking distance from USF so it's super convenient for college students. A coworker of mine took me here after work one day saying it's one of her faves... I ordered a burrito and a white sangria. THE SANGRIA IS THE BEST I'VE HAD SINCE I'VE MOVED TO SAN FRANCISCO. It's so sweet and fruity, you taste no alcohol, you can tell they let it marinate. And after my meal and drink, I spent the rest of my conversation throwing back $2 pacifico's. I enjoyed it so much that I brought my roommate back two days later haha. 

The only change I would make is to add a happy hour!
author: Shannon C.

description: I like going for salad and sangria. If you're looking for flavorful Mexican food, this is not the place to go. It's even technically billed as "New Mexico" food, whatever that is. The pie down the street by these same folks is pretty good.
author: Larisa J.

description:
I am updating my review again, a bit better than last time, still not good enough.

I picked up an order of green chili stew and I got myself the standard grilled burrito with pork. The pork in the burrito was over half all fatty meat. Inedible mouthfuls of chewy gelatinous fatty pork chunks? While I'm not completely disgusted I'm definitely not pleased by the quality of meat.
I've eaten here so many times and the quality never seems to get any better. I miss the old days when it was so much better.
And in this particular day I felt like the flavor of the burrito was also slightly off.

I really want to like green chile kitchen because you can't get New Mexican cuisine just anyplace. Unfortunately over the years the place just can't hold up to the city standard.
author: Ben M.

description:
Green Chile Kitchen is around the corner from us and does "New Mexican Cuisine". My roommate from New Mexico tells me it isn't authentic New Mexican food. But isn't authentic New Mexican food just inauthentic Mexican food? So what's inauthentic New Mexican food? Have I said anything offensive yet?

Well authentic or not I'm down: nice ambiance, no wait for dinner, they also do takeout (can order online through Yelp, for those of us who don't like talking to humans). Green chile stew, sopapillas (hadn't had those before, they're awesome) and wet burritos are all great - hearty portions. Their dessert/bakery place a few doors down - "Green Chile Pies" is also amazing - see my review over there to understand just how amazing. 

See ya there
author: Bud P.

description: Really one of my favorite local restaurants.  Food is terrific.  Wine list is good.  Great service and a fun atmosphere.  Would like too see them add a happy hour option.
author: Ryan K.

description:
Disappointed with the service here and the prices. 

The woman at the register was super sour and had a bad 'tude. She picked up the phone mid sentence and looked generally bored and disinterested in taking my order.

I got the market salad (beets, greens, broccoli) with chicken. Chicken was good but with a total price of around sixteen bucks, I felt underwhelmed and like I overpaid. Definitely not a place where you get value for your money. 

Will not be back.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
I've eaten nearly everywhere in the Nopa/Divis area and this is my #1. It's the restaurant that comes to mind first when I am sitting at home deciding what to eat. 

GCK has lots of variety and everything I've ever had has been executed well, whether for breakfast, lunch, or dinner. I see a lot of people order the burrito-which is awesome-but I recommend being more adventurous; there are many unique things to try here. And no matter what you order, definitely try the green chile salsa! Their sides and sauces are excellent.
author: Andrew M.

description: I have been coming here for years (a little less recently as I am no longer in the neighborhood). This place is a go to for healthy, well prepared food. The staff is friendly the service is prompt, the location is gorgeous and the place is clean and well kept. I love coming here for a relaxed lunch and a nice day as the wall to wall windows let lots of light in. If you are in the area, don't miss out on this gem of a restaurant. If you aren't in the area, expand your range and make a trip to Green Chile Kitchen!
author: andy g.

description:
Nope. Nope. Nope. Had dinner here this past week. We ordered a grilled chicken burrito, red chile chicken posole and homemade tamales. The food did not taste good or feel authentic and very overpriced. 

Grilled Chicken Burrito:
I ordered it with guacamole inside (paid extra for that which is normal in any Mexican restaurant). What did I get? A burrito with no guac inside but instead a small little dot of guac sitting on top of it. I had to get back in line and order more guac on the side to eat with this burrito. The chicken had no flavor, there seemed to be white rice in there (different than the rice that came with the tamales), black beans and some pico de gallo salsa. I ordered it to have a small amount of rice and more black beans, I got the opposite. Either the one taking my order didn't make that note or the cook didn't follow it. Or maybe she didn't give a sh**. I don't know. Either way, this burrito was one of the worst I've had in a really really long time. Dare I say, Chipotle can make a better burrito than this for a fraction of the price. 

Homemade tamales:
Ordered the chicken and pork tamales with the green chile sauce. It was made with blue corn. First, there was barely any meat inside of the pork tamale. It was mostly blue corn and did not taste like anything at all. This thing lacked seasoning. The chicken tamale had more meat but still the issue remained that it did not taste like much. Typically there is more corn than meat but this place made it more drastic than that. I would have been okay with that if the blue corn tasted good, but it didn't. The rice that came with it was hard as a rock too. Horrible dish...

Red Chile Chicken Posole:
The only thing they got right in this place. Tasted really good actually. The blue corn tortilla it came with though, not good. 

Lesson learned, this place cannot compete with any hole-in-the-wall Mexican restaurant. Hell, Chipotle and Chevy's beats this place.
author: Josemaria G.

description:
We ordered this from postmates tonight.

- Bowl of posole . I'm not feeling well today so I wanted soup tonight & was excited when I found a place with posole ... Unfortunately I was very underwhelmed with this one. There wasn't much pork in the soup and the broth just didn't have much flavor. I was also expecting it to come with cilantro, onions and some fix ins on the side but I got a lime slice that I didn't find til the end and some tortillas. 

- New Mexican smothered burrito. This was loaded with cheese so it was hard to taste anything but the green chili and cheese. The burrito is incredible spicy so if you're not good with spice I wouldn't recommend you try this. We had to refill our waters while eating because this was so spicy. It does come with rice, beans and some lettuce on the side so it's a good size meal though
author: danielle a.

description: I love the atmosphere here, it has really high ceilings and big sliding windows and a mix of booths and tables and high tops and bar seating. There are some good vegan options, the tamales are great plus one of the specials seems to usually be vegan. The portions are pretty big. They have a few good beers plus the usual Pacifico etc. You order at the counter and then get a number for your table so there aren't a lot of wait staff running around.
author: Matt P.

description:
7 years living in the Bay Area and I'm just now finding a New Mexican restaurant?!?! Have to give myself a big Fail on that one for you see I was born and raised in NM. This past weekend a friend was touting some Mexican restaurant, proclaiming that everyone he's taken there has loved it. So we figured we'd give it a try. Much to my surprise as we drove up this was no Mexican place, but a New Mexican place! To the untrained palate these might sound one in the same, but believe me there are differences. (You wouldn't say Chinese, Japanese, Vietnamese, Thai, Korean are the same would you, same thing here).

I must have looked like one of Pavlov's dogs (*ding*) when I saw Zia symbols and claims of Green Chile on the windows!  I went straight for the stuffed sopapilla with carne adovada, my favorite dish back home, and a bowl of green chile stew to back it up. In New Mexican dishes it's all about the chile and how well you balance heat with rich flavor. As far as the carne adovada goes I'd say the red chile here is on point with what you can expect in NM. Not the best I've had, but certainly far from the worst. However, I was surprised that although the dish was called "stuffed" sopapilla there were instead pieces of sopapilla mixed in with the carne adovada. It's usually sopapilla (fried bread) stuffed with the meat. No biggie. Now the green chile is where many New Mexican's will get snobby, each remembering where/when/with whom they had their best bowl. To that regard, I wasn't a big fan of the green chile stew. It didn't really have the rich flavors I crave when yearning for a bowl. But similar to the red, not the worst I've had and even better than some restaurants in New Mexico. Part of it I think is due to chile having to be shipped here, and not being as fresh as it is when I have it in NM.

Great job bringing this flavor to the cultural crockpot we call SF. Great execution on the red chile, ok on the green. I'll be back!
author: Stephen R.

description: Unbelievable.  This place was never really known for its service but now it's horrible.  Online ordering has destroyed the service here.  The staff and infrastructure are obviously not equipped to handle this and it appears to take precedence over dine in customers or walk ins.  Save your money....better yet, save your time....the food is not that great.
author: Gabriel F.

description:
Despite the great food from this place they are absolutely incompetent when it comes to order accuracy. 
I have given this place a number of chances because there tomatillo avocado salsa is amazing but what is the point if I order it and receive it less than 50% of the time? 

It's a shame, I'm not this guy, just incredibly disappointed - again.
author: Nicholas D.

description: Love the food and location.  No longer living nearby and now looking for an excuse to go back  for a lunch!
author: Patrick H.

description: For a place that's presented and priced the way it is, the food was surprisingly mediocre. The salsa was delicious, but the sides felt microwaved and generic. The rice tasted like it was sitting out overnight: both gummy and dried out. The steak filling of my sopapillas didn't wow me, compared to any other Mexican joint in the city. To top it off, our order was mixed up and we weren't served for over 45 minutes while the food got cold on the counter. Overall for the price point, I had a really hard time feeling I got my value as far as food and service.
author: Jason H.

description:
This place is Mexican fusion restaurant - not really authentic Mexican food but super yammy and tasty. If you are in the Divisadero area, it's definitely worth a try.

I had the dinner plate - chicken with mashed potatoes and salad and was definitely fulfilling. The ambiance is an open-space, a little hipster, and very clean. There are a lot of families that come to this restaurant. Everyone says that you should try the quinoa chicken salad.
author: Silvia L.

description:
Like everyone said, its pricey. 16$ for quinoa, roasted veggies, and pulled pork? Um okay... Anyways that what I ordered, and its good!! I liked it. A bit spicy so be warned! Only suggestion for this dish...would be to use less pulled pork (I know crazy right!?) and put in more roasted veggies (which then hopefully would bring down the price huh huh huh???) Yeah just a little heavy on the meat, would be nice to eat more veggies. 

cute SF restaurant! great outdoor seating, awesome location, great natural light. friendly staff, great beer selection.
author: Hayden C.

description:
Wow! Fantastic New Mexico cooking, which in my mind is the highest level of Mexican cooking. 

I'm not at all familiar with this part of San Francisco so I asked the bus driver to stop at an interesting place and he stopped here. Lucky for me. 

I'm usually pretty quick on deciding what I want to eat from a menu but that wasn't the case here because they have a fairly extensive menu. I finally told myself, come on Neil it's just lunch so I chose the chili reyano plate at  $18. It features 2 green poblano mild peppers stuffed with a real nice light cheese and I think a frothy egg batter surrounding it. Then a small beef taco, a moderate amount of chicken and pozole stew, a nice helping of Spanish rice and a generous helping of your choice of black, pinto, or refried beans. I chose the refried beans and wasn't disappointed. 

I don't rate may places at 5 stars but this makes the grade. 

You do have to line up to order and pay at the register which is a little difficult to do when you don't know what they have or what you want, but there's benches to sit and peruse the menu. Wasn't too much of a problem for me and they bring the food to your table. 

I highly recommend this restaurant. It's not what you are used to in Mexican food so go try it.
author: Neil W.

description:
I really like this place. It's a neighborhood gem and close to home. I think their burritos are incredible but I also love their enchiladas and nachos. I actually never order nachos but here, I order them all the time. 

Don't skip the Horchata!
author: Mariko F.

description:
Went for breakfast today. Very limited options. It was either burrito,  burrito bowl or enchilada plate. I mean come on. If you're going to offer breakfast, give some options. 

I ordered the breakfast burrito with chorizo.  I had them out the "hot" green chili sauce on top. Wasn't even hot. Wasn't even mild.  I can't even imagine what the "mild" green sauce would taste like...cilantro sauce?

Anyways, food was pretty bland and underseasoned. It wasn't bad but it definitely wasn't any good. Also tried their horchata. Wasn't well done either. Had absolutely no flavor. Just tasted like watered down mild with essence of cinnamon. Definitely a let down.

Finally, I tried their elote  (corn on the cob). It was the best item I tried here but still wasn't great. Corn tasted undercooked and the cheese, lime, chili, weren't evenly coating the elote. 

Overall, was not a fan (for breakfast), will not be back, and would not recommend.
author: Robert R.

description:
Just waited nearly 30 minutes for a take out order that was just half a rotisserie chicken. Literally takes two minutes to cut that and pop it in a paper container. Had to ask for it three times. First two people were less than helpful. Also - it came with nothing despite online description stating that it comes with rice, beans and tortillas. I kind of assumed that was a mistake, but they really should fix that. Or offer someone a side dish if you're gonna make them wait 30 minutes to cut a chicken in half. 

Just moved half a block away and was stoked to have yummy healthy food nearby. Apparently need to adjust my service expectations.
author: Dani G.

description: The green chili is the star, nice and spicy. I got a bowl of the green chili pork stew ($12) and it needed more pork but Delish comes with a tortilla or sopapilla.  We also got a burrito bowl and empanadas and a side of green chili mashed potatoes (not very much flavor I added some green chili). Those were ok. The drinks WOW they were so good, I want more! Spicy margarita and a spicy (green chili) lemonade. These were the perfect balance of sweet and spicy I really want to know how they make it. Got a piece of green chili apple pie to go and I felt it wasn't sweet enough for that great balance of sweet and spicy, spicy though. Great atmosphere and nice staff. Our bill before the pie $60, pie slices are $6 each
author: K C.

description: Pretty good! The restaurant was FREEZING. Tamale plate was okay- so much corn and not enough meat and cheese inside. Would come back for a quick meal!
author: Alyssa C.

description:
Wish I could do three and a half. 

Their combo plate hits the spot and is a good sharing size for two people. However, I just can't get behind the prices, sometimes grainy tortillas and lackluster flavors.
author: Patrick T.

description:
I think something's wrong with Yelp right now, because this is not a 3.5 star restaurant. Pozole: amazing. Green Chile stew: double amazing, and actually spicy for a change. Orchata: so good, not too sweet, which is usually the mistake people make. Plus a free refill! They also have a variety of salsas available, all of which were delicious. Tamales: respectable, fresh. Not too much meat, not too much corn.

If you like Mexican, come here.
author: Alex M.

description:
Come here for green chiles. If you love new mexican green chiles or chile verde ,this is the place!

Prices are reasonable portions are bursting off the plate. 

The presentation is gorgeous. Each plate is work of art punching w color.

The customer service is awesome. But lines can be brutal. When busy they are unable to do phone order aheads, which is rough because thats the best reason for phone ordering... To beat the lines.

Nice house made drinks are a great touch.
author: Michael P.

description: So disappointed... My coworkers and I were very hungry and decided that we would try out this location for some good Mexican food. Unfortunately our food came with no forks! Mind you we had 4-5 different dishes that we couldn't eat while hot because we had to venture out to find something to eat them with!
author: Sherelle K.

description:
Great food - chicken is outrageously good. Nice relaxed atmosphere in a beautifully restored building.

Outstanding service and family friendly too. My kids are already grown but when they were little I would scour the city looking for places like this. Big tables for kids to color while eating.

I have no idea what New Mexico food (see other reviews) is supposed to taste like, so cannot comment on that. I also read the negative comments before I went and saw nothing that justified concerns.

I will return to try other menu items but it will be hard to pass by the chicken. Huge portions by the way: the half chicken was more than this big guy could eat.
author: E F.

description:
I really enjoyed my lunch at Green Chile Kitchen.  I've never had spicy lemonade before, but gave it a try and thought they pulled it off quite nicely. I also enjoyed the chicken and feta Quinoa bowl - very hearty, and the chicken moist and tasty.

I love New Mexico cuisine so look forward to coming back to try their stews.
author: Jack K.

description: This place is not worth the wait not worth the steep price for a burrito. The guy who was taking our order took 10 minutes to do so and left the register twice while taking our order to go do something else. As for the food, I am vegan and ordered accordingly, but when it came out, it had egg on it, so they re-made it and again, it came out with sour cream, I mean I said VEGAN and said no eggs, no dairy, no meat. Not only that, when the food finally came out right, it was 30 minutes from the time we placed our order. Then when I finally got my food, there was a pile of grease on the plate, so unappetizing. Additionally, they only had one bathroom, so there was a huge line. $12 for a pile of greasy bland food and huge wait time, no thank you!
author: April B.

description: Staying at a great Airbnb nearby and this place was recommended. Had the kale quinoa chicken salad and it's great!  Seeing all the other meals coming out and everything looks and smells awesome. Burritos, tacos, burgers, all looks good. Great bar too, solid selection of draft beers. Great environment too. Cool Kings chairs at the steel and copper bar. I'll be back here while in town for sure!
author: Curt B.

description: I can't imagine why this only has 3.5 stars on Yelp ... Everything was excellent and perfectly prepared. We absolutely LOVED everything!! My NM girlfriend said it tasted like home and to this Texan it was positively perfect. Go. Eat. Enjoy.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Green Chile Stew: 4 stars

Smothered Burrito (Chicken): 3 stars

Tamales: 2 stars
One pork, one cheese. Very dry. Could've been because we picked up the food 20 mins late, so I would give them another chance.
author: Letitia L.

description: Love this place. Not your regular Mexican restaurant but this the most authentic New Mexican restaurant I have found outside of Santa Fe and Albuquerque. The green Chile stew is the real deal and the tamale was fabulous. The flat enchiladas and tacos are made with blue corn tortillas. Muy sabrosas. I wil try to come here every time I'm in the city- it's that good
author: Robert T.

description:
Popular place for NM transplants, and the green chile is amazing. Great place for casual dining - went there on a Wednesday night and it wasn't too crowded. 

Warning: the setting is casual, the price less so.
author: Kendra B.

description: I love their burritos because they grill them after wrapping (recently tried the tofu and loved it). Today I tried the kale salad with quinoa, black beans, corn, jicama, and I added avocado. Very good southwestern style salad with a chili lime vinaigrette that's tasty and spicy.
author: Sue D.

description:
Good Mexican food and service, came here with a big group and it wasn't nearly as stressful as it could have been. 
Try the red chili stew!
author: Emmaza216 ..

description:
Our company had them cater lunch to us and I thought their food was pretty good. It's considered New Mexican-style cuisine, so everything has a "southwestern" influence to it.

I tried their steak burrito, their chicken tamale steak taco fillings, Spanish rice and their refried beans. The food was pretty good, but nothing blew me away. I was a little sad that the salsas weren't better labeled and therefore had to play guess and check to figure out which one was the mild one, but that's more our company's fault than Green Chile's.

I thought the meat was flavorful but a bit dry, but that might've been from transporting between the kitchen and our table. Otherwise, no huge complaints.
author: Anna W.

description:
It's like an order-then-sit-down kinda place. Just FYI. I had the green chile roasted pork buritto and it was pretty good. I wasn't even that hungry but ate the whole thing. In my head, everything with the word 'green' has lots o' vegetables but there's actually not that many veggies in this burrito! Don't be fooled! Only the chile sauce is green. 

The restaurant also has pews. #church
author: Juliana P.

description:
this is my local so I've come in quite a few times. It's order at the counter and self serve seating. 
Their Agua fresca is awesome. Steak tacos are fabulous and their nacho dips with 4 choices is highly recommended too. 
I love their corn on the cob starters dish too. 
Great casual fun vibes and great service from servers and managers on ground. Good for groups too with long communal tables or booths.
author: Van-Anh N.

description:
This was my first experience with New Mexican cuisine and I am a fan! This spot came highly recommended and fortunately, we were able to do lunch here with Ruben's extended family while we were visiting the Bay Area. It's a casual eatery and orders are taken at the register. There were 13 of us and we were lucky to snag the large picnic table that was just big enough (we added two extra chairs at the ends).

Without even knowing its popularity, we ordered the Stuffed Sopaipilla with Carne Adovada ($16) served with rice, pico de gallo, and shredded romaine. Oh, and topped with mild green chile (you can choose hot or mild green chile or red chile). OH MY GOSH. My tastebuds were jumping with joy! I'm a big fan of marinated pork (Al Pastor, Korean Spicy Pork, etc), so it's not a big surprise that I'm obsessed with Adovada. The meat was tender, juicy, and so flavorful. What more could you want? Plus, the sopaipilla was crispy with a nice chewiness. Fried dough? Always.

Since it was Sunday brunch, we also ordered the Root Vegetable Hash ($13) that was topped with Carne Adovada, overeasy eggs, and red chile. Served with a side of sautéed greens. The hash was okay, but I had no complaints since there was more Adovada. Ruben's cousin also ordered baskets of Sopaipillas ($5) for the table, so it was nice to try them plain and with New Mexican red chile honey. Yum! Loved the subtle chile kick in the sweet honey. Really good stuff! Plus, I really liked their Green Chile Lemonade ($3).

Everyone really enjoyed their meal and it was a nice atmosphere to catch up and just hang out on a Sunday afternoon with the family. I would love to go back for another Carne Adovada-stuffed Sopaipilla!
author: Amelinda L.

description:
Interesting 
Hopes were high for this neighborhood place.  Unfortunately started off with a very bad VERY SMALL lemon Collins drink.   For 8 dollars I had one of the smallest drinks I have ever had.   I have never felt so ripped off before when I comes to alcohol and I have spent plenty of time with a drink in my hand.   It was almost insulting to be handed this after paying the bill.   Shame on me for not taking it back.   The food was also small portioned but pleasant.   My fiancée and I looked at the bright side and realized we had plenty of room in our stomachs for another place. 

Regretfully can't recommend the place and certainly won't be going back.    The city is expensive.  I have been here for 15 years but have never felt ripped off like I did today.
author: Patrick H.

description: The food is good and the chicken dinner is a great meal that can easily serve 3 people, but there is only about a 60% chance they will get your order right (if you order to go). I say this after eating here about 40 - 50 times (again, it's good!), but I've seen everything from wrong sides to no salsa to different amounts of chicken than was paid for. In the grand scheme of life does this matter? No. Not at all. But for the love of God, check your order before you leave this place.
author: David K.

description:
I had a hardcore craving for tamales the other night--I'm talkin' HAAANGRY for some tamales. One of my friends pointed me toward Green Chile Kitchen and oh my lord I am so happy she did.

I ordered one cheese and one pork tamale with "Christmas" chili (both green and red) and a side of refried beans and rice. To keep this short and sweet I'll just say that I was sad when my food was over. Absolutely delicious. The only issue I have now is knowing that these exist because I can't stop thinking about them. 

Thanks Green Chile Kitchen, you really helped a girl out.
author: Leah G.

description:
Meh..just an overpriced Mexican place. Nothing special. They were generous with the size of their margarita tho.

If this place was 20% cheaper I would have probably given it 4.5 stars.
author: Ninad A.

description:
It's a great place to eat during non peak times. 
Sometimes the service can be hit or miss.
author: Joy F.

description:
I can't keep living like this. Eating in San Francisco is gonna take me out of here. I get so ravenous for all of the offerings that I eat like my 'full sensation' (that has, like, a real name, right?) doesn't work. And then I rub my big belly and sing 'Unpretty' to myself. Vicious. But what do you do when there's pie to be eaten.

Yes, pie. I get it that people come here for New Mexican fare. Bully for them. But if you're living right, it's all about pie & ice cream. I live right. Armed with healthy scoops of Three Twins ice cream, I was ready to dig in to the pie choices of the day. But, the question beckons, what kind to have? This is why it's important to always travel to these places with friends: you can pick more than one dessert (and eat most of your friends' selection). Because I have friends from New Mexico who raised me right, I opted for the green apple green chile pie. What?? I know! I talked my friend out of a chocolate selection and into another fruit concoction. She ordered the apricot blueberry pie.

Healthy slices of warm pie, topped with top-notch ice cream and paired with coffee...is there a better way to end a day (food-wise, you awful perverted heathens)? I don't think so. True, this place is popular with families with small kids. Duh. Check the location and the fact that there's pie and ice cream on the menu. Come on a Tuesday and avoid the pitter pat of little ones, if that's a bother to/for you.
author: Johnny T.

description: It's been a while since we ate here but the boyfriend and I split a grilled steak burrito. The restaurant itself is large and open which felt perfect for summer. We ordered, sat down, and received our food. The presentation of the food was underwhelming (large brown plate, burrito, chips) but the burrito was pretty tasty. I accidentally drizzled their red chile honey on the burrito (apparently it is used for dessert) but I gotta say, it was delicious! If they're not marketing this honey as their special burrito condiment they definitely should!
author: Jamie B.

description: The restaurant it's ok, but the people work is slow and I saw one of the workers in the counter cleaning the nose.Very expensive food :0
author: Elisangela S.

description:
It's better than Chevy's or Chipotle but still Americanized yuppie Mexican food, virtually any place in the Mission is better for half the price. $90 for 4 without drinks. Yikes.
