And it's cafeteria style, which I can't blame the place for, but we sat down and wondered why for the longest time no one came over for anything. It was unexpected to have cafeteria dining in a yuppie/hipster atmosphere at those prices.

If it were around the corner I'd go back just because it's there and it's inoffensive, but no way as a destination would it even be a blip on my radar screen.

And our order taker was really really stupid. She meant well, and was very pleasant, but could not understand simple math or the concept of "what sides does the meal come with?" Apparently the common phrase "Your choice of X, Y, or Z -- P, D, and Q are optional extras at additional cost" was not in her lexicon.
author: Rob C.

description:
Tried my friend's half chicken last weekend - pretty good, the skin has a good crisp, well flavored, but the meat was a little dry. The mashed potatoes were definitely dry too, and kind of stuck together!
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/z50O47Al64Y6YrLsVmnjpA?select=aF5zbtgrtb7Ltu2rnQ5FdQ#aF5zbtgrtb7Ltu2rnQ5FdQ
author: Ziyan C.

description:
For someone who is from New Mexico, this place does not feel like home.  I have a hard time paying $14 for something I know is overpriced.  I tried the tortilla burger with green chile and was not impressed.  I mean, it was okay, but it certainly was not a representation of New Mexico.  Calabacitas were waaaaay too peppery.  I did like their Yerba Mate red Sangria, though.

The berry pie was very tasty.  

I will return to try other items, but definitely disappointing.
author: Christina S.

description:
I'm writing this update while waiting for my food, at Green Chile. Be forewarned: I'm a little cranky. I've been coming here for years, and spent hundreds of dollars here; nonetheless, I find some aspects of this business super annoying. At this moment I'm actually contemplating staying away for good, due to an extra frustrating scenario that unfolded today.

First, understand that it's always crazy busy and there's bound to be a line and a shortage of seats. Thus the objective is to place an order and claim a spot ASAP.  Today my experience was: wait in line for 10 minutes, then find myself at the front of the line, hoping the open spots at the bar don't disappear before I place my order. Suddenly, some guy is sidestepping the line and asking register dude about his to go order. Instead of telling him to stand in line like the rest of us, he rings him up and spends several minutes conferring about the guy's order with the kitchen employees. After this, some girl decides to try her hand at cutting the line - register dude rings her up, too. Finally I place my order, miraculously claim a seat, and discover that another register guy is taking someone's food order from the bar, despite the fact that an actual line still exists. 

What the f*ck... this is seriously absurd.  If there's some additional system aside from the main line, at least tell the rest of us so we aren't wondering why we're getting pushed aside for other customers.

Edit: I've come back here, at times when it's less busy, because I do like the food and atmosphere. However, there is a real problem with crowd management and customer communication at this venue. It's not reasonable that a longtime customer like myself would find out via a Yelp comment how the line is supposed to work - this should be immediately clear to all.
author: Janna M.

description:
In an effort to be healthy, I ordered the carb-free butter lettuce tacos with ground beef, chicken and steak (an extra $1). The chicken had very little flavor and seemed to have been defrosted, not fresh at all. The ground beef was similarly bad. The steak was juicy and probably my favorite out of the three but I was a little annoyed by the extra charge. 

I shared chips and guac (an extra $9) with my friends and thought that it was decent but not worth the price as they also don't give you more chips if you run out. 

Overall, I had a bad experience with the food and service. Well actually there is no service; you just order with the cashier who was a bit of a sour puss. 

I'm wondering if I just ordered too healthy. The burritos and nachos looked pretty good.  I guess you really can't mess up a cheesy, sour cream filled, beany burrito.
author: Raha G.

description: Went for lunch, knocked down a star because they didn't have a lunch menu. No table service. Had a burrito, $3 extra for a little bit of sour cream and guac on the top. With a bottle of coke lunch came to 18 and the quality was mediocre at best. Will not visit again.
author: Anastasia J.

description:
This place was recommended to me by the people I'm staying with and I wish I went with one of the other options given to me.
I ordered the two taco plate, one steak one chicken. The steak had good flavor however, the chicken had none, both tacos had very little in them and both shells broke while eating. The plate also came with rice and refried beans, the beans were piping hot and the rice was hard. Best part of my meal was the beer.
Also, I'm a stickler for customer service and this place lacked it, it took a while to get my food and when it was it was just thrown in front of me and was given no silverware, I had to ask a random bus boy that looked like he was on his break. I'd go somewhere else if I were you.
author: Margo D.

description: Dont let the fancy mason jar water glasses and contemporary wood paneling inside fool you, this place missed the exit to Guy Fieri's Flavortown! If you walked inside having never been in before like I did, you might expect some good food with a modern twist of Mexican flavors - WRONG! Green Chile should be ranked at the same level as that Green Burrito joint at the Carls Jr down at your local gas station. The burrito I had lacked so much flavor- the joke of a chile sauce, pinto beans straight outta the can, and the chicken that had absolutely no seasoning. Of course, this was just my meal and I cannot vouch for everyone else's opinions. In the end, if you are looking for some zesty authentic Mexican food, it is your best interest to look elsewhere in SF.
author: Elijah L.

description:
We live a few blocks away from Green Chile Kitchen, and it is our "go to" place to take visitors or friends.  What I love about Green Chile Kitchen:

1.  It's always open -- no break between lunch and dinner.  We frequently find ourselves eating at odd hours, and that is when Green Chile Kitchen is at it's best -- uncrowded and easy to get a table.

2.  You order your food at the counter and pay up front.  They bring your food to you (the service is generally quite good), and then when you're done, you can just get up and leave, no waiting for the check.  You get water and silverware yourself, which I prefer to hoping that the waiter or waitress might come by and offer me some more water.

3.  Great Mexican or New Mexican fare, with great vegetarian, vegan, and gluten-free options!  I love Mexican food, but since we became vegan many years ago, we've hardly ventured into any Mexican restaurants since there rarely are any vegan choices.  Our top vegan choices at Green Chile Kitchen are the Grilled Vegetarian Burrito and the Quinoa Stuffed Poblano Peppers.  Also great is the Grains & Greens Salad and the Homemade Vegan Tamales.  There are many attractive omnivore choices as well, so a good place to take your omnivore friends.
author: Matt and Rita C.

description:
Man, am I lucky to live best one of the best burritos in San Francisco. Green Chile Kitchen is one of my favorite restaurants as their food is always fresh and oh so tasty. Not only are their burritos, quesadillas, bowls and salsa out of this world, but they have friendly employees and great service.

Yum yum yum
author: Jalahn W.

description: It's right front of my house and convenient! I feel healthy eating Mexican food from here.  A little over priced tho.
author: Erena S.

description:
The food is good however for the type of dining that it is it about $3-5 overpriced! We came to try it out using a groupon so it was crazy crowded bc it seemed everyone else was trying to use it too before it expired. And the staff seemed really overwhelmed.

There was a slight mix up with our order, where the cashier told us they were out of ribs. So we got the enchiladas instead. However, there's a $5 price difference and she didn't seem to want to give it to us. Which seemed shady since we still paid $30 after the groupon. But it ended up working out bc their was a misunderstanding and we did get both rib and enchiladas along with our other order. 

Overall this place is good just overpriced with slow service. And if dishes are costing $18 a plate call me uppity but I want a server!
author: Veronica R.

description:
Apparently popular among USF students as it is in the vicinity, this is a New Mexican restaurant and I was impressed. It has a cool vibe the moment you walk in. It has a weekly specials menu on large poster paper with hand drawn artwork. It has self serve water that you get in mason jars.

FOOD: I ordered the New Mexican homemade chicken enchilada. I did not add an egg, but I was tempted to. I ordered it with black beans and hot green chile. This was superb. Served with rice, lettuce, and sour cream, I was personally disappointed with the portion for the price of Mexican food. But the enchilada was delicious. The chicken was cooked well and went great with the cheese and the sauce. The black beans were especially flavorful but the rice was a bit lacking. But when you put everything together for one bite, it was amazing. I also got chips and Tomatillo avacado salsa. This was also very good. Not quite sure how to describe it, but it was hot, sour, salty, avocadoy all at the same time and it worked well.

The only problem was the slight wait. It felt like the cashiers were in no rush despite the line going pretty much out the door. Despite this, I was fully impressed with the food and would definitely come back to try what else they have or just to have the enchilada again.
author: Bryant C.

description: We have had some great delivery meals from here! Super good Mexican dishes with fantastic soups! I recommend giving them a try sometime. Very reasonable prices as well.
author: Kirk M.

description: I love their stews!!! Always so consistently delicious. Corn tortillas too. One of my fave places
author: A W.

description:
This is a three stars purely on a one-time New Mexican cuisine dream gone bust, but I actually have high hopes for my next visit to Green Chile Kitchen. I'm a guest in this city, so when my best friend told me "we're going to have SW food!" and I saw sopaipillas and red/green sauce on the menu, I was ecstatic: I miss ordering Christmas and getting me some New Mexican eats, after having some spent time out in the Land of Enchantment recently.

But alas - the veggie stuffed sopaipillas were not of the same nostalgic calibre. Still, I enjoyed them. Good, well-seasoned medley of vegetables though somewhat lacking on the SW spice kick even with the Christmas sauce. Also, the portion here was actually much more manageable than the local-diner-grandma's-hosting-a-banquet oversized meals I had whenever I went out in NM. 

Looking forward to coming back. My friend's chile relleno burrito looked pretty dang good. And of course, I want sopaipillas, plain with a generous drizzle of honey. Noms. Wants now!
author: Allison C.

description:
Pretty great. Wasn't expecting a lot as I'm definitely more partial to the hole-in-the-wall type joints for my SF Mexican food, but this more than did the trick.

A tad pricier than a lot of other options you'll find, but the food was definitely plentiful. I had a pork super burrito and it definitely filled me up. Came with chips and Sour Cream, Guac, and Pico on top, with a choice of beans.

We were there pretty early (around 11am) and it had more than begun to fill up by the time we left. I can see why! Only complaint is that the service could have been a tad faster, but not too much of an issue at all.
author: Nate L.

description:
New Mexico native here, dad is a chef. Here's the deal. 

I join in heartfelt (though bittersweet) agreement with those who have commented on the lack of flavors in most of the dishes. While the ingredients are fresh and authentic, I have yet to eat a dish here that felt 'right' as far as the spices, intricate flavorings, and 'oomph' that true New Mexican food requires. There is, I regret, a richness that is missing. Call me crazy, or maybe I've just had my family's cooking for 20 years too long, but they simply don't use the right combination of salt, fats and spices to make me swoon. The blandness of the food, however, is of minor concern compared to the unnaturally ostentatious air that the restaurant itself presents. 

According to their website, the food is "inspired by Logan's many years spent in Santa Fe, New Mexico." First of all, spending many years (ahem, college) somewhere is not a qualification for understanding of an area's culture or cuisine. Good business idea, buddy, but I would leave it to the pros on this one, especially if they are an 82-y/o abuelita who could school yo ass in making tortillas. Second of all, Santa Fe is to Albuquerque as Marin is to the Mission. An hour apart but a world of difference. Obviously the food in the actual Santa Fe is just as good as the food in the actual Albuquerque, or Las Cruces, or Bernalillo, but it is also more flashy and more expensive, something that evidently also inspired the owners' restaurant design. At least in Santa Fe, if you splurge on lunch at a fancy restaurant, you can feed your whole family with one enchilada platter (that's how we do). Lastly, in New Mexico, chips + salsa come for free BEFORE your meal and sopapillas come for free WITH or AFTER - neither one is ever $5 a pop. 

On the upside, many of the dishes served here (posole, calabacitas, stuffed sopapillas) are genuine and unique to this restaurant in SF. I respect that the owners are bringing attention to the fact that (Yelp categories notwithstanding) New Mexican cuisine *is* a distinct cuisine, of which green chile is an important though not sufficient element. Unfortunately, I can't get over the pretentiousness of the prices and decor, which combine to form an inauthenticity unmitigated by the admittedly ideal sourcing of their namesake ingredient. New Mexican food is southern food both in the sense that it is comfort food and in the sense that you would NEVER pay $13 for fried chicken and a biscuit. Am I right? So why are you paying $15 for a burrito, ye hipster scum? I suppose for the same reason I might pay $12 for Kung Pao chicken, but I digress. 

Instead of coming here, make yourself a burrito and order your green chile from Hatch (http://www.elreyonline.com/) directly. Then you can taste and BE as authentic as New Mexicans have been for hundreds of years.
author: Eileen T.

description:
First of all, I used to live in New Mexico and I love NM food.  This restaurant comes close and is, to be honest, the only source to help my craving for hot green chile sauce and all that.  Their drinks are pretty good too.  I would say everything except the stew is amazing.  I come here once a month and order for delivery as often.

The reason they are only getting two stars?  They are UTTERLY INCOMPETENT when filling orders.  Literally, I've had them, multiple times in a row, get every last detail of an order wrong.  Want green chile sauce?  Great!  You'll be getting red.  Needed two meals for that delivery?  Hope you're not too hungry because we're only making one!  You ordered carne adovada?  Fantastic, try our NM Family Style enchiladas instead!   

If I were running this restaurant, I would waste no time in ferreting out the incompantancy and quick!  I do not want to lose my favorite (and only) NM place to this crap.  It really pisses me off and saddens me this is the case.  It didn't used to be this bad.  I want the owners to WAKE UP and realize there is a problem in your kitchen.
author: Oedipa M.

description:
I love the idea of bringing the unique twist on mexican food that you find in New Mexico, here to SF, but I still can't help but feel this is only the beta test version of a better New Mexican restaurant that is yet to come.

Of course the food is a bit pricey, but it's generally solid and the atmosphere is nice. 
I think if you live or work in the neighborhood, you should probably just check the place out for yourself. I just can't say with any confidence that once you do, you'll want to keep coming back. 

The burritos are solid but not great and are probably not the best example of what's best about this place (or New Mexican food in general). If I go back, I'll stick to the stews and other items and adjust my review accordingly.
author: Baron C.

description: Very happy to discover this place.  Great selection of Southwestern inspired Mexican Food.  There are great vegetarian options and a nice draught beer selection, including 3 IPAs.  The IPA I chose went very well with the Green Chile and Chicken enchiladas with the spicy green chili sauce. We will definitely be back!
author: Michael B.

description: Excellent neighborhood restaurant. The food tastes fresh and the options are great. If you are a vegetarian you will definitely find something yummy to eat. The green chili enchilada dinner was delicious paired with a nice IPA made my night.
author: Debbie B.

description:
Being half-Mexican, I am a Mexican food snob. (Sometimes even an American food snob...) Things that are covered in cheese and sour cream are not really authentic. This place, well it's like a hipster foodie version of traditional Mexican. 

I hadn't tried blue corn tortillas before this visit, but I feel robbed that I have lived 25 years without them. They are delicious on their own. 

Why come here? Decent parking around the area, not very crowded, and the food is super good.
author: Stephanie S.

description: convenient spot. I want to love this place but can't help but feel it's a bit overpriced. at least there's outdoor seating! great interior and a really cute place.
author: Vanessa S.

description: We ordered pick-up to go after watching the sunset at Ocean Beach one night - thought we could pick it up on our drive home. The food was terrific as always - though I wish the service (for pick-up - I mean come on) would have been better. We went in to pick up our food and were told they were slammed and it would be about 20 more minutes (for two salads) - but we could see they were busy so we said totally fine we will wait. Sat outside with out dog for 25 minutes and then went back in to get the food. Asked the guy at the counter if it was ready yet - he said ten more minutes - But he also had a to-go bag sitting next to him with two boxes in it. I said okay and stood there hoping if they could see me that would light a fire under them to get our food that we had ordered over an hour ago going. 5 minutes later, I asked again he turned asked the kitchen and they said "Dude it sitting there next to you and has been for 20 min" - bummer.
author: Madie H.

description:
I love green chile kitchen and New Mexican inspired food!  

The nachos with green chile, tortilla chips, beans guacamole are great for sharing!!!  The beets & greens and green chile roasted corn are delicious.  In this dish you will find kale, cotija, roasted corn, pepitas & citrus vinaigrette.  

I felt the seating was comfortable and cozy.  I enjoyed the picnic tables layout with long benches.

Don't forget to go down a couple blocks to Chile Pies & Ice Cream!  It's the best I have tasted in a while!
author: Nell C.

description:
This is a place where you never doubt if something will be good. We had two margaritas and a watermelon non-alcoholic drink it was amazing. Then we did guacamole a tamale and the half chicken. The flavors of all these dishes was very good. I really enjoyed the blue corn tamale. 

Service was good they have high chairs for the kiddies. You get your own water and utensils which is cool. Sit where you want and order and pay up front. This makes for a great flow. This place is a model for many other businesses they do it right here IMO.
author: Junebug J.

description:
Juuuust right in the middle. Great for a quick bite if you need food and aren't feeling adventurous. 

It will never blow you away. 

Then again, it will never make you sick.
author: Russell W.

description:
Good mexican food with a cool ambiance. Came here for lunch after having my eye on this place since first attending college at USF. The place has a very open environment, open windows and a lot of sunlight even though I came when the sun setting. The menu is pretty good, has its burritos, tacos, enchiladas and a couple unique items which were a nice change. I decided to go with the house made chicken enchilada with chips and 4 salsas as an appetizer. The chips were good, although not home made still fresh. The salsas were awesome! The green and orange( I think habanero?) were my favorite. 
My entrée was good, not amazing though. The chicken was very soft and juicy, but the salsa was not spicy and lacked flavor, luckily it was drenched in cheese which I love, so it's saved it for me. Wish the salsa was more flavorful and that the chicken had some spices or a kick to it as well. Nonetheless the meal was still very filling and pleasant. I would recommend this place for a good lunch!
author: Josue V.

description:
Green with envy.

Who: Anyone watching me eat breakfast.

Why: Homemade granola with pumpkin seeds, coconut oil, almonds, raisins and maple syrup with assorted berries was so good pretty sure it prompted spontaneous smiles.

Comes with whole milk Straus yogurt. Know this only because the very friendly staff took a look. Served on the side. Turns out a bit of honey is all you need.

Loved the $6 price almost as much as the final product. Unlike the last visit felt this was more than reasonable for such a delicious creation.

Don't be envious. Just go.
author: Jason B.

description:
This place was so much fun and so delicious!! A potent combination and a great way to get customers coming back!

My friend and I had the wet burrito with chicken and enchiladas as well as the chips and salsa. Everything was flavorful and not too heavy. The chicken was cooked to perfection! And did I mention their pacifico is $2 EVERYDAY?! 

so yeah, definitely coming back here!
author: Asmita J.

description: This a neighborhood favorite. Whenever friends or family come to visit, I do not hesitate to take them to Green Chile Kitchen. I love Green Chile Kitchen because they have excellent vegetarian, meat and seafood options. My all time favorite is the Fish Tacos. They also have delicious Kombucha on tap that pair well with each meal. I would consider this type of food to be San Francisco's versions of Tex Mex- well done.
author: Margie S.

description: Great ambiance but definitely overpriced for the quality of food. I found the enchiladas to be swimming in cheese and not a great balance of flavors. Salads are decent. Gluten-free consumers beware - the pozole has four in it, make sure to clarify you are actively avoiding gluten before ordering. Some waitstaff is more knowledgeable over others.
author: Shireen T.

description:
I like the space: It's roughhewn industrial chic with a New Mexican bent with lots of red and dark wood. They certainly quintupled the space they had at their prior location.

The food is good, the crispy tacos I've had seem a bit light on the meat (you can get pork, steak, chicken) and the guacamole is good and chunky served with thick and crispy (tastes like) house made tortilla chips.

I feel the entrees are a touch expensive but then again, you can order small plates if you're looking to spend just a few dollars for reasonably healthy fare. 

Green Chile Kitchen's settled into the neighborhood nicely; I'm sure I'll head over there once or twice a month for a quick bite and maybe try their brunch.
author: Jennifer O.

description: Worst service ever! I never got my meal. I was soo excited to try this place. After about an hour I asked the guy who took our order who admitted he never gave it to the kitchen, and said he would bring it right out. I followed up again (since I was starving and had been there over an hour). I finally left since it never came. I'm never coming back.
author: Emily W.

description:
Authentic New Mexican food, and a nice twist on the typical Mexican fair you get elsewhere in SF. There is an emphasis on Green Chile (like duh), and I'm not 100% sure if I'm a fan, but it definitely is a nice change from other types of Mexican.

The vibe of the place is relaxed, and you order up front at the counter. It can easily be the place where you hang out, or just eat and go.

I had the quesadilla, which was good, but I think I did myself a disservice by not trying some of the more unique things. My friends had those items, and they definitely looked good!

Service was quick and food was tasty.
author: Peter T.

description:
Holy smokes!!! The food here is divine! 

I enjoyed the Green Chile Stew and the Poblano Kale Salad. If food in New Mexico is this good I must visit this tasty state! 

The bowl of the Green Chili Stew was so satisfying. Portion was fairly large and the flavors were HUGE! So flavorful and just the right amount of kick in spicy. 

The salad was great too. Unique flavors. Very fresh 

Service was great and atmosphere was very welcoming!
author: Jenni R.

description: Heads up: good food, best around if you're from NM. Green chile is from Hatch. They don't have Tequila and their margaritas are made with wine and triple sec.
author: Amy C.

description: We ordered our food at 2:20. It is now 3:20 and still no food. We asked why it was taking so long and they told us that they forgot to put in our order. They offered no apology or any sort of refund.  We are never come here again - ever!
author: Matthew S.

description:
Good location in Nopa and decided to try this place out for dinner one day after work. 

I am on the Whole30 diet and had the market salad with chicken. Since I couldn't have the dressing, I asked for olive oil and balsamic on the side. That never showed up. The salad just came by itself. Since I was so hungry and didn't want to wait around, I just used their Tapatio as my dressing instead. For what you get, it's super expensive. I can't believe I even tipped this place considering the service was no bueno.
author: Victoria B.

description:
Toggled between 2.5-3.0 rating

I purchased an Amazon Local coupon the other day knowing my friend and I were going out for lunch to do some catching up.  Paid $20 for $40 worth of food and drink. The whole time I'm thinking of the green chile pie dessert place on the other corner.

I park the car a few steps away from the restaurant thinking what a great parking space.  Well, no wonder.  It's Friday street cleaning day between 12p-2pm.  I found out the hard way.  Walked back to the car afterwards and noticed I got a parking ticket.  $64.00. 

I digress.  We walk into the restaurant and perused the laminated menu.  We decided to go with the two tamale lunch plate and the chicken enchilada plate.  Both came with Spanish rice, choice of refried or black beans and chopped lettuce, onion and tomato.

The tamales were made with purple cornmeal.  Edible.  Small and not much filling.  Lousy rice.  Hard and lukewarm as were the beans.  The chicken enchilada was very good.   Chunks of chicken with cheese and green chile.  

The side order of guacamole and chips was alright.  Chips were thick and there was a big piece of avocado that was mixed in the guacamole.   It didn't or couldn't break down.   

Drinks - we each got a Arnold Palmer.  Nice.    

I still paid $4.97 out of pocket.  For the money it wasn't worth it and the food was lackluster.  And it's not Mexican food.

We walked down the block to the dessert place.
author: Shirley N.

description:
Wow...well what can I say. As a native New Mexican I was thoroughly impressed with the decor and menu selection. It's order and sit down style which is cool for San Fran living. The salsas are spicy and flavorful. I ordered the two chile rellenos combo....which serves great when wanted to sample as much food as u can. Chicken posole was good, moist rice, great pinto beans, choice of mild or hot green chile, sopaipilla crisp and soft center, blue corn crispy taco. Quite the experience, I have fallen inlove with this restaurant. Highly, highly recommended. 
:-)
author: Melissa J.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in my neighborhood. I am only bummed it took me 2 years of living in NoPA to discover it! 

It's just good, healthy, home style cooking! I have tried everything on the menu and you cannot go wrong! Some personal faves: Green Chile Chicken Enchilada, The Green Chile Bean and Cheese Dip Appetizer (which could be a meal in and of itself), the Taco Salad, and the Chicken Salad.

Oh, and the sangria is killer. A must have!
author: Serena Q.

description:
So, I live literally a 10 second walk from this place and have lived near it for 3 years. I've had a love/hate relationship with it. The first item I ever ordered was a breakfast burrito. It was tasty, but it was small and overpriced. It barely filled me up and that's unacceptable. The breakfast burrito from Beanbag Cafe on Divis or the breakfast wrap from Oasis Cafe are way better.

I found out a few months back that they offer a burger. Well, I ordered it for take out and it's actually very flavorful. You get the cheese burger wrapped in a tortilla with green chiles on top and the condiments on the side. Fresh lettuce onion and tomato. The fries are these seasoned crinkle cut ones.

I went here last night to sit down and have a $2 pacifico. I was going to order the burger but I wanted to revisit the enchilada after he said it was bigger portions than the burger. It was a decent square sized slice of enchilada that had "succulent" chicken. Small side salad with pico de gallo and rice and beans on the side. I was satisfied. The hot green chiles were as warned, hot, but that's what I wanted.

This place is a happening spot and is always pretty busy but not too busy. They also have a big screen TV now. I can honestly admit now that I like this place. Who cares if my ex got a crappy salad from here one time.
author: Marty J.

description: Very much enjoyed  Green Chile Kitchen. I came on the recommendation of a coworker. The 7 layer dip was fantastic. I didn't even want to eat my meal it was so good. I also ordered the New Mexican chicken Enchiladas. They were also really good with crispy corn chips in between the layers. An unexpected but delicious twist. The rice and beans were far from noteworthy. But still, that bean dip is on my mind.
author: Megan T.

description:
My son and I eat here every week and sometimes more than once. It has been a go-to spot since they moved in. 

Our fav dishes are: 
green chile stew bowl, flour tortilla
7 layer dip, roasted corn (summer only)
burrito w/ brown rice, black beans, cheese & sometimes steak
whole roasted chickens (they sell out quick)
all of their salads are delicious!
burger (in a tortilla)

I really wish they would bring back the fruit sopaipillas.
The decor is inviting.
Service is great.
Overall this place is a winner in my book.
author: E B.

description: Amazing chile relleno burrito, warm green chile soup, homemade tortillas, and good prices. Seating was hard to find on Sunday morning but other than that it was an instant favorite with New Mexican style food in San Francisco now within easy grasp. Check it out.
author: Ian S.

description: As someone who spent 17 years growing up in New Mexico and spent summers there during college, I'm always craving green chile, quite possibly the world's greatest food. The problem is, as other native New Mexicans know, finding green chile outside of the state is almost impossible! What a sad world. Fortunately, I stumbled upon Green Chile Kitchen. They have it all - enchiladas, burritos, chile rellenos, green chile stew, posole, tortilla burgers and even sopaipillas. While the food - perhaps a little more refined - may not be exactly like my favorite hotspots in Santa Fe (such as Guadalupe Cafe) the food is still very good and authentic. The cashier even understood me when I requested Christmas for my chile. If you're from New Mexico or you have ever spent enough time in the state to fall in love with green chile, then eating at Green Chile Kitchen is a must!
author: Brian L.

description:
GREAT New Mexican food. It's pretty casual and cash only. When we went they were offering $2 Pacifico's- score. Between the 4 of us, we loved everything. The tamale appetizer was good w/ great sauce and seeds. We also had an order of guac. The rotiserre chicken is juicy and I loved the side dishes of squash, corn etc. We had dishes with both green and red chili. They give you a choice of black or pinto beans and white or brown rice. Nice. 

After our meal, we also walked a block to Chili Pies (pretty sure they are related somehow). Good ice cream selection and both pies we tasted were yummy.
author: Leah B.

description: Kind of on the pricey side, but I'm OK with it because it's so good. My go to is the pork burrito or if I'm feeling like something healthier, I'll do the chicken dinner. It's new Mexican not Mexican so expect more green chili flavors. Also try Chile pies down the street for dessert!
author: Stacie C.

description:
cute spot. solid new mexican food. airy space. no huge lines. Love the new Mexican flavors of fresh chili and fresh ingredients without weighing your stomach down. I also like the casual neighborhood feel to the place.

The green chili stew is amazing, invigorating kick of the green chill with chunky chicken. Fantastic start to any meal. The sopaipillas (fluffy fried dough) was surprisingly delightful, especially for someone who is a low-carb eater- it has to be amazingly delicious to break the norm. Lightly fried, crunchy and fluffy at the same time.

I also like the best of everything green salad. Solid. The mesclun leaves are really fresh. The carrots could be better - better to cut them fresh to mix in the salad. Like the dressing.
author: Rebecca C.

description: This place is great, one of my favorites, and used to be 5 star. But, if there is any sort of line expect to wait at least 5 minutes PER PERSON to order. So frustrating. Something has got to be done to speed up ordering time. I would think it would be a priority of a restaurant like this to take people's money as fast as possible. I won't be coming back if there is any sort of line.
author: Evan M.

description: This place is a neighborhood favorite. I live down the street and get the same things every time. Always delicious and super fast. My favorites are their naked chicken burrito and their taco salad. The staff are lovely, and they always take care of us. Their drinks look awesome too. Definitely recommend if you're in the area.
author: Brodie J.

description: I love the place!! It is a little pricey for a restaurant where you order at the counter but the food is delicious.
author: Alexis G.

description: The food was completely bland. The portions were tiny. The items were not cooked to order....they came out a minute after we ordered. All image no substance.
author: S. T.

description: Green Chile's food tastes fresh and clean.  I usually get their wet burritos with red sauce and quinoa instead of rice, a great option that more burrito joints need to implement!  I've also had their salads, stews, sopapillas, and pies- all delicious!
author: Anna K.

description:
I have had real great meals every time I've been here.

Just yesterday I had the flat enchiladas with chicken (with sour cream) and it was delicious. Some of the best enchiladas I've ever had. The burrito I had the first time was also pretty good but wouldn't rival some of the best in the city.

I will say that this is a bit pricey for Mexican food, but relatively to to other great tasting food I think it's great!

Staff is nice and atmosphere is spacious and neighborhoody.
author: Peter M.

description: A little oricey but cool ambience that makes it worth it. Food is great, esp the burritos!
author: Jenna H.

description:
I'm not dying to come back here again, but I would definitely come back... which is saying something, especially in a city with a million and a half restaurants (I'm not a math major, but I'm guesstimating something around that).  

Green Chile Kitchen is exactly what it markets itself to be: New Mexican food.  And that's great.  I don't typically like paying too much for Mexican food, but Green Chile Kitchen was pretty reasonable, especially because its burritos were big, service was great, tables were clean, etc.  I liked all the tacky décor, large windows, mason jars, the bar... oh and I guess the food ;)  Super chill / relaxed place, and reminds me of lunch places in FiDi... maybe like a New Mexican version of "The Grove."

I got a vegetarian burrito with a chile tofu, but it wasn't that spicy... at all.  I just put salsa on my burrito from the chips it came it, and it tasted a lot better.  Next time, I definitely want to try some chicken enchilada combos or tacos though, because everyone else's food looked great!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I think it is ludacris that this place doesn't have a higher star rating. Are you people accidentally hitting the wrong button? 

Don't be deterred, the food is great and the only thing worth complaining about is the open seating - get over it - this is SF, things like that happen. 

I had the enchilada with an egg on top and it pretty much blew my mind. Between that, the beans and rice, and the neighborhood restaurant atmosphere, this place is on point. 

Pick what you want, go to the counter, order it up, and you'll be feasting in no time.
author: Katie K.

description: I am from New Mexico and Love Green Chile and was craving Huevos Rancheros so was excited to try this place when a friend suggested it. I got the Huevos Rancheros and a Tomale. My friend got the Migas and a small cup of Posole. The service is minimal with the customer having to go up and place their own order and serve their own water.  The price is very high in proportion to what you get:  we paid a total of $55.00 for tiny portions of eggs and re-fried beans.   The food taste is mediocre at best.  What galls me is the TINY portion size relative to the price. My plate, the Huevos Rancheros, had two small tortillas with a smearing of pinto beans (about a table spoon), topped with two small eggs, a bit of tasteless chili sauce and some cheese.  The Tomale was dry (we had ordered a cheese Tomale and were brought a tiny and dry sweet potatoe Tomale) - all in all, this IS NOT worthy of being called New Mexican Food. Additionally, the price verses portion is a rip off. I will not return.
author: MJ R.

description: Delicious! The service is not especially great but the food exceeded my expectations.
author: Jodi D.

description:
Came her for dinner around 7pm on a Tuesday and the place was packed. My fiance and I each ordered an entree (no drinks, apps or anything else), it came out to about $40. Pretty expensive for a place where you order at the counter from a girl who gives plenty of attitude and blatantly hates her job. 
 
I'd gladly pay $40 for hot, fresh, tasty food. That is not what we got. The refried beans were cold and crusty, seemed like they had been sitting out all day. The mashed potatoes were also cold and seemed like they had been sitting out all day. The avado pork had a pretty decent sauce on it but I could only eat about half of the serving they gave me because the pork was so covered in slimy, gross fat. 

The rotisserie chicken was good but so is the organic rotisserie chicken you can get at Safeway for $6. There is nothing special about this place at all. It is LOUD, packed with families w/ small screaming children. I think it gets so busy because it's easily accessible to the families who live in that area. There aren't too many restaurant choices on that block but it's well worth going down to Divis and getting a good meal. Will not ever be returning!
author: Desa F.

description: I happened to be in the neighborhood for work and saw this little gem. We went in and the daily specials were what really caught my eye. Was this sign deceiving me?! Nope, I read it right. NAVAJO TACO'S, while the bread wasn't my all time favorite I was very pleased. One bean, one zucchini and the final one being ground beef. All of the ingredients were ripe and fresh. Three dishes order, three dishes completely gone... FYI if you like chili relleno you are in for a treat. I will absolutely be back to devour each dish.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I first visited Green Chile Kitchen not too long after it opened and I have to say, I was honestly not that impressed.  I tried their Chicken Enchiladas and they were pretty flavorless.  In fact, many typical dishes one would find in a New Mexican restaurant were absent from the original menu (Sopapillas, Carne Adovada).  In the years since many people had told me that the food was really good and I should try it again.  After my recent visit, I can say that I do really like Green Chile Kitchen!

The newer space is great - large with a more room and a nice ambiance - Urban Rustic New Mexican.  The food was very good: 

Green Chile Stew - a subtlety-flavored chicken stew with some good flavors, especially from the green chiles.

Carne Adovada - a nice hearty stew of red chiles and tender pork.  This has a nice smokey flavor that is natural from the chiles and the seasoned tender pork creates a great balance in texture.  The rice and beans that arrived were decent.

Sopapillas - soft and delicate pillows of fried bread, these went perfectly with the adovada or stew.  I saved a bit for dessert and enjoy it with the Honey Chile.

While I did really like the meal, I can't say it was very authentic New Mexican.  Green Chile Kitchen is definitely a California interpretation of New Mexican cuisine - not necessarily a bad thing, since I like the healthier food (no lard!).  A diehard New Mexican food connoisseur may not be a fan of this, but a Californian with health food sensibility will probably enjoy this spot.
author: Ken G.

description:
So depressing: more sublime regional ethnic cuisine "adapted" to accommodate and please pale palates. 

Go there if you want bland burritos for twice the price and half the flavor of any taqueria in the mission. New Mexico is known for the variety and forceful assertiveness of its chiles. Where?
author: Josephine M.

description:
Pretty great food, New Mexican which cannot really be found anyplace else.
Good ingredients means you'll pay more for a burrito and the like, but when you taste the food you'll understand! Nice chill place and the staff there are pretty much always cool.  .....pffft, check out the ground beef burrito!
author: Marlow M.

description:
My favorite is their *deconstructed chicken burrito* after the restaurant owner, Mark ordered this for his break the first time I ate here -- now it's my main go-to here!
*think Chipotle's burrito bowl but well-portioned, with fresher ingredients! 

Love the dark wood dining and the natural lighting this place gets!
On an especially nice day, the windows are typically cranked open.

Great neighborhood spot with consistent, great customer service!
author: Kat L.

description:
I live around the corner from this place, so I've eaten here quite a few times in the past few years. Everything is a pretty solid option. My go to is usually the vegetarian burrito with calabacitas and hot green chile. I love the chips and salsa appetizer too and usually get the 4 salsa sampler. They're all so delicious! 

There sister restaurant/dessert place is one block down the hill and they have free wi-fi and amazing desserts. I sometimes get take-out at green chile kitchen and take it down to chile pies to work.

It's a good staple restaurant in the area. If I lived on the other side of town I probably wouldn't travel to eat here. But if your in the hood, its worth the stop.
author: Carlynn A.

description: We had pardon peppers, corn on the cob and green chili stew. Everything was very good. I'll be back. I noticed a few tables were there for the first time. Everyone seemed happy.
author: Kim S.

description:
Verbena cocktail is cool. Service is good. Green chile stew made
My night. Satisfied.
author: Matthew A.

description:
We were craving Mexican food like we typically do but we didn't realize it was Cinco de Mayo until we got to Green Chile.  I'm not sure if the line is normally out the door but it moved relatively quickly so it wasn't too bad.  Plus there was still seating inside for the three of us.  I ordered the green chile roasted pork burrito and it was really good.  It had a bit of a bite but not so much that it overwhelmed the flavor.  I also got a watermelon drink which was delicious.

We'll be back and hopefully it will be before next Cinco de Mayo.
author: Blake B.

description: My fiancé is from New Mexico and he loves this place. He will tell you it's not as good as food straight from NM but that doesn't stop us from ordering from here almost every week. I usually get their salad. The chicken salad with blue cheese or the beet salad is amazing! They do NOT skimp on the meat and the portion size is huge. It's always two meals for me (it's a salad!) and always tastes fresh. Everything else is really good too, especially the sopapillas doused in honey. :)
author: Helen F.

description:
We came here on a rainy evening with family who highly recommended it, and really were not led astray.  I can imagine on any other night, GCK could be packed (not the largest place) and might have impacted service, etc., but you have to review for what it is, right ?  So here is what it was for us: very friendly counter service, food arrived quickly and when we pointed out we were missing something, it came within seconds.  Just couldn't have been better service, made even better by the woman at the counter going out of her way to get us coupons for the pie shop down the way (owned by the same people, and that place is a whole other story...definitely a 5 star shop).

As for food, highly recommend the rotisserie chicken and the tamales (chicken and pork) that we had.  Tamales looked a little off because they are made with blue corn, but were just spot on.  The green chile sauce is off the chain.  Should have ordered more to bring home with us (if we could).

If all neighborhood places could be like this, we'd all be a bit better off.  Really nice job.  We'll be back.  Hopefully in a rain storm that will keep crowds away (yes, selfishly).
author: Dave H.

description:
My friend lives two blocks away so we frequent Green Chile for brunch.  It can get busy on the weekends, but there are communal tables and we've always managed to finagle room.  You order at the bar, then take your number and find a seat.  The food comes out pretty quickly and as it is made, so some people may have to wait while others have their dishes.

Try their migas or healthy breakfast bowl with a carafe of mimosa.  Their mimosas come in orange or mango, I'd suggest trying both...  They've recently updated their menu, and I've found that everything on it is quite delectable (granted I've never had anything but brunch foods).  Definitely suggest giving it a shot!
author: Michelle K.

description:
I'm first to admit, spending a couple of days in New Mexico does not make an expert on green chili. But I did get exposed to this legendary Southwestern salsa. And yes, it's as awesome as advertised. You can throw a rock down the street and hit 39 places that make fantastic green chili.

However, the same cannot be said for San Francisco. Green Chili Kitchen is the latest in a long line of failed attempts to recreate New Mexico style chili.

It's not just the less than average chili that makes this place a "no go". The high prices, the stand in line and place your order, trying to find a table afterwards and then discovering you want a another drink and having to get back in that line all over again. Meanwhile, your hot chili has turned cold.

Go if you must, but if you have sampled green chili in NM, you will be greatly disappointed.
author: V B.

description: Eh, just eh.. And that's being nice bc I was really hungry. If your looking for Mexican food, this isn't the place. I'm leaving two stars bc I'm not a mean person and didn't want to leave 1. Also this restaurant is the epitome of gentrification.
author: Drew R.

description:
We are big fans of the green chile group of restaurants (especially the chile pies).

Their salads always hit the kale-loving spots in us with the recent kale and beet salad perfectly filling that role. Our other order of carne asornado was really just okay. We wished it had more spice or bold flavors somehow. The sopaipillas were absolutely delicious and fresh though. Not a bad meal although not one we'll be craving anytime soon.

Overall, we think we'll stick with their traditional chile pie and salads.
author: Amy D.

description: I got the mild green chicken enchiladas and they were amazing. The food looks and tastes just like home. I'd recommend this place to anyone. I looked at the food other people got and everything looks just as good as what I had ordered. The service was fast I got my food in a promptly matter as well as the 3 others I'm with that also ordered food. It was reasonably priced and that's always a good thing. I will definitely be back in the future. Thank you Green Chile Kitchen.
author: Javier M.

description: This is not what I call my authentic Mexican food organic or not I been to better places in this city the prices are extremely expensive and the service sucks
author: Gregory H.

description:
Is this possible? Christmas all year round in SF?

New Mexican cuisine is famous for their "Christmas" sauce -- red and green chile sauces atop savory dishes. The fact that there's a resto here in my own city where I can get this? Oh, definitely TOPS.

The bold red color on the walls matched with the wood furniture add layers of warmth to an airy space. Picture windows slide open to let the breeze in. From the booth we were sitting, I could see the rotisserie oven which held my breakfast captive.

Fulton Valley Chicken. Never. Looked. So. Good.

Since I already had breakfast at home, I decided to stick to a smaller sized serving. Breakfast tacos are priced at $3.95 each with a choice of beef or chicken. Chopped lettuce, fresh tomatoes, mild green chile sauce and sprinkling of four cheeses rounds up my simple meal. Freshly prepared and delicious. My friend's steak burrito is big enough to kill those hunger pangs but with nicely seasoned meat, scrambled eggs and melted cheese, how could it not?

I'm excited for the next time so I can taste more of their menu items. Posole. Tamale plate. Sopaipilla. Red chile sauce. Green Chile sauce. I can seriously get this without going to Santa Fe?

Sure looks like Christmas here in SF.
author: Janice C.

description: It's probably the best the New Mexican/ south western food I've had so far!. The real deal. Check it out
author: Dorian M.

description: My last visit witnessed a notable decline in quality here, or at least value. My "smothered burrito" was small and dry, and had a teeny squirt of red sauce, and one of green sauce. With tax, tip, and various nickle and dime charges (a tax for SF health care, an extra $1 for something else), this was $20 burrito, which was about $10 more that it was worth.
author: Nick C.

description:
Definitely try the sweet potato tamale and quinoa stuffed poblano. Both are SO good and are dished your don't find often, or if you do, they're not made this well. They have some tasty salsas as well. Plus, the dishes come with cactus, rice and beans so you get a variety of foods and it fills you up. 

I ordered this for delivery, so I don't know what the actual restaurant is like, but speaking just in terms of the food, it's delicious, filling, and delicious again.
author: Maleenee B.

description: Delicious! Love the big, gluten friendly menu! Lots of choices and customizable options. The food arrived quickly and was perfect. Would definitely recommend!
author: Andrea R.

description:
Have been here twice now. 
First time, I was fairly surprised by the price initially. 
The restauraunt itself is in a perfect area for USF campus,  and is very cute, classic looking San Francisco restaurant.  

First time I ordered Chicken Nachos. Was feeling a cheat day and it was sub-par at best. Maybe could be considered a 4 if they were a little warmer and had the topping I asked. 
Second time, I had a chicken quesadilla.  Ordered sour cream,  guac, and pico for an extra two dollars and they gave me about enough to fit half a spoon. 
The quesadilla itself was good, just over - priced for pretty basic flavors and food. 
Overall review: spend your money somewhere else. 

There is better food for cheaper other places.
author: Kayla A.

description: The environment is super fun. Nice big open seating, good bar and great back ground music. The downside is the pricing. I don't mind spending 9 bucks on a burrito, especially when the employee says they are big. Lies, they are Americanized burritos that aren't filled at all like a burrito should be. I ordered a vegetarian burrito, expecting a hefty burrito filled of goodies. Instead I got a burrito filled with just rice, some beans, maybe three slices of avocado and some cheese. Not impressed at all. This is my first time and last time. Just new to the neighborhood and was trying restaurants around us.  Also, if you order the veggie burrito you may just get a meat burrito...
author: Sam S.

description:
One of my favorite neighborhood spots.  Lots of veggie and vegan options.  My favorite is the healthy breakfast bowl. I sub potatoes for the eggs, add chorizo and drizzle the red chile honey on top.  So good!  Many other options from stew to burritos to empanadas and more. The mild green chile is actually pretty spicy but really good.

They also have delicious watermelon Aqua fresca which can be added to champagne if you like (and I do like!) the atmosphere is nice with big windows, lots of wood, and a tv at the bar if you want to grab some guacamole and a $2 Pacifica and catch a game. A meal is anywhere from about $8-15.     You walk up and order at the counter, but they do have people floating around to bus tables or if you need to ask for a box or more salsa or a refill on your agua fresca (you get 1 free).
author: Natalie W.

description:
Full Disclaimer: I absolutely love Mexican food and Green Chile Kitchen is only three blocks from my apartment, so I eat here all the time when I'm home.  

However, this place is still FULLY deserving on five stars, and is one of my favorite (if not my favorite) restaurants in the city. 

I mean what's not to like? The staff is friendly, its convenient, they do take out, brunch, drinks, and of course lunch/dinner, so basically they have it all. 

As far as the food goes, I've had their burritos, taco salads, enchiladas, tacos, and enchiladas and they've all been good. But honestly I usually just get the stuffed sopaipillas with carne adovada and don't even bother with anything else - it's too good. By that I mean its my FAVORITE restaurant dish to order. Period. 

Carne adovada is basically slow-roasted pork braised in chili sauce, and as you can guess by their name, no one does chilies like "Green Chile Kitchen". So my advice is to come here, order the carne adovada, and leave happy.
author: Brian S.

description: Food is pretty good but the service sucks. It takes forever to get the food and they are clearly understaffed. Waited almost 1 hr for take out order. Have had similar problems when eating in in the past. Update: waited 1 hr and 1/2 the order was missing despite the servers insistence it was all there. Couldn't  go back and they only refunded a portion of the food they forgot.
author: Brandon K.

description:
Love this place. The chicken is good, the service is friendly and it's neighborhoody. 

It can get a little crowded and disorganized when it's busy. Best bet is to come for lunch on a weekday.
author: A R.

description: I love this place. It is convenient to get to, taking the 5, and down the block is Chile pies. I love the steak burrito and steak enchilada with egg. They are eco friendly when it comes to take outs.
author: Kelly O.

description:
Cute little place with long benches and rustic  picnic tables - perfect for families and friends alike. Everything on the menu is really good, especially: chicken quesadilla, grilled burritos, carna adovada, nachos, sopapillas...mouth is watering...Also, the food is (?)healthier and much tastier than most Mexican food I have had around.  

Oh...and if you are into pie...one block away is their Chili Pie shop...oh yum.  

And, if you don't want to eat in the restaurant, I recommend doing take away/pickup (2 person job) over the very expensive delivery with Caviar.
author: Jenn D.

description:
A friend and i ate here for lunch today. We're both vegetarians and we ordered the sampler platter or whatever with all of the vegetarian options ($18). It was enough for the two of us to get full off of. The sweet potatoe vegan tamale was my favorite, but the flat enchilada was really good too. The taco was okay, kind of tasteless ~ but it's hard to make quinoa taste good imo. 
The staff are very friendly and the place is in a nice quiet neighborhood.
author: Emma G.

description:
For all you yelpers monitoring and following my reviews and get a laugh or two about my continuing and record-breaking burrito-journey, I came here for a "Breakfast Burrito". It counts, right? 

At first I thought this NOPA neighborhood was all residential. "Boy, was I wrong!"

There are some lively businesses here as well, including this huge corner New Mexican restaurant. From the outside of the restaurant, I can smell the chicken being cooked on the huge rotisserie cooker. 

Inside the place has a kitchen (Taqueria-style) on the right and a cool wine bar on the left. Cashier is in the middle as I walk in. And I ordered the Chicken Breakfast Burrito. For $8.00, I get a lean chicken meat, which is from Fulton Valley and made from the aforementioned rotisserie cooker, scrambled eggs, potato chunks and Pico de Gallo sauce in a flour tortilla with green chile, guacamole and sour cream as toppings. My burrito was loose on a plate with an artful presentation. Tastewise, the meat was lean and smoky with a noticeable rotisserie flavor. I also added a Limon Jarrito to wash my burrito down. 

Remember, "Breakfast is the most important meal of the day". 

"So eat a burrito!" 

I did and I will definitely come back and again eat the breakfast burrito and other foods from the restaurant.
author: Matt G.

description: Clean and simple. Simply delicious. Good atmosphere and decent service. Margaritas are a decent complement to the food too.
author: Chris T.

description:
We walked over on a sunny Saturday afternoon for an early-ish lunch. Little did we know that the rest of NOPA would be finishing (or just starting) their brunches, but the place was packed, and there was a line (quite literally) out the door. So there was a little hassle getting our order in, a little wait until a space for the three of us opened up, and a little hassle getting a high chair from the far end of the restaurant, but in the end all was well. 

I ordered the quarter chicken dinner, which comes with rice, beans, salsa, and a huge tortilla (probably meant for a burrito). The chicken is truly delicious. Crispy, juicy, and super-flavorful. That you can get a whole one with rice & beans for $20 is a deal I need to keep in mind for the future.

I'm really eager to come back soon - the rest of the menu looks fantastic, especially the pozole, the tamales, and the sopapillas.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I've been here several times now (ah, the convenience of living two blocks away) and just learned that Green Chile Kitchen is a New Mexican restaurant. As in "New Mexico" the state. Not "new Mexican" like a new take on traditional Mexican food. Mind = blown. Guess you do learn something new every day.

Anyway, I've had a variety of dishes here, from the veggie quesadilla to the carne adovada to the chile relleno, and I've always been satisfied. After a brief wait in line (there is always a line - which I think is a good thing), you order at the counter and bring your number to an open table. Service has always been prompt and friendly, and portions are sizable and fairly priced - actually I think cheaper than some other SF options of equal quality. Atmosphere is lively and usually there is everyone from singles to families, so it makes for good people watching. Alcoholic drink options are wine, beer and your classic mimosas and margaritas. Go for the house red, you won't be disappointed.

I will be back, because - well - obviously I already have.
author: Allison B.

description:
Favorite Mexican (specifically New Mexican) restaurant in San Francisco! I don't know how this place doesn't have better ratings. I'm a regular here - probably stop by a couple of times a month.

The food is absolutely delicious, especially if you are a green chile lover! The burritos are very large and incredibly delicious and my personal favorite - the corn chowder - is to die for. The salads are also fantastic if you are trying to avoid an especially heavy meal. To be honest, the only dish I've had here that wasn't great was the "burger" (ground beef patty wrapped in a tortilla).

Prices are very reasonable and orders are taken at a pair of registers as you enter and then you are given a number to help the waitstaff find you. This place is often packed for dinner and there are no reservations (seating is self serve) so plan ahead and keep an eye peeled to grab a table when one opens up!
author: Naeem I.

description: Green chili has been a weekly staple for our family for over 5 years . Their staple brunch and dinner items are amazing . Smothered burritos ( Christmas style) , enchiladas , green chicken stew, and homeland taco salad are some of our favs . Spicy lemonade washes it all down nicely.  Carnitas is also legit . With all the Mexican spots in SF , green chili offers a unique twist . Their dessert spot around the corner is also legit . Great pie's and 3 twins ice cream.
author: Tucker s.

description:
Probably the best nachos in town.  And everyone who works there are very nice.  Also, the soup us quite good as well.  

Hope they consider breakfast tacos.
author: dyl n.

description: The veggie stew is fantastic and so are all the poblano dishes. Also one of my favorite breakfast places.
author: Madeline H.

description:
Can't find hatch green chile ANYTHING in the city, so when I took notice of this little spot, I had to try it. 

This isn't a typical restaurant, you order and then you stake claim of any available table.  But not before you mean mug the couple that just sat down at the table that you've been waiting for for the last 30 mins. 

Aside from the seating arrangements (which I hope they reconsider), their food is savory, plentiful, and the agua frescas are refreshing.
author: Cynthia V.

description: I have been here several times. The service is OK and the food is pretty mediocre but with that said it seems to be pretty healthy Mexican food it's just too bad that to get healthy Mexican food at this place you have to sacrifice taste.
author: chris c.

description: A great Mexican restaurant. I had there green chile enchiladas which were fantastic. My husband ordered the green chile stew with pork, and loved it. Their guacamole was mediocre and rice was undercooked. Plan on coming back!
author: Sarah W.

description: Firstly, it is New Mexican food as in Hatch green chiles, sopapillas, Santa Fe five and dime, not as in Nouveau Haute Cuisine de Mexique. Secondly, it is really good for what it is. The service can be a bit slow, and the Michelada is terrible, but  I would take the flat enchilada plate with egg on top every day of the week.
author: sellMyFing n.

description:
I've come here on multiple occasions and have always loved the food.  While just slightly on the pricier side, each dish I've ordered has been delicious and totally satisfying especially on a rainy San Francisco day.  

It does get a bit crowded during lunch time so it might be somewhat hard to find a table if you're with more than one person, however they do have seating at the bar and I haven't found it too inconvenient.  Overall great place that I like to take friends who are visiting from elsewhere for a good quality/not so expensive bay area meal.
author: Xiuli S.

description: I've tolerated their overpriced gut bomb food because it's close to my house and my daughter likes it.  But last night, my daughter's dad took her to eat there and when he took her to the bathroom in the middle of the meal, the table was cleared, their unfinished food thrown away, along with one of my daughter's toys.  Don't go here, because quite frankly they are typically clueless when you order anyway and it takes forever for them to make a bloody taco.  Take a ride down to the Mission and buy a decent burrito for 1/3 the price.
author: Jana T.

description:
Would have been 5 stars for the food and ambience BUT when the service is so belligerently bad it ruins everything else.  Thanks JOAN for hating your job and making sure everyone else's day is a little worse for meeting you.  

1.  Got our order wrong
2.  Bitchy throughout
3.  When corrected told us we were wrong.
4.  Got the right order... But still wrong.

Go work at Lucky 13 JOAN.  You will fit right in.
author: David L.

description:
Came here yesterday for dinner, I'm a fan! This is a "order at the counter and get a number for your table"-sort of place.

Positives (+): 
(+) Cool vibe and atmosphere
(+) Very authentic New Mexican food, as I was sitting at a table with some New Mexican food experts 
(+) Stuffed poblanos with ground beef, roasted corn, cheese. Really good. I'd recommend. I did ask for a side of sour cream to add to it though, and it was even better with the sour cream. 
(+) The enchilada - order the fried egg with it! Really good, I'm getting it next time. 
(+) Green chile pork burrito looked really good, although I didn't try it myself. 

Negatives (-): 
(-) The rice that accompanied my dish was really dry, like it had been sitting out for a while
(-) Sangria was only okay
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Awesome food!!!!

We ordered the rotisserie chicken with fried egg on top and might I say that it was simply sumptuous.

Simply said, you will be missing out on some very great food if you don't go here.

Also ask for their homemade habanero salsa.
author: Suraj R.

description:
Cool place but has a forced hipster vibe.

The food was made with great, fresh ingredients; however, it was extremely bland. I was not impressed. I would not return because it was far too expensive for the lackluster taste.
author: Hanna M.

description: As someone from New Mexico I needed to find out about this place. The taco salad was brimming with beans, lettuce, just the right amount of cheese, avocado, and salsa. Portion size was hefty but not too large. Delicious horchata! Def would go back again and again!
author: Abbe K.

description: I liked this place, I'm trying to figure out why I'm hesitant to give it a full 5 stars and I think it's because the red chile chicken soup I ordered was a little too spicy. ha but that's knit-picking obviously, everything else was great. I loved the blue corn tortillas (best corn tortillas I've ever had) and it was fun to have the water glasses be glass mason jars. It's a serve yourself feel- you order at the counter and you get your own water and silverware, but the cool feel of the restaurant made up for it. Slight hipster but not in an "in your face" kind of way so it wasn't too over the top. ha overall great place, just don't order the soup if you don't like spicy food.
author: Haylee A.

description:
Date & Time:  Saturday October 31, 2009 @ 2pm
New Location:  1801 McAllister
Company:  Michael & Jack
Crowd:  Neighborhood Peeps in Hip Casual Clothes; Printed Local T-Shirts, Jeans & Sneakers
Vibe:  Cool
Decor:  Warm & Rustic.  Wooden Tables and Booths
Service:  Efficient
Imbibe:  Libations Served in Mason Jars.  Beer & Wine Available
Devour:  Super Nachos, Niman Ranch Beef Burrito w/ Green Chile, Ciao Bella Gelato
Total:  $25.83
Note:  Happy Halloween Everybody!!!
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
Awesome New Mexican food, turnaround time and cafeteria style with great service. They have a pickup counter for to-go orders which is key.

They once forgot one item in our takeout order, we called to let them know, and they personally drove all the way to our place within ten mins with our food and extras. Loved that service!

One of our weekly staples for a quick, delicious meal!
author: Brent T.

description:
Very good authentic Mexican food. It's a bit pricey but well worth it for the size of the plates and the quality of the food. They've also got a bunch of vegan options. 

Check it out.
author: Jason A.

description: It's really disappointing when you stumble across over priced Mexican food. This place is decent at best but $5.00 for chips and salsa? Are you serious? I should have just walked out but I just spent $18.95 on a burrito and a Diet Coke. That's insane. Jokes on me. But then again this is San Francisco and this is Nopa. Any hole in the wall Mexican joint in the mission makes this place seem comedic. I'll never come back here again.
author: Jonathan B.

description: Excellent! I'm so happy to have found a restaurant that specializes in New Mexican cuisine. My friend and I loved everything we ordered and we were tempted to order everything. We appreciated that the ice cream was homemade--way, way better than from a tub that has been sitting in the freezer for months. I wish they had a GCK in the East Bay, or at least a cookbook.  Although the restaurant has been around for 10 years, this is the first time I've been here and I consider it one of my new favorite restaurants in SF. I'll definitely be returning!
author: Sakura V.

description:
Can't say anything about the restaurant ambiance. I've only ordered for delivery, but I was impressed!

Great southwest flavors and moderately priced.

My rice was a LITTLE undercooked, but the rest made up for it!
author: Amanda Z.

description:
There's not much that's memorable about this place aside from the long line you're going to be waiting in to order and the community seating that will likely leave you a little frustrated. Why will it frustrate you? Because the local yokels will resist sharing the space around them. Don't rely on anyone being decent. You're going to have to elbow your way in. 

The food, well that was just... meh.

Maybe two visits isn't a large enough sample to draw such conclusions from, but that's how I feel after my two times here.
author: Don W.

description: Came here for a work lunch and had the staff tweak one of the items to make it vegan. It was full of veggies (which I dug), but wasn't exactly mind-blowing. Not somewhere I'll go out of my way for, but a solid meal nonetheless.
author: Jon T.

description:
Good full flavor and wonderful sauces. 

Not too spicy but still makes my taste buds happy. 

I went in the afternoon and it was dismally dark with no charm or ambiance and although a comfortable temperature, I felt cold due to the starkness. When the lights were turned on at dusk it didn't help. Not great but I'd come again if I found myself outside and hungry.
author: Justin S.

description: Love this place!  Everything is delicious and fresh.  Plenty of healthy options and all high quality.  Parking is difficult around this area, so be warned.  Wish I lived nearby!
author: Laura M.

description: 5 stars dedicated to the best breakfast burrito in town. Get the steak!! Otherwise the food is good, not authentic Mexican, but good. 2 dollar Pacificos and pretty bomb sangria also. Restaurant - 7/10, bfast burrito - 10/10!!
author: Robbie S.

description:
Salsas have no spice to them and the flavor is meh. Chicken doesn't have much taste. Quesadillas was one of the worst I've ever had given the $9 price tag. I don't think I'll be back.

Burrito and soup were mediocre. Better than the quesadilla.
author: Pat W.

description: I don't usually post reviews on Yelp but when I do you know it must be good. Maybe a bold statement BUT - Best fruit/yogurt/granola bowl I have ever had. I live in San Diego and visit SF regularly as my bf lives here. This is this second time I have eaten at Green Chile Kitchen & ordered the parfait & my reaction was just as great as the first time. Also, the coffee is on point. I will definitely be back.
author: Courtney U.

description:
The food here is beyond amazing.
But the service is slow as hell!
My friends food came to the table cold..
they forgot to deliver a soda that we paid for (i didn't realize till i got home!)

don't come here for the service...come here for the food which is beyond amazing!
author: Ripley B.

description: Not worth it. Too much hype for nothing. Go to Papalote at Fulton that you're better off. Ordered a pork chili that came with just fat but pork. My husband's burrito was just ok for the price. Not happy and not returning.
author: Logia G.

description:
Pluses: The atmosphere was nice and it wasn't crowded on the Saturday we went. I like that can order at the counter and then the food it brought out to you. When I asked for some tortillas to compliment the beans on my plate, then kitchen staff gladly obliged. Prices were reasonable.

Minues: While the menu items looked enticing, the food was rather bland. I ordered the quinoa stuffed peppers. Basically just tasted like unseasoned quinoa and the peppers it was in. Would not go back for the food.
author: Crystal H.

description: Green chili is OK, a little flavorless but the best I've found in SF yet. Breakfast burrito is a little heavy on the eggs too.
author: Aimee O.

description:
Some of their specialty dishes are to die for, and their main dishes are very good. My wife would give them five stars.

In particular, their homemade lemonade is incredible, the sopapillas with honey (and chile honey!) are delicious, and the Navajo tacos are heavenly.
author: David S.

description: Best tamales I've had in my life! Wish I could write more but I'm currently in a food coma from the deliciousness we experienced here today! Looking forward to trying the slices of pie we took to-go later from Chile Pie...much later! Great location, parking decent, great vibe, excellent service, AMAZING FOOD!!
author: Satomi C.

description:
Earlier, in the library, my friend came up to me and inquired as to why I was surrounded by day quil, ricoloa, emergen-c, tissues, and why I sounded like a duck.
"I'm ill. And I don't mean fly. I mean sick." 
"Omg how did that happen!?"
*Blank stare.* "... Well... a virus got into my body through an air passage and started multiplying and is currently ransacking my bloodstream. That's how that happened."
"Oh. Well... what are you going to do about your dinner tonight?"
"Uh..... Hope hot mess is back in style?"

Turns out, hot mess is back in style. But I'm generally a hot mess so that goes with the territory. 

I really wanted a super burrito, and had to be in the area post dinner, so I picked this place for a [things I don't go on] date. I had been looking forward to a burrito and a beer for a week. But because I was down with the sickness, I got green chile chicken stew only to realize... I couldn't taste anymore. Which caused quite a bit of an internal chaos. 

Getting to the actual substantive review, this place wasn't like I imagined it, it was far more rustic, refined, and moderately priced. It was unexpected, but I was pleasantly surprised. 

Anyway, I ate my soup trying to not look like I was panicking (I was) and simultaneously trying to look like I could breathe. (I couldn't.) And about half way through dinner I realized my neck gland was swollen to the size of a ping pong ball- at which point I realized my meds were wearing off, I was loopy, and I wanted to go home and go to bed ASAP. 

I'm going back once I have an appetite and can taste things.
author: Emily D.

description:
One word: Bland

I got the vegetarian burrito dinner with tofu. Burrito was covered in the red sauce - it was practically flavorless, as were the black beans (and I ordered pinto beans). The tofu was pretty good. 

My friend got the 1/4 chicken dinner. He said it was pretty bland. His beans were bland too. The potatoes covered in cheese (he ordered without cheese) - not overly flavorful. 

Total cost for these two items w/tax: $30

Note: perhaps our flavor buds were a bit off b/c we just had sex an hour ago but I am pretty sure that wasn't the case. This was my second time there and I was hesitant to go b/c I wasn't impressed the first time. There won't be a third time for sure - I've had my fill of not so great but expensive New Mexican food.
author: MissyE X.

description:
Get to the back of the line that stretches beyond the front door, but don't make the mistake of thinking you're waiting to be seated (more on that later).  

Once you finally make it to the front of the line, your hopes momentarily soar as you order food you're asked to pay for up front (just like in your favourite coffee shop!).

Great, so you've ordered and you've been given a number to carry around.  Problem is...you don't have a table.  If you aren't with one of the savvy groups of people (read: snakes) who sent in recon to stake out and lay claim to the first available table, you'll be one of the many with a stressed/hopeless look holding a number of their own.

Surprised to see so many occupied tables with no numbers for food on them or patrons dining?  Don't be, because the rest of their party is still waiting in line to order their food.  

But alas, all is well (or so says the friendly management at the mercy of this Kafka-esque system), since the kitchen will gladly hold off on making your food until you've notified them you finally fought for a table of your own.  

I don't like hovering over people eating, so I didn't make it to the Green Chile Gauntlet finish line...I walked out in search of a more civilised resto.  I imagine the one bonus to the GCK system is that you're probably not expected to tip since there's no service to be had.

In the end, if you're into a Lord of the Flies inspired dining experience, the Green Chile Kitchen is your spot.
author: Paul K.

description:
First of all, parking is a bitch. 

Let me save the people who have never been here from looking like loonies. You order then take a seat. So as soon as you walk in, grab a menu and take a seat on the bench while you decide what you crave. Order, receive number, grab water and utensils, and then take a seat.

Although it may seem crowded, you probably CAN find a seat before you orders out. Courteous customers so far. 

I had the blue corn flat enchiladas which came with "a New Mexican classic made with housemade organic blue corn tortillas, cheese & ground beef smothered with your choice of red or green chile, topped with sour cream & served with refried beans and rice."
