My food came on a square plate: refried beans (1/3), the rice (1/6),  lettuce and tomatoes (1/6) and blue corn flat enchiladas (1/3). I guess because the food tasted really good, I can let portion size slide by this time. (My friend who is a regular says you can substitute. ex: instead of beans, more chili)

They serve green chile cheese fries after 5pm. I think I am going to try this next time! Yum!
author: Jess W.

description:
This place has good food. Nothing fantastic, but it's fine. Also the price is reasonable. 
HOWEVER. they will mess up your order. I have gone on several occasions and my order is wrong every time. I ask for sour cream, there is no sour cream. I ask for refried beans, I get black beans. The last time I was there, they added hot chilies inside my burrito, I couldn't even finish the first bite!! Really not worth it. From now on, I'll just go elsewhere for Mexican.
author: Richelle M.

description:
Green Chile's food is pretty basic. 

Healthy Mexican fare.

They carry brown rice and their meat fillings are fresh and local and not drowned out by heavy greasy sauces or cheese.

My veggie burrito here was decent and light. The spicy green ranchero sauce drizzled upon it - tied it all together well.

But the real standout was the mixed berry pie. Big juicy dark berries squeezed into a soft doughy buttery crust. I had the vegan horchata ice-cream with it as well. The ice-cream was fairly bland tasting, but the pie was packed with home-made excellence.

If you want some light healthy mexican dishes - Green Chile has a nice assortment of choices. But it you want to be wowed - just go for the pie.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
I can't believe this place only has 3.5 stars, I love this place! When I lived nearby I called it my cafeteria! 

Chicken enchiladas are the best! The soups, especially the posole, rock my world! Saldas are good. Burritos decent, but there are better out there for sure. Except for the breakfast burrito--that is a solid breakfast. 

I also love that they serve good quality meat here--Mary's chicken and Niman ranch Beef. Also, Blue Bottle Coffee.
author: Amanda D.

description:
I came back to write a new review since my last one.  See my previous post below.  This place has always had great food, however, they use to have the worst service possible.  I live one block away and eat her often.

They used to get my order wrong 50% of the time and I had finally had it.  It's also pretty expensive for Mexican food, but as I said above, it's really good and always filling.

This new review is targeted at the new manager they hired, Mark.  He answers the phone all the time, is usually in there whenever I come. Breakfast, lunch, or dinner....he's always there.

I gave it another chance since I live so close and have not had a screwed up order sine he's worked there.  It's about time the owner paid attention to all the yelp reviews and hired someone who knows how to run a business...customer comes first and is always right.  When you make the wrong order, just fix it with a smile and apologize profusely.

Nice work, Mark, I'm finally a happy customer at Green Chile

Old Post below:

This place is extremely over priced and the customer service could not be worse.  I live a block away and used to eat here when I was too lazy to go anywhere else (not a great neighborhood for take-out).  

Never again will I come here.  They screw my order up 75% of the time after I go out of my way to state everything twice and confirm they heard me.  They honestly just don't care to get it right.  Always someone else working there, half the time you call in they don't answer the phone, and when you tell them they messed up again - they look at you upset because they actually have to get off their lazy ass and do something while I stare at them in disbelief.  How could someone, or so many, be so bad at their job??

NEVER AGAIN
author: Matt P.

description:
After weeks of the raving yelp reviews haunting me about the breakfast burrito here,  all I can say is I am thankful to have this out of my mind. Here's the truth: it wasn't the best breakfast burrito of my life. Here's why: sauce was on top, forcing me to eat it with a fork and knife, and the tortilla to ingredient ratio was a bit off. In fact, I do not remember a single bean in this burrito. These are personal preferences. I'm also willing to attribute my lack of enthusiasm for this burrito to the soyrizo I had added, and maybe I'll give it another chance. Maybe.

The huevos motulenos I had during my first dining experience here are worth talking about. I am a sucker for plantains, and it had a good balance of sweet, salty, and unexpected without feeling too heavy. It was perfect with the watermelon agua fresca. I also tried several of my husband's nachos. He ordered the regular nachos with pinto + black beans.  These alone are reason enough to come back.
author: Alicia L.

description: We're from southern New Mexico (Las Cruces, which is about 15 miles from Hatch) and we know what good green chile is and should be. The Green Chile Kitchen does a decent job of creating the southern New Mexico flavors and traditional dishes. I will tell you the menu is very limited. They are definitely on the $$$ side, lunch for 2 adults and 1 kid was over $40 with just entrées and non-alc drinks. Green chile they use does lack any real heat, even the 'hot' was eaten by my 5 year old. But, overall a good meal. I didn't give 5 stars because they are over priced, lacked a sufficient kids menu, limited menu options, and lack of heat.
author: JB A.

description: New Mexican classics were executed very well.  These are the best chile flavors you will find in the city!
author: solomon B.

description: The cashier was rude, the cooks forgot my burrito after they brought food for the whole table.  It was a mess. Food was okaee tho. Just service was bad.
author: Omar J.

description:
I had breakfast (well, which they call "Brunch" on the weekends) at green chile kitchen yesterday morning. This was my first time ever eating there (breakfastarily or otherwise) and I am pretty sure it will not be my last.

I had the "new mexican homestyle frittata". It was really very good and worth going back for itself, but I really do want to get back again to check out some of their other interesting-sounding dishes (exemplī grātiā, "quelites & eggs", "root vegetable hash", or "huevos motuleños", to name just a few more... three to be exact).

If you would like to read a more meandering review of this place, just click on my profile name here and check out my stupid 'blog-thing that is linked there. (yelp* does not allow any actual hyperlinks in the reviews here.)
author: Brian M.

description: I find this place to be underrated! It's a little expensive, but I think the food is excellent. One of my favorite burritos in the city, the steak salad is delicious and for a healthier option, the lettuce tacos were really satisfying.
author: Sarah P.

description: I think the 3.5 star rating is on the mark for this place. It's a good but not excellent hipster Mexican restaurant in nopa with cheap beer ($2 for a bottle of Pacifico). Although the tacos I ordered looked delicious, it felt like something was missing when I ate it. Seasoning, probably. I however did like their mimosas as they were extremely drinkable.
author: Becky L.

description: Overpriced, loud and a long wait. The food is mediocre. There's nothing comparable around so they can gauge you.
author: Sfgrl P.

description:
This is the kind of food I can eat all the time. Although my body might protest. Mmm mmm New Mexican cuisine.

So I'm a huge fan of Chile Pies (their pie place just a few doors down) and finally decided to stop in Green Chile Kitchen for a Saturday lunch. Nice place, clean, feels New Mexican with a more muted color scheme. The first thing that stood out were the prices. Poor college student visiting SF for the weekend = not a lot of options.

I ended up buying a single tamale that cost $4. However, it was an outstanding tamale. Made with blue corn and topped with some of their Chile Honey, I was pretty satisfied. My friend ordered a $6 burrito that I nibbled on and it was also delicious. If I had not had a piece of pie after, I probably would have been hungry still. Most of the plates I would have preferred to order were between $11 - $14, which would have been fine if I was ordering dinner. 

Of course, this place serves yummy sangria and Blue Bottle coffee. Win. Staff is helpful and friendly. Never seems too crowded whenever I've walked by and we found a place to sit pretty easily. If you're willing to spend a few more bucks, then this place is great!
author: Sasha T.

description:
I was recommended to this place by my roommate so was really excited to finally try it. I ordered take-out and got the chicken soft tacos, guacamole appetizer, and my friend got the 1/4 chicken with salad.

First off, the guacamole wasn't even in the bag (which was $8) but was paid for on the receipt. Frustrating... I'm not going to get in my car and park to go back to get something they left out.

The tacos would have gotten a 5/5 if I would have gotten the correct number. The plate should come with 3 tacos and I only got two. I was starving so this was disappointing especially after they forgot the guac appetizer as well. I was supposed to get 3 tacos and I only got two. The chicken was tender and the guac was good. The tortillas were interesting but falling apart so they were hard to eat. I was still hungry after eating these two very small tacos and every morsel of the 1/2 cup of rice on my plate.

The 1/4 chicken and salad actually looked like a lot of better of an option since it came with the salad, tortillas, rice and beans. Much more of a meal than mine.

I may go back here if friends were to dine-in but definitely not worth the price and take-out was obviously poor.
author: Jane B.

description: I've tried so hard to like this place over the years. But time and time again it just disappoints (yes, I keep coming back because it's two blocks away and it has space to deal with kids and associated gear). The last time my chicken pozole soup was served with zero chicken, the time before my order was served cold, the time before that the cashiers were about as apathetic a team I've ever experienced... It's pretty much par for the course. They know they have a captive audience of families with young kids that pack the place every night... and frankly just don't care that much about the food they serve or how it's served. Welcome to NOPAs overpriced New Mexican cafeteria...
author: d. g.

description: Phenomenal food, great service, quality ingredients. One of our favs where we take visitors and family, it's a regular spot for us. Get the sweet potato tamal and the burritos, and the grains and greens salad, yum!!
author: megan c.

description: Food is good and the service sucks.  All I've seen is the bartenders back at 5:45 in the afternoon.  The servers avoid eye contact at all times.  I've spent 28 dollars.  I'm sitting at the bar and no has asked me if I'm having a good experience.  When the bubble pops this place will close.
author: Mark M.

description:
Wow!! So good!! We got 2 combo plates to share between 3 of us and it was PLENTY! And so delicious! I'll definitely be back. Also the enchiladas we probably the best I've ever had. It was more of a pie rather than wrapped up.

Only down side is that it seems people like to sit and talk after their meal for at least 30 minutes.... that's cool... unless it's busy... i want your booth.
author: Madison M.

description: Pretty amazing food. Go with nachos for starter and the home style chicken enchilada for entree.
author: Stephen B.

description:
NEW MEXICAN?! 
(3.75 stars)

It doesn't look like a rundown restaurant like those in the Mission - and it's NOT in the mission, which actually drew my attention (so does that make it "new mexican"?). I'm not a Mexican food kind of person but had booked marked this for several months on yelp. For some reason after my daily gym routine, my palate was crazy-craving Chicken Tamales. Stopped in for "bunch-time".

- Food, good
- Prices, step up from average
- Service, okay
- Ambiance, chill (parking can be challenging)

My expectations were at an ultimately low before coming here. But after my experience, I actually liked it. Do not think it's overly packed and you have to wait. The seating varies from single seats, to table for two - four, to huge tables where large parties or many individuals can sit at (and mind their own). Order your food, get a number, and take a seat. I waited about 10 minutes to recieve my food. Get your own H2O (their cups are jar glasses, love it). 

HEFFER-STYLE STATUS.

**see photo**

TAMALE PLATE ($12) - Off the Breakfast Menu (not Dinner menu) 
two homemade tamales, i chose chicken. side of red or green chile, i chose green. side of posole, i think thats what it was. and a side salad.  ENJOYED IT. I liked the Tamale but it did not beat my favorite place to get a chicken tamale. The texture of the masa in the tamale was too soft (reminded me of mash potato) and wish their shredded chicken was shredded down a little more and distributed within the masa. it was like one big piece of shredded chicken and covered with masa.I had to eat bites of masa to get to the chicken and prefer masa and chicken to be meshed together (but thats just me). The two sides came in a very tiny serving (few bites) but felt it was just enough to not make it a heavy "breakfast". The green chile was a bit spicy, i hardly dabbled into it. The posole was delicious, i think i would have been fine with a cup of that and one chicken tamale. The side salad was good, the greens were cut to smaller pieces which made it easier to eat and it was topped with almost like pico de galla (minus the onions). 

Berry Good Honest Tea - this was actually made for "kids" but I saw no kids in the restaurant. Ordered it because of how healthy it was compared to the other drinks. 60 calories in one pouch. 

Will I be back? I definately can see myself coming back for something "New Mexican" to try.

Until the next reivew....
author: Jane A.

description: We came here a year ago and thought it lacked a lot but we had a craving for green chile stew and  gave it a second chance. Boy are we sorry we did the place has gotten worse since last year... I lived in New Mexico and these people have destroyed the unique cuisine of that beautiful state. I had the Stuffed Sopaipillas which usually is a large,fluffy and fully cooked dough with a flavorful boiled pork, cheese with an amazing christmas style sauce. What I got burnt bought,  chunks of gristle Christmas Style sauce  lacked all flavor.  In New Mexico they serve beans with Papas(potatoes) never rice but besides that  the rice that GCK  was under cooked and hard, so that is just lack of caring about what you are serving your guests.  Green Chile stew has 6 ingredents pork, potatoes, green chile, flour, water, salt garlic but all their stew had was green chile and tomatoes??If you don't know your New Mexican you will think this place is average. I find this whole restaurant offensive to New Mexicans and I hope people who eat here get to New Mexico to try their wonderful cuisine. I think their whole staff need to go get some training from the cooks at Sadie's New Mexico, The Shed or Tomasita's they need a refresher course. Last I'd doesn't after if you import fresh green chile if you have know idea what to do with it.
author: Susan S.

description:
This place outright rocks. No it is not mission hood food. It is thoughtful, carefully prepared food with wonderful taste and care towards quality.

We had the niman ranch pork burrito, the niman ranch steak burrito, two Mary's free range chicken Tamales and of course guac and chips.

Each and every dish was really awesome...burritos were wonderful, tamales really flavorful, and the guac to die for. Chips are nice and home made....and their red salsa is exquisite.

Their menu is really good...now I have to come back many times.

I am sorry gordos...I love you but I have found my new place.

Check it out!
author: David G.

description: We had the bfast burrito, chicken nachos n one more bfast item. Everything was superb. Love this place. Would recommend.
author: C A.

description: I moved to SF after living in NM for almost 20 years. The apple pie was good, but the food is seriously overpriced for the taste. If you want New Mexican food, take a road trip to New Mexico. SF (and especially the East Bay) has amazing Mexican and Central American food. Go patronize legit places, not this hipster imitation.
author: Da Wei S.

description:
My fiancé and I love New Mexico, we've been there several times antiquing, exploring the amazing rock formations, hiking, and of course eating our way through.  Needless to say we love green chile and we miss Santa Fe.  Every bite brought us back to Santa Fe, and we talked about how we wanted to go back during dinner.  

We ordered the chile rellenos combination, a cup of the green chile stew, 2 beers, and a basket of sopapillas.  The green chile stew is possibly the best we've ever had, and the chile rellenos were great, we were a little disappointed with the sopapillas, we are used to going to Maria's in Santa Fe where they are fresh, softer, and bigger.   But overall we will be back to submit to our green chile cravings.
author: Clover S.

description:
Decent place, with a refreshing twist of being "New" mexican cuisine (as in the state).  This translates into green chile, which was quite tasty.

The place is a typical burrito joint service model - order, and then sit. I was there on a Saturday at lunch time, so not too crowded and I didn't have any issues getting a table.

My burrito had the requisite green chili topping, and was pretty good.  Not overly flavorful, but not bland.  Kind of in the middle.  I'd go back and try some of their other dishes.

Frankly, it's the location - - near my house - - that is one of the bigger draws of the place.
author: Tobin S.

description: I am burrito maniac and this place is my JAM. Delicious delicious burritos, good prices, quality ingredients, great sauces, super friendly service. I make sure to hit this spot every single time I'm in San Fran. Do yourself several favors and eat this food.
author: Ali C.

description:
I'm upgrading to three stars, and I'm going back to this place to give it another shot. I'll give it a fair shot too, and if they earn five stars that's what they'll get.

I just got one of the best letters I've ever read from the General Manager of this restaurant. He acted with such integrity and class - I was really floored. He took full responsibility, acknowledged the disappointment, and offered a personal resolution - a gift to my brother-in-law for his birthday. Whoa. I instead intend to give Green Chile another chance, because we all have bad days. I'm looking forward to posting a new review.

It's always nice to run across a business that is run with integrity. Although I still acknowledge that I had a bad experience on my initial visit, the management has already shown that they take customer satisfaction seriously and have made a genuine attempt to make me feel heard and taken care of. That's worth another shot in my book for sure!
author: Nick B.

description:
I'm not sure what this restaurant  is trying to be. I'ts certainly priced like a sit down establishment but then the food and god forsaken ordering process is much more like  a regular Taqueria. Only most Taquerias give you a fighting chance of finding a place to sit after ordering. At Green Chile Kitchen, you jockey for position around occupied tables with a beer in one hand and your order number in the other waiting for a table to vacate. It kind of feels like a ski lodge cafeteria at high noon.  If you are lucky enough to get seated before your food arrives, you are golden. If not, I guess you have to make some fast friends. 

After about 5 minutes of standing around, we secured a booth. The food arrived shortly after. Speaking of, I ordered a chicken burrito with green chili salsa smothered on top.  It was accompanied by a side of rice and a salad - all for about $14. It was pretty good but then, I know of no combination of meat, beans, salsa and cheese that isn't. 

My suggestion to Green Chile - become a sit down restaurant. You don't have to take reservations - jut get a list and send people to the bar to wait their turn.  Keep up the takeout service register because lots of people just want a burrito to go. Follow this advice and you'll make your customers much happier (well as least me).
author: Steve M.

description:
Great food, Poor value... been an infrequent customer since they opened shop on Fulton many years ago.  The flavors and quality are there, but inconsistent execution, steep prices and stingy portions keep me away.

I gave up on their burritos long, long ago, but I am a sucker for a good enchilada.  So gave it another go tonight and for $17 (including tax/tip) I got exactly ONE enchilada, lukewarm with beans rice and a pile of lettuce.  It was pretty good but I'm still really hungry.  Perhaps some chips and salsa would have rounded out the meal but I'm not forking over more cash for a simple courtesy that almost any Mexican restaurant provides gratis.

In years past I've splurged on the combo plate, but several times the enchilada wasn't even melted.  A couple years back I tried the breakfast tacos and had to send the plate back (first time in my life) because the eggs were still totally liquid, dripping all over the place.

The pluses?  They do a very distinct sangria that is tasty and potent.  They definitely bring some vibrancy to the sleepy reaches of NoPa, never a bad thing even if it's overrated.  The pie shop is equally underwhelming but their beer floats demonstrate inspired genius.
author: Ryan O.

description:
I like it! I've had a Living Social deal waiting to be used and I also saw the restaurant on Check Please, so its been on my to-go list for quite awhile. I had a good experience here. 

This was my first time trying food from New Mexico, and it was good! My boyfriend had the Carne Adovada and I wish I had ordered that- the flavors were SO good. I was less impressed with my green chile enchiladas, but the tamale was pretty good. We decided to stick around and order dessert, and we tried the Sopapillas. They were pretty good.

I really want to come back and try a few more items on the menu. :)
author: Stacy S.

description: Great food. Crunchy tacos amazing. Salad on the side was yum. Guac was so good. Have come multiple times and if you want some yummy pie and ice cream, save your receipt and take that dollar off coupon (on the receipt) and head down the block to their sister cafe.
author: Vicki T.

description:
I wished I'd discovered this place sooner, I would have been here frequently if I had! If you need a green chili fix this is your place. The chips and salsas with four varieties of salsa is tasty. The burrito is huge and very tasty. The enchiladas were SPICY but also very good. If you can't take the heat get out of the green chili kitchen I guess. 

Very casual place, order and pay first then sit down your food is delivered to your table. Get your own water and utensils. There can be a wait for dinner but they are fast at getting orders out. This is definitely a place that you go to for the food not necessarily the ambiance.
author: Marissa P.

description:
After starving for half the morning, I needed something to eat. "Let's go to Green Chile" and BAM I was there. Not only was the set up awesome (open and breezy), but the food was very good. I love simple, fresh ingredients partnered with spice and color. I ordered the Southwestern Steak salad and it was a good choice. 

I would suggest hitting this place up and see what shakes. I don't think you'll be disappointed.
author: Abra B.

description:
I really wanted to like it. But you see, I just got back from Las Cruces and I am a picky bastard that can't be pleased unless you offer me exactly what I want:
A chile relleno burrito, with Hatch chiles. It should just be a relleno, with refried beans, in a flour tortilla.
The chile was fine! It did the trick. Why did I only get one seed? Nooooooo.
Rice! Whole pintos, not refried! The foul offering of sour cream, guac! Green chile salsa on top that was kinda bell peppery! Those things are FIIIINE on a California burrito, don't yell at me, it's just that's not what I wanted, I wanted a real New Mexico relleno burrito and I didn't get it so I'm leaving an A-OK review. 
The rest of you that don't care if it's strictly NM cuisine - you'll be fine, it's good.
author: Elyse P.

description: Best stew I've ever had, best flour tortillas I've ever had, best tacos I've ever had. I'm partial to the pork version of the stew and the ground beef version of the tacos, but every version of everything I've eaten here has been SO good I come back multiple times a week. 5 delicious stars, yes
author: Kim H.

description: The kitchen was out of the food that we ordered and they made us completely different meals without informing us or asking us if we wanted something else. They then refused to refund us on our orders. We won't be returning.
author: Dave L.

description:
If anything i would give the place 2.5 stars based on food. The food was at par and didn't have anything that wow'ed me in any way. The ingredients tasted fresh and wasn't the type where I knew I would sitting on the toilet all night.

I got the spicy burrito which was not spicy. The place is expensive for a burrito that is just decent.
author: Dorris W.

description:
I want to say upfront that the missing star is only due to the prices, which I just find ridiculous. I ordered a veggie burrito and a kale salad to go and it was $20.

Now that the whining about over priced food is over, I will absolutely come back next time I'm in my old neighborhood again just for the kale salad with quinoa, jicama and this amazing spicy dressing. The veggie burrito was pretty yummy, but nothing special. They moved to a larger location since when I lived up the street, and though it's not as cozy and intimate as the last place, its Mexican rustic decor works well. Definitely not a spot I'll go out of my way for, but a good place for a yummy salad when convenient.
author: Katie B.

description:
Food was excellent. Good portion sizes. Got the green Chile burrito and was happy with my choice. Solid Mexican food and good service.

Sangria was not good and the wait to actually order was quite long.
author: Josh S.

description:
I love this place and eat here almost once a week. It is great for kids, really casual and very friendly. The manager remembers us and always checks to make sure everything is okay and fixes anything that isn't. Parking is pretty easy (for SF) and while it is sometimes crowded, we've never had to wait too long for a table. Take out is great as well. 

What to order:
kale salad
salsa and/or guac apps
taco salad
horchata

My kids love the burritos.
author: Nicole M.

description:
Yummy!!  While I waited for Workshop to set up their Christmas holiday sale, I decided to jaunt over to Green Chile Kitchen to check it out for a quick lunch.  I wanted something light so I ordered one chicken tamale and sides of chips and guacamole.  For my drink, I just helped myself to a mason jar and filled it up at the water decanters they provide.  

I saddled up to the window sill table looking out, and my food came shortly after.  The tamale was lovely steaming hot, spicy and YUM!!  It made me sweat a bit, so I drank a lot of water - loved it!!  They gave me a mix of chips, regular corn and purple corn - nice!  The guacamole little dish could've been a tad bigger (3x as big would've been nice) as I like to pile on the guacamole on each chip.  The guacamole was fresh and yummy - I wanted more!

But definitely if I'm in the area, especially if I'm taking a class at Workshop, I am stopping by!!
author: Maile N.

description:
Solid Mexican food - nothing out of this world but consistently good and not overly greasy or sauce smothered (unless requested...). You order at the counter and then the food is brought to your table which is not immediately apparent upon arriving at the restaurant.  

The margaritas looked good, the tacos I had were yummy and the atmosphere is clean and lively. It gets pretty busy around dinnertime and can be challenging to locate a table immediately. 

There are definitely better Mexican places in SF and even close by but its a good option for a more varied menu.
author: Julia W.

description:
We went on a Saturday night and it was CROWDED... be prepared to fight for a seat.  Funny story, I had one friend parking the car, and two friends ordering for the 4 of us, I was in charge of securing a table.  There was an empty 2 top right next to another 2 top that was about finished eating. So I secured the empty 2 top ready to pounce, they left and I quickly pushed the two tables together.  (So I was 1 person sitting at a 4top now.)  A woman came over and told me that she was in line right before me and my friends and that she was entitled to the table.....hmmm, is this right,? I think whoever gets the table, get the table - right?  (Luckily as soon as she finished her sentence and before I could really respond, one of my friends arrived with 2 bottles of wine, and she huffed away).  

The food was good, but all sort of seemed the same from dish to dish.
author: Amy W.

description:
Having recently visited NM, I was quite happy to be introduced to this place by my coworker. 

If you're craving some New Mexican food or are curious about type of cuisine, this is definitely the place to go. 

Be sure to get the chicken blue corn enchiladas!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
The adovado I ordered did not taste as New Mexican as I had hoped so I was disappointed. It was still ok, but a little dry and a little bland. 

I ordered to go and it was a decent wait - not too slow. The decor was nice and there was a good amount of open seating.
author: Christy Y.

description: Great neighborhood place. Fresh ingredients, reasonable prices and generous portions.  Their daily specials are always something yummy to try.
author: Gwen S.

description: Ever since moving from Denver I have been looking for good pork green chile. Although not as great as what I am used to they come very close.  And the New Mexican Homestyle Enchilada is delicious.  It reminds me of a very similar dish my mother would make.
author: Scotty M.

description:
I really wish this place was better because it's right out my front door and some good Mexican that's that convenient would be a dream come true. Even decent and cheap would be lovely. Not so much.

I cannot understand for the life of me why this place is so popular. Great for kids and families, sure, but for people who actually like to TASTE their food? Come on. 

The three times I've been here (yeah, REALLY wanted it to improve) I've had one massively bland and overpriced experience after another. My girlfriend commented that her tacos tasted like Old El Paso out of the box and that despite the nostalgic kitsch value there was nothing else to enjoy. 

The vegetarian burrito, when cheese, guac and crema are added nears $10, is just so boring. No distinct flavors whatsoever. Just, bleh. If it even somewhat held a candle to Farolito, Pancho Villa or any one of the hundred other taquerias in town I might justify paying that price to walk there in my jammies but as it stands, nope. Sorry.

Unless you're a tired parent who wants a night off from cooking and a glass of wine skip this place and wave down a taco truck. I guarantee it's better. And cheaper.
author: Jesse H.

description:
Been here now a few times for lunch and dinner.  

I had a salad which was just above average.  I had a burrito which was excellent.  I had the Horchata and that was great (one free refill).  

The Ambiance is super nice and service is great.  It gets very packed with locals at dinner and it's a seat yourself situation, so it can be a bit messy trying to sit during peak hours.  They could fix this with some management of the seating arrangements... But that's that.
author: Mark K.

description:
I love this place.  I've been coming here for 4 or 5 years and I have never gotten sick of it.  I started eating there when I still ate meat, and the chicken was to die for.  Now that I'm a vegetarian, I actually love it even more.  My go-tos are: the calabacitas burrito, nachos, vegetarian green chili and I think it's called the garden veggie salad (first thing on the menu).  Honestly this place is so good--I tell everyone to try it.  

My only complaint is the prices.  When I first started going it was less expensive, but since they've moved into a bigger location and added more staff, the prices have become absurd.  It's $40 + tip for my bf and I to eat lunch (we get free water).  $20 per person for a casual dining experience must be costing them customers.  The food is great, but every time we go there we are shocked by the bill so we don't go as much as we would if it were more like $12-$15 for lunch.  Hopefully they can figure their pricing structure out.
author: Shala M.

description:
I hate to give this place such a bad review, but it has REALLY fallen off.  The last three times I've gone the quality of food has decreased while the price has increased.

When GCK moved to this location about three years ago, it was one of my favorite spots in the neighborhood - delicious high quality food for reasonable prices.  Since that time the prices have nearly doubled (e.g., $35 for two loaded breakfast burritos;  $60 for four taco entrees; add-on prices for basic ingredients).  The quality of the ingredients and food preparation has also dramatically decreased (e.g., the meat is grisly, the rice is burnt, the beans are cold, and the tortillas are stale, the taco shells are now fried, the nachos no longer have hot queso, and the food is all around bland and flavorless.).  It's a shame.  GCK has been 3-for-3 FAIL this year, so it's Little Chihuahua from here on out.
author: COQUEDdotCOM C.

description:
Had the enchilada combo. The tamale Washington great, and the taco shell was delicious, but the steak enchilada was a little too overwhelmed with sauce.

Would go back again, but need to try other places first.
author: Cam V.

description: Always have great service here. However, wasn't a huge fan of my tamale tonight. Got the sweet potato ones, there was only sweet potato in it and a very small amount. It was a bit dry and not very good. The margarita was good and I love the space.
author: Gina H.

description: The food in this place is decent, but the style of ordering and self-seating is miserable. They serve "upscale" Mexican in relatively decent portions for the price, and the green chile is always delectable, but the way you order food and have to steal a table makes me never want to come back. Plus, the quality of food is similar to taquerias in the Mission, which won't gouge you in price and will generally have seating for you. Burritos, quesadillas, sopapillas, stews all made with plenty of seasoning, and the blue corn tortillas are a nice touch. Having to stake out tables and steal them from under people is such a horrible way to run a restaurant. And, don't pay the extra .75 cents for guacamole. You'll get about a tbsp of it. And, don't bring too many friends either. You'll be waiting forever to try to wrangle together some tables and seats.
author: Danny C.

description: LOVED the vegetarian burrito and chips/salsa. It was a ton of food, I went for the burrito/chip combo rather than the burrito with the side of rice and beans and it was still TONS of food. I really appreciate yummy vegetarian options, and I'll definitely be going back.
author: Stormie L.

description:
If food had been this good when growing up in New Mexico, I might have reconsidered relocating. There wasn't anything that we had that wasn't shy of delicious. We started with a Yerba Matte White Sangria, which is if not the best sangria I have ever had. It was defintly the best white sangria to date. Then we moved on to the dos quesos 7 layer dip, which is nothing like the dip you encounter at pot lucks. This was arrived in a hot iron gridlle with fresh tortilla chips on the side.Then on to one of the newest additions to the menu which was the stuffed pepper with quinoa. If you are looking for a healthier option, this is a great one.
My only regret is that I was so stuffed from all the above, it left no room for sopiapllas. OH well, I guess I must return.
author: Angela P.

description:
Since writing my original review during a visit to San Francisco in 2010 I have recently relocated a few blocks away from Green Chile Kitchen. The proximity has been great for allowing me many opportunities to try different things on their menu. I came for Brunch once, which I never would have thought to do in the past (Mexican food for brunch!?) and had a kick-ass breakfast burrito which I would highly recommend. However, don't think you can order that breakfast burrito to go and take it into Matching Half cafe across the street or prepare to be snipped at-- but I digress.

I'm mostly writing this review on behalf of their Green Chile stew with chicken added in. It's bomb. Sometimes (just sometimes) I'm trying to stay healthy and not chow down a million burritos a week and thus going to Mexican restaurants gives me anxiety. Thank goodness for this stew, it's light, filling, flavorful, vegetable-y, and good on my conscience. Highly recommending this under-appreciated player on the GCK menu.
author: Sabrina M.

description:
This place has quality food. Consistently. Great breakfast burritos and dinner menu.

Service at the new location has been pretty bad. Seems like there are different people in there every time. Even when I call ahead and I arrive with my order ready on the counter I sometimes have to wait 10 minutes in line to get my food.

Still the best food in the neighborhood.
author: Ross H.

description: Their sopaipillia are just okay, only offered at night.  Nothing is better than the real thing in Albuquerque.  The plates are huge and tasty.  Great selection.  I can see why this place is so popular, booze and more booze.  Loud to have a conversation.  Great big tables and made me think of swinging a turkey leg around.  The nacho dish is a meal in itself.  Burritos are huge.  Bring your wallet!
author: Helen L.

description:
I read about how they mess up all the orders and figured I was safe since there's only 8 people here on a Sunday morning. Well, they totally got my order wrong. I told the lady behind the bar, she went to the kitchen and never came back to me. I guess they figure that since I already paid it doesn't matter. 

The food is nothing special and is on the expensive side for what you get ( you get what they bring you). I won't be back.
author: Lou Z.

description: Ok not the best but will do for hungry stomach. Order first then seat your self once you get a number.
author: B M.

description:
I outgrew Papalote as my favorite burrito place near my house and now make the longer trek to Green Chile Kitchen because it's worth it. My go-to solid meal is the super grilled steak burrito. That little bit of grilling plus your choice of chile just makes a difference to make this burrito a little more special than your average burrito. Also, I recommend the breakfast burrito which is basically your burrito fixings with eggs. Good thing I love eggs!

I like that this place is off the main streets and is mostly surrounded by residencial housing. It makes it more local neighborhood-y. But, this place fills up during high demand hours (dinner time, weekend brunch) with a line going up to the door and children everywhere (Apparently, this is a family family friendly place). If you can, try to go in the off hours so you can get the same food experience without the crowds foggin' up the joint.

Oh yea, and their horchata is respectable and not a watered down mess like many others. Yay horchata!

5 stars!!!!!!!!
author: Brian M.

description:
Good-enough roast chicken; chile lemonade an interesting twist.

Airy venue. Pleasant staff.
author: Inigo M.

description: Meh. I don't see what all the hype's about.
author: Dimple B.

description: the food was delicious and was prepared under 5 minutes. They have a great selection of Mexican delicacy (veg and non veg) and the staff was great too! I will recommend the place to my friends :)
author: Parikshit T.

description: Picked up my order and it was delicious but I, like some other reviews I've read here, only got two of the three soft tacos I ordered. Seems to be a recurring problem between counter service and kitchen.
author: Erin W.

description:
No one I know loves green chili like Sir Nicholas so when he found a place called Green Chile Kitchen on Yelp I knew it was just a matter of time until we tried it. And that time turned out to be about 4 days. This is a pretty casual place - you place your order at the counter, take a number, and have your food delivered to you. But, for being such a casual place they sure do have a nice organic wine list.

I went with a taco plate for dinner - 3 tacos (your choose of beef, chicken, pork, or veggie), rice, and mixed vegetable. Because I heart variety I chose one of each type of taco except veggie. It was weird - all the tacos were good, but none of them had any sort of Mexican flavor that I know and love. And I don't love just one kind of Mexican flavor. I enjoy the stuff I eat in Denver, Arizona, southern California, heck I even wholeheartedly enjoy Tex-Mex. Actually, now that I think about it this was like Mex-Tex perhaps. Because they used corn tortillas and a nice salsa, but the meat itself was plainly flavored and there were fancy vegetables instead of refried beans. Anyway, the beef was my favorite as far as flavor went, but really it just tasted like a nice cut of beef on a corn tortilla. 

This place gets way crowded so I highly recommend going during off times and not with a big group. I probably wouldn't come back here on my own, but Nick enjoyed his green chili and being that he loves that stuff I'm sure we'll find our way back here again sometime soon.
author: Tiffany N.

description: I have 9 people ahead of me now with only one cashier open. I requested the guy behind the counter and he said that they can't open a second cashier. Terrible line management. I have been here for 10 min and probably another 10 min to go. Food is good but is overpriced for this level of service.
author: bora o.

description: Green Chile Kitchen is hands down, my favorite go to place in SF.  I make sure to make my GCK stop at least 3-4 times a week.  Not only is it delicious, but it's so healthy and it's not the kind of place where you have to pick the same healthy item out every time you go.  You can pick from the vast selections so it never gets old.  I have been going there since opening day and I still look forward to it every time!  It is also made with love and the heat of Santa Fe which is some of my favorite cuisine. THANK YOU GCK!
author: Margaret B.

description:
This review is only for Green Chile's breakfast - which was great! Definitely a tasty Mexi spot right by Divis. I recently visited a friend in SF and she said this is her go-to breakfast burrito spot. Works for me! I had the spicy chorizo breakfast burrito and added guac. My ONLY complaint is that they put the guac on top. I guess I just assumed it would come on the inside when I said "add guac, no potatoes." Well, I guess I that's what I get for being an annoying substituting customer. Anyway, the burrito was awesome! Quite hearty and very filling. I don't know that I would call the chorizo "spicy," but it was still good.

It might not be the most authentic Mexican food, but I don't think that's what Green Chile is going for anyway. I really liked that the food seemed relatively healthy... Well, as healthy as you can get with a massive Mexican burrito, haha. Basically, I didn't feel greasy or totally food-bombed afterward. The coffee was really good too. That was my first cup o' Blue Bottle Coffee, good stuff!    

We also walked by the restaurant on Saturday night. The place was PACKED. I also love the open, airy layout of the space. Much fancier than most of the Mexican joints I usually frequent :) Maybe next time I will have a chance to come in for dinner!
author: Stephanie K.

description: Pay for chips, pay for salsa, pay for rice and beans, pay for extra corn tortillas. But hey, that's what you get for trying to get Mexican food outside of the Mission. I suggest going to the Mission.
author: John R.

description:
I'm giving this place four stars because of their rotisserie chicken. It is sooooo good! The skin is flavorful, and the meat is juicy. Love it.
The burritos and enchiladas are good; they're nothing super special, but they're really good. The rotisserie chicken won me over.
author: Cami J.

description: I am a native New Mexican and all I have to say is they're doing it wrong. The green chile flavor is decent with a good amount of heat considering we are not in New Mexico However, everything else is incorrect. The sopapaillas are sad--not puffy and are over cooked, and the enchiladas are layered, not rolled, with unmelted cheese throughout. The tamale was also a sad attempt. This attempt at New Mexican food was disappointing, especially considering the SF price tag. The food is isn't bad, but it isn't New Mexican as advertised.
author: Hillary S.

description:
EDIT: I'm upgrading this review to 3 stars, but only because of the root veggie hash for breakfast.  I'm a big fan of it, but that's about all.  I've had a few other items as well, and they all struck me as sub-par (especially the dry burritos) for one reason or another.

As much as I wanted to like a place that was so close to me, I couldn't help but feel like I had to fight to get all the things I needed.  Fight for a table while someone else places your order by proxy.  Go get your own silverware.  Go find someone to refill the knives, then go get them yourself.  Go get someone to refill the napkins and water, then get your own damn water.  I can go to Taco Bell for $3 and they'll STILL get all this shit for me!

Original:

Would love to say I tried the food, but the place was apparently inconvenienced by our presence, so we left.

I'm no stranger to restaurants.  I've been to sit down places, stand up places, places with windows.  In my experience "Order at the counter" places have a sign that says "Order here" and a menu above the counter to inform you of their offerings.  Also, a place with a bar ALWAYS lets you order at the bar.  If they, for some reason, do not let you order at the bar, they're usually sure to tell you that you need to go somewhere else to get what you need, instead of letting you stand there forever in vain.  Any respectable restaurant, I would hope, would notice you after standing at a perfectly reasonable area to place an order for 15 full minutes.  

We were afforded no such decency, nor the time of day--they couldn't even take 0.13 seconds to say 'hi' when we walked in, then or the 8 subsequent times I made uncomfortable eye contact with any of the employees.  When I finally asked what was up and mentioned that it wasn't obvious that you need to stand somewhere OTHER THAN A BAR to get a beer, I was shrugged off entirely and told I needed to wait in line I've been standing next to for what seems like an eternity.  

I'm giving it a generous two stars because I plan on going back when I'm not seething mad about a place that apparently doesn't give a crap about its customers.  I feel that's generous, and I hope that someone in management stops apologizing to all these reviews and actually does something about it.  I'm clearly not the only one with this sentiment, and they should probably stop brushing people off that just want to give them money.

By the way, when people are flapping their arms at your restaurant, they're probably not trying to fly.
author: Adam R.

description:
Yum. Yum. Yum.
Had the veggie salad and added pinto beans. I'm still thinking about how delish it twas. My man had the half chicken plate - wow - thats a lot of food. A tad bit expensive for the guacamole but it was good so I'm not complaining.
Will be back. Fast, easy service & I personally like ordering at a counter - no awkward wait staff incidents to be had.
author: S. M.

description: This was my first time here. What a nice lunch. I had the Stuffed Poblano Chiles and a cup of Pozole. Best meal I have had in quite a while. Service is a little lacking but the food is excellent. Feeling satisfied without feeling stuffed and sludgey. I will be back.
author: Brian D.

description: Middle class white slob family restaurant. Good burritos and nice staff though.
author: Tracey W.

description:
Oh Green Chile Kitchen....what to do with you. 

I was bored of everything around you so I gave you another chance. But you're still not worth going to and I think I'm done forever. 

GCK has no niche and no gimmick other than to be expensive to eat at. While they plate their food much better than your standard taco dive; their rice, their beans, their meat, their tamales, their tortillas, etc. don't taste any better. Their sauces are a couple of steps below average.  

And there is just some lazy, shiftiness on the menu. One tamale is $4. Two tamales with a little lettuce and tomato thrown on the plate are $12. Fail.
author: Luke M.

description: I find it weird when they mix the Mash Potato with Jalapeno. It tastes spicy and feels awkward. The Rotisserie chicken is good but you can always get it from Costco or Safeway at more reasonable price.
author: Evander J.

description: Best breakfast burrito in the city and super nice staff. Really great neighborhood gem. They also have a great kombucha on tap. Never had anything by a delicious meal here.
author: Sarah K.

description:
My credentials: I grew up in New Mexico. I love New Mexican food, and I love green chile. 

We came here for dinner one night, myself being pretty darn excited to eat some of my home-state's star crop. The atmosphere is earthy and trendy, but what frustrated me immediately upon arrival was the lack of instruction about what to do. Several people were waiting in a line, some people sitting on the bench by the line, some people milling about. I was the first of my party to arrive, so I took a shot and got in line. 

The restaurant was buzzing, and as I looked around at the dearth of open tables, I started to realize that I was doing something wrong. It seems that the frequent customers knew how to cheat the system, and upon arriving, would send one of their group to claim a rare table while the rest of them stood in line to order food. I watched as table after table became occupied by patrons who had arrived AFTER me. This may fly for a casual lunch thing, but certainly wasn't appropriate for a dinner situation. 

Luckily once I placed my order, I was able to claim a free table. The margarita I ordered was delicious, but that's the only thing I would come back for. 

When my friends finally arrived, they had to stand in line for a while to place their order as well. When the runner brought us our food, he did not bring silverware, and we had to get it from the self-serve area at the front of the restaurant. Again...not appropriate!

The food itself was okay. For the price, it's definitely not worth it. If you're hardcore craving New Mexican food, still not worth it. 

I certainly did not feel taken care of, and actually felt pretty duped (both by the restaurant and the familiar patrons). I'll save my money for the plane flight home.
author: Stephanie S.

description: If you're completely new to New Mexican food, this is a good place to start -- in the Bay Area. If you're from New Mexico, this place just might irreparably piss you off. The food isn't half bad, but some of the variations border on sacrilegious, some are just weird. I always picture myself ordering the stuffed sopaipillas (all but unknown outside of NM), but strangely always settle on the crispy, blue corn tacos (arguably among the least New Mexican items on the menu). All told, the real drawbacks are economic (gougey pricing, sneaky, upchargey service), and not culinary. Give it a try, but come by my house later for the real deal. Bueno.
author: Joe V.

description:
The ease at which I was just able to purchase a gift card online was admirable.

On a personal level, I'm not much into Mexican food.  But we come here a lot because the world does not revolve around me.  I'm always pleased, as are my friends.
author: Nora S.

description:
Yum!  I got the very last Beet Margarita of the night (at 6:15pm) and it was delicious. I'm convinced that there wasn't a drop of tequila in there but that's okay because it was so good that I would pay $8 for the drink sans alcohol.  

Don't skip on the chips and (4) salsa sampler.  Be warned that the habanero one is no joke! It will set your mouth on fire.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
The tortillas were seriously undercooked. They were borderline mushy.

The pozole was fine. The sopaipillas were not as chewy as a remembered them in New Mexico, but my sample size is too small to make any conclusive recommendations.

The tamales were also a bit "mushy" like the tortillas.

As for service, it was decent enough. It seemed that they were intent on bringing the forks and spoons to the table, but they didnt bring the right qty and combination of utensils we needed, so I had to keep getting up to go find out where they hid them to get some.
author: Norman P.

description:
Reading my friend's quick tip in the car ride over - long lines at 7pm, and we were driving over on a saturday at 7. Damn, we'll probably have to wait. Oh wait, we found parking right outside the restaurant? there's no line and plenty of tables? Oh well I guess we just have great luck. The boy actually saw some of his students there, kind of awkward, but it happens. 

I ordered the new mexican homestyle chicken enchilada that was delicious! The portions were a bit big, but damn, so delicious. The chicken was tender and it was smothered in this green sauce and definitely worth every bite. 

The boy ordered the tamales. he seemed to like them, but then again, we like our mexican food. 

the boy's dad ordered the carne adovada, spicy, but not overly so. Apparently not too authentic. Delicious though.

The boy's mom ordered a 1/4? maybe a 1/2 chicken, looked pretty good. 

We also got the sopapillas. they're like fried bread that's kind of puffy. It's weird looking at first, but so delicious esp with their red chili honey. 

by the time we left around 830, the place was packed and definitely really hard to get seats, apparently just down the street they have a place to get pies or something. sounds interesting.
author: Nina Y.

description:
Although I live just a couple blocks from here, I rarely frequent this place. The food is enjoyable (that is, unless you get the spicy lime dressing on your salad, like I did, and find yourself burning off taste buds with each bite) but the prices are higher than I would expect for a laid-back neighborhood place. Plan on spending $10-12 for each entree. Granted, they are considered "plates" so your $11 burrito is actually a burrito "plate" with organic sides like rice and beans but still. Burritos really shouldn't be in the over-$10 range.

I find myself just going down the street to Papalote to get my burrito fix. Well, until they jacked up their prices. The NERVE!

Because I do find the food enjoyable on occasion, my go-to dishes are the southwestern steak salad (again, I'd steer clear of the chipotle lime vinaigrette unless you're hoping for nightmares later on that evening) or the blue corn flat enchiladas. My husband swears by the tamales, which are delivered fresh weekly on Tuesdays, I think.

As for the space...their old space was much nicer. This current location larger but also much louder. Not nearly as cozy.

To satisfy that sweet tooth, head down the block to their old location where they've opened up a pies and ice cream place. It's got mixed reviews but worth trying it out for yourself.
author: Jasmyn M.

description: Hmm, came here for dinner and had the tamales and the fry bread. Both were just okay...I'm not sure why all the great reviews. I'm a bigger fan of papalote. Nothing tasted that extraordinarily delicious. Also beware seating - you order and seat yourself, so our group of 8 had to squeeze into a table for 4.
author: Christina K.

description:
Delicious. I usually only go to Yelp 4 star and above. I'm going to change that because this place is fabulous. Fell in love with New Mexico green chili when traveling. Theirs is every bit as delicious. Also, I rarely eat tortillas, but I took a taste of one and couldn't stop. Fresh blue corn tortillas to die for.
It is probably best to know what to order so u love it as much as I do. Green chili stew and blue tortillas.
author: Patricia B.

description: THE. BEST. As a New Mexico native, this is my saving grace when I'm craving some home style meals. The hatch Green Chile is a must. You cant find that anywhere outside of the southwest besides here (and if you can, please let me know where those places are!). Some authentic New Mexico cuisine and I bring all my friends here.
author: Vanessa G.

description:
This is one of my neighborhood spots.
It's order at the counter, grab your number and find an open table. 
The pork at GCK is delicious. I love it on top of the nachos or in the green chile roasted burrito.
I love that GCK gives you lots of options -- type of beans, hot or mild chile, etc. Opt for the hot.
If you're still hungry after dinner I highly recommend walking one block for a slice of pie at Chile Pie and Ice cream.
author: Teryll H.

description:
New Mexican cuisine. I liked it and plan to eat there again. I ordered the New Mexican layered chicken enchilada. The chicken was very flavorful not to mention the perfectly spicy sauce (just enough but not too spicy). My friend and I also shared nachos which were also good.

Next time I will get the green chile stew (on a cold day) and the nachos to pick at. The partners of Green Chile Kitchen are good as well like Chile Pie down the street for desserts (i.e. Daddy's Cardamom ice cream!)
author: Raj P.

description:
Ordered three dishes: Chile Relleno Plate, Half Chicken Dinner and Seven Layer Dip.
Tried one entree with re-fried and the other with black beans. Both beans were well done, classic flavors. The rice just tastes like it's mixed with tomato sauce, otherwise not much flavor. The chicken was underwhelming and a bit dry (better rotisserie chickens at Haight Street Market). The dip was tasty and simple. The relleno had a nice batter and was cooked well with a flavorful, spicy green chile sauce. Overall, for the price there are much better restaurants.
author: Max G.

description: I love the burritos and the green chile. I wish it wasn't so crowded with yuppies most of the time, but what can you do.
author: Grey Z.

description:
Best Chile Relleno I've ever had.   Definitely hit it up if it's listed as the special.

Loved the beer selections and kombucha green tea.
author: John H.

description: The food is pretty good. But for that price, I expect my food on a plate with real flatware- that box and plastic fork bullshit is obnoxious. And waiting in line for another bar drink or dessert? Its as if they don't want to make money.
author: Alexis S.

description: I was born and raised in New Mexico and the red chile posole is authentic and fantastic, complete with blue corn tortillas.
author: Billy W.

description: Sangria is SO GOOD. Food is delicious and there's tons of seating. I usually go there just for the sangria- strong and tasty.
author: Laura M.

description:
We saw this restaurant on Check Please Bay Area and really expected to like it.  For a Saturday lunchtime it was busy, but not to crowded, just enough time in line for me to read the menu.  

Cashier was very friendly and explained one of the dishes to me.  However when the food came there was no chicken on the salad we'd ordered.  Back to same Cashier who when he looked at my receipt had me pay for the chicken - I guess it wasn't on there, but I wouldn't know as he then kept the receipt which I asked for back and was later given the wrong one.  Then realized there was no pork in my green chilli stew.  The manager added in the pork and the stew was good.  

The chicken was bland, even salt and pepper didn't add much flavor to it.   The pork was flavored by the stew. but nothing special about it.  A lot of dishes did look good, so might try one more time.
author: Timothy S.

description: The carne adovada stuffed sopaipillas are f'ing amazing. This place has a native New Mexican's stamp of approval.
author: Sam B.

description:
Excellent New Mexican breakfast burrito. Interestingly awesome chile honey at the table on your burrito? Daaaaaayum.

Also saw something pass by, sopasito maybe? Looked amazing, trying next time
author: Josh T.

description: Lunch is good, just be aware that they might double the tip on your credit card, keep your receipt and check your statement later, sneaky skinny guy at the register did this to me the other day.
author: Anna N.

description: I LOVE this place - tried them for the first time for lunch delivery at work and then decided to stop by their NOPA location. It's a great community neighborhood spot - but it does get super busy and short on tables, so plan accordingly. They have a massive Mexican menu with more of a southwest/healthy twist. Loved the stuffed peppers.
author: Jeanna B.

description: Love this place! This is the only place that can do a breakfast burrito right, smothered in green chili and the potatoes inside! Reminds me of growing up in Colorado. Sometimes we go and I'll just get a bowl of the chili stew. It always hits the spot.
author: Cassie F.

description:
Short version:
Great atmosphere. Great food (but quality/taste can take the occasional dip). Service is good. Make sure to check your to-go orders before heading out. Pricy. 

Long version:
I have a bit of a love/hate relationship with this place. First off: the food is great! At least most of the time. Occasionally the meat in my burrito will suddenly be chewy and not as flavorful as i'm used to. It's worth taking the risk though, since when done right, Green Chile Kitchen serves the best burritos in town. Hands down. Just keep in mind that you'll be paying around $12 for one. 

One consistent issue has been them getting the order right when ordering over the phone for pickup. My wife is allergic to avocado and I can't tell you how many times we've called in an explicit "no avocado!" order only to come home and find avocado/guac in her burrito. 

They seem to have heard our feedback tho and it hasn't been an issue the last few times we ordered. Hence 4 stars instead of 3. 

P.s. Just in case a staff member is reading this... Please add a little more cheese to the beet/kale salad. All the right ingredients are there, but in it's current state it's rather boring.
author: Pep G.

description: Delicious. I'm a big fan of their Carne Adovada and my wife loves their naked burritos with real green chile. My wife is from New Mexico and considers the food to be very authentic.
author: Luke F.

description:
Perhaps I need to come by for breakfast, because as far as dinner is concerned - ¡no me gusta!.

I'm not sure if this is how authentic Mexican food from the great state of New Mexico is supposed to taste, but if it is, I feel sorry for residents of the Land of Enchantment (state slogan). I was SO excited to try the new location on Baker/McAllister and finally had an opportunity to do so this evening. I munched on the two tacos plate, and it was beyond disappointing to say the least. The beans and rice were about as boring and bland as a Jonas Brothers sex tape, the tacos themselves (one chicken, one pork) were completely average at best, and the salsa looked tasty, but it had absolutely no kick whatsoever. Unless I'm missing something on the menu (and please, let me know if I am!), I just don't understand how this place is jam-packed with diners every night. 

On the positive side, they have a small, yet nice selection of draught beers on tap. Racer 5 (one of my favorite IPAs), Anchor Steam, Blue Star (Mendocino beer, FTW!) and a few others. They also do have a communal table and their glassware makes you feel as though you're eating inside of an adobe in the middle of the Southwest. 

They have breakfast tacos on the menu, which I've tried in Texas and absolutely loved... so I'll be sure to give those a shot. I'm crossing my fingers that my taste buds have a better reaction to the morning fodder than they did the fare after dark.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
Going to this place for Mexican food is like going to San Francisco for the beaches.  The dude behind this resty was pining for good old New Mexican food from college days of yore when he started Green Chile.  For a long time I saw the $12 burrito price tag as the NOPA yuppies' favorite flavor of fangerbang.  I'm in fucking California and I'll be damned if I pay more than $6 for a burrito the size of Arnie's bicep.  Plus, I thought, these burritos taste totally funky.  Funky like New Mexican!

After I adjusted my expectations and ordered the Green Chile Pork Stew, I was done.  Pro tip: DO NOT GET THIS SOUP TO GO.  They're reaming you with the $9 bowl when you eat-in, but you actually get HALF the size if it's to go.  That isn't an exaggeration, I did empirical research tonight.  Half. 

The line can be ridiculous sometimes, but you get the food faster b/c there's no waitstaff. You might have to sit with strangers (don't pretend that you like that, because nobody wants to stuff face in front of some beanie/scowl wearing chick/dude [who can tell these days (the only thing hotter than ambiguity is surprise)] they just met).  Best part of this serve your own water place: enormous glasses.  I don't want to get up a zillion times to cool my pathetically sensitive palette.  Well done, dudes.
author: Ellen C.

description:
Green Chile has a special place in my heart and memory. I used to love on the NOPA neighborhood and this was a stomping ground for me. I mean this place is magical. It's not only beautiful and modern, but their food is amazing, literally makes you question why you ate that frozen pizza for lunch and disgrace the holly than all else Green Chile burrito. Most of the times when making praise of all things beans and rice and of corse chile's at this establishment. There is a first bite silence that everyone else seems to partake in. Lets just say I only go back to that neighborhood to get my nails done and to have Green Chile burritos.

Pros:
Food- burritos and tacos
The beautiful restaurant
Bar

Cons:
First come seating
Can get loud
come before 6 pm and there's a lot of families and kids
Hard to park

All in all the mission has amazing mexican food, but NOPA has the holly burrito at Green Chile Kitchen.
author: diana b.

description:
We walked in, grabbed a menu, ordered at the counter, and then waited with our little number thing until a table became available. It always feels a bit awkward - just standing there, waiting.

After a short while, a table became free and we claimed it. I sat while my beloved got up to get us waters, napkins, and utensils. 

I got the blue corn flat enchilada- which was nice and filling. He had the green chile soup. All the food was nice, not too spicy, and satisfying but I couldn't see myself coming back and getting them again. I might be curious to try something else but I'm not in any rush for it.
author: Loli L.

description:
Great neighborhood spot!  It is easy place for large groups. Order at the counter, find a table and your food is brought to you. 

Winners: homestyle chicken enchiladas, flat enchilada and dos quesos 7-layer dip

The green chile stew was good, but very spicy.  I was disappointed they ran out of padron peppers, though.
author: Catherine T.

description:
My partner  (who is originally from El Paso and knows his New Mexican cuisine) found this place a couple months ago. Since, then we have been several times and have brought along friends to enjoy the beauty of Green Chile's food. Although feisty and rarely-pleased Mexicans, we have bowed down to the fantastic posole, stacked enchiladas, steak tacos, calabacitas and the chicken burrito (christmas style). 

The staff cooking and bringing out the food are great, knowledgeable about the food and throwing down some mean food with a smile. 

That said, the cashiers have been consistently helpless. Although we have been there numerous times now, we're trying to work our way through the menu and therefore are not experts (perhaps because we're not the ones being paid to be the experts). The person at the register (we're going on 4 people so far) have never seemed too eager to help us figure out the menu; don't know how to pronounce anything on the menu (rather offensive in some cultures); and, seem so rushed that our business tends feel as if an inconvenience. 

But, at the end of the day, this bitchy Mexican keeps going back to face the unpleasant experience of rude cashiers. If that doesn't tell you how good the food actually is, nothing will (which, in my book, makes this an EXCELLENT REVIEW OF THE FOOD).
author: lorenzo h.

description:
Great service & food. Use caviar for delivery 
https://www.trycaviar.com/san-francisco
author: Peter H.

description: 5 stars because I eat here weekly and it is always great. Mark is usually working and he runs a tight ship. The food is delicious, there's still a lot of things I need to try but I want to plug the rotisserie chicken because it is greatness. Fun place, too. Well deserving of 5 stars!
author: Alexander M.

description:
The good: They have good burritos and chicken dinners.

The bad: The quesadillas are nothing special at all, something I could put together at home is a snap. I don't care for their salads and the guacamole is way overpriced.
author: Chris H.

description:
I love this place, I love the food. Creative without pretentiousness. Delicious, fresh, great, refined Mexican food, not your typical Mexican joint.. 
The only problem is that very often they mess up my order. 
This one last time my friend was almost done with his food and mine had not even been started (I was watching). I had to remind them. This happened three tomes already, yes three times.  
The food is fantastic. I am a vegetarian, and I love it here! 
The kitchen needs better organizing.
author: Dave C.

description:
AWESOME ! 
When I'm visiting my friend who lives near by we usually end up here for breakfast. 
Delicious full plates of food with a great staff. 

Try the breakfast bowls.
author: Lee O.

description: Boss treated us to lunch today so we picked this restaurant.  I ordered the steak salad with spicy chipotle lime dressing, and it was really a great twist of a salad.  It had beans which I usually don't eat but now learned to appreciate.  Also, corn , salsa, advocado, red roasted peppers and tasty tender steak slices. This salad is a fresh ending to my Friday!!!
author: April N.

description:
Why are the lines so long at Green Chile Kitchen?  1) Quality ingredients (Fulton Valley chicken, Niman Ranch beef, Pueblo chiles grown in New Mexico, Mexican music), 2) a casual/rustic atmosphere (hanging clusters of dried chiles, dark wood, Virgin Mary paintings) and 3) homemade New Mexican comfort food.  The place was PACKED for brunch and most people ordered the breakfast burrito with Niman Ranch beef and green salsa.  

I tried the breakfast taco plate ($8.95): two tacos with fluffy scrambled eggs, your choice of meat (I chose rotisserie chicken), cheese, lettuce, your choice of salsa (red or green) on corn tortillas, a thimbleful of yummy posole, and a pile of tender pinto beans.  You can get both salsas but that costs an extra $1 (Christmas) - which seems a little lame. The tacos were very good because the chicken chunks were tender and had more flavor than usual and the spicy green salsa tastes fresh and bright.  The pinto beans were a bit boring.  More salsa would have helped but they don't give you much salsa...or much posole.  

Brunch is served from 9 AM - 2 PM.  The post-brunch menu includes tacos ($2.50 each), burritos, quesadillas, stews, salads, tamales and nachos.  They have organic sodas, soyrizo, flan, hot chocolate, and gelato.  The prices are a little higher but not too bad.  My main gripe is salsa stinginess.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Just went here with one of my best friends. We were so excited to try something new. Having been out of the Bay Area for some time, I was looking forward to the great mexican food we have here. I found that the food was alright.

I ordered the cheese tamale (with poblano pepper), a side of spanish rice and a glass of horchata. We also split a guacamole and chips starter. 

The best part of the meal was definitely the drink. Tamale was mediocre as it was somewhat dry. The Horchata was delicious and could have drank a few more. Guac was pretty good, lots of flavor and topped with fresh tomato and onions but the chips seemed almost too thick and not crunchy enough. Rice was also mediocre, not too much flavor going on there. 

All in all, i'd maybe go again just for chips and guac and a drink. Then again, I've been to many places in the mission and you just cant beat that food!
author: Marissa S.

description:
Okay, this place is literally 1 block away from me.

I was really torn on the starring of Green Chile Kitchen. The thing is, it really is not spectacular food. It is even a little expensive for what it is and the food takes a while to come out. But the goddamn breakfast burrito always hits the spot so well that I want to give this place 4 stars just for that burrito.

Some tips / info:
-I ALWAYS FORGET THIS, but CHECK IN ON FOURSQUARE BEFORE ORDERING and get a discount!
-The green chile (for which the restaurant is named after) is rather bland in flavor to my indian tongue. I was really shocked when I first tried it. So tip, if you enjoy flavorful  or spicy food or are of indian origin, try to get spicy sauce / don't get things just b/c they have the restaurant's "green chile"
-I like the cantaloupe juice drink, try it!

I love the space / decor / communal table feel. Great place for a casual (and filling) breakfast after a night out (so long as you aren't concerned about the value.)
author: Neeharika B.

description:
Can't believe I've never reviewed my regular saturday ritual.

Everything I've had here is awesome. The only thing bad about the gradually evolving menu is that I haven't had a burrito in a long time because I've been busy trying everything else.

I read a review in which someone said the food was bland. That ish cray! The stuffed breakfast sopaipillas are a texture sensation (crispy bacon, fluffy eggs, crunchy sopaipilla smothered in chile sauce.)

My all-time fave is the green chile stew with chicken (it's the rotisserie chicken). Perfect on a cold night, best hangover/cold cure with kick.

I also really like the burger, I read a yelp tip that the patty is frozen. If that's true, I think it is still a great burger.

My least fave is the crispy tacos because of the premade shell, I think it represents green chile kitchen the least. Maybe that's geared toward the kiddies?

You can get Racer 5 IPA on tap or an individual drip coffee.

Conclusion: the existence of this place has enriched my belly's city life greatly!
author: Mirba E.

description:
Right down the street from me and the food is pretty great! I love the tamales, the burrito with steak is very good, and so were the nachos. I ordered the Chile Rellenos and is was decent, but I wish there was more flavor. 
Also, I'm not one for Horchata because places always mess it up, but I enjoy it from here.  
It's pretty loud and there's always a fight for a table and people can be pretty rude about it. Like sitting in the seat where my purse is.
author: Amanda M.

description:
I've always liked Green Chili Kitchen..but they definitely have upgraded when they moved to its new location.

There is still a long line out the door..but no longer do people have to fight for tables. The new location is super spacious..lots more tables and even a long communal table.. great for large groups and baby strollers. 

Same great food and friendly service--I just wish they'd do their breakfast burritos with eggwhites...maybe someday...
author: Mimi T.

description:
Delish! I had the tacos since I wasn't hungry thinking they'd be small (they weren't) but I ended up eating everything anyway. Excellent food and good house red wine.

The only negative was the atmosphere at dinnertime (7ish) on a weeknight. I guess isn't a review of the establishment so much as irresponsible SF parents, but there seemed to be a lot of parents letting their kids run wild up and down the aisles and nearly knocking over glasses, trays, etc. I didn't realize this would be the scene here. However. amazing food and I want to go back and try more.
author: Lauren C.

description:
This one was just not my 'cup of tea'...

The plates look very pretty and contemporary, but we were just missing that deep flavor of an authentic Mexican meal. We had the sweet potato tamale appetizer. The flavor combination just did not work for me. For our entrees we had the burrito and the chile relleno plate. Both dishes were good, but a little too contemporary for my taste.

All in all, it's decent food on a more contemporary side. Price/Service wise - I felt it was a little on the pricey side for a self-order place with very limited seating.
author: Isa T.

description: Great food, cool ambiance, weird managers. We had ordered chicken tamales and got vegetarian tamales. When I went up to ask about it, the chefs who happened to be mexican told me in limited english that they were out of it. The manager then huffed and puffed and goes "this is why they are so difficult"... I found that offensive. But the food was solid so.....
author: Na L.

description:
Green Chile Kitchen is fine if you want to have a cheapish brunch with some friends at a casual location. We came at 10:30am on a Sunday morning (before the rush!) with 4 other friends and put in our orders. This is where we start deducting stars.

-2 stars for the service
The guy at the counter acted like he was a terrible mix of stoned and hungover. I repeated my very simple order (breakfast burrito, steak, mild sauce) to him many, many times and he still entered it wrong on the machine. Of the 6 of us who came, he got every single one of our orders wrong. Dude, your job is to listen to some people who are speaking pretty damn slowly and clearly. Just repeat it as you type it in. NOT HARD.

Otherwise the food is just fine for your Americanized breakfast burrito. My burrito was loaded with soft scrambled eggs, chunks of potato and some steak. Covered in a nice mild green sauce. Nothing fancy or mind blowing. 2 of us paid $25 for 1 burrito with meat and the breakfast soft taco plate (2) with meat. Kinda expensive, but compared to normal brunch it was fine.
author: Wendy T.

description:
