The Good - I moved to California from New Mexico in 1988 and until now, I have never been asked "red or green," nice job.  Also good were the sopapillas, a certainty in any New Mexican restaurant but a first for me in any Cali eatery, and they were good.  Served hot and a bottle of honey was already on the table for the obligatory filling.   I had the chile rellenos and the chile actually had some flavor to it, it was clearly a New Mexican variety and not the usual Anaheim pepper used in most of the Mexican restaurants here.  

The not so good - The style; you order, pay and then find a seat and wait for your food to be delivered.  The place was busy and with a line to the door, the food service was relatively quick.  But if you wanted another basket of sopas, or green chile stew, then get back in line.  If you wanted a refill or another beer, the wait is a little better because you only have to wait for service while standing at the bar.  The food; the cheese in the relleno was azadero (I think) or some other type of mexican cheese.  This is not how they are built in NM; try a visit to Chopes for a reminder.  The tamales, were horrible.  They used a bleach white masa that was about an inch-thick all the way around a small mass of green chile at the core.  Every bite was almost solid masa; not good.   The taco was ok; served with a blue corn tortilla, very Sante-Fe-ish.  

Combined with the diffiiculty we had finding a place to park, we will probably not go back.  If anyone does eventually bring an authentic New Mexican restaurant to the Bay Area, we will definitely give it a try.
author: Dan E.

description:
Order at the counter and sit yourself down ... if you can find a seat.  Seats were almost as hard to come by as parking the Wednesday evening we stopped here.

This is a sort of New Mexican style of mexican food, and we enjoyed the flavors a lot; tried all their salsas; chicken, pork and veggie tamales ( good but filling ); a flat enchilada was probably the highlight of the meal, despite being filled with ground beef.  Tacos - hard blue corn shell - were interesting.  The flavors are complex without being muddled - some of the best Mexican-derived food I've had in a while.

They have an excellent selection of beer on tap ( Racer 5, Ommegang Hennepin featured prominently the night we were there ), though I question their choice of bottles ( do not like Bison Brewing, despite them being Organic and All That.).  They like to do beer floats and have some interesting ice cream flavors to go with.

Service was relatively fast and friendly, and the food certainly came out quickly.  We ended up finding a couple stools at the bar, which is basically just additional seating at this point.

Would come back.
author: Albert H.

description:
After eating at Gordo's every week for about two years, this place is a step up.  I wouldn't say it's as good as tacqueria can cun, but it's pretty good in its own way.  I just had the chile relleno burrito, and it was amazing.

Now that I live a block away, I don't know how I will convince my lazy self to eat elsewhere.
author: Andy H.

description:
I don't ever say no to Mexican for breakfast.  Luckily, my husband was craving a breakfast burrito and this place happened to be open at 9am.  He ordered the breakfast burrito with red sauce and crema and I got the breakfast bowl with green sauce.  The burrito was stuffed with juicy, tender chicken and lots of scrambled eggs, and then smothered with very yummy red sauce.  The burrito came with pinto beans, lettuce and potatoes on the side.  I think I would have preferred to have all the sides inside the burrito.  The breakfast bowl was suppose to be the healthy option with black beans, scrambled eggs, lettuce, green salsa, and blue corn tortillas.  I liked the red sauce more than the green sauce.
Everything could have used a little salt, and I'm no expert but it didn't seem very authentic tasting. The food comes out quickly, the prices are reasonable and the restaurant is clean.
author: Lucy H.

description:
Sunday morning , we walked in ordered some tacos and 2 coffees. The lady tells us "Oh I cant find the coffee right now". Hmm ok...

Food is great and kinda pricey!
author: Jangalina J.

description:
Came here in a big group and we ordered a LOT of food.  We all just tried a bit of everything and it was all delicious.  One of my friends treated me to a beer which was phenomenal! It had lime in it...and was dark...that's all I got haha.  

It's a cute place where you pay for your food, then get it, so no waiters to fuss with!
author: Jessyca M.

description: Very tasty food and kid-friendly place!!!  We will be back!!
author: Stefanie H.

description:
I really don't have any particularly good reason to update this place except for 1) I'm pretty sure when I wrote my original review it was when they were at there old location (the new one is bigger and there is more seating), and 2) I'm not sure if it's just laziness on my part, but the last month or so I've been eating here quite a bit again. It was only three blocks away from my house to begin with, and now it's only two... 

They still have the same great food as before & the prices are reasonable (although I couldn't access a menu online the other day when I was ordering and I found a really old takeout menu in my house from here...this place used to be CHEAP!). I really haven't tried anything new, but the past few times I've had out of town visitors we've eaten here for hangover breakfast and the mango mimosa's are ridiculously good!
author: George A.

description:
GREEN CHILE STEW: 5 stars.  Everything else 3 stars.

AMBIANCE: Casual rustic.  There are communal tables as well as smaller group tables and seats along the edges of the room.  Be prepared to WAIT for your table.  Best bet is to hover around tables that look close to finished and hope to snag seats before other people do.  Try not to poach.  GCK seems to attract large family groups with young children-- so don't be too offended by dirty table tops (although the staff does it best to clean everything off) and kids running around under your feet.  It ended up getting pretty noisy while we were dining; so much so that it was difficult to hear someone speaking to me from across the table.  

SERVICE: The girl at the register was really friendly and helpful.  Otherwise no real service to speak of-- you grab your own utensils and water.  The busboys have hawk eyes and swoop on your plates as soon as they're empty.

FOOD:
***Green Chile Stew ($9 16oz bowl): MMMM so hearty and delicious.  Absolutely hit the spot from first spoonful to last slurp.  There is quite a bit of heat, which I wasn't prepared for, but enjoyed immensely.  Beware if you can't handle spicy.  I asked for sopaipilla (you have the option between that or a flour tortilla) and wasn't impressed.  It was stale, greasy, and smaller than expected.  Wish it had been fresh out of the fryer.

- Blue Corn Flat Enchilada ($13): Got this with ground beef.  It was ok, but not great.  It didn't really have any bold, standout flavors or textures, but I was hungry and it did its job.
- 1/4 Rotisserie Chicken Dinner ($9): Received a leg/thigh, plus black beans, veggies (zucchini), rice and a shredded lettuce salad.  The chicken was also only ok-- moist but lacking in any flavor.  I liked the rice that came with this dish more than the chicken.

I also got to try a small bite of the green chile burrito (again, meh.  It was super cheesy, but I felt like it was just a "normal" burrito) and some of the green chile nachos.  TC and PL were both satisfied with their choices, so I guess my one bite of each didn't really do the dish justice.

OVERALL: Strange that I found the majority of the dishes bland.  Maybe its because my taste buds were so enamored with the green chile stew that they snubbed all other flavors.  Who knows.  All I can say is wow, GCK, your green chile stew was AMAZING and I'd definitely return for that.  However, if the wait is 1+ hrs for a seat, I'd rather just relive my memory of the meal.
author: Susanna W.

description:
Green Chile Kitchen is great!

Went here the other night with a few friends for the first time. You order first then sit down. They have a nice selection, but the menu is not too overwhelming. I had the chicken tamales which had the perfect ratio of masa to meat. They also have a great house red wine for $5. 

The atmosphere is warm, fun and energetic, even on a Monday night.
author: Daniel K.

description:
Bigger space feels more intimate and cozy. Now serving alcohol but I wish their sangria was stronger. Red chile is better than the green, but I went xmas style to try them both. Creamy vegetarian refried beans make me happy. Try the enchilada with veggies; more like blue corn tortillayum.
Can be too pricey :(.
author: Cori W.

description: You can have a spare rib experience here that is unique.  At the risk of breaking writing rules & being redundant, I must say that the spices used for the ribs are not like any previous eating experience I have ever had.  Usually, there are 3 or 4 similar types of barbecue sauces that seem to go along with eating spare or 'baby back' ribs.  Not so, with the New Mexican spices used in the rib sauce served @ Green Chile Kitchen.  The ribs are glazed with red chili honey, and the red chili sauce, coming from New Mexico, is served on the side.  Combine the sauce with the meat, and you have a food flavour marriage that will not end in a messy divorce.  In fact, the way the ribs are cooked, they are not nearly as messy as the usual rib fare.  They are not dry, but they are not dripping with grease.  Somehow, in their preparation, they have found a method that makes for a happy medium, sparing you the mess problems often associated with consumption of barbecue ribs.  Served with a salad & mashed potatoes & a flour tortilla.  They are simply the best & healthiest tasting ribs I have ever eaten.
author: Thomas O.

description:
Green Chile Kitchen is good.  Not the most amazing, mind-blowing, fantastic food ever.  But hell, I'd come back any day for that spicy hot green chile!!

Oh, and I just realized that they're open for breakfast.  I got the breakfast burrito.  Good, but again, not fantastic.  It could have had more pico de gallo (I think I saw maybe 4 tomatoes in my whole burrito) and maybe more potatoes!  But I got it smothered in the green chile which made everything better!
author: Angela G.

description: I am a fan of this neighborhood place and have been coming for years, but I have seen inconsistencies in the kitchen (stale tortillas, tiny servings of beef in the crispy tacos) which drops it a star.  We do not come as often because of this.  The staff on the whole is really nice, and it is hard to beat $2 Pacifico's.   GCK is pretty kid-friendly weeknights until 5pm or so.
author: Wendy L.

description: Their veggie green chile stew is amazing!! I seriously have dreams about it! So good dipping the tortilla covered in chile honey into the stew! Also, some of the best horchata I've had in SF.
author: Sami L.

description: It's a casual joint (you order and get a number to put on your table).  The food overall was good, if a little light on the spice (as in hot not flavorful). The servers were pleasant and the atmosphere casual trendy. The white sangria was good... not too sweet not too alcoholic. Overall, I left a happy camper.
author: Amy L.

description:
Great place for a casual breakfast or lunch experience. I found the breakfast offerings so-so, as it usually takes a lot to impress me. I had the breakfast burrito after reading several reviews here on Yelp, and found it a little more standard than I expected. That's not to say it wasn't worth the experience, just not a 5-star breakfast burrito in my opinion.

However, their lunch menu is fantastic. Excellent burritos, quesadillas, and other Mexican fare, with a feel of homemade goodness. I recommend carne, the quarter chicken, and of course everything smothered in green chile.
author: Dave T.

description:
I purchased the chile relleno combination plate and an order of sopaipillas for a little over $20 in addition to grabbing a glass of water at 7pm on a Monday night.  A few minutes after ordering, I received the enchilada with pinto beans, salad, and Spanish rice.  The salad was a basic greens with diced tomato.  It was solid.  The Spanish rice was over-seasoned and in clumps; the pinto beans were overcooked; and the enchilada was bland.  In actuality, the enchilada tasted more like it was an enchilada from Trader Joes (edible but not great) that has been defrosted and heated.  I kept on eating since I was hungry and asked a worker to check on the lateness of my sopaipillas.  They eventually came as I was finishing my food, twenty five minutes after ordering.  The sopaillas were good and the honey I used made them even more flavorful.  

I expected a delicious New Mexican meal but, instead, I was delivered a New Mexican inspired inedible plate of food. Do not recommend this restaurant.  

Stay away if you expect good food.
author: F.D. R.

description:
4.5 stars.

Considering how many times Yelp friend Ace L. suggested I should try this place I think I would have been quite disappointed with a mediocre experience.  Heck, she even sent me a link to the menu so that I would know exactly what I wanted to order as soon as I walked in.  After finally making it here I am thrilled that everything she told me was true.  The food is very good and very fresh tasting.

I ordered the Blue Corn Flat Enchiladas made with chicken from Fulton Valley Farms, had sour cream added to the top, and I chose the roasted green chile.  In addition I was curious about the Niman Ranch beef that is used so I ordered a Crispy Taco on the side.  I had a bottle of blueberry Fizzy Izze to wash it all down with. The restaurant was packed in the mid afternoon, but luckily I was able to find a single seat next to the window.  Don't forget to grab napkins and eating utensils on your way to your seat.

With a crowd of people inside I was expecting a much longer wait for the food, but my two plates were brought to me quite quickly.  The enchilada plate (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/teiDORLx2rFqNabJgUdMgw/l) comes with a simple salad of shredded leaf lettuce and pico de gallo, organic rice and organic beans served mashed (or refried as some might suggest).  The enchiladas are rolled in blue corn tortillas and completely enrobed in a thick layer of melted cheese and the green chile salsa.  I loved the taste of the salsa with the cheese combination and once I uncovered the actual enchiladas nesting inside I found them filled with nothing but moist chunks of braised chicken meat.  The green chile is not spicy but has a very robust flavor to it.  I liked it, but I will try the red chile on my next visit.  I enjoyed everything on the plate except the beans.  To no fault of the restaurant's I simply don't like mashed beans.

The Crispy Taco (http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/j9l4-YL1eT7it5vQN9WtWg/l) looked amazingly fresh.  I don't think I've ever seen a fresher looking taco.  Served in a crunchy blue corn shell my first bite yielded the natural taste of fresh beef.  That's right!  Although a bit oily the beef is mildly seasoned so you can really taste the actual beef.  In the photo you can see a spot of oil beginning to form underneath the corner of the taco shell; that was the oil dripping from the beef.  The red salsa that came with the taco was very mild.

The prices at the Green Chile Kitchen are slightly on the high side, but when you consider the quality ingredients being used it all levels out.  I was mostly amazed by the fresh taste of the food.

Oh, and before I forget ... Thanks Ace!  The Green Chile Kitchen is a real gem and I will be back!
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
Moving from LA, I have been dying for a taco here and was pleasantly surprised to find a place in my neighborhood. However, I cannot give this place a full and glowing endorsement-- instead it just will have to do.

Green Chile has pretty solid food. The soft chicken tacos and blue corn tortias just melt in your mouth and have some really nice flavors to them, however the hassles of this place make it less than perfect and I often have to weigh the benefits of the food with the cost of dealing with the setup.

First it generally runs a bit expensive, but I would be glad to pay if the customer experience was more positive. This place always has a huge line and it set up in this awkward way where people stand at the door to order and then have to find their own table.  Often times to get a table you literally have to "stake your claim" and stalk people who are eating. Also, the food does not come quickly so you are the jerk taking up a seat while other people want to eat. Also, the staff is quite slow and they don't seem to care about the mess going on on the other side of their counter most of the time.

Once I tried to just take my order out to avoid all of this mess, but the restaurants green policy means they just wrap everything in foil and throw it in a bag. I think there ended up being more open face chicken taco in the bag then left for me to eat...but then again I did almost get my taco fix.
author: Ashley A.

description:
A Double O restaurant - Overrated and Overpriced! N

After reading the numerous 4 & 5 star reviews, I was anxious to give this "New Mexican" restaurant a try as their website mentioned that they had the chile's flown in from New Mexico.

We went there for lunch and ordered the flat chicken enchiladas "Christmas" and the cheese tamales. Two entree's no drinks, over $30 for lunch.

With Christmas you're supposed to get equal parts red and green chile, my plate was more like 3/4 red and 1/4 green. The red sauce tasted watered down and was not the normal NM dark red earthy color, the green chile which I could taste was tasteless. Both sauces were bland and barely lukewarm. 

Didn't taste the tamales but I did not see any cheese only two cylinders of blue corn masa.

Pros - 
found parking within half a block.

Cons - 
Bland tasting red and green chile
No substitution of beans so they gave additional rice and lettuce
Cold and old rice, some grains must have been @ least a couple days old as they were hard and dehydrated
Price for the quality of food
Counter ordering and they bring your food, everything else you're on your own

Will Not be back or recommend to anyone seeking true New Mexican food.
author: George L.

description:
I write with a little hesitation that next time I come in, someone is going to glare at me.

Anywho, I've tried Green Chile on numerous occasions, at all times of the day, for all meals, and the one thing I do like is their service.

Food, however, consistently disappoints me. Burritos are maybe a 4 and cheese tamales are a 5, but everything else is a 3 at best in my book. The plates always look delicious but the flavors miss the mark and I often leave feeling that I could have made the same thing at home and been more satisfied. Breakfast I find particularly not appetizing, and the organic coffee they serve is really not good.

So, if you're in the neighborhood and need a quick snack, get a few a la carte tamales. Those are great. Otherwise, eh.
author: Emilia S.

description:
I love this neighborhood eatery! Although, it feels geared towards the american crowd, new mexican inspired dishes, it is very good still!

I come here often, favorite panhandle restaurant!!!! I swear I ate here a lot!

I always order the guacamole and chips, "crispy taco plate w 2 homemade organic blue corn crispy taco shells stuffed w/ niman ranch ground beef, lettuce, cheese & pico de gallo, served w refried beans & salad"....It's sooooooooooooooooo good! And can't forget an order of "Dagoba organic hot chocolate" yummmmmmmm!!!

Although this spot is super pricey, I didn't mind, I don't mind spending a bit much for food.....cuz food is so good in the tummy!!!!
author: Rae R.

description: Lately I've been going to Green Chile Kitchen for take out.  I've been getting the heartland salad which I LOVE.  The ground beef (Niman ranch, super finely crumbled and perfectly seasoned), pinto beans, avocado, tomatoes, finely shredded cheese and buttermilk dressing rocks!  Just one small suggestion for take out orders: can you please put a sign for people so they know they don't have to wait in line to pick up?  I'm hoping you're thinking of a second location, you guys would pull it off well!  Great job Green Chile Kitchen!
author: Andrea R.

description:
It's sort of embarrassing/hilarious how often I go to Green Chile Kitchen. Yes, it's 2 blocks from my house. Yes, it's inexpensive. And yes, I have an unhealthy obsession with breakfast burritos. But it's a great change of pace from typical "Mexican" food and almost everything on the menu has its own distinct take.When I'm on the road for a few days, I crave their red sauce--it's this spicy/smoky combo salsa that I can't seem to find anyplace else. 

Plus, GCC is one of those uniquely SF eateries, where the staff mostly all look like they just came from a show at the Independent (or they're about to go). You sort of feel at home when you're there.

Highly recommend for a casual dinner with friends or even a nice 2-person meal.
author: Andy L.

description: The tamale, enchilada, taco combo is awesome. Delicious, great service. Will come back to try the sopaipilla- I hear it's amazing!
author: Steph P.

description:
The 4-stars is only a review of their brunch as I have never been there for any other meal.  

I love their brunch.  Seriously.  Good portions.  Burrito bowls with flavorful salsa and fluffy eggs,  blue corn chips, and strong mimosas.  Also, the wait is always short.  There is a part of me that wants to give them a bad review so there is never a line here.  But then again, that might mean that they will stop serving brunch, and that would make me a sad panda.
author: Tia B.

description:
A very unique take on New Mexican food! The chicken stew was worth ordering -- a bunch of warm homey goodness served in a bowl with a warm tortilla on the side. The blue corn enchiladas were also quite yummy. Definitely opt for the green chile sauce!

Not much on the dessert menu, other than some mexican hot chocolate and flan. The had a special the night we went and offered sopapillas as well. 

The ambiance of the place is very warm and neighborhoody, and there was a constant flow of patrons at dinner time.
author: Mansi A.

description: Okay so this place isn't as ~authentic~ as the places in the Mission in terms of flavors, etc. but it's a great restaurant if you're simply craving Mexican food of any sort. Steak tacos were good but a little bit too salty and watery--the watery-ness made the tortillas soggy which made the tacos fall apart which made me sad. I mean they still tasted fine but it looked messy. I like that they have lots of veg options for people who are into that. Service was nice. The water cups are really cool. I'd love to come back here someday and try some of the other stuff on their menu!
author: Idk A.

description:
12.11.19  First Visit

Food    3 1/2 - 4  Stars
Place   4                Stars

The green chile quarter Rotisserie chicken 
            - was not bad but roasted slightly too long.
            - one side of the drumstick was dried out slightly
            - wish had more marinaded flavor

Pork tamale
            - pretty good 
            - small for $4

Papilla's
            - tasty fried triangles
            - basically Mexican fry bread
            - taste better with their honey mixed with chile

This was just snack items ... didn't try their main dishes.
Will try again to balance the review.
author: S.K. Y.

description: This isn't authentic New Mexican food, it's like eating at Blue Corn Cafe. The chile: It doesn't scratch the itch, it teases. Sopapilla is a shameful triangle: F+
author: Reba N.

description:
Meh.

I mean, just the biggest, most resounding meh I can offer, here.

I grew up in New Mexico. I have a special, heartfelt relationship with her food. I was very excited to come here.

But boy, this was some horseshit.

First, let's talk rice. Let's talk reheated, insipid, dry-ass rice that crunches as it hits your teeth.

Really? I just gave you money for this nonsense?

If you can't nail the fundamentals, I get very skeptical about the main event.

The main event was nothing special, either. A blue corn tortilla enchilada with chicken. Shredded beef would be a better filling, but they can't be bothered to do anything interesting here.

The whole thing was as flavorless as the rice. The chicken was bland as a paper towel. The cheese carried a bit of flavor, but not enough to redeem the dish. The green chile, the ambrosia of my youth, barely registered on my tongue.

What a disappointment. What a shame. And then there's this nonsense about not serving sopaipillas until after five? What is this? Is this a New Mexican restaurant or not?

Service sucked, too. One of those fun interactions where it seems you're creating an inconvenience for the person operating the register. 

The whole place has a sloppy, listless quality about it that's really disappointing.

Finally, it's a terrible value for money. $12 for a, frankly, crappy enchilada and yesterday's leftover rice? Come on. That money will take you a long way with much more delicious foods in San Francisco. Not  worth it.
author: Danilo C.

description:
I don't usually write reviews of this sort, but I've made a vow to take the time to compliment people rather than just complain.  I live in Southern California and needed to quickly throw together a birthday party for my daughter.  I ordered off the catering menu and everything was wonderful.  Everyone had more than enough to eat and the quality of the food was great.  But even better than the good food was the help in pulling it together last minute and the patience of Mark, the manager.  I ended up calling several times and never once did Mark make me feel like I was bugging him and never rolled his eyes once (you can hear that over the phone.)
I highly recommend Green Chile Cafe for your next party. 
Thanks for the great service AND wonderful food.
author: Becky K.

description: Amazing food...totally overpriced though for a place where you order at a counter and then sit.  The sopaipillas are amazing.
author: Amanda B.

description: Food was amazing!! Lady taking order was extremely rude and seemed annoyed that we were here! So if she wasn't working here or had an attitude adjustment would have gave this spot five stars.
author: Jenni M.

description:
For those of us that are becoming a little TOO regular at Gordo's - Green Chile Kitchen offers some delicious fare at very reasonable prices and, best of all, it doesn't leave you feeling like you need to be wheeled home and plopped onto your couch for a 72 hour food coma.

The hot sauce is delicious. The veggie burrito is absolutely killer. The staff is very, very friendly (friendliness always knocks a 4-star up to 5 for me). Also, their beer selection is pretty darn great.

Cannot go wrong eating here. I'd recommend it for anyone... anyone at all.
author: Dalton C.

description: Had a huge piece of mexican chocolate cake for dinner which was very very very good.  It went well with the two dollar beer. Please don't tell.
author: El B.

description: We used GCK to cater a company event and I was blown away: both by the service and the food!  Having moved [back] from LA recently, I am usually underwhelmed by Mexican food up here.  This was not the case with GCK.  We hosted a taco bar with: chicken, ground beef, veggies and all three chiles (mild, hot and red).  The food was fantastic, and staff were responsive, easy to work with and professional.  We worked with Mark - and he made sure that everything was perfect, that we had what we needed and followed up to make sure we were satisfied.  Which we were!!  Thanks!
author: Bryce R.

description: Food is decent but my Burrito was cold on the inside. I saw that thy have the burritos pre made and just throw them on the grill - and to top it off They're solution to that was a microwave . DEF NOT WORTH $10 for a non-authentic burrito. Last time at this joint
author: Nick K.

description:
Holy habeanero salsa, that was HOT. Be careful...do not consume as regular salsa. So one star for the heat.

And one star for leaving full and no stars for leaving unsatisfied. $10 burrito with all the fixings usually leads to awesome. Except at Green Chile, a chicken burrito is made with plain, boiled, seasonless chicken. Really. No seasoning. Why, god, why. I hope my burrito was only a lemon and I just took one for the team.
author: NickJess S.

description:
I don't like to give 5 stars as usually there is something...something that can be improved upon!  Granted, I have only been to Green Chile Kitchen once...but it was amazing and is now my absolute favorite San Francisco eatery...too bad I only go a couple of times a year!

Very modern inside...not a tacky, south-of-the-border feel.  Very clean too.  You do go up to the counter to order...no servers (at least for lunch...I don't know about dinner).  

We got the Blue Bottle drip coffee...a San Francisco thing...it takes about 10 minutes but is worth it.  You have two cups, one over the other, with the top one having some sort of open bottom.  They put a filter and coffee in the top cup, then slowly pour hot water over the coffee and it drips...slooooowly...into the bottom cup.  Makes a delicious cup of coffee (but not too hot).

We also got the watermelon agua fresca...delicious and, unlike most of San Francisco, you got free refills.  We both sloshed as we walked after drinking coffee AND cup after cup of agua fresca.

I got a sampler plate.  It included guacamole (probably one of the top 3 guacamole's I've ever had), fresh made chips, a sample of ALL of their house-made salsas (4 or 5 of them) and two house-made tamales (your choice of flavors).  I had a cheese tamale and a chicken tamale.  

Everything on my plate was perfect...I don't know how they could have improved on anything.  The guacamole was thick, with a true avocado flavor with a hint of lime and garlic.  All of the salsas were delicious...there is no way I could pick a favorite.  But the tamales...the tamales...I am now ruined...I can't have them anywhere else (except maybe from the famous San Francisco Tamale lady...a whole other review!).  They were steamed perfectly, the fillings were wonderful, the corn flavor shone through...but spicy enough to bring tears to your eyes!  Easily the best meal I had during this trip!!
author: Tricia B.

description: I've become somewhat of a regular now because the food is so great! There are tons of options and I'm always satisfied regardless of the size of my appetite. The seasonal items (especially the lettuce tacos and padron peppers) are such great additions and I really hope they stay beyond the summer.  The staff is very friendly and can accommodate almost any type of substitution or addition to a dish.
author: Malinda T.

description: Green chile makes a d*mn good burrito. I like that they lightly fry/toast the exterior of the burrito once it has been rolled, and the green sauce poured over top is delicious. This place has a nice atmosphere and plenty of places to sit (although weekends tend to get very crowded). Service is good and cashiers are always friendly. The horchata is pretty good too. Oh - and so is brunch.
author: R. J.

description: This place is okay.  The food is pretty spicy, but somehow also manages to be bland.  The prices are pretty high for the atmosphere and quality of the food, too, so it's one of those places that might be a good spot for a neighborhood lunch but not great enough to go out of your way for.
author: Erin B.

description: A place that does well only by virtue of its location and price point (in an area that lacks decent casual dining options). I've eaten here several times, and each time have left totally underwhelmed. But I know I'll return because it's a good spot in the nabe to meet up with friends for a meal when you don't want to eat pizza or wait forever for a table. The food is generally bland, inconsistent, oftentimes not warm enough, definitely not made to order, but edible/not terrible. My fave is the green chili soup and the salads are decent. The chicken is free range so + for that. Yesterday I found a hair in my lukewarm breakfast burrito, but didn't want another bland burrito so didn't bother to tell them.
author: Pria P.

description: Tonight for dinner we had the chips and 4 salsas, pazole, enchilada and horchata. The chips were delicious as well as the salsas which ranged from mild to spicy. The pazole was delicious. A little oily at first but the flavors were amazing and it was really tasty. The enchilada was good as well, and I'd recommend getting half red half green sauce so that you can sample both. I've had better horchatas, but this was still good. The ambiance was casual and seems like a good place to hang out for all ages. Not "blow my socks off" delicious, but definitely a solid 4 stars.
author: Elizabeth W.

description:
WARNING: Another know-it-all southwest native about to weigh in on her favorite food - GREEN CHILE!!!  

I have been meaning to get down to this place forever since my very favorite food is green chile and I happen to think my green chile stew is the BEST IN THE WORLD!!! The problem is that it takes a whole afternoon to make and I am almost out of my fire roasted chiles in the freezer. Nobody around here seems to know that New Mexico is a state much less that they have their own cuisine! (I digress..) 

I arrived with pretty low expectations, given my obviously snobby chile predilection. Imagine my surprise that they also make fresh sopapillas!! 

The menu had lots of delish looking staples but did I miss the big sopapilla with ground beef, veg and chile that I know and love? 

We went a little crazy and ordered green chile burritos plates (veg and ground beef) queso con green chile, and sopapillas. Here is the play by play:

Sopapillas: 5 stars. Perfectly made and served piping hot! 
Queso: 5 stars - REAL cheese and green chiles (that makes it fat-free right?)
Green Chile Burritos: 3.5 stars Ground beef was perfect, the squash in the veg one was a good choice but cut too big and could have been sauteed with onion and sweet corn to make it more flavorful. The big chunks were too hot and made everything soggy. Also could use some more Chile smothering! Great rice, BTW.

But the star of the show: GREEN CHILE. At this point I have to say its about a 3, but I know I will HAVE to go back and sample the stew to know for sure. We ordered hot chile on all items but it would barely pass for mild/medium heat in NM (IMHO). As an ingredient it was good on all the things we ordered but lacked that fire roasted flavor just a little. I am giving this place an extra star just for bringing NM flavor to SF finally and being a walkable mile from my house.  I think I burned at least one bite of sopapilla on the way back.
author: Kourtney P.

description:
The best part about moving to a new area of SF?? It's finding the best local spots of course! 
I love Greene Chile Kitchen. I am so thankful I discovered it and that it is only a few blocks from my new pad. Even if I didn't live close by I would drive here, from wherever, it is THAT GOOD!!
The enchilada's  are my Favorite. Whether it is the more traditional new mexican or the blue corn tortilla ones. Both are great. The Nachos are out of this world!! 5 people shared them and everyone was grabbing for more. The tacos are good, so are the salads and they have a great and interesting take on a burger. 
Try to call ahead or give yourself plenty of time to get food. This place gets BUSY but it is worth it! I'm taking two yelpers here on Wednesday and I cant wait to see what they think.
author: Wes P.

description:
Being born in Las Cruces, NM makes me constantly crave green chilies. The smell of the roaster filled with green chilies in front of supermarkets there forever fills my heart with joy. I have constantly considered having them shipped, but it's super pricey. 

Green Chili didn't disappoint, but it didn't wow me either or bring me back to being in the land of enchantment. 

Sopapillas were fresh and delicious. I wish they put the honey on for you though instead of self serve from bears on the tables. 

The green chili stew was soooooooo good. Spicy, filling, and a dollop of sour cream to top it off. 

The tamales were quite plain. They weren't stuffed with enough filling and I could hardly tell the difference between the pork and the cheese. 

The green chilies were mild when I ordered spicy  . . .  meh. 

EXTREMELY kid friendly. Lots of people had their little ones. 

Great for takeout!
author: Tina P.

description:
This might be a new Mexican restaurant, but it is bad New Mexican food.  Anyone that has had the wonderful food from 
New Mexico will be disappointed.   The green chili enchilada was as bland as my Irish mothers cooking.  Missing were the rich flavors, spicy sauces, the distinctive taste of hatch chillies.  

I quizzed the help, asking if this was real New Mexican cuisine.    I was assured the it was.   It was not even canned La Victoria.  What a disappointment.   On the positive side the help was nice, and the quality of the food, while bland and not what was advertised, was good.
author: Howard P.

description:
Breakfast burrito review here. So I love eating at Green Chile Kitchen but have always missed getting a breakfast burrito.  Luckily after an early morning shoot for Harvard Medical School I was around early enough to grab one and try it out.

The free range eggs were nice and fluffy and the burrito overall was pretty darn big and filling.  The potatoes  inside it were ok (but not as perfectly crisp on the outside like the ones at Arlequin in Hayes Valley (one of my fave breakfast burrito spots).

The cheese for some reason didn't really melt inside my burrito - not sure why since the inside was hot and all but that was a little annoying but really not a big deal.  Overall a solid breakfast burrito and not greasy in any sense filled with good organic stuff!
author: Gene X.

description:
A fast-casual twist on some Mexican dishes and I think Green Chile Kitchen executes it well.  My girlfriend had the Blue Flat Corn Enchilada and I ordered the New Mexico Homestyle Chicken Enchilda.  We both liked how they used blue corn and the sauces complemented the enchiladas nicely.  The plates come with some rice, beans, and a simple salad.   Expect 10+ for a plate, a few dollars more for the typical burrito and tacos, and don't expect chips and salsa while you wait.  If you want cheap Mexican food, steer away, but if you're in the mood for some fast-casual Mexican food in a classy, hip setting then come on in.

JJ
author: Josselin A.

description:
I love Green Chile Kitchen. being a New Mexico expat, it is the only place around to get a regular infusion of my favorite New Mexican foods. Green chile stew, pozole, carne adovada, calabacitas - give to me! love it. I've been eating there since it first opened. It is a friendly and welcoming place with the proper rustic, found art sort of Santa Fe ethos to it.

An added bonus: they sell frozen New Mexico green chile in 5 lb. blocks that you can take home and make yourself. It seems to be the only place in the area where you can find the stuff.
author: Chris Patrick M.

description: Great food, recommend the green chile stew. Love the vibe of the restaurant and the family table/ group seating.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
I'd describe this place as having simple, rustic Mexican dishes with decent flavors. More of a 3.5 star kind of place based on the prices for a order-at-the-counter place.  

I ordered 3 tacos (one pork, steak, chicken) with a side of grilled veggies, and my guy had the quarter chicken with a side of black beans and salad. Again, nothing fancy, but simple, tasty and fresh, although I could have used a bit more kick with both dishes. Also wish they weren't out of Sangria, maybe next time...with a burrito that looked really good when it came out. Service was great (we ordered, they brought it out quickly and hot, simple concept.)

Between here an Napolito, I'd probably choose Napolito, but I'd give GCK another chance, perhaps with a big group of friends to split of bunch of dishes and some pitchers of Modelo.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Ugh, I can't believe there is still so much confusion out there. Green Chile is NOT a Mexican restaurant. And when some say "New Mexican" it doesn't mean a new type of Mexican food with a modern update. NO people. When they say "New Mexican" they mean from New Mexico, in the Southwest. It even says it on the restaurant's sign. Capish?

The breakfast burritos at Green Chile are THE BEST EVER!!! Huge, stuffed to the brim with delicious chile goodness. My mouth waters at the thought. You can also get a veggie version with Soyriso instead of chorizo.

The rotisserie chicken is absolutely scrumptious! I love getting the 1/2 chicken dinner plate and saving the leftovers for the next day. You can also just buy whole rotisserie chickens to go. It's helpful to call and place your order ahead of time. This is a life saver during busy hours like Friday night.

I highly recommend the Posole soup. It's the best thing for a hangover or when you're just feeling tired, under the weather or in need of comfort. It's spicy, flavorful and loaded with juicy chunks of rotisserie chicken and hominy. A squeeze of lime juice and chopped cilantro on top and you have perfection.

Just like in New Mexico, they give you the choice of adding red or green chile to your meal. Chile is a big deal in New Mexico, and Green Chile's signature chiles do not disappoint. You can even order "Chirstmas" and have both chiles added to your meal.

Another thing I love about Green Chile is that they offer green tea Kombucha on tap. Theirs is refreshing and delicious, much better than getting it from a bottle.

The restaurant is spacious and family friendly but it can get quite busy on weekends. Lots of families come, so if you're not in the mood for screaming children, try to go at night.
author: L. L.

description: I love this place. Great New Mexican food for a reasonable price and fun, casual atmosphere. I have to pace myself from going back too frequently.
author: Luke K.

description:
My favorite place to take food lovers who have never before tried new mexico style green chile (a necessity in life).
This is a savory roasted chile bursting with flavor, not burn!
Extremely fresh ingredients that melt in your mouth.
I grew up in new mexico and these folks def know what theyre doing.
author: Kelsey W.

description:
- Pay the extra $1 for steak. Tender and full of flavor.
 - The namesake green chile is good with a solid amount heat - I prefer it to the red, which is kind of bland
 - The blue corn tortillas are great, especially in the enchiladas
 - The tamales are so-so. They masa is a little bland for my liking, but the filling is good.
author: Matt J.

description: Great burrito spot. They get busy on the weekends all day, but if you're looking for a take home order this is the best! Call in, get the spicy salsa and pick up in 15 mins.
author: Conrad F.

description:
Tacos, burrito, enchiladas, quesadillas -- all great.

Only complaint was that the food was a tad bland despite requesting the hottest salsa they could put on it.

Definitely worth a repeat visit, though.
author: Vandana N.

description:
Delicious food and a great ambiance that keeps drawing me back for more.

There are plenty of veggie options to choose from. On my last visit I tried out the Savory Stuffed Sopapillas - christmas style. The portion size was good, the salsas tasty and complimented each other nicely. My dinner-date enjoyed the enchiladas.

They had a christmas stout -float on special, I wasn't a fan. Next time I'll stick to jalapeno-lemonade, which is a real treat.
author: Amanda S.

description: a staple in my life. my favorites are big blue salad, taco salad, lettuce tacos. my friends love chile relleno burrito and the green chile. casual, friendly, and good.
author: Tatum T.

description:
As a New Mexican, I wouldn't exactly call it New Mexican food, and neither do the owners/chefs at Green Chile Kitchen. New Mexican *Inspired* is certainly the right phrase for it. Either that or 'gentrified.'

I've eaten here twice, and neither time have I felt like I was eating at Sadie's or Los Cuates; I really felt like I was eating at Flying Star (Albuquerque-ans, you know what I'm talking about.) For those of you who don't get the reference, Flying Star is a spot for hipsters to hangout and get organic food of all sorts, and it all tastes lackluster and overpriced. Yes, it tastes overpriced. 

The food just misses the spot. Maybe it's because none of it is smothered in a pool of Red Chile, or maybe they've just been using a mediocre batch of green chili when I've been in the restaurant; or maybe I'm expecting too much as a recent transplant from New Mexico, but it's just not New Mexican.

Good try though, I'll give you a 4 for effort.
author: Benjamin B.

description:
I think the thing I liked best about this place was the hot sauce on the table.  The food was so bland, not even the hot sauce could help.  I seriously regret the calories consumed in the meal I ate here.

I ordered a chicken and a pork tamale.  The pork was slightly more flavorful than the chicken, but neither satisfied my craving for Mexican food.  Both tasted like they had been boiled... I can say that the food did seem pretty healthy... but that was the only benefit I noticed.

My friend, who joined me in this venture, was far from impressed with his order as well.

Skip it.
author: Lauren R.

description: Fantastic breakfast burritos. Great options for vegetarians. It wasn't too busy the weekend morning we came, but a line had formed just as we were leaving. Good seating outside.
author: Katie L.

description:
One star down for getting my order wrong half the time, despite me repeating it twice, sometimes THREE times.

Another star down for the middle aged woman at the register who I always seem to encounter when I go in. I've never seen her in a good mood, she almost never smiles, and always looks like she just shouldn't be bothered. I've actually AVOIDED going into Green Chile because I just don't feel like dealing with her cranky ass. Fairly sure she's probably the one who gets my orders wrong too. 

That being said, everyone else who's helped me out there has been wonderful. Ariel (I think that's her name?) is especially a sweetheart. It's too bad I encounter this other woman 90% of my visits. Let her go, already! She's bad for business.

Anyway, about the food. The food is good ya'll. Nothing to call home about, but it is consistently tasty and fills me up. I tend to order a naked burrito of some sort or a couple of tamales if I'm not super hungry. The best thing to get here, though, are the breakfast burritos. Bacon, potatoes, eggs, cheese, and salsa. You can't go wrong. And the first bite you take into that releases that molten lava cheesy goodness... hot damn! Never hesitate to go in for one of their breakfast burritos. Cranky McCashier never seems to be around for breakfast/brunch either, which is a definite plus.

All in all, not too bad. Does the job and is conveniently in my hood.
author: A Mandolin D.

description:
I came here with a friend and we each had different opinions about our meals.

On the good side, my friend ordered the chicken dinner for $9.  It came with beans, rice, one tortilla, salsa and your choice of a green salad, chile mashed potatoes, or calabacitas.  It was $1 more for all white meat. He got the dark meat, a nice size leg. He got quite a lot of food for his $9 and thought it was really good.  He'd give it 4 stars.

I, on the other hand, ordered the green chile quesadilla, a side of mashed potatoes, and a watermelon agua fresca.  My total was $19.  The quesadilla had jack cheese, roasted corn, sauteed red onions, green chiles and pico de gallo.  It was $8, two dollars more if you wanted meat.  It was really small and not satisfying at all.  I thought it was quite a rip-off for $8.  And I ordered guacamole with it which should have been 75 cents more but the cashier included it.  I thought that really nice of her until the quesadilla arrived, there was literally 1 teaspoon of guac on top.  If I had paid 75 cents for that I would have felt even more ripped off.

The mashed potatoes were just OK, they sounded special with green chiles and cheese but they really didn't taste any better than plain mashed potatoes.  Kind of bland, I couldn't taste the chiles at all.  At least on mine the cheese was melted, on my friend's they just dropped it on top and it was not melted at all.  But I was glad I got them because that tiny quesadilla didn't fill me up at all.

The watermelon drink was very good, $4, and they let you have one refill for free.  Normally I wouldn't have taken advantage of that but I did because I felt so ripped off on the other items.

Based on my food, I'd give it 2 stars.

So if you come here, choose carefully, the dinners with more things included are a better option.
author: Madeline M.

description: The interior of the place is nice and modern. I had the hard tacos. The ground beef had a good seasoning but they were taco shells. Tasted like a fancy Taco Bell hard shell taco. I expected more. The rice and beans were decent. The refried beans were mashed well but lacked flavor, as if they needed salt. Very bland. Also same goes for the rice. Made well, had the right texture but lacked flavor. Also it is pricey for New Mexican food. The horchata was terrible. The green chile was okay, it had too much juice like salsa and not enough actual green chile. I don't recommend this place unless your desperate. It's not terrible to eat here, it just lacks flavor.
author: jacobo a.

description:
Simple order to go: Rice & bean burrito with guacamole; the guacamole was an up-charge mind you.  Got home ready to devour my burrito and the first thing I notice is the teeny tiny size of my burro - I mean really small!  But it didn't stop there.  The first half of this little burrito was pure rice.  It wasn't until the second half of my kid-sized micro burrito that I got to the beans!  That prompted me to wonder if they had forgotten the guacamole I paid for.  Well, I found the guacamole in the last 10% of my micro burrito.  About a teaspoons worth of the stuff folded in the butt end of the burrito :(
I really can't say how disappointed I am especially since I have liked this place since its inception on the corner of Baker & Fulton.  For this child size meal which included chips & salsa I paid $11 - boo!  Very bad - No bueno!  In it's defense, the flavor was still as good as ever but the value was very bad.  It's as if they were so busy they forgot the quality and value parts of the restaurant experience.  Guess I have to find a new burrito spot :(
author: Fred F.

description:
4 for food but 2 for service- they were really rude. 

Everything we had was really great food-wise- from the chicken enchiladas to the tamales, to the wine. 

However, they were super crowded and the woman taking our order had a lot of attitude- which was pretty unfortunate.
author: Mary S.

description:
Full disclosure -- I live close by and eat here a lot. Like, a LOT.  It's my go-to, my fall-back, my 'I'm in need of real comfort food' place.  I can't tell you how many times I've eaten here, but it's more than 50 and less than 100.  I love the food.  Excellent New Mexican style eats, and the spicy green chile is da bomb. Fresh, high-quality meats and other ingredients really show through in GCK's preparations. I've never had even mediocre food here.  When they added Torpedo IPA on tap I was over the moon.  So why 4 stars and not 5 you say?  Service.  More often than should be the case, there have been mix ups on orders, slow, occasionally surly, and not so occasionally seemingly stoned staff behind the register.  The register staff  rotate frequently, to the detriment of the overall experience. It's too bad that in the 6 years I've been coming here they haven't been able to get consistently good staff at the 'front of house.'  Of course the same faces have been making the food for the past six years, so it is the same, outstanding, consistently delicious food.  I LOVE this place.  

ps -- I do sometimes miss the snug and cozy former space, which was a real refuge on foggy nights.  While I like the new space, it doesn't have the same warmth (literally).
author: Catherine N.

description: Best Breakfast Steak Burrito I ever had!  Customer Service is great and We are happy they are a part of our community :)
author: Davey J.

description: Good Southwestern food. They're known for their Posole, and it was quite tasty. Also got a sweet potato tamale. The filling was excellent, but as with most tamales, the ratio of filling to corn shell skewed too much to the shell for my taste.
author: Rachel B.

description:
Oh, the novices writing reviews and calling this food Mexican.  Even the menu says it isn't Mexican, and I assume if you can write a review, you can also read, right?  

If you can't tell already, I take my chile seriously.  And that is no typo - we New Mexicans spell chile with an "e."  There is a big difference between Mexican and New Mexican food.  Call me a snob, sure.  But its almost the same as confusing Chinese and Vietnamese, and you wouldn't do that, right?  

New Mexican food features green and red chile - arguably some of the best varieties of the pepper on the planet and Green Chile Kitchen does a great job offering a menu that boasts excellent combinations of both.  The green chile stew is fantastic.  The red chile chicken enchiladas were outstanding.  If you have never had a sopapilla, douse it with honey and enjoy the ensuing tongue-gasm you will have.  Best of all is they now sell frozen chile - 5 lb. bags.  I'll clean one of those up a month.  

They have a limited beer and wine selection, so while you're there, try the Gruet wines.  They're no Napa or Sonoma wines, but NM still has decent wines of their own.  

The restaurant is always clean, the staff is always friendly and the restrooms are clean, too, for those of you not quite used to the chile yet!  

One of my newest favorites in the city.
author: Sean O.

description: Ordered food from here from Try Caviar. I like how there are unique vegetarian options here (but I guess it's a norm for fancy Mexican restaurants?). Anyway, they have tamales stuffed with sweet potatoes (yum!) and peppers stuffed with quinoa (I think you can tell that I like things stuffed haha!). My coworker also really liked their salads so, a plus in my eyes!
author: Christina C.

description:
been wanting to try this place for a while, finally got around to it. 
convinced the gf to do the wiggle on the tandem bike to go out to dinner on a saturday night. 
crowded, as expected, I mean, it was saturday night. 
seating was tight, but we managed a spot at one of the communal tables. fine with me. 
ordering was straight up, counter style, then they give you a number & bring your food when ready. 

I got the bowl of green chili stew, with 2 sopaipillas. 
it was pretty good, not exactly like NM, but pretty close. straight up hatch chili, which was fine. the sopaipillas were very good, pretty much my main reason for going here. 
gf had the veggie quesadilla, she said it was bland. It had some zucchini in there. The side of hot sauce it came with was pretty good, and made the thing much better. 

2 beers on top of that and it came to $27, which was reasonable. 

too many kids running around, but that is probably why they go there. 

not quite a 4 star joint, but what gives them the extra star was the guy taking my order was so super nice, and seemed really happy that I liked the sopaipillas. 

we'll go there again to try the frito pie and some dessert. 

tip: draft beer is $5 but bottle beer is $2
author: Adrian M.

description: Best horchata I've had in the US! Freshly ground cardamom on top? Yes, please! Major props for the free range eggs. To many restaurants support factory farming. The food was awesome and at least partly organic ("where possible and not cost restrictive"). I will def come back again.
author: Robin T.

description:
I've always thought their burritos were pretty good.  A little on the bougie side, but delicious.  Then, last week I got the green chile stew, which made my mind up about this place.  It was precisely what I was craving on an sf summer night (read: cold as eff night).  In a strange way, it reminded me of a bizarro chicken noodle soup.  Instead of chicken there's pork, instead of noodle there are tortillas, and instead of soup, it's...green chile stew?  I guess they're actually not really alike at all, except in their abilities to put comfort in my stomach.  Anyway NOM.

This place also somehow manages to be both family friendly and a little hip at the same time.  Take that, Hometown Buffet.
author: jon y.

description: First time here.  Quiet a pain to get a table as it is a small place and self seating.  But wow oh wow.  We got chips and salsa to start. The salsa was fantastic!  And also had the half chicken and was amazingly good.  Excellent seasoning and juicy!!  Wish they had a host doing assigned seating when it is busy.  It's too stressful on the customer to fight over tables.   But I will be back.  Most likely for take out if it is busy.
author: Daniel A.

description: Sunday Brunch was easy.  Service was friendly and quick.  Food was nicely plated, satisfied our appetites, with the Veggie Roasted Hash, the Migas, and two Breakfast Bowls, bacon/pork.  We'll be back for more.
author: Geri S.

description: Always on the hunt for veggie tacos. These are okay, not great, but I do love their guacamole. I'd easily go back if someone else suggested it, but for the price it's never at the top of my list.
author: Megan S.

description:
I've been on the hunt for a chill mexican food spot in my hood in SF and I think this just might be it! Walk in (generally wait in line for a minutes, but spend your time looking over the menus, good and drink, and making a choice meal selection), order your food and drink, take your number and hunt down a spot to eat. Nice and easy. 

Now, in regards to the food- mine was great. I had the stuffed burrito and it was evenly filled with chicken, cheese and beans, covered in chili and served with sides. So good! 

The atmosphere is chill, the music was a bit wack but whatever. I will be going back to this spot again, for sure!
author: Shanna T.

description: Green chili stew is soooo good! Everything on the menu is super fresh made with high quality, organic food! I've had brunch, lunch, dinner, take-out and catering for special events from the Green Chili Kitchen and Chili Pies and am always thrilled with the taste and quality! Thursday evenings at the bar in the Green Chili Kitchen are my favorite! I go there for the great food and excellent service from the bartender, Miche!
author: Ally W.

description: I'm regular again, as they've stepped their game up, making sure orders are correct, and added a to go line!!!!!
author: Aaron O.

description:
I found this place while biking around SF. A few friends made the trip up for an event at Golden Gate park, and ended up following a couple as they were leaving on their bikes. They were fast! When we finally caught a light, I asked them where to eat, and they directed me to Green Chile Kitchen. 

I ordered the Super Steak Burrito (They have a fancier name for it) and I thought it tasted great! We also got some of their specialty pie (don't remember what it was called, sorry!) and it was divine. 

All in all, a great place, I'd definitely go there again. If the random cycling couple sees this, Thanks! You guys were a blast to follow through the park! Awesome quick pace!
author: Jesse D.

description: Little more expensive than the average burrito joint, but the ingredients are definitely higher quality and more fresh. Also has good selection of salads and sides, if you want some alternative Mexican dishes other than just tacos and burritos. Definitely my go-to Mexican spot for takeout in NOPA.
author: John M.

description:
GCK hits it out of the park on almost everything. Note that if you're looking for a leisurely meal, valet parking, fine wine or a huge menu selection, GCK isn't it. But if you're looking for the best taqueria food, mod and clean surroundings not the usual tac-dinge, a "hit the spot" beer and a place to refuel kids without them driving you nuts and/or embarrassing you, this is the place. I wish they had carnitas but the beef and chicken are fab. My fave is the carne adovada which is often listed as a special but then they pointed out was actually on the regular menu. 

Definitely the place for a burrito and a pie for desert.
author: Rachel H.

description:
I love green chile!  I love it!.  I'm sure if you've read my previous reviews you know that there's a distinct difference between Colorado green chile and the California-style "chile" we generally get out here.  

Well, if you want to understand what I love about CO green chile, then this is the place for you!  They serve it up in a bowl as a stew with tortillas, just the way I like it.  It could be a little thicker in consistency, but other than that, it's quite nice.  I like to go here on a reasonably regular basis and enjoy a bowl with a nice modelo.

NOTE - the tacos here are only average at best.  But I don't go here for them, nor do I care :)  The green chile bowl is where it's at.
author: Nicholas N.

description:
Green chili can become a serious addiction.  In New Mexico it is a way of life.  I was thrilled but not surprised when I learned that a restaurant in San Francisco opened that claimed to have NM GC.  While holding true to having NM chili, being a NM native, this place misses the mark when it comes to authenticity.  
Their chicken is great but as far as the "NM" dishes, all they do is make me home sick.
I'm fortunate to have a source for green chili when my supplies run out but going into GCK, don't expect a true NM meal.
Maybe it's because I'm used to GC being used with such freedom that when when I get charged an extra $2 for a ramekin of enchilada sauce, I can't help but feel like I'm getting hosed.
But once a green chili addict....
See you in line prospecting for a table.
author: John W.

description:
Loved it.  I love New Mexican food.  Love green chiles.  The burrito was fantastic.  They even had tofu for us veggie types as a filling.  

My one complaint:  MORE GREEN chile sauce.  I want to drown my burrito in it.  Next time, I'll know to ask for extra.  

The sangria was ok - I've had better, but who can complain about sangria?

I'll certainly be back. 

Parking is a bitch.  Don't drive.
author: Jim P.

description: This is a really good spot to bring vegetarian friends/family to. They have a large offering of tasty vegetarian dishes. No worries, meat-eaters (like myself) are welcome too. The 7-layer dip is delicious. It can be a meal on its own. The green chili soup is great as well with blue corn tortillas for dipping. I was told it's spicy, but it wasn't - at least not for someone who loves spicy food. The place has community seating so be prepared and open to sitting with strangers. It's definitely not your average corner taqueria - it's fancy Mexican food, if you will.
author: Joy M.

description:
Their green chile stew is perfect for a sick day, especially since it's only a few blocks away from my apartment.  It's got plenty of tasty green chiles to help clear those sinuses.

Their breakfast burrito with chorizo is the best in town.
author: jane d.

description:
I'm a huge fan of New Mexican-style food.  If I don't hear "Red or Green?" when I order my food, something is definitely missing.  If would help if there was a basket of sopapillas and a side of honey handy too.

The Green Chile Kitchen comes close enough and is a very good alternative to driving all the way to New Mexico to get my fix.  Although there wasn't a sopapilla in sight, the red chile ristra's, the Kia logo, and the beloved "Red or Green?" question were welcome and appreciated touches.  So too was the well-appointed and comfortable(albeit small) space with friendly staff, good beer and a better than expected wine selection.  However, I still do miss Maria's New Mexican Kitchen in Santa Fe.

I had a chicken burrito (red) which was fresh and delicious.  The square plate and the tasty blue corn chips were also nice touches and there was more than enough food to make me happy.  The prices were also reasonable and the food was out relatively quickly.

I was here for a Friday lunch and because of "street sweeping" from 12-2, parking might be more challenging than usual.
author: Eric B.

description:
I can't wait to come back here.  FIRST of all, $2 Pacificos forever!  I didn't even get one because I didn't see until too late.  But they also have other yummy beers (like Racer 5) and even kombucha on tap.

I went with my friend Anne Marie before a show at the Fillmore.  I got the chili rellenos and they were fantastic and quite filling.  I really enjoyed the scenery, the staff were super nice, and the atmosphere was lively.  My friend very much enjoyed her meal and by the end were were stuffed (though not too stuffed to not split a piece of pie down the street at Chili Pies and Ice Cream, same owners).

Some criticisms would be that is was rather loud, and worrying about being able to get a seat is kind of nerve wracking, but even on a Friday at 8pm there seemed to be enough for everyone.  I would add some sound baffles and try to squeeze a few more tables in somehow.  Or maybe just go on a weeknight.
author: Kyle T.

description:
IMPORTANT POINT:  
This is not a mexican restaurant or mission burrito place or a taco truck.  If you are looking for a mission burrito, go back to the Mission.  

This is not "americanized" mexican food.  It is food from NEW MEXICO. It's regional cuisine from the Southwest.  THIS IS A "NEW MEXICAN" RESTAURANT!  

This place honors and celebrates the magic of the New Mexico green chile.  Folks, if you focus on the green chile, you will leave completed blissed out and buzzed from the chiles. 

To folks who have lived, visited, or had friends/family/co-workers from New Mexico -- green chile is like CRACK.  You want more, you can't get enough, you crave it constantly, and it gets you high.  Green chile is a state of mind, a cultural experience, and a sense of community.

I think to really understand this place. . . you should always order to Green Chile Stew (pork or chicken).  Especially if this is your first experience with green chiles.  For $7.95, you get a huge bowl of this magical concoction.  Each spoonful will make you more and more blissed out.  I actually tried to tip the bowl into my mouth so I could get the last chile goodness but it's shallow shape doesn't work so well for pouring into your mouth.  I had to tilt the bowl and use my spoon and my sopapilla to mop up the last dregs.

Green chile stew will heal the winter blues, PMS, hangovers, hipster melancholy, parental anxiety, and political apathy (well, this one may be incurable).

I leave the place hyper, turned on, giddy and buzzed from the chiles.  

There's so much more I can rave about but after reading other reviews, I feel it's my duty as a chile loving citizen, to straighten out the misconceptions about this place.  Green Chile is the medicine you've been lookin' for. . .

P.S.  I also appreciate that this is child-friendly restaurant.  I love seeing the little people enjoying food, being out with their parents, sharing space with us "the adults."  If that's not cool for you, go back to the Mission.

P.P.S This place is not expensive!  The ingredients are HIGH QUALITY, local and organic.  If you want cheap, go back to your favorite burrito place or taco truck.
author: Freida N.

description: This is classic New Mexican food. It's good for what it is - great guac (which is not New Mexican) and yummy tamales. I don't like chillies but that's what makes New Mexican food what it is. Husband said it was great. Ask for it Christmas, don't pick red or green, get both! Beans could use more flavor. Great margs!
author: Emily K.

description:
If you are really hungry and can't muster down a walk further away to Papalote (on Fulton at Masonic) then come here because they do have a cozy ambiance that fits groups or individuals comfortably.  I have come here a handful of times but i can't say its a great place.  It takes awhile to get your food, the food can sometimes taste a little bland and it isn't cheap. 

I can only recommend: their blue corn tortilla tacos for dinner and any breakfast burrito.  

I also dont recommend ordering their mexican hot chocolate ($5).  I'm not sure how many people order this, but they should either have a disclaimer that it takes about 20 minutes to prepare or pay better attention when a customer orders this unique item on the menu.  I tried ordering the other day and it seemed as if they had forgotten, and my friend had a similar experience.  Perhaps they had forgotten about the order or maybe it does take a long time to prepare, but for a bustling restaurant, its a little surprising  and disappointing and they should set clearer expectations.
author: Leslie U.

description: Classic California casual style restaurant with amazing Mexican/Tex-Mex cuisine. We were there with a large group heard everyone raving about their dishes and I didn't loved everything I tasted. The roasted chiles with salt and lime are awesome although they vary in heat so be prepared. My first few were mild and I got a huge bite of an extremely hot one. Fortunately the nice selection of beer cooled my aching mouth. I had the chile relleno and it was just as good as the authentic Mexican food I'm used too back at home (Southern California). Would highly recommend the green chile kitchen to anyone who loves good Mexican cooking!
author: Mike C.

description: I dont know what all the fuss is about. Yes the menu is different than the usual fare around town and The food is good but not great, not by far. And it is very pricey...for mexican. They dont wait on you. You get your own water and silverware. But then it seems everything is pricey in the city nowadays. Even mediocre places such as this. Two and a half stars.
author: fred h.

description: Portions getting smaller. Seasoning kind of bland. God awful house red wine. Stick to the basics.
author: Priscilla C.

description: Great new style mexican. Margaritas are prob the best ever...very strong. Enchilada was amazing. Fast service but very loud atmosphere.
author: D T.

description:
Okay.  

Maybe it isn't *the* most authentic New Mexican style place around. especially if you have actually been to New Mexico and have a basis for comparison.  

But....
they fly in their chile from New Mexico...
and you can buy a 5 lb bag (BUENO) for $35.00

I went today (thank you Yelp well really Kati K. ) and decided on the green chiile enchilada (blue corn tortillas).  Lika Maya to Mexican, Green Chile Kitchen is above all an upscale version but...

they only had the mild green chile when I went, consider what might happen when we get to the medium green chile..

it was good enought to make my heart go pitter patter...and good it was.  Now when I get a hankerin for my green chile fix, I will head here.

Plus they have a family night, not only 1/2 off the kids burritto but 1/2 a glass of wine for the brave parents....

Plus they will bring your "to go" order to the curb......

Lastly, they will ask "Red, Green or Christmas....?"  If you know what this means.....you'll be right at home here.  What more could you want...Okay, okay.  Eating green chile enchiladas while watching the sun set over the sandia mountains, that would be better.
author: Tracie P.

description:
Have been a neighborhood fan of this place since they opened but went yesterday and am convinced they've reduced their portion size...Same price for a burrito...smaller burrito. They're already on the pricey side so this will definitely make me think twice before going back. 

Has anyone else noticed this?
author: Pamela S.

description:
Delicious! I love this place!!! Yummmmmmy! 

Try the enchilada combo plate...  Or really anything on the menu! I have never had a complaint about anything I have ordered. 

Breakfast! 

The one star deduction is for too few vegetarian options, but I LOVE this place!
author: Jeannette F.

description: The food is nothing special. Had some overcooked carnitas that were recommended to me. Nice decor and 2$ beers is a plus, but you probably won't catch me back anytime soon. Oh, and getting charged a buck for a tortilla after I didn't like the sopapilla (sp?) didn't help their cause either. I'll stick with papalote and nopalito.
author: Alex G.

description:
This place was awesome...I got a naked burrito (oh yea) and it was pretty on point...the meat wasn't made of crushed cinder blocks, and the rice, pico de gallo, and the other stuff didn't seem like they were from a lego set...AND...it tasted awesome...for me thats a Sheen Win...haha...i tried their Wheat Monkey Ale and that was a perfect fit for my burrito...also they have Blue Bottle coffee there so that's also a Sheen Win for me (for all your B-fast peeps)...i'll definitely go back again because they have stuff that I want to eat for a decent price :)

MUCH LOVE & BEATZ
author: Indy N.

description:
The stew. Oh dear Jesus, the stew.

I was feeling pretty under the weather last week but somehow mustered up the energy to meet up with a friend I hadn't seen in a few weeks for dinner. We got to Green Chile Kitchen and I was immediately grateful that I didn't have to sit at a table and wait for a waiter and all that non-sense. 

Walked up, ordered, waited a short hot minute(s), and ate delicious green chile chicken stew that was exactly what I needed on a cold evening to soothe my violent sniffling. 

I felt pretty rejuvenated after the steaming pile of Mexican Goodness warmed my insides; essentially TheraFlu with hot peppers. Delicious.
author: Krystha B.

description:
We come here pretty regularly, as it's a great place to go with rugrats.  Totally kid friendly, with special menu offerings, a couple high chairs, and a generally chaotic atmosphere which means that nobody really notices when Junior has a meltdown or throws food.

The food is quite tasty - nothing mind-blowing, but solid New Mexic-esque offerings, well-executed.  Great rotisserie chicken, decent enchiladas, nice brunch dishes and good salads.

The big opportunity to improve is the service.  We typically go for weekend lunches, when it's super-busy, and they don't seem equipped to manage the crowds.  Today - a typical weekend lunch -  the line to order was out the door, and the wait for food was about 20 - 30 minutes, even though everything is pretty much pre-prepared.   Half of the tables needed to be bussed, so people were circling the restaurant, in some cases cleaning up the dirty tables themselves.  Used dishes were stacked up all over - the bar, the window sills - which is kinda unpleasant.

I'm sure we'll continue to be regulars, but I hope they can get the service thing under control - it would make for a much nicer experience.
author: Katy M.

description:
Summary: Decent, not-too-expensive mains. Killer apple pie. Chill atmosphere.

Came here with a friend on a Mon. night around 8 PM - had some people in there but wasn't crowded. Decor was nice - laid back, chill, communal and individual tables.

Meals cost us about $12 each (1/2 chicken and sides, enchilada and sides). Food was solid. Nothing spectacular, but not bad.

The apple pie though was killer. Cheddar cheese crust, jalapenos, apple filling. Definitely worth the trip within itself.

Would come back again for the apple pie, probably not for anything else.
author: Gary Y.

description:
This place is Grr-eat! I love mexican food so this place is perfect, although I often forget that it exists  when I am in the mood for mexican... which may be good or else I would be here every day.

My wife has the rotisserie chicken every time we go there. She loves that rotisserie chicken. I've had the chicken enchilada and the pork burrito both were exceptional choices. Also, the sopaipillas are addicting and brings back fond childhood memories of Casa Bonita.
author: Steve K.

description:
The pozole and most of their stews are excellent. However, most of the other stuff has been pretty average. The burritos are more tortilla than anything else. Although I get the feeling that all their ingredients are ultra-fresh, most of the food comes out tasting almost a little too homemade. If I think I could produce what came out on the plate at home, I'm not sure I should be paying to eat it. The menu is quite large, so maybe I just haven't hit on the right things yet. 

The service is above average, and they have 2 beers for $2 specials. Can't beat that. The seating is kind of a lurking grab whatever opens up system, so if you come when it's crowded (which is pretty often), you might end up squeezing in with some other people. This can be a good thing at the big communal table. The tables do seem to turnover pretty quickly, though.
author: Saunders C.

description:
This place was a few blocks from my friend's place, so we decided to check it out. This was the first New Mexican food restaurant I came across other than the ones actually in New Mexico, and I was quite happy to find one since I love New Mexican food. 

I ordered a New Mexican Homestyle Chicken Enchilada Plate with Christmas Sauce (Green and Red Chile), and it was pretty darn good! It came with some lettuce, beans, and rice. The chicken was cooked perfectly too very very moist. I think the portions are a bit on the smaller side, but hey, for a person that can't eat American sized portions, this was perfect! I also really liked the sour cream for some reason. It was very rich and creamy, and kind of tasted like cream cheese. 

We came on a super sunny day in the city, and the restaurant had all their windows open. It was nice to feel the sun light in the restaurant while enjoying a delicious meal. 

Definitely coming back again.
author: Ayaka S.

description:
after having a friend recommend this place and heading to watch a show at the independent, we were super happy with the experience.

the margaritas were a good balance of alcohol and lime juice/sweetness!

chips and salsa
we had the 4 different salsas. great options!

carne adovado
black beans and a sopapilla
super tasty! really nice flavors and portions

mary's rotisserie chicken
I chose the 1/4 chicken full meal of rice, black beans, tortillas and salsa with the green chile mashed potatoes (no cheese)
the chicken was tender and flavorful, the beans and rice were perfectly seasoned and the mashed potatoes were a good yet random addition. i felt like i got soul food and new mexican food all in one.

Service was fine- things got a bit busier after we ordered and sat down. but overall, pleasant experience!
author: Jamie R.

description:
Not a bad place.
