But if you are from New Mexico and travel a good distance (I live on the other side of the city) to get here or are highly anticipating a meal like home, you will be disappointed like I was.  First of all, the organization - wait in line, pay before you eat, then take a number and go to whatever spot you can find on a picnic table and wait.  And wait.  And wait.  No tv's, no atmosphere, just wait for your food at uncomfortable seating.  I understand the concept - it works to promote high turnover if you have limited seating, but for the concept to work , your kitchen has to keep up and theirs does not.  The meal was incredibly slow - 30 minutes to arrive and I was literally flagging down the staff for a box when the appetizer I ordered with my meal arrived.  Not enough waitstaff is another problem, but they have been trained - when I needed silverware and condiments they were nowhere to be found, but when I was at the bottom of my $7 beer, they appeared like magic to sell me another one.  So - minus one star for the manager or owner who doesn't know shit about running a restaurant.

If you want high turnover great - but you can't have a Chipoltle's atmosphere and have high prices - my second minus.  One of the keys to New Mexico cooking is that it is cheap to prepare.  My dinner consisted of some cubed pork, red chile spice, corn starch, wheat flour, pinto beans, rice, lettuce, tomato and onion.  About $3 worth of ingredients when bought in bulk.  So charging me $35 for the meal is outrageous.  I understand this is the big city and prices are high, but it's still a rip off.  If I am dropping $70 on a meal for two, there better be some frigging table service and a waiter.
  
Then the food itself - average.  Red chile was pretty good, on the low end of hot.  The pinto beans were a bit al dente.  The sopailpillas(sp) were too thick, greasy and heavy.  If you are from NM - better than Garduno's, about the same as Tortilla Flats (which is 1/3 the price) and nowhere near as good as Sadie's.  So if you are from NM and want a taste of home, you will probably come anyway and deal with all the hassle.  I would go again and order take out, or try on a Wednesday afternoon with no crowd, but i won;t go out of my way to return.
author: Ken P.

description: Roasted chicken has come cold on occasion. Love the crispy chicken taco plate and posole. Guacamole feels over priced at $8.
author: Frankie W.

description:
Recipe for a culinary fiesta in your mouth...get up early on a Saturday (I know, I know...) run 8 miles and climb 1,700 feet on the trails of the Marin Headlands, go straight to Green Chili Kitchen, brave the madness of the line and order the eggs w/enchiladas + a Blue Star beer on tap. Done. That's all I've got for you...bliss.

tip: if you're "two" and encumbered by a car, drop one to order and secure a table while the other searches for parking.
author: Gary C.

description:
Every time I pass Green Chile Kitchen on my way to the bus stop, I pause for a second outside its doors and inhale deeply. *Sniff*. "Aaaahhhh." Spicy aromas abound as I happily skip to the 5!

The truth? It smells a lot better than it tastes. Yeah.

Not that it's all bad. I recall having bought a burrito to go from there a couple times and  vaguely remember enjoying it as I lounged in front of the TV. However, it must not have been good ENOUGH, since I always seem to gravitate back towards my marinated tofu burrito at Papalote (God bless you), which is also close to my house but not AS close. I figure that if Green Chile is on my actual corner but I've only frequented it a few times then it must be just so-so.

To give the place a fair review, I actually ate in about a week ago, opting for the New Mexican homestyle chicken enchilada plate with blue corn tortillas and HOT salsa. Having read other reviews of this place, I wanted a sample of authentic New Mexican cuisine, to see if my tastebuds could handle those homegrown chile peppers. The result? Again, not bad, not good. Just ok. And it wasn't even *that* hot. I was kind of disappointed. 

It IS pretty cute and cozy inside, though. And the rest of the neighborhood seems to like this place a lot--it was POPPIN' on a Thursday night! Line out the door. I was confused. To see so much activity going on right down the block from my house was surprising, but cool. I wonder, sometimes.
author: Kate V.

description: One thing, I like about this place is when they say vegetarian, it doesnt mean JUST bean and cheese. They put zucchini and fun things. Very good. I would recommend both locals and tourists.
author: Kara S.

description: Love the vibe, cute little place, had the pork tamales and the pasole and it was amazing. loved sitting next to the open windows and watching a great city and people watching! Visiting from Miami and finding such a cool place that was of the beaten path made our trip
author: Shane A.

description:
On the plus side, this is the only authentic New Mexican restaurant I've found in the Bay Area.  They use real New Mexico chiles and you'll find most of the dishes you'd expect in Santa Fe: sopapillas, green chile stew, et. al.

The problem with this place, for me, is the spice level.  It's really, really mild.  They only seem to use the mild variety of Hatch chiles in anything, and the variety of spice levels (and ripeness) in the different chile sauces was one of the things I loved most about New Mexico. 

HOWEVER, you can buy their frozen, chopped, green chiles to go at a cheaper price than you can typically order them from Hatch through the mail ($8/lb vs. $12/lb).  Thus, while I don't actually eat here that often, I do come all the time to buy chiles to make green chile stew at home, where I can pump the spice up to wherever I feel like.
author: Patrick Z.

description: The food was essentially solid, a little bland and unappetizing around the edges.  Ordered the tamales and enchiladas. Unless you're desperate for Mexican and drop in in the neighborhood I'd go elsewhere.
author: Liz S.

description: literally 2 blocks from my house and the beer isn't expensive and the food is pretty good. what's not to like? I guess it's a tad expensive but it does taste mad fresh and they took my word on a beer not being delivered to me and obliged my quickly
author: Misha T.

description:
If you are expecting Mexican cuisine, you came to the wrong place. 
This is New Mexican and it should have a category all it's own! 

I came here the other day, after seeing this in 
Chronicle's Bargain Bites. 

Their green chili is awesome! I like it mild, but my dining companion likes his hot and loved his too. We shared a cup of Pozole, and it was wonderful. I would come back just for this, but the rest of the meal was equally good. 

Beef taco, green chicken enchilada served with rice and beans. Really hit the spot. I would go back if I was in the neighborhood. Parking was pretty easy during an early lunch hour.
author: Colleen B.

description: I lived n New Mexico prior to moving to cali for 6 years and this place is a god send. Food is exactly the same.  I'm in heaven.
author: Joshua D.
Christine B.

description: Cute neighborhood restaurant with a "order at the front then seat yourself " service. Food and sangria was delicious. Highly recommend the pork quesidillas and pork tacos.
author: Kelly C.

description:
NOT A GOOD REPRESENTATION OF NEW MEXICAN FOOD (except for the stew).

I'm going to come back here for the breakfast burrito that changed Dan L.'s life. They stop serving breakfast at 10 AM and they don't serve the burger until after 5PM, so it was kind of frustrating.

We tried the beef steak burrito with green chile sauce, as well as the green chili pork stew.

To be honest, the burrito was just whatever. The green chili salsa dip was delicious and the stew would make me come back for it. SO, if you are going there, try the stew.

The atmosphere of the restaurant was fun and it was nice decorated with pretty affordable prices.
author: Katherine F.

description: I live a few blocks from Green Chile and find myself going often.  A few of my standards are the fantastic posole, the green chile stew and the sopaipillas!  They're all made on site, large portions and so delicious.  I'm also a huge fan of the big blue chicken salad - try it with the cotija dressing.  The service is efficient and sweet and their sister store - Green Chile Pies - will fix your sweet tooth afterwards.
author: W D.

description:
Great stuff. Not excellent.

Roast Chicken is awesome.  Burittos are above average.  $3 pacifico's?  Can't go wrong.

Brunch is also great.

Only problem is you come out of there smelling like the place for the entire day - have to wash clothes - cannot wear again.
author: Walker C.

description:
Went for dinner this past friday night with the Bf and had a nice time. Exquisite is the resident crazy hobo outside in a red shiny shortie jacket loudly cursing at the straw statue behind the cashier. Very angry and very schizophrenic. Mission charm, I suppose. 

Some say that authentic Mexican food is just about taste and not fancy schmancy presentation. I violently disagree. I was about to keel over and chew on the wooden tables after being stuck in rush hour bay bridge traffic, and I still remember that my plate looked like the vomirrhea of the homeless people outside the heavy wooden doors of this establishment. The 4 corners of my square plate each featured a nice heap of lumpy brown-dark-greenish mash, and at the center was my entree, looking equally depressing. Wop-wop.

This place lost a star for the disgusting soggy mess they tried to sell me as Chile Rellenos. There's something wrong with enjoying everything on my chile relleno combo plate more than the headlining chile rellenos. And the sides were quite excellent - they had this red finely diced salsa that really hit the spot and was very zesty and the potatoes and beans all outshined the star player. Still not great for the price - I've come to expect good Mexican food in SF at wholesale prices, so $16 for this fugly food seemed unfair. 
But Bf had the signature green chile pork burrito and was a huge fan, so maybe I just ordered wrong. 

But I actually do plan to return to try out the intriguing dessert menu, so maybe I'll add that star back. And instead take it away for the mythological parking opportunities in this neighborhood.

Ambiance: low key but not comfy. Urban picnic setup and felt kind of cafeteria-style. Chairs are hard and plastic and bare-minimum, and condiments and water and utensils are self-serve. Not a huge fan of having to seat ourselves and awkwardly stand around until tables cleared up. Staff is very friendly tho.
author: Atticus L.

description:
I've been here several times and will keep coming.  Have tried various burritos and they've all been great.  Comes with rice and beans so makes for plenty of food.  Got some chips and salsa one time as an appetizer because I was hungry, and while good, kept me from eating everything.  I've also tried to pozole which is great for cold/rainy nights.  My girlfriend prefers the chicken stew, which she gets every time without fail.

Took a bunch of friends here and they all raved about how much they liked it (and I think most of them have been back again since).  The only issues with this place is finding a seat during busy times and parking in the area if you drive.
author: Ken L.

description:
3.5 stars, for now

I've only recently been here once, and will probably update my review and up my rating if this place appeals to me again, but as of now I don't know enough about the rest of the dishes to give it a whopping 4+ stars.

Per the hundreds of other yelp comments, I tried the breakfast burrito with chorizo with both red and green chile sauces ("christmas" for an extra $1). You can also add sour cream, guacamole and cheese for $1.50. The red sauce was tasty, but the green sauce blew me away! What I love about these types of sauces is that it doesn't have that one-dimensional "spicy" spice that stings your taste buds and hits you all at once, but is more of an underlying and slowly-developing heat that adds another layer of flavor to the dish. The burrito wasn't drowning in sauce, which it should NOT be!

All-in-all great, close, and reasonably priced. I can't wait to go back and try their stew!
author: Ronald T.

description: Delicious vegan options, good service, & a relaxed atmosphere. Recommended (especially the sweet potato tamales and red chime tofu burrito)!
author: D. B.

description:
OK I am being a little more realistic and bumping my previous review down one star.  The lines to order are ridiculous during the dinner rush.  There has to be someway they can speed up the process.  They also ran out of the enchiladas the other night after I ordered and waited  5 mins before they let me know.

I tied the New Mexican Burrito with Christmas (Green and Red Chili).  I don't really like the red chili.  

But I can't give them a lower rating because their food is still of so good.
author: Danny P.

description: When I need a New Mexico Chili fix its nice to have this place around the corner. I have been a little underwhelmed with the dishes as a whole though.
author: Kelso H.

description: good quality food. Service was ok. Concept could use some work. Chips and salsa served with food, as opposed to during wait. Also ordered guacamole with my burrito and received about enough to enjoy with 3 bites. Overall value wasn't amazing.
author: Aaron M.

description:
WHAT HAPPENED to this place?
This used to be a great go to for salad with fresh roasted chicken and always something really nice for the kids, USED to be made the way you want to eat - fresh and well thought out.

I could not even take one bite of what they just put in front of me - uninspired greens with a hot STEAMING glop of wet looking white (boiled?) chopped stuff on it.
When I looked appalled the waiter claimed they were "out of chicken" so this is the chicken  (what?) -  It looked exactly like what we feed our dogs on top of their kibble.  Still so revolted, I just had to leave. But assuredly not
 one of them cared.
author: nicole s.

description: This food was really tasty. 5 stars reserved for things I crave and I'm really craving the appetizer pork tamale with green chili sauce. The vegetarian red chili tofu burrito was delicious as well with its red sauce blanket. I'm also craving the homey atmosphere. When they say kitchen, it means it looks like a bigger version of someone's New Mexico kitchen/ dining room area. Just lovely. Went for chili icecream around the corner for desert!
author: Adrian A.

description:
Fresh and good,

I've never really had authentic southwestern food before, but I was told this was the place to go. I really liked the blue corn flat enchilada, nice and cheesy. The atmosphere is nice too, laid back but you feel like you're eating in a church pew. One of the best sit down Latin restaurants in the city, in my opinion.
author: Asa S.

description:
While the food is probably a 4 star, the rude cashier warrants a perfect zero at this order and pay at the register restaurant.   We ordered apple pie for dessert and were asked if we wanted whipped cream (that would be no.)   When she shared the total amount due and it seemed a little high I asked to see the bill.    She explained we would be charged extra for ice cream (which later did not come on the pie.  WTF?   Since the menu showed apple pie both with and without ice cream (2 different prices) after we finished I revisited why we were charged extra for something we didn't want.
Her condoscending and rude response suggested she was not aware that everyone does not celebrate being overcharged for purchases.  If you visit here, count your change.
author: David R.

description:
In the aftermath of Hardly Strictly Bluegrass, my small group of 3 hit up Green Chile Kitchen this past Sunday night. Our first choices, Little Chihuahua, Nopalito and Ragazza had enormous wait lists, so we thought GCK would be a good option for some fast mexican. Boy were we wrong.

Let me first say that the food at GCK has never been stellar. Their burritos are the best things on the menu. I've tried their soft tacos (gross), salads (yawn) and enchiladas (meh). Each time, I think I'll find some hidden gem but I have yet to be impressed. This time, I went for the veggie burrito and a cup of green chile stew. My bf got the nachos and my friend, a smothered burrito plate.

The service and wait killed me. We waited 40 minutes from placing our order until it was ready. Let me say that again, 40 minutes. I could have gone to New Mexico and made my own green chile stew. We watched our nachos get fried under the broiler when the cook forgot them and then watched him get huffy when we asked for new ones. When we mentioned our wait time to the girl working the register we got a thanks for waiting and we're doing the best we can. My friend asked for a bag of chips as a courtesy and we were told that she could lose her job if she were to give away free chips. Really? Rude. 

Overall the food at GCK is not worth the bad service and wait. Definitely avoid this place after any event in GGP and beware the salty staff. The kitchen is anything but efficient. Was there a silver lining to the whole evening (besides Sharon Jones and time with my sugs)? Indeed there was, I finally had something really tasty here: the green chile stew. Delicious!
author: Corey F.

description:
I came here for dinner last night with my brother.  The place was just starting to fill up for the dinner rush, but we were lucky to get 2 seats at the bar tables by the window.

My brother ordered the new mexican homestyle enchilada plate, while I ordered a cup of the pork green chile stew, a quarter roast chicken, and a cheese tamale.

It was pretty busy so it took us about 30 minutes to get our food.  The tamale came out piping hot and was pretty tasty.  Nothing remarkable about it, but certainly better than others I've had.  The masa portion was in itself rather flavorful (but not as great as La Oaxaquena) and the filling was fine.

The roast chicken was very tender and juicy.  I had ordered the green chile flavored/season one, but I found very little green chile flavor in it at all. The skin had some, but otherwise, to me, it was a simple salt and pepper roasted chicken.  It was tasty but not what I was expecting.

The stew was also good. The pork chunks were pretty tender and the flavors melded well together.

I had a bite of my bro's enchiladas and they were also good, but the rice was undercooked.

I guess, for a place called Green Chile Kitchen, I would think the green chile items would stand out more compared to other places.  The food at GCK is solid, but I didn't taste anything spectacular while I was there.

A great neighborhood joint, but I'm not sure I'd go out of my way to come here.
author: Naoko M.

description:
Holy overrated!  Now - let me start with this:

1) The food is good.  Not better than other places.  But it's good.  I would have gone back, before my second point below.  Now I won't.  

I had the tamales and there was definitely not enough meat in them.  I had a pork and chicken tamale - you could barely tell the difference because of the lack of meat.   But whatever...I got over that.  The rice and beans that accompanied them were sufficient - a little better than average (ie: a taqueria).  But 10 bucks for two tamales is just way overpriced.

2) The service BLOWS!  Two awful service experiences in one sitting.  First of all, the couple that went out with us never had their order delivered to the table - they had wrapped it up for take out.  Ok, oversight... but this is where it gets bad.

When they finally did delivery the other couple's meal, they spilled the soup all over me.  Ok - fine...it was an accident.  So the lady apologized and went to drop off the soup to my friend.  As she was placing it down it began to spill so my friend grabbed it.  The waitress snapped "I got it, I got it, move your hand".  Huh?  No you don't got it.  You just damn near showered me in hot red sauce.  She offered to dry clean my shirt after that.  But it was a t shirt, so I said just grab me a wet towel to clean it.

She came back with a towel and started to clean my jacket.  I didn't realize the jacket was hit too.  I said something like, "oh man, my favorite jacket!" - in a totally neutral tone.  And they lady retorted with a scowl - "I already said sorry!  What else do you want me to do!".  Excuse me?  You just ruined my jacket idiot.  I have reason to ruin you.  But instead, I'll ruin the review of your establishment.

She was the woman at the register with dirty blond hair and glasses.  Kinda frumpy.  Or maybe she's a hipster.  I couldn't tell.
author: Marc L.

description: Went here last night because my date said it was one of his favorite restaurants in the city. And guess what? My date had good taste...the food was amazing! I had some chicken tacos with squash on the side. Light, flavorful and spicy. I finally gave in and tried soju because I really wanted a margarita. The margarita tasted good so I wasn't going to complain about the low liquor content in the drink. My date got the veggie stew and some enchiladas. Loved it. Also, the setting is great, not just the food. Hardwood floors, solid wooden tables, candles (or fake candles) in little paper bags as if we're in Santa Fe instead of San Francisco. Great, unpretentious setting and good food, what's not to love?
author: Erin W.

description: Absolutely fantastic breakfast burritto. Chorizo is a bit on the salty side. Some of the best blue corn tortillas I've ever had. Decor reminds me of growing up in the southwest desert with lots of cocapelli (sp?) and hopie Indian influences making it truly distinct New Mexican feel. Coffee is so-so but everything was as good as can be expected.
author: Chris C.

description: Love this place. Great ambiance, great food, always crowded and fun. It's an order at the front, take a number and wait for you food place. I personally love this style of restaurant when you are just looking to grab a quick bite to eat. Super convenient and fast. Just a great place to get dinner!
author: Chris D.

description:
I am so thankful that I decided one day to get off the 5 bus and try the food at this charming and cozy cocina. This place is truly something special and may just be my new favorite place to eat in the city.

When I tried the food, I did not know that is was considered "New Mexican" cuisine. I just figured it was savory and flavorful beyond my years of eating mexican food my whole life. The quality and richness of the food is easily detectable within every bite; it's sets a new standard of what organic and natural should taste like in any food.

I also love the fact that they serve Pozole; I do not know of that many places that have it or offer is EVERYDAY like GCK does. A cup of that with ONE soft taco and my stomach was full. This is coming from a self-proclaimed Miss-Eats-Alot.

Yes the portions are small in comparison with price, but I am willing to throw down money for this place. They have a variety of food options and items to choose from, and I am going to do the best I can to bring friends with me the next time I go to this place to share the love and try new things. Although I do not know how friendly the staff is here, at least they all seem happy to work here. For the best dine-in experience, do try to go anytime before the sun goes down.
author: Megan D.

description: I ate here last night and it was wonderful! It is Mexican food, but high quality with some common items and less common items. I had the soft blue corn steak tacos, with retried beans and sautéed squash on the side. My friends had the blue and yellow corn tamales, and the carnitas burrito. The total dinner, without drinks, was $40 with tax. The quality if the food is excellent and I can't wait to go back. After dinner, the Chile Pie place is down the street for fresh pies, ice cream, ice-cream sandwiches, or cake!
author: Vanessa B.

description:
I think I liked the Green Chile in its "before" state versus the one now, but it's still good. I've been here a couple times, most recently this weekend for some blue corn crispy chicken tacos and rice and beans. The tacos were a little bland, and I found a few bones in my chicken. I guess that accounts for the freshness? The rice was a little mushy, but the beans tasted pretty good. The chips and 4 salsas appetizer? Yum. The green chile salsa was the best. Go figure.

I'm never blown away by the Green Chile, but it'll hit the spot when I'm in the neighborhood. 

Oh, and their margaritas are made with Soju because they don't have a license to make them with tequila!
author: Jennifer B.

description: The guys at the counter are consistently stoned out of their mind and screwing up my order. Any "extras" here (like extra salsa for chips-- duh) cost you $.75 and  up....and then they end up forgetting to include extras anyways, probably because homeboy at the register was on a mission to mars and forgot basically 50% of my order.  Extra SOUR CREAM MAN...how hard can it be!?! Its already overpriced here as far as I'm concerned. Skip Green Chili and head to the Little Chihuahua on Divis if your looking for quality Mexican-American (and even a FREE salsa bar! Ey YI yi!).
author: natalie n.

description: Had the savory sopapillas, great texture, moist flavorful sauces. HIGHLY recommend the black beans for a side. Yummy yummy yummy!  Super casual, cozy, family-style seating and self-serve utensil/water station were convenient!
author: Cara L.

description: Not bad, good for breakfast. Coffee was pretty burnt.
author: Kunal S.

description:
I think every neighborhood needs a place serving great breakfast burritos. In NOPA, Green Chile Kitchen is that place. The ingredients are local and organic and they taste great. GCK prides itself on its New Mexican chiles and they are delicious. The healthy breakfast bowl with a side of blue corn tortillas are also really good. 

For dinner, they have a lot of good choices and I've never been disappointed by anything I've ordered. They have a daily $2 Pacifico special which is hard to beat. There is a good amount of seating including a bar which is convenient if you're going to eat there.
author: Chris S.

description:
One, two, three times a burrito.  

I came here with the taste of Golden Pride breakfast burritos in mind but these were a little more Frontier than Golden Pride (they're big and wet). 

The decor was cute, not overly zia-ey and comfortable.  Something about the temperature or the air in there or something made the food extra steamy which added a certain asthetic appeal.  

I got the breakfast burrito regular, no meat.  And a fantastic cup of pinon coffee.

The first burrito that was delivered to my table was gorgeous and steamy, and smothered in hot green chile.  I was almost drooling waiting for my friends' food to arrive before I dug in.  I cut it open and there was bacon inside.  So I sent it back.  

Burrito number 2 arrived pretty quickly along with polite apology.  I cut a piece off the end and it was delicious, and the green chile was nice and hot.  What I really wanted was some nice spicy fresh roasted green chile on the inside, so I cut a little closer to the middle... and what do I find?  (Not green chile) CHICKEN!  Are you serious people?  So I sent that back too.  

Burrito number 3 arrived even more quickly, and this time my order was right.  However, the cheese was cold.  Yeah, not only not melty, but cold.  They could have used velveeta for extra authenticity, and avoided this problem.  Also, the potatoes were a little too hard in my opinion, which I think is because of the type of potato they used.  

I have to say that despite taking 3 times to get my order right, the service was good.  The gal was super nice and she refunded my money.  She handled the mistake exactly the right way.  Overall, still a good place to quench that green chile craving.
author: Linda L.

description:
What?!-- you're out of your home-made blue corn tortillas?! How COULD YOU?!

It's okay, I still love you.

I got the healthy breakfast bowl and felt super, super satisfied. Eggs were fluffy and not overcooked, served with a giant bed of toppings. They are generous with their food here, and the food itself has a very satisfying array of flavor and color, which is often difficult to achieve when working with vegetarian and organic ingredients.
author: Jen N.

description:
The food at this place is super!  I had the Fulton Valley Chicken Burrito with green chile sauce.  The chicken was very flavorful and all of the textures in the burrito mixed very nicely.  The tortilla was also bomb (I don't see why anyone would ever want it "naked" [without the tortilla])
The value is also great.  Huge, delicious burrito for about seven dollars.  I ended up bringing half home with me.

The service is super fast.  Right when I sat down, my food came out of the kitchen.  However, that being said, Green Chile Kitchen is not the restaurant for a long, relaxing meal for catching up with friends. Basically, it's-an-order-at-the-counter-and-take-your-number-to-a-table-type-place. 
 
There also aren't many tables around, so I'd recommend it for a day when you need a quick, satisfying meal that you can just pick up and enjoy at home.  

I'll definitely be visiting it more often!
author: Alison L.

description:
New Mexican food  is one of my weaknesses; however, I've never found any of it in Calif. to measure up.  I had the chicken enchilada plate with hot green chile.  The dish was tasty, great free-range chicken, rice and beans with a small side of lettuce and tomato.  Overall, the portion was a bit small for the price, and the chile was not as hot as expected.  I was excited to see sopapillas on the menu and ordered a plate of them.  They had a strange texture and fell apart easily. Disappointing.

The menu is large, and there may be better dishes here.  

Overall, I probably will return sometime when I start to crave green and red chile again, but, alas, it appears that another trek to Santa Fe is more likely.
author: John K.

description: I'm gonna start by saying that I'm not a fan of order/sit down dining.... No one likes to stand, and I was ready to pass this eatery off as not worth reviewing, however... I had asked if there was a charger for my phone that I could use (semi-emergency) none available so I plugged in across the st. When I had stepped away, my plates were cleared!! Accidental, I hadn't said I was leaving but when I returned the staff was so apologetic and awesome they replaced my plate and when I enquired if I had to stand in line for another glass of wine, they offered one on the house.... A lil bumpy but then a great save! Thank you green chile staff, well played.
author: Griddly B.

description:
I was here 2 days ago with friends who were raving about the place.  The food was ok, and I enjoyed the lime  margarita I ordered.  The real kicker was the poor quality of service.  I ordered my food with what appeared to be the manager.  He stopped taking my order to take a phone call and then paired my order up with my friend's so I didn't have a number.  Long story short, my food came out 20 minutes after my friends, and was made incorrectly with no apology or attempt to remedy the error.  I was irritated because this mistake came from someone (the manager)  who had the power and agency to provide a solution, and either didn't know or care or was too harried to be concerned.  
Really disappointed by the service after all the good things I had heard.
author: Nora M.

description:
GCK is the bomb if you understand what it really is all about.  My family is from New Mexico, so I'm very familiar with, and fond of a properly made green chile stew.   They make it just like my grandpappy used to make it.

If I ever want to feel as though I've just taken a trip back home I roll over to GCK and have the stew and a couple tortillas.  It's the ultimate comfort food to me, and they make it perfectly.

I see there's some griping about their prices on here, and I think it's a little misguided.  Because I'm in the business, I know how hard it is to make a buck in THIS TOWN in the restaurant game.  I think their prices are competitive.  But I'm probably not the guy to ask because I'd pay double for a bowl of their stew!
author: Steve P.

description:
The burrito I had was large, filling, came with good salsa, and priced at around $9. 

Was it good? Yes.

Would I go back? Its proximity to my place and the atmosphere/decor is cool. Sure. 

Was it anything spectacular? No. 

I like my food to be special. Enough said.
author: Roxane W.

description:
Food is very good.  Service is like everyone says, slow.  Still enjoyed it.  The apple chile pie is so good.  Not too sweet & just a kick of chile flavor.  I was skeptical about it but I highly recommend it!  Yum! 

I wish they would wait on the tables instead of having to order at the counter.  I like having a tab run so you don't have to get in line again & pay separate if you want to order another drink or something else.
author: Donna W.

description: Decent Mexican restaurant with their green chili served along with burritos. It was slightly more spicy but I love this place.
author: Balaji B.

description: Sweet, delicious, fresh and creatively seasoned PIE. Absolute flavor party in my mouth. :) Need i say more?
author: Cris T.

description:
If you like REAL green chile New Mexican food, then there really is no other option for you in the bay area. This place hits the spot, so much so I'm barely looking forward to the food on my trip to NM in two weeks :)
Large parties should send a few people ahead to reserve a big table. I appreciate the efficiency of their cafe style of service. 
And of course the unique touch of the water jars instead of glasses with straws adds something new and fun.
author: Dharam K.

description: Knocked off one star cause it's a little pricey for what it is, but definitely worth going again and again. Green Chile quesadilla, nachos, and sopapillas are where it's at.
author: Stephen F.

description:
Saturday night was a big night for us.  Dinner in SF + Concert in SF (The Dan Band, since you asked) = Happy Peninsulers!

We chose the GCK because it has a tofu option for my veggie hubby.  For the rest of us carnivores, it was a no brainer.  Food was presented nicely, tasted fresh and was good.  A bottle of wine was $15.  It was an all around great experience.  

It's a "grab a seat - quick" arrangement; which made it a little awkward (long line out the door) because we could feel eyes boring into the backs of our heads to HURRY UP, but we didn't.  We weren't rude by taking our sweet time, but we also didn't rush.  Aside from that, it was a fun night and all of us were happy to have eaten there.
author: sheridan r.

description: This place is amazing, one of my favorites. Casual, reasonably priced, and really good food. I recommend the super nachoes.
author: Andrww B.

description:
May be I messed up by not coming here for the yelp-raved breakfast burritos, but from what I tasted of the non-breakfast items, I am not too sure I'm so convinced of the wothiness of Green Chile's hype. 

I ordered the chicken stew, which was hearty, and made with fresh top quality ingredients, but the taste is far from perfection. The carnitas is nowhere near the "melt in your mouth" goodness that I was used to with tex-mex. The pork was chunky, tendony, and um... hearty... not what I was expecting and all around just not right. It wasn't very well seasoned either, as with the Carne Asada. 

This place doesn't hold a candle to the Little Chihuahua. May be I would give it another try at breakfast.... or not.
author: Charlie L.

description: Update: Quality control/consistency has definitely improved since I wrote last review in June '13, so I'm giving them a bump up.
author: Jeff W.

description:
I seriously cannot believe all the negative reviews Green Chile Kitchen has gotten because they SO do not deserve them.  It seems to me that people have very particular expectations based on previous experiences elsewhere and then are livid when the place and food are different.  News flash: it is a different place and a different kitchen.  I can't believe someone complained about there not being TV's while you wait for food.  What has the world come to?!  Sad.  
We live in the neighborhood and just love this place.  It's clean, quaint and the food is fresh and delicious.  The people working are always pleasant to us and make us feel welcome.  We've had breakfast and lunch here and were never disappointed.  I recently brought a friend with me who is a major food snob, and after one bite of her chicken enchilada she said "oh my god, this is delicious".  I'm a vegetarian, so I love that I can come eat here and have plenty of different yummy, fresh and healthy options.  
It's one of my favorite places to go in our neighborhood.
author: Dara P.

description: I just moved to the area and went here for the first time last week. It was really cute and not at all what I expected! It's usually really crowded when I go by, so I thought it was just a sit-down place, but really you can just grab and go takeout super easily. The service was fast and everyone working there was really nice. The food was also really good! Got the grilled burrito and in comparison to the other burrito on the menu, it was a couple bucks cheaper and probably just as much food. Sooo good. Tasted much healthier than most burritos which I was pleased with. So yummy, glad I live nearby because I'll be coming back!
author: Katie V.

description:
Can someone please turn the lights on? I like to see my food, before I put it in my mouth.

I just grabbed dinner here with a friend and the first thing that struck me was the lack of lighting in the dining room. Oh well, moving on. 

I remember the food and service being much better at the Fulton location. The overpriced, 
'best" of everything salad, was terribly lacking in beets and artichoke hearts. I got a generous portion of quarter of a beet and two, halved artichoke hearts. In addition, they claim that they make their salads with Organic greens, but I highly doubt that having consumed them. The greens weren't very fresh. It could just be a bad night.  My friend had the Super Nachos, which were nothing special.

The service, especially at the bar, is terrible. The people who man the register are in charge of the bar as well. So if you're seated at the bar on a busy night, don't expect any service for a while. 

It's an ok experience i guess, but it is definitely not what it used to be.
author: Tushar V.

description: I love this place!  It was closer to our house before they moved, but I don't care.  It's the only place I will go to for my vegetarian burrito Togo.  Their ingredients are always fresh and really good.  They even give you compostable bags to carry it home in.  That alone puts them at the top of my list.  They make the best vegetarian burrito in town.
author: Betty G.

description:
This is one of my two favorite burritos places in SF!!! The thing I appreciate most about this place is how fresh the food is - more than I can say for most places in the Mission. Don't get me wrong, my other favorite burrito place IS in the Mission, but I still really appreciate GCK's healthy options and imported New Mexican green chile, a unique addition to my burritos. 

Favorite menu items: veggie burrito, breakfast burrito, green chile stew, nachos, blue corn enchiladas, sangria

The only negative thing I do have to point out is that this place has become insanely popular (busy) recently and seems to be outgrowing the current restaurant space between too few tables and too small a kitchen. There can be quite a wait for your food at rush hour. That being said, once you get your food, the wait was MOST DEFINITELY worth it.
author: Rachel B.

description:
On the up side: Tasty, healthy, nice presentation for lunch.

On the down side: the service wasn't the greatest. The workers were roaming around the dining room, talking to their friends instead of manning the counter.
author: Heather S.

description:
I must have dane brammage. For whatever reason, I block out about how irritating it is to order food to-go from Green Chile Kitchen, yet I keep ordering from here forgetting that it takes 40-50 minutes (after calling in) to get the food. I have to give myself credit, I thought that after Green Chile moved to a bigger place on Fulton, they would change their system and be able to get at least one of our orders right (nope!) or at least have it ready 30 minutes after we call it in. We've tried this experiment at different times of the evening and it doesn't seem to make a difference. 

The odd thing is we order the rotisserie chicken meal which is already prepared. I know this because I have watched them (after waiting at the counter) eventually plop my food from the heating trays into the to-go boxes. It isn't as if they had to actually cook anything while I waited, it is just a matter of throwing a precooked chicken into a box and then ladling beans, rice, squash into containers. And if I'm lucky, occasionally wrapping up a tortilla and throwing a package of salsa into a bag. Why does this take almost an hour to do when there are only 5 customers in your restaurant? 

Tonight, not only was our order f*cked up (no tortilla or salsa) but it took 40 minutes (from the time we called in) to receive our order. Apparently, there still isn't a way for the staff to check the orders before sending it out but they do profusely apologize each time I have to go back. From now on, we're eating at Delessio and Nopalito, which is about the same price but with much better ingredients. Or maybe I don't understand the Slow Food Movement but whatever it is, Green Chile Kitchen is giving it a bad name. 

Eat before ordering, this includes dining in (which is much worse).
author: Mitsi M.

description:
After months of wanting to try Green Chile Kitchen, Kyle T. and I finally made it the other night for dinner before heading to a concert at the Fillmore.  Why we didn't come here sooner, we don't know, but we'll definitely be back with our housemates in tow.  

It was a Friday night so the place was pretty packed.  We were unfamiliar with the system, so luckily the long line for food gave us time to observe and acclimate to our surroundings.  Lots of communal seating.  Order at the counter, then take your number to your seat.  Menus are on the table by the front door.  Water, napkins, and silverware are off to the side.  

I opted for the blue corn flat enchilada with steak and my friend got the chili rellenos.  I thought mine was delicious.  I cleaned the entire plate, sides and all.  You can choose what kind of chile sauce you want on top, and taking a cue from the name, I opted for the green chile sauce, while my dinner mate chose the red.  Both were good and generously scooped.  

When we come back, we'll take advantage of the $2 pacificos, order some appetizers, and obviously go back to chile pies and ice cream down the block for our slice of pie and scoop of three twins ice cream for dessert.
author: Anne Marie B.

description: This is one of my favorite spots in SF. I usually get a burrito, but nothing I or my dining companions have tried has been bad. And best of all, their menu features Mary's Free Range chicken & Niman Ranch meat!
author: Philip T.

description:
+ 3 stars for tasty food and a really great innovative menu with Southwest regional treats and staples. 

+1 star for very friendly locals. Seriously - the crowd here looks marvelous. 

+1 for super service. Even when slammed. 

This place is no joke!
author: Mark S. I.

description:
I like this place mostly for the vibe. Yes, there are a lot of delicious taquerias in SF, but not many that you actually want to dine-in at. And for those that are worth staying at, there's usually a ridiculously long wait or not enough seating. 

Green Chile Kitchen is cozy (but still spacious and not cramped), casual, quick, with a cool NOPA-esque feel (I don't totally know what that  last part means but it is true). It is not the best Mexican (or New Mexican...) food I have had, but I still really like it. 

Also it is next to their associated Chile Pies (& ice cream) which I can't wait to try next time.
author: Richa A.

description:
Just went here last night.

I got the chicken burrito with spicy green chile, added sour cream and guac.

The burrito was excellent.  The chicken was roasted and sort of smoky (in a good, not so over powering sort of way) and the ingredients were all fresh.  Due to the green chile sauce, sour cream, and guac on top, this is definitely a fork and knife burrito.

It was good and filling, served with chips and salsa.  I washed it down with a Pacifco (was only $2).

Very satisfying.  Total bill for beer and burrito was around $12.  Also a really cool atmosphere.  Maybe a good place for an unpretentious 1st or 2nd date.
author: Joseph H.

description: Tasty Mexican food and fast service! I kind of wish the food was either cheaper, or the restaurant offered table service. But it's definitely a good meal in a great space (enormous windows on a nice corner), so I won't hesitate to come back.
author: Lian C.

description:
The best breakfast burrito in SF! 

Cool atmosphere, great food, friendly people...what more do you need?
author: Daniel D.

description: The first word that pops into my mind about Green Chile is average. The food is good but not amazing. I mean all burritos in San Francisco taste good right!  A lot of people speak highly of their breakfast so I will definitely give it a shot. The atmosphere is cool but I do usually get it to go (out of default since I live down the street). The price point is a little high compared to what you could get at a place like Papalote. Sorta like the Alex Smith of NFL quarterbacks.
author: Craig B.

description:
this is my favorite restaurant for hung over morning food.  Their breakfast burritos have given me back my soul on a number of terrifying mornings. I'm actually and literally salivating while I write this.  That's kind of embarrassing.
4 stars because it's a little pricy, though worth every penny.
author: Rachel R.

description:
I would say that my one star review is a little out of the norm for the service at Green Chili Kitchen. I mean, any other time I've been there, the food has been good (except for their tamales). I've been going there for years, beginning with their little location on Fulton (now their ice cream place). 

Aaaaanyway, the other day I went there and ordered a chicken salad, and the chicken was bad. I mean, when I put it up to my mouth, I could smell that it was bad. Now, I could maybe guess that the cook didn't take the time to smell it, but when I sent it back, they were less than apologetic. In the end, I just got my money back and left. Sad, too, because they used to have much better quality in the old location.

I'm thinking that the next time I think of Green Chili Kitchen, I'll probably just head to Papalote or The Little Chihuahua.
author: cynthia c.

description: Really great location. The ambiance is really cool, indoor and outdoor seating. The decor is really nice. Not authentic Mexican flavors, by any means. The salsa's flavors were bland. The reason why I rate this place at three stars is because of the quality of food. This was my third time here and the two times before, I thought it was average and was hoping to try something that finally blew my mind, but that wasn't the case. I ordered the tamales and the amount of meat inside was minimal. My tamale was 90% corn and the other 10% meat. When I complained about it, the service worker was nice enough to give me another for free. Unfortunately, I experienced the same small amount of meat in that one. The food portion is not worth the price. Sadly, this place is so close to work that I would naturally enjoy frequenting it more, but will stay away.
author: Lissette L.

description: Been here a couple of times and tried different things, including the guac, burritos, chiles rellenos, and pozole. Of those, the pozole was decent, but the food overall is uninspired and bland. The food always arrives at the table barely warm or cold,  which doesn't help. Expensive, too. Better places abound, so I don't think I have any reason to go back. I can't recommend it to anyone else.
author: Maria C.

description:
Great breakfast burritos with veg options. My fav is with soyrizo.

Lunch fare such as tamales, tacos, "normal" burritos and soup are also solid.  Most dishes are have interchangeable beef, chicken, tofu, veggie options. I've even heard someone call the green chile sauce "divine".
author: Jessica P.

description:
First visit to Green Chile Kitchen today, I have to give them 3-stars for overall experience.  Most impressive things I had today were as follows in order of deliciousness, (1) Spicy Green Chile Salsa(authentic in flavor, texture and heat level) (2) Guacamole(clean and simple) (3)Sour Cream(I think they make their own) (4)Tamale(just because the Masa was very delicate and (5)Chile Relleno(basic but tasty).

Ok, so why only 3 stars?  #1 reason, the food just wasn't hot enough in temperature or heat level.  We ordered spicy but it all tasted very mild so it would be nice if they had another level up in heat.  We were tempted to ask them to throw our plates back under the broiler because who can stand luke warm food!?  But frankly we were just too hungry to be our usual outspoken food snobish selves.  One more issue, they charge for additional salsa, I mean "COME ON" - that is ridiculous!!

I will definitely go back to this place and try new things, I just will be sure to get my food piping hot.  Oh, last but not least, the ice cream at their sister restaurant kicks butt.
author: A H.

description:
The classic lunch spot for my classmates and I after exams at USF.

The food is really good, everything I've ever ordered has been consistently good, there are big communal tables that are nice for groups, the decor is pleasant, and there are $2 pacificos.  It's not as cheap as mission taco joints, but the quality of the produce and meats are also a lot better.

All in all, pretty tough to beat.
author: fraggle l.

description: What a cool little chill spot. I waiting here for about 2 hours, while waiting for a friend to get home from work and the staff were so friendly, full of welcoming energy and accommodation. The crowd was pretty serene considering it was after work rush hour.  The food smelt amazing but wasn't too hungry to eat. I'm sure it's fantastic tho! Next time certainly!
author: Jess C.

description:
Overall I can't say I was very thrilled with this restaurant. I guess I enjoy more authentic mexican food. 

I order the 3 taco plate with pork. Tacos were alright. I didn't care much for the rice. It tasted bland and just not what i am used to. I wish instead of the veggie mix it came with beans.

Husband got nachos and a steak taco. I have to say the steak in the taco was extremely yummy. Hubby said nachos were alright. 

The place is tiny and it was extremely crowded the day we came. Luckily we scored seats next to their large window. 

I did like that they had a place to serve your own water. I find it cool when places use mason jars for their cups. 

It was a decent experience to try someplace new but I don't think I am going to go out of my way to come back.
author: Jenniffer T.

description: Crazy busy but the super friendly staff and quality food make it a really fun place to grab a bite and a solid margarita.
author: Justin L.

description:
The breakfast burrito here might have changed my life forever.  

I had the chorizo breakfast burrito "Christmas Style" - with red and green sauce.  It was BY FAR the best breakfast burrito I have ever had.  I may come back here every Saturday morning for the rest of my life....or until I gain 100 lbs.
author: Dan L.

description:
If you're desperate for NM food- it'll somewhat satisfy your cravings.  The green chile stew is great.  If you know NM food well this place will be very good but not great.  It's not quite a taste of NM but as close as I've found in the Bay Area.  If you're not used to NM food, you will think it is fabulous. 

A little pricey for what you get (my plate at Gardunos is only 10 bucks- come on guys, give me the same meal for under 30 please).  The sopapillas could use a little work.  The service and table hunting environment need improvement since sometimes my meal is being served but there is no table to be had. 

Overall a good place.  I'm glad there is a restaurant giving NM cooking a shot.  Keep up the good work guys- just do a few more visits to NM to perfect that menu
author: Daisy S.

description:
Good food, but there's lots of good Mexican in SF. 

Cons:
- No waiter service, order at the counter and they bring it out to you. 
- No liquor license. I don't like mexican food without a real margarita.
author: Julie W.

description: Good, but very pricey.
author: Michael E.

description: Unfortunately I don't jive with new Mexican, so I'm just marking this review to remind myself that this is a cuisine I don't like. The service also took fooooorever.
author: Shang S.

description: This place is great!  I don't what's up with all the hatin' in the Bay.  We have yet to find  anything better to eat in this neighborhood than Green Chile Kitchen.  They've never screwed up my order, and my food is always hot, delicious and very filling.  They also have yummy agua frescas of various flavors - it's a lucky day if you get watermelon or cantaloupe.  The sangria is good, too.
author: Sam V.

description:
Now that I've lived in the area for a bit and have had the opportunity to go here many times, I figured it was about time I updated this review. And to remove a few stars.

The more I go there and try the various dishes on their menu, the more blah I realize their food is. Even if it may be healthier then traditional mexican, it's still got to have some good flavor to it. I mean am I crazy for thinking this? Maybe organic/vegan/hipster people dislike flavorful foods? I don't know.

And in a city full of restaurants, service is what's going to set your place apart from every other place, and at the GCK this holds true. The service from the kids running the place, and the cooks, is horrible. I mean they just really don't even try. I've had 4 orders IN A ROW messed up now, and none of them were really fixed. I'm talking about simple stuff to, and then when I raise the issue with the little girls working there they get defensive about it. The attention to detail by the cooks is really the thing, since it's them messing up the orders not the girls behind the register.

Example: I got a burrito, and wanted to make it a super burrito. This is just where they add guacamole, sour cream and cheese. I asked for NO guacamole on it, and if I could have it on the side. I get the burrito and there is no guacamole on the side. I asked the girl if it was put inside it, and she said "If it's a super, then it' got guacamole in it". Ok, remember I asked for NO guacamole on it? She says "Oh ya, there isn't any on it". Not very convincing since you just told me it did. I asked her if she could ask the cooks - they didn't remember. 

I asked if I could get a new burrito since now it had been like 20 minutes, it was cold, and we had no idea what was in it. She said the cooks would open it up for me, and if there was no guacamole in it they would have"no choice" but to charge me for a new one, or I could eat the now cold one they were about to open. 

Really?

So the cook opens it up, and what do you know - there is no guacamole on it. With a *sigh* I watch them wrap the burrito back up, give me a little side of guacamole and I head home with my cold burrito. 

End of the story? Pfft no way, I still have a burrito to eat.

So I get home, unwrap the burrito and start to eat its cold remains. As I get about 1/2 way done I realize that not only is there no guacamole on it, but no cheese or sour cream either! 

For real?!?!

I felt like I wanted to go down there, put them all in a line and then 3 stooges slap everyone!! 

So in the end I got a cold burrito that wasn't made correctly, I paid for something I didn't get, I was given a hard time by the cooks and the girl working there, and had an hour of my life wasted that I'll never get back...

This sound like a ridiculous story? I've got many more, but hey just go here yourself. Then you'll have an equally ridiculous story to share on Yelp!
author: Erik B.

description:
I was wanting Green Chile Kitchen to be more than it turned out to be.  Their website says "New Mexico Inspired."  I know New Mexican cuisine well and this restaurant unfortunately misses on several points.  Better NM food is based on subtleness.  There is no better dish to begin with than Green Chile Stew---it is easy to over spice and over power the base ingredient and that is what happened here--the potatoes should be soft and the stew meat should be tender and the green chile should not be overspiced and hence the entire dish can shine proudly.  The salsas need more focus and the red salsa needs a slight red chile touch and the other salsas could use more New Mexico inspiration.

The blue corn enchiladas were not inspired as they could have been.  I asked for the Christmas version but it came out green only.  I was hoping for refried beans and feather-like Spanish rice but neither came out that way.

  The sopaipilla should be large nearly pillow-like object and steamy warm.  Large enough to be more of a bread than a dessert (thought sopaipilla and honey can be quite nice).

Overall the price points were high for this cuisine and the total experience could be uplifted with a few touches in the food department.  I am not sure what "inspired" means?  Does that mean one might eat at a French restaurant that is just merely inspired--wouldn't one want a fuller experience?

I wanted the Green Chile Kitchen to be a place to go to beyond my kitchen.   Occasionally I would prefer to eat New Mexico food out in San Francisco--looks like I will be eating NM food at home.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: Good stuff, but was slightly disappointed after all the great things I've heard.  Feel like they were so busy the food was a little cold and could have been slightly more on its game.  Don't get me wrong, I'd come back and loved the menu - but hope they don't get complacent with all the money they're making.
author: Andrew S.

description: Oh man, as a NM resident for 20 years it's hard for me to express just how happy it makes me that I can get relatively authentic New Mexican food in San Francisco.  And this place makes some seriously tasty food. My favorite so far is the homestyle enchiladas, the chicken is amazing. Pro tip:  order the "hot" chile for an even more authentic experience. Thank you, Green Chile Kitchen, for spreading  the awesomeness that is hatch chile to the west coast!!!
author: Aaron K.

description:
All I wanted on this particular morning was a breakfast taco. I also didn't feel like trekking to the Mission.

I tried to order 2 b.tacos with flour tortillas, which I didn't think would be impossible b/c they had flour tortillas on the menu. Apparently they cannot stray from how they serve breakfast tacos... 2 miniature corn tortillas laid out like a Venn Diagram with potatoes, eggs and cheese piled on top. How the heck was I supposed to eat this? It wasn't easy - that is for sure. I managed, but only b/c I wanted it so bad.

The place had a cool vibe and I am most interested in going back for lunch/dinner or maybe even a breakfast burrito, but not for the over priced, poorly served breakfast tacos.
author: Lauren J.

description: had the burrito bowl for breakfast. fairly priced, generous portion. more than i could consume anyway.
author: Flix N.

description: So I just ate there with my daughters, it was horrible food to say the least. I ordered the enchilada plate, it was a quesadilla that i got instead. In my opinion enchiladas come wrapped with filling inside, and sauce glazed over. What I got instead was two flat tortillas with a green sauce with no real taste. The plate comes with beans, well the beans had literally no flavor as well as the tamale which they screwed up too. I ordered a pork tamale, instead I got sweet potato, well I can see serving this to a dog perhaps but I feel my pooch would turn it down for a good ol' scooby snack. One of my daughters ordered the homemade tamales, she chose to go with cheese tamales well this place must be in real financial jeapordy because there was not a single trace of anything other than masa. I can only think they have no choice but to mislead people by serving them anything but what they requested. As for overall taste,  your better of buying from those ladies selling tamales in the Mission, its definitely a much better choice than to eat here where apparently taste is not of any concern. I will say the $2 Pacifico beers and the strawberry lemonade was the highlight of our dinner if you want to call it that. And yes we all left the majority of the food on the table, totally disgusted with the food that's being served...Never going back oh and my youngest commented thats why they make you pay first so you wont get your money back unless you make a real fuss...
author: Roy G.

description:
I was introduced to this fabulous spot by a fellow USF grad student while suffering through an all day Saturday class. We had about an hour to grab lunch, and she recommended Green Chile Kitchen.

I can't believe I've spent so much time in this area and I didn't know about this place! The food is amazing! The place is packed on the weekends, so be sure to allow enough time to get your order in and eat (indigestion and a 7 hour Saturday class do not make for pleasant times!)

I'm a fan of their enchiladas, burritos and tamales. Can't say I've tried anything here that I haven't thoroughly enjoyed!
author: Christy L.

description:
This place was memorable... but for all the wrong reasons. The biggest lasting impression was really that there was no indication of the name anywhere on the store (it looks like they might have moved here back in November, but one would hope that, that would still be plenty of time to fix this).

The prices were not great, especially for the portions. We were disappointed with lack of complimentary chips and salsa, as this is what we were craving for that day, but we were hoping that the food might have made up for it... it did not. The biggest drawback was really the beans, which were the least flavorful we have ever eaten.  We ordered two dishes, one with the beans as a side and one with the beans in the burrito. The dish with them as a side suffered, but the true casualty was the burrito, where in the beans acted like a black hole of flavor and killed the rest.

Overall, it wasn't horrible... but not something we were grateful to have visited the first time around.
author: Sami R.

description: The food is fresh and delicious.  I especially like the amazing rotisserie chicken!!  The staff is super friendly and the best part is they have $2 Pacifico beers all day!
author: JT N.

description: Just ordered the big blue salad. Opened the box and first thing there's a thread laying flat across the salad, the salad was all wet- a pool of water underneath and totally overpriced $14 really? Not good.
author: Liz S.

description: great food. healthy food. nice people. good ambiance. this place is right on my corner and im glad they're here. if you haven't tried their breakfast burritos, you're missing out!!!!
author: Cecily B.

description:
I am a fan of the ambience and the service here. The food is always delicious. The carne adovada is addictive and their salads are actually real meals. 

The one thing I have a hard time getting over is how pricey it is. Every meal is a few more dollars then what you'd expect to pay at any other decent Mexican place.
author: Hillary W.

description:
I've been here twice. The food is good, make no mistake. If you go here, you will probably not leave here feeling ill, or in any way disappointed with the overall quality of the food. This is a New Mexican restaurant. In a very big way, red and green chile sauces are the focal point of New Mexican cuisine. It is what sets it apart from other regional variations (Tex-Mex, etc.). The chile sauces here are NOT included with your meal. It's like ordering spaghetti and meatballs, but you have to pay extra for the marinara or bolognaise. It's absurd. Without the chile sauce, it's just Mexican food; and with that being the case, you might as well just go to a tacqueria in the Mission where you won't be paying 8 bucks for a quesadilla.

Good food. Overpriced. Does not include the essential components of New Mexican food.
author: Kamran M.

description:
I love the rich sauces, the rotisserie chicken is delish.  The mashed potatoes aren't so good, they are rather dry, doesn't seem like they use any fat (cream, butter).  
The beet margaritas are damn delicious when they actually put alcohol in them!  I'm not sure what's up, but only 3 of the 8 or so margaritas had any alcohol in them.  I mean... any.  No blood rush to the cheeks, no warmth in my throat, absolutely no urge to pee.  Makes me sad because they are pricey.  I'm cutting two stars on the margaritas.  Other than that, it's not terribly exciting food, but the rice and beans are tasty and the flat enchiladas are my favorite.
author: Michelle L.

description: My wife and I had dinner tonight at Green Chile Kitchen. It was our 2nd time to the Restuarant and we love it. I had the blue masa tamale plate and it was awesome. My wife had the crispy taco plate and she was thoroughly happy with her meal. I am a native New Mexican and the food at the Green Chile Kitchen is the next best thing to a trip home and enjoying that "back home green chile". Thanks for a great meal at a great price. We'll be back soon.
author: Amado P.

description:
Delicious.

The first time I came here my vegan friend told me he was going to take me a really good taqueria.  This statement is not really accurate.  If you want a really good taqueria style burrito, this is not the place to come.  If you want a bunch of amazing and fresh ingredients rolled into a tortilla topped with a delicious sauce, this IS the place to come. This is one of those places that you can really tell only uses the best quality and freshest ingredients.  Now that I understand what this place is all about, I crave it all the time.

I highly recommend it if you want really good and flavorful food.

I don't recommend it if you're looking for a burrito like you would find in the mission.
author: Aaron L.

description:
I'll admit - I'm not the best critic when it comes to Mexican food.
But, I will always rave about their burrito bowls!!

Tender carne asada, fresh salsa... even down to the plating and the cute mason jars as water cups - they do know how to appeal to my classy taste!

The only gripe is parking, but that's already a given!

So please do yourself a favor and give this restaurant a try. I'm incredibly sad that I haven't been in months.
author: Sharlene D.

description:
I decided to come back to Green Chile Kitchen after staying away for awhile after my last experience with frozen enchiladas. Now that GCK has moved to a new location and the fact that I was jonsin for a Green chile I thought let's try this again? My good friend and walking partner Tony arrived just before the lunch crowd today, the location is nice, lots of seating especially for groups and singles. I think GCK will satisfy any New Mexican's craving for a taste of good food from the Land of Enchantment, I should know, I'm from New Mexico and my mother is Latina from Northern New Mexico. Is it as good as home made? Yes and no. I felt the spicy chile was still not hot enough but then I tend to like really spicy food, the flavor was certainly good. I thought the freshness of the salad was amazing, the colors so vibrant and the dressing just right. I was excited to see Sopapillas on the menu but they are only served after 5p, guess I need to go back? 
Here's what we ordered:

Best of Everything veggie salad
Roasted beets and peppers, carrots, cucumber, mushrooms, red onion, tomato and broccoli.

Blue Corn flat enichiladas with cheese and veggies (Zucchini, squash, mushroom, onion) and smothered with red and green chile, topped with Sour Cream. The New Mexican way to eat blue corn enchiladas is with a fried egg on top!

I did try a bit of Tony's Carne Adovada plate which didn't hold a candle to my Aunt Lena's Carne Adovada (Sorry Green Chile Kitchen) but it was still pretty good. Carne Adovada is tender pork that is marinated in red chile and spices and slow cooked.

On our way out the door we were both craving dessert,  I remembered seeing a small shop called Chile Pies and Ice Cream that is one block away from the Green Chile Kitchen, they are sister businesses, please see my review.......
author: David P.

description:
Green Chile Kitchen has moved.  

This is not news to those of us who live nearby, but it renders all the old reviews and pictures obsolete.  It may take a while to get it all sorted out.  

We dropped in at the new location on a Saturday at 5:30pm, and found that the company had adapted to their new location.  More space, more tables, more customers.  

My Lady ordered the 1/2 rotisserie chicken meal, her favorite, and I had the blue enchilada plate.  What's a blue enchilada?  It's a blue corn tortilla with some stuff on it.  Her tea and my Blue Sky soda brought the tab to $34.03, including tax and a service charge.  

I can't say that the food was any different than at the previous location, but I can say that this was a welcome refuge from the cold and a good place to eat close by.  

Does this sound like faint praise to you?
author: David D.

description: The lines can be out the door, but I do love this place.  There aren't enough sit-down Mexican eateries in SF.  This one is very trendy and hip, with nice low prices, great moist white chicken meat, and pretty good margaritas.  When I know I won't mind a bit of a wait, and feel up to tolerating some moderate to high noise, I come here.  I've been here for breakfast too, and it's very tasty... egg burritos, yum.....l
author: Steve S.

description:
Green Chile Kitchen has moved a block north.  It now occupies the space that used to be Cafe Neon (good riddance--kinda).  While coming here now requires me to trudge up a hill (I'm lazy, remember?), I'll gladly do so in the future.  I actually feel bad that I haven't been hitting up Green Chile Kitchen so much now that I'm semi-addicted to Papalote, but I'll remedy that once I have a full-time job again.

I did kind of like some of Cafe Neon's wicker furniture, but it's all gone.  The space itself is much livelier and less cramped than Green Chile's old digs.  The seating options are weird, though; you can grab a booth (against the west wall), a traditional table for two (in the middle on the booth side), a bench at the communal table (in the middle on the other side), or a stool at a high shelf (along the east-facing windows).  If you can't picture it, think of a combination of the shelves at Bean Bag (http://www.yelp.com/biz/bean-bag-coffee-house-san-francisco) and Blondie's in Berkeley (http://www.yelp.com/biz/blondies-pizza-berkeley).

There are more options than there used to be.  I had the vegetarian soft tacos with tofu, and they were excellent.  If you order soft tacos, be aware that they give you a bunch of extra tortillas, so you should distribute your taco-innards rather than rely on Green Chile Kitchen's over-stuffing.

Alyssa G. also liked the fact that they have a kind of smoothie she loves and has only seen at Berkeley Bowl.

I really miss hanging out around this corner.  Thankfully, One World Cafe's former location is now occupied by a new coffeehouse.  A review of that place is in the works.
author: John S.

description: Truth: Not a huge fan of their standard New Mexican Fare here, but, my God do I love their roasted chicken and refried beans. For a mere $21.70 (tax included) you can get a veritable feast for at least 4 people with the entire chicken along with a veggie side, beans, rice, tortillas and all the sauces you'll need and is probably the best deal you can find on this side of the panhandle. Also...those beans just make me want to OM NOM them so badly, like all the damn time.
author: Clarissa S.

description: This place is great.  I go often and love all their grilled burritos, the heartland taco salad, the big blue chicken salad, and their salsas.  They have a cool staff and also serve a pretty good breakfast.
author: Andrew R.

description:
One of my pet peeves is when a restaurant doesn't make it clear how to order and how you are seated. Would it kill you to have one of those double-sided signs that says "please seat yourself" on one side and "please wait to be seated" on the other? Apparently. You look through the menus (on a table near the door), order at the counter, and then find a table and they bring the food out to you. This should save the 90 seconds of awkwardness we had while figuring out what to do.

The food was pretty good, although nothing to write home about. Nobody was dissatisfied in the least, and the menu was just creative enough to bump the place from three to four stars. No complaints.
author: Zach Y.

description: perhaps my favorite ribs in the city.... also love the green chile buttermilk dressing.
author: Wakako U.

description: This is one of my favorite places. I'm here at least once a week. The posole soup is sooo yummy and the rotisserie chicken with tortilla's is classic good. Great neighborhood atmosphere to have a beer or glass of wine too.
author: Lisa M.

description: Had lunch here.  The Place was nice and roomy. Ordered a Medium Burrito and a Coke, it came to $14.00. Although it was tasty, that is way to expensive for a Burrito with about 10 chips on the side.  I had Carne Asada, brown rice, salsa, avocado and cheese with a bottle of coke. There were no extras. Mexican food is fairly inexpensive to make. I grew up on it, and Rice, beans and tortillas are staples. I have no idea why this Burrito would qualify to charge so much.  The atmosphere is great , religious art work from New Mexico.   It was close to work so thought I'd try.  I wish i could give it a better review, because the food was tasty, but it just  not worth a $13,00 burrito. San Francisco has plenty of Mexican Food in the Mission, tasty and and money left over for some Cerveza's.
author: Susie S.

description:
Green Chile used to be my all time favorite neighborhood spot.  When you walk in your mouth instantly starts watering at the smell of rotisserie chicken with green chili rub.  I was addicted.  We frequented at least once a week, often more.

But since the move to their new location the food has not been as good.  The chicken tastes different, the burritos are quite horrible now, and the tamales are now very very dry.  And if the change in food wasn't enough the service is down right awful.  Several times I have had to wait while to order while the counter staff finishes a chapter of their book.  

I thought the ownership had maybe changed, grasping for some sort of explaination.  But I think the standards are just gone.

I keep going back now and then hoping that the quality will return, but sadly I am always let down.  Our take-out orders are never right.  We have to check every item and every side.  The food is dry, the staff confused or just apathetic.   I have given up.

It's still an okay experience, but it is not what it was.  And who wants to keep going back for okay.
author: Sharon C.

description: I've lived in northern New Mexico and love NM territorial food. GCK is the best example of northern New Mexico cooking in California, you just need to know what to order. They have a decent Posole, and without a doubt the blue corn pork tomales are simply great, the only problem is that they don't understand the concept of pecante sauce, not Santa Fe style. Plus, they seem to be out of blue corn masa a lot of the time. Recently I ordered blue corn tamales, they were out of BC masa,  the waiter substituted regular corn masa tamales without bothering to inquire if i wanted them. Nor did they bother to comp me. So service or consideration for the customer seems to be on the low side-a standard complaint. But over all the food is very good. The chicken dinners, the tres tacos, all good. So forget about the quality of service (tip or don't accordingly). And enjoy the food!
author: John C.

description:
It was good. But it ain't the cheapest. The place is tucked away in an obscure spot, but that's cool. It's not far from Lower Haight. The ambiance is cool. Order at the counter, which is nice. 

I had the green chili chicken soup and it was legit. Very spiced, very good. Served with some fresh hot tortillas. And the pork green chili quesadilla. It was pretty good, but not cheesy enough. I think it was actually pretty safe, maybe not as flavorful as I like. 

All in all a great place, but not for the price. Still, I'm a fan.
author: David L.

description:
My 600th review goes to one of the best breakfast burritos I've had. Super soft and fluffy eggs, spicy chorizo, hot green chiles, salsa, and stewed potatoes round it all out on a toasted tortilla. 

Saturday morning, get thee a burrito.
author: Derrick V.

description:
If I keep giving out 5 stars people are going to think I'm getting paid off.

But this is worth it. Man oh man is this worth it. 

The restaurant (if you could call it that) that I had most loathed in my time living in this great city was Cafe Neon. I never thought I would be having such an incredible time in the building, which I had highlighted in my review of Neon as one of the lowest points, being cavernous and kind of formal feeling.

But Green Chile has done it. They really have. 

The atmosphere is well done. Whereas before the tile floor seemed kind of surgical and cold, the restaurant is filled with warm South of the Border feeling red tones, old dry wooden decor minimally spaced for style across the walls. The columns, bar and tables are thick and strong looking wood. 

We ordered the plato de apertivos, a green chile stew, a Niman Ranch steak Burrito and a Roasted Chicken Burrito. Everything was above average. The salsas were flavorful and out of the ordinary. Our tamales were equally good. The guacamole was chunky and tasted freshly prepared. The burritos were of high quality; we could taste the quality of the meat and the care of preparation. 

They have beer on draught as well for an added bonus. There is something also to be said for the value. This is upscale Mexican cuisine. I ordered the largest appetizer plate, 2 entrees and 2 beers and it came out to a ridiculously affordable 35 dollars. 

I can affirm that I will be going back, again and again.
author: Jay C.

description: Having relatives in Santa Fe/Albuquerque and visiting for any extended amount of time makes me really miss SF Mexican food. But, living in SF I find myself missing real Southwestern food on occasion, so this place takes care of me. Avoid going in a group at peak hours, it's seat-yourself/order at the counter so it can be tough sometimes.
author: Mike T.

description:
