i'm definitely a fan. i've enjoyed everything we've tried so far:

southwestern steak salad (this one makes me think about it when i'm not there, so i've ordered it both times i've been)
green chile stew (delicious with pork)
posole (rich and stewy, and still managed to feel light)
new mexican homestyle chicken enchiladas (it's served up like a lasagna with layers of tortilla and stuffing with a top layer of green chiles - yum!)
enchilada omelet (not sure if this is the exact name of it, but something like that)

first 2 items are my faves so far.

parking's not the greatest, but looks like there are buses nearby... and there's always some place for your bike :)
author: Kariz M.

description: There's a moment in Pulp Fiction where QT tells Sam Jackson he likes to buy the more expensive coffee because when he drinks it, he likes to TASTE it.  The steak burrito (And probably the whole menu) at Green Chili Kitchen subscribes to that methodology.  You'd swear they just killed the cow prior to your order, and with the addition of their rich, prickly green sauce, your tongue will be buzzing like Dick Dale's guitar all night long.
author: Michael D.

description:
Came back here to slurp down more posole, which I regularly crave.  It was still delicious, but since they have moved it looks like the portion size may have been reduced in the process.  The bowl seems shallower and now I'm thinking I need to explore more of the menu because $7+ for the quantity doesn't seem like it's as good of a deal anymore.  But hey, still damn good food!  Had some nachos with the green chile sauce + refried beans and they were winners.

The new location is bigger and more crowded, which is a positive thing to see these days.  More people able to experience the flavorful dishes.  Less cozy and more open-air than before - a fair trade.

One negative was the fact that it was so crowded that everyone was in "vulture mode" to obtain a table.  People jumping on tables as soon as there was a hint that someone may be done with their meal.  And this was a midweek (Wednesday) evening dinnertime.  Not what may be their biggest rush.

My companion and I were able to get a decent place by the window at some bar seats, but unfortunately after several minutes nobody came by to bus the prior diner's plates.  We ended up busing them ourselves.  Bleh.  Sloppy half-eaten sour cream and meat slop splash all over the counter.  Collect napkins and wipe.  Customer shouldn't be doing this kind of work.

Not enough to keep me away though.  In fact it looks like the ice cream establishment in the prior location is from the same owner?  Definitely interested in that.
author: Bryan T.

description: I would really give this place 3.5 stars, but Yelp still disallows half stars sadly. The food was pretty well done, I had a quarter chicken and a kale salad for dinner. The salad could have been presented a bit better, the flavors were good but everything looked a bit mushy. The chicken was good as well, nothing stood out about it but it had good flavor and wasnt overly cooked
author: Greg D.

description:
Full disclosure: this place used to be right down the street from me. Since it moved, it is now right on my corner. This is both a blessing and a curse.

Now I give it five stars as a vegetarian. In that context, all the meals are reasonably priced for their portions. However, for you meat eaters out there, it is a bit more pricey, hence the $$.

My favorite here are the burritos. Vegetarian, no sour cream, green hot, smothered in cheese. I would have it every meal if I had the money. But many of the other menu items are just as good. Only once in my long history of frequenting this place have they messed up my order and it was pinto beans instead of black beans, so it was still enjoyable.

Green Chile does a good job creating an atmosphere. The chili peppers hanging everywhere, the religious paraphernalia, the jars for glasses, and lots of hardwood make for its own feel. The people behind the counter are always friendly, but definitely spacey, so for take out you need to ask sometimes if your food is ready in case it's just sitting there. 

The wait varies based on the time of day you go. During down times, ten minutes is the average, although calling in 15 before is preferable at these times. When it is busy, it can take from half an hour to an hour, so bring a friend or a book in that situation.

The location is perfect, right off the 5-Fulton, a few blocks from the Panhandle, and close to Divis. Between this place and Matching Half, this corner has completely transformed in the last couple of months into a lively little area.

Overall, a great place to sit and have some good New Mexican food. They open in a couple of hours, so my wait isn't much longer.
author: Jake W.

description: TO GO! Take the food to go!! This is a nice little neighborhood find, but it's cheap and that means families with little kids. On my last visit there were toddlers jumping on a bench and a dad who thought it was cute to leave his little girl crying inside the restaurant while he teased from outside. This is unfortunate, but what can the restaurant do about their customers who will not teach their children how to behave. Have these people not heard of 'inside voice' or taking their kid outside during a tantrum? That's what I did when the kids were small. Sheesh. It's sad because the food is truly delicious, fresh and the portions are reasonable.  I have ordered their green chile, the chicken, the tamales, the breakfast healthy dish, the chicken and southwestern salads and the pozole. Consistently delicious. I love the decor and the staff. They are always nice.
author: Susan B.

description:
Two words: Wet burrito. 

I've been here a bunch of times for their awesome salads and chicken, but yesterday I was in the mood for a burrito. Thanks to the urge, I now believe in God. 

Praise you, wet burrito. You changed my life.
author: Kate P.

description:
Love love love this place. Love this place so much my friends often pass by to see if I'm there. Everything I have tried there is good. Love their flan!
Their meat comes from great sources too. The sauces are amazing. The entire staff is very friendly. The new location is even better because now I can find a seat of instead of ordering to go.
Have take many friends from out of town or family there and they too can't stop talking about it. They have been great with my sometimes strange requests.

I LOVE YOU GREEN CHILI KITCHEN!!!!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Nothing really special.  Yes they have green chile, but I wasn't thinking it was great.  I've been to New Mexico and had green chile there, I'm sure this is a healthier version of New Mexican.  I had the flat blue corn enchiladas and the green chile w/pork....like I said, both were ok.  (I did not try my rice and beans b/c I was full).  My mom had the grilled veg burrito with the tofu and green chile, she said it was good and she was stuffed after.
Skip the sangria...not worth it.  The seating was interesting, didn't like the order at the counter and wait for the food with a table number.  LONG lines of people ordering to go on a weekday.
Interesting selection of vegan organic wine for sale.
author: Q L.

description:
Um. Yum.

That's the only word to describe this place. It's very cute and casual -- rustic-looking almost. It was a cold San Francisco afternoon, and I was craving soup. I came to the right place!

I ordered a bowl of the Green Chili. It was spectacular! Perfect amount of spice, great flavor, and a dollop of sour cream to top it off. I will definitely be back to try some other things on the menu.
author: Lauren F.

description: The vegetarian green chile stew is so very delicious that I often dream about it.  Very spicy so it's great when you're sick and want something comforting with layers of flavor (I think you can also order it milder but maybe I'm making that up).  I've also had the sweet potato tamales (vegan!) and they were great as well.  I dock it 1 star b.c I do think it's a bit over-priced for Mexican food, but I've yet to discover a green chile stew that's as delicious as this one.
author: Rani V.

description: I'm a big fan of Green Chile Kitchen.  They have New Mexican food, which is pretty close to the Tex-Mex that a lot of people are more familiar with.  My favorite dish is the homestyle chicken enchiladas--ask for them "Christmas" to get both green and red chile sauces.
author: Dan W.

description: Currently one of my favorite spots for lunch. I wish it were in my neighborhood! Every time I get over to the Fillmore, I stop and have lunch here. You've got to try the roasted chicken w/green chile rub, and mashed potatoes. Their soup is delicious, you can get it veggie if you want. I had it with pork. They also have really good coffee (blue bottle I think), and a great atmosphere. The restaurant is on the corner, and they have community picnic tables inside. There are lots of windows, and the place is large and airy.
author: Michelle W.

description:
Oh, Green Chile Kitchen, what would I do without you. I'm from New Mexico and green chile is one of those things I just can't live without. This place gets contemporary New Mexican style food just right with fresh ingredients and balanced flavors.  I'm a fan of their super chicken burrito, vegetarian breakfast burrito, green chile stew and enchilada plate. All green, all spicy, yum! 

As for the move from Baker and Fulton to Baker and McAllister, I can certainly understand the need to expand. The old location was always rather cramped sometimes. Still, I liked the coziness of the old location. Something about the old Cafe Neon space is a bit cold and industrial feeling. It's also odd to me also that in expanding, they would abandon their flagship location. But, maybe I'm just bummed I have to walk an extra block to get there as it seems to be just long enough to make me question changing from sweats to jeans to pick up. 

Overall, I'm a devoted fan. Nonetheless, I do have to ask, "where are the sopapillas?!"
author: Maya B.

description: The food was good. The staff was rude for no reason.
author: L M.

description: My husband and I just moved here and this was top on our list b/c we had heard such great things....needless to say, it did not disappoint.  We got a burrito to split - they are enormous so it was plenty big for the two of us.  Also, they have $2 pacificos all day - can't beat that!
author: Jesse B.

description:
I might've expected too much from this place as my friend told me it was New Mexican food and I was hoping for something that wasn't your generic Mexican food. I've never been to New Mexico, I don't know what their particular cuisine is like, but I'm always up for trying new types of food.

It tasted like your average Mexican food... Over-priced Mexican food at that. My question is: what makes it New Mexican? The blue tortilla? The lackluster green chile? The food is decent and portions are decent (I couldn't finish my enchilada plate, but I was pretty close). While it was good, it was also uninspired and not at all memorable.

My rating is exactly what it is, "A-OK".
author: Annie Y.

description:
I've been going to Green Chile for about 5 years now, as I used to live nearby. I must say that their service and food have gone downhill since their move up to McAllister. I was excited for them to occupy a larger space, but now I'm bummed that they moved.
One of my favorite things to order here is the regular burrito sans meat "supered", which I've been ordering for years. For some reason since the move they can NOT seem to get this correct. How hard is it to make a burrito without meat that is not their veggie burrito?
When they do make orders correct the food is still pretty good, but not as good as it used to be. I miss the old Green Chile. =(
author: Kate O.

description:
Normally, I am a bit suspicious when it comes to Mexican food that isn't down-home-greasy-sleazy from a divey Mission taqueria, but I enjoyed the food at Green Chile. 

My enchiladas were hearty and probably a million times better for me than a ginormous bomb of a burrito from Valencia St.
author: Marcus C.

description: I loved the place and the food was good, but to anyone gluten intolerant  STEER CLEAR as I experienced a terrible allergic reaction. #GFPride #myGFgirls #2014noGF #ouchmystomachGF #tummyproblemsGF #GFmoms
author: Grace E.

description:
Well, they moved and they brought the great taste with them.

My personal favorite at GCK is the chorizo breakfast burrito.  Someone recently posted that they did not like it.  Well they're crazy, and normally I wouldn't say that because everyone has a preference, but here's what tipped me off: "Eggs, overcooked potatoes, salsa, cheese overload, nothing for crunch.  Not good!"

What's better? Over-cooked or under-cooked potatoes? Crunch?!?  When has a burrito ever crunched that wasn't at Taco Bell?  Are you thinking of Chimichangas? Those crunch, but for fully-fried reasons.  

I don't know, I'm just a man that likes greasy, fully loaded hangover cures within stumbling distance from my bed.  I don't mean to disrespect you Sam M., but I do agree with Keith.

Oh, and remember to get the super burrito.
author: Alex P.

description:
I live 4 blocks away from GCK and I have been here many, many times.

I'm surprised that people find the food inconsistent. I have always had a bomb meal here! Lots of flavor, lots of options. Delicious organic, Niman Ranch meats in generous portions. 

The restaurant is modern, spacious, and filled with light. A great place to eat, enjoy, and digest for a while. This is not a dine-and-dash taqueria, and if you're looking for that, head to Papalote.

Come to GCK for delicious, hearty, NewMex-meets-traditional-Mex cuisine. And come hungry!
author: Colette H.

description:
The GCK has recently moved one block north and the food and location are lovely.  The staff is friendly but I sometimes wished they remembered my name and were glad that  I came.  

The menu is filled with modern twists on quesadilla's, enchiladas and burritos.  The atmosphere is comfortable, cantina styled seating and huge booths.

I always grab eats here around lunchtime and never have a problem finding seating and always short lines.  

Enjoy.
author: Naeem N.

description:
I lived down the block from GCK for about a year and ate there or got takeout often.  My two favorite items on the menu are

1. The roasted chicken, there are two options for the rub and they're both great.  The meal option gets you calabacitas or salad, rice and beans...  This has never disappointed .  Healthy-ish, clean food.  The chicken is reliably delicious, and not dry.  

2. Breakfast burrito with steak (the chicken is a little blah in this), though when I last checked they stop serving them early enough on the weekends that I can rarely make it in time to get one.  

I'd give them five stars but they have made mistakes on my order so many times, especially with takeout, that I can't in all honestly give them a fiver.  Often the salad dressing is wrong - they make a bomb blueberry vinaigrette, so when you open your salad and see creamy goop all over...  ich.   Or you ask for it on the side and it's still mixed in, seeping out of the corners of the box.  Once I bit into my burrito (I usually get it with black beans, no rice, meat, cheese, guac) and it was mostly empty inside with sour cream and guac all slopped in there...  really foul if you're expecting a drier burrito, not to mention the color.  Mistakes have mostly been with takeout, and things other than the chicken meal, which is pretty hard to get wrong.  
They have some wines, and pleasant people behind the counter.  

Last note - it's not my favorite place to eat in.  It's huge and noisy and reminds me of a cafeteria.  A lot nicer than a high school dining hall, but still.  It could use big plants or something to divide the space and make it a little more cozy.
author: Sofia K.

description: Finding this place sure put a smile on my face. I have been missing New Mexican food for a long time now. Not as good as the food you can get in NM but pretty damn close. Only let down, where are the huevos rancheros?
author: Celina E.

description:
(Hopefully everyone knows they moved almost a year ago, but Chile Pies in their old location is great too!!)

Maybe it's because my friends work here, and maybe its because there are $2 Pacificos all day every day, but this place warms my whole heart. While I consider it "burritos for the bourgeoisie," I can't complain about free range chicken and hormone free steak, fresh made sour cream and my plate not dripping with grease.
Faves: breakfast burrito with bacon, super nachos with steak and christmas chile, and blue corn flat plate enchiladas. (Did I say $2 Pacifico?)

Come, sit at the bar, talk to my friends and enjoy a delicious meal. 
Then head down Baker to Chile Pies and fall in love with the Chocolate Peanut Butter pie :)
author: Sarah C.

description:
I love the atmosphere here, the lights are low, the smell of sizzling chiles and grilled meats hangs in the air, and you drink your ice water out of a mason jar.

I knocked this down to 3 stars because I actually was not blown away by the food. I know there are a lot of positive reviews, and I liked what I got, but it just didn't change my life. I had the Blue Corn Flat Enchiladas with pork. The dish is supposed to come with ground beef, but the menu mentions you can also have it filled with chicken, pork, cheese, or veggies, whatever. I just thought the pork, which was cubed not shredded, was kind of tough and not too flavorful. And the rice and beans were good, but I've had better. And everything seemed just a little heavy.

Maybe it was an off night, maybe I was off. I live around the corner, and it was pretty good, so I'll definitely be back, I hope to be more impressed next time.
author: Lowen B.

description:
I'm often ridiculed for not knowing more about the restaurants, shops, etc in my hood.  Yes, I live in Western Addition/NoPa but I don't often get a chance to go out there because most of my friends live in other areas.  However, I have slowly but surely gotten around to many of the places I've walked by on a regular basis over the years and this is one of them.

Sadly, I never made it to their old location but I always loved the Neon Cafe location which GCK has taken over.

I came here last night with Tim V whose opinion you often have to temper with the fact that he says "epic" about many places that in the end, I don't agree with. (Love you, Tim!)   That being said, this place is fairly solid.  Good prices for New Mexican style food.  I ordered the Grilled Chicken Burrito which came with blue corn tortilla chips and salsa.  It was pretty tasty although I think the green chile could've been spicier (I ordered the hot) and there could've been more on the burrito.  Another thing we noticed was that there were only two types of hot sauce on the table.  I really think they could benefit from having a better selection but that's just my opinion.

I'll definitely head back here at some point to try some of the other things on the menu.  Looked like a great selection!
author: Melanie N.

description:
Back when this place was Cafe Neon I used to come in here all the time.  It was dead normally.  The fact is I knew the owner wasn't putting the effort into the place and I think it suited him.  I would read my books and I eat food that was three stars at best.

Years later I saw him at the Sea-biscuit, another cafe he owns, and he said that Green Chiles bought him out.  I have been here several times since.

Just off the beaten track, Green Chiles has some of the best food I have known in the city.  Seriously, I am not about to buy the Guacamole for 7 dollars but some of the other items on the menu are worth eating.  This is especially true for their Carnitas Tamales-- I have that every time I'm there.  I have a problem with the prices, which are not what I think the food is worth and the service which could use some tuning but the over all product is just what I wanted!
author: Kevin F.

description:
I ate here for lunch today. I have eaten here many times and usually enjoy it. I think that if I would have written this review on any of my other experiences it would have been four star but lunch was disappointing.
I went with Roommate while we were doing laundry down the street. 
I had the best of everything veggie salad with the creamy dressing...forget which one it was...salad and dressing were super tasty. I also got a cheese tamale....and instead they served me chicken which I took a bite of, which...is sad...because i dont eat meat....so...yeah that was a downer. So then I went and told them and they gave me a veggies one...which....was okay but I wanted cheese so....there you have it.
Roommate had the Chile Relleno which was cold in the inside. Instead of taking it off the plate and reheating is alone they i think put the whole plate in the microwave or the oven or something because the plate was steaming. This was especially unfortunate because there was fresh lettuce and tomatoes on the plate which were just not as good looking after.
author: Yuliya R.

description:
I love GCK! I've tried one of their breakfast burritos with the Christmas Sauce and a chicken quesadilla. The food is great and portions are pretty big!! but the main thing i like about this place is the atmosphere and location. 

(but now that they've moved... i dont know how different it is yet!)

Anyway in simple words.. this place is a combo of hippy +european+ down to earth + relaxing place to have lunch or even a drink.
author: Hanna K.

description:
Green Chile Kitchen has really cheap Pacifico ($2!), delicious food, and a fun, comfortable atmosphere. A quick dinner out here with a friend had him waxing rhapsodic about how food like this was the reason he loves living in the Bay Area.

It can be a little loud by the counter, so minus half a star for having to yell my order at the woman at the register, apparently unsuccessfully, because (minus another half star) the only thing about my burrito that was what I asked for was the color of the chile on top of it. I'd usually take off more, but I couldn't bring myself to do it because the beef burrito with black beans was incredibly good, but it's still not the pork and pinto that I asked for. 

Anyhow. If you go in knowing that this is food from New Mexico and not Mexico and you don't mind a little noise, I highly recommend Green Chile Kitchen.

Bonus points if you stop by Chile Pies and Ice Cream a block away on your way home for pie and/or delicious Three Twins ice cream. (The Venetian Coffee is particularly good.)
author: Mary H.

description:
So goooooooooood.

Blue corn tortilla flat enchiladas with chicken and mild green chilies all over=heaven.

Their green chile stew is also great with sour cream.

This place is really pricey but worth it, for sure!
author: Marisa R.

description: 5 star salsa, 4 star salad, 3 star prices, 1 star lemonade.  The salsa outweighs the lemonade.  Go to Green Chile's, just get a beer or a mexican coke instead (soda not drug type) of flavorless lemonade.
author: Jeff G.

description:
great sounding menu with all the right buzzwords, but overall not tasting any better than other taquerias.
e.g. Mary's Free Range Roasted Chicken -- got regular with refried beans, organic rice, pico de gallo & green chile.  basically, heat the tortilla, add the fillings and that's it.  a soft content burrito with healthy ingredients.  this kind of place fits in with sf.
author: Rob C.

description:
I lived in Santa Fe for three years, and every once in a while (more often than that), I get a jonesing for some New Mexican food.  That is not the same thing as Mexican food, as anyone from New Mexico will laboriously explain to you.  So it was with great anticipation that I went to GCK for the first time.  Yum.

I shall repeat myself:  Yum.

I got chicken enchiladas, and of course, Christmas, because I had to try both the red and green chile sauces.  

Did I say Yum?

I also like the common tables, which is just a good, homey vibe. I got a kick out of these two blokes who were not-so-patiently waiting for a party to leave so they could take their places, even though there were two empty seats across from each other right between that party and my party.  Common tables, you maroons!

My only disappointment was that the sopapillas weren't puffy like you get in New Mexico.  

I shall go back, again and again, count on it.
author: Paul S.

description:
The prices are just too damn high!

Ok, but seriously let me start from the beginning. This is the first time I have been back to Green Chile since their move. First of all, I love their new location. I think it is just right; the old place was just too crowded. 

As for the food, I had the steak burrito and a side of guacamole. Its really good food to be honest. I really enjoyed it. Nice presentation and it is definitely a notch above your favorite five dollar burrito joint (which usually tend to be in the Mission). Their guacamole is pretty god damn good if you ask me. It is one of the best guacamoles I have had in this entire city. I will certainly be back if only to get some take out guac. The burrito was also really good, and their extra effort in tastefully dabbing on guacamole sour cream and salsa while making it a super did not go unnoticed. 

Now lets talk about why I'm giving it 3 stars. Bottom line, the price is just too damn high. I paid nearly twenty dollars for the guacamole appetizer and super burrito! If they could drop the price by just one dollar on every entree I would automatically give it 4 stars. Nonetheless, since I live around the corner, its a nice addition and I will be back, but I wouldn't go out of my way for it.
author: Jeff C.

description:
The food here is okay, but not great. Nothing spectacularly good or bad, so I'd say Green Chile Kitchen is a solid choice for a lazy evening where no grander plans have been made.

The posole soup is the one gem on the menu; so delicious.
author: Brian D.

description: Ate here for lunch and loved it!  I had the green chili quesadilla with pork.  It was delicious.  I want to go back and try something else soon!
author: Christy L.

description: The green chile stew with pork is freakin delicious.  Probably one of the best things I ate this year.  I found this place via bay area check please.  Parking here is a bitch so if you can try going during a weekday.  The blue corn enchiladas were just ok.  The tamales were pretty good.  They were even better if you add a touch of their chile honey to it.  I'll be back for the stew.
author: Fatty A.

description:
Who knew I liked soyrizo?  Well I do!
My darling roommate called me last weekend asking what I wanted for breakfast - I nearly swooned right over as I was trying to drag myself down the street for coffee and couldn't quite figure out which sweats went best with which flip flops so it was taking a while. 
He came home with a gigantic (no potato) breakfast burrito for me which I promptly inhaled, sharing with him the relative joys of soyrizo (in that, omg, it's not disgusting and actually tastes a bit like chorizo!).  Add to that scrummy green chiles and a nice grilled, brown, crispy outside and I was in breakfast burrito bliss.
Fan!
author: Jennifer D.

description: Nom nom.  I got the Southwest Steak Salad with Cotija Queso dressing.  What a journey that salad was.  I loved every component from the steak to the roasted corn to the jicama.  My friends entrees looked equally tempting, whether it was the roast chicken or smothered enchiladas.  And the sopapillas with red chile honey were to die for.  Be wary that families come here in droves on a Friday night.  Other than that, this spot is a gem.
author: Jeremy G.

description: This place is okay. The vibe is pretty nice and the food is just alright for the price. The servers are really nice and they have great customer service. This place was fine to stop by once because it was near by, but I doubt I would go out of my way to come back.
author: Caitlyn C.

description: This place has a nice vibe but I had way too high of expectations. It's nice that a place has cool decor and a nice drink selection but if the food is terrible, then it's all just a waste. To be fair, I've only been here once and I got the crispy tacos. The tacos were gross and the rice and beans were even worse. They completely missed the mark. It's not that hard to make good tacos, rice and beans. They failed big time. I'm curious to see if maybe it was just an off night.....maybe their salads are a lot better. I don't know, I'll probably never come to this place again.
author: Natalie H.

description: i love this place. it's consistent, fresh and delicious and has become a reliable standby for us. it has a light and relaxed atmosphere -- literally, there are large windows, so it's airy, and the staff are very friendly.
author: BayArea L.

description:
I love Mexican food, I can eat it 7 days a week. I'm not really even that picky about it but that doesn't mean I don't know a good muthersuckin burrito when I have one. 

vegetarian burrito...make it a super. YUMMY pinto beans, YUMMY rice, good tortillas, amazing red sauce.

that burrito was one of my best mastication experiences all month.

oh, and it's great hang-over food.
author: chandra g.

description: Holy sh!t... The only reason anyone wouldn't give this place 5 stars is if they are smug  as hell... Dope food! Seating is tight but it moves... Besides its sf and hipsters love that crap, so get used to it. Did I mention that the food is AMAZEBALLS!!!
author: Sunset W.

description:
It's funny - the idea of GCK always sounds REALLY good to me.  When I get there, the menu also looks pretty good (although I don't eat meat, so somewhat limited in options).  Then, when I get the food, it's good - not great - just good.  But I guess between the vibe, the decor, the friendly staff and the fact that's it's only a couple blocks from my house, I continue putting it in my "really good" category in my head.  

Overall, I'd recommend it, but note: This is southwestern, New Mexican food....different than what many Californians are used to when it comes to what we (ignorantly) think is "Mexican food"...an adjustment I had to admittedly make but came to appreciate and enjoy.
author: David M.

description: I come to Green Chile probably every week so I guess it is pretty good. It's one of nicest (looking) places near my home so distance helps. My favorites in the menu are posole, stew, herb chicken and veggie burrito with everything and as spicy as they make it. Too bad they don't have Negra Modelo anymore.  Maybe if they had wifi and coffee I wouldn't leave. Perhaps better that way :-)
author: Jari S.

description: I really liked the vibe of this restaurant.  It was fun and the decorations were unique.  The 5 stops right outside so it's ideal for muni/bike riders! If you were to drive it'd be a little difficult but still doable.  When we walked in, we were a little confused if we were to seat ourselves or order at the counter because there were menus sitting on a sidetable.  But the waiter directed us so we ordered right away, got a number, and sat down.  The food came about 10 minutes after we ordered, and it was excellent! I ordered a burrito with guacamole, pork, and the works.  It was delicious! My boyfriend had the same except with chicken.  We are definitely coming back! It was inexpensive, about $8-9 for a burrito depending what you want in it (extra for cheese and guac).  There were 2 families with young children there, so it's good for the whole family! Definitely coming back!
author: Alicia Q.

description:
Ah, really tasty organic New Mexican food.  I love the crispy taco plate w/ ground beef, but I won't get it for take out because the shell breaks down after a few minutes.  The spicy green chile stew is also good.

It's a little pricey but well worth it.  Come early to avoid the lines and the wait for a table.
author: Arthur C.

description:
When my order was recieved, there was a stack of orders about 15 deep, only one girl at the burrito assembly line and she looked overwhelmed. So she pulls our her blackberry, talks on the floor, then gets to work. Touches her hair, touches the tortillas...

Eventually 3 more workers come out and assist, but they all looked confused at the ticket line-up. The burrito was bland, no green chile which I asked for. 

Both cashiers told me at different times "its almost ready" when it wasn't even being grilled. They were apologetic . Shoulda gone to Papalote
author: Megan P.

description: They redid their brunch menu recently, and it's definitely worth a visit. Possibly even worth bypassing the NOPA wait altogether.
author: Kristen C.

description: i ordered the enchiladas. They were good... but something was missing. I'd like to say that this place is a cross between an upscale Aqui and a taqueria.  Not sure if I'm inclined to come back.
author: Ting B.

description:
Yummy green chile stew, vegetarian and pork are both delicious! 
I just called them and they said Sopapillas will be served as soon as the end of the month, I can hardly wait.  Warm, fluffy sopapillas with honey are the best!
author: Full T.

description:
Just made my first visit to Green Chili Kitchen (at their new location...) based on my neighbor's recommendation. The space is bright and inviting - much more appealing than their old, darker place on Fulton. (Though the new location is the site of several previous failed restaurants - let's see if GCK survives at this spot...!)

... but on this occasion, I opted for a burrito to go. I got the Nieman Ranch steak "super" burrito with the no-so-hot green chili sauce. At about ~$10, it's a little bit more than I'm used to paying for a burrito (and just a little bit more than the comparable Papalote). But the burrito is big, quite tasty, and the blue corn chips & spicy salsa that come with the burrito are very tasty. 

Good, solid, burrito (though not a match for Papalote!) But - I think I need to go back and eat at GCK to get a better sense of the place.
author: donal c.

description:
If there's one thing that San Francisco is sorely lacking in its collection of restaurants, it's got to be Regional American food. GCK goes a long way in correcting that by being the only place in town that servers New Mexican (as in the state, New Mexico) cuisine, and more specifically, chile covered everything.

This is not really a taqueria - sure they have burritos and the like, but really the main reason to come here is for the chile-based items - especially the chile stew. Although the red chile sauce is pretty good, I prefer the green - spicy and flavorful to say the very least. The enchiladas are a great way to bring out the flavor of the sauces as well. I'm pretty stoked to come back and try the breakfast options.

In terms of the pricing, I guess if you compare this place to Farolito or Cancun, it's going to look expensive, but don't be fooled by the casual setup (i.e. order at the counter, get a table and wait). The truth is that the food is better than what you'd get at some upscale nonsense place like Tres Agaves and definitely worth the price.
author: Owen R.

description:
I went here today to get a to-go plate for my grandma. She is from Santa Fe and LOVES NM style cooking, especially red chili from Hatch Co.  
We got her 2 tamale plate with sides. She didn't care for the pinto beans, but I thought they were good. She wanted re-fried - ah well, I tried. 
She thought the massa was perfect and the pork super tender - I agreed! I can't wait to go back to get a dinner for home. They have 1/4, 1/2 or whole green chili rubbed chickens togo!
PS - please have flan next time, you were out today!!!!
author: Erica C.

description: Wow wow wow bomb. The chicken is a must and any alcoholic beverage is really good. Okay chips but the friendly staff makes up for it! A little pricey too!
author: Sinea T.

description: Thee best Green Chiles  stew in Cali! I've been to New Mexico several times and haven't found their fresh green chiles anywhere in SF, even the Mission! I love the Pork Green Chile Stew/soup but it's been a tad bit over-salted lately. I'm just add some chicken broth or hot tea to it. Yumm
author: L T.

description: I remember the first time I ran into this place on accident. At the time was only a couple of blocks from my place and boy was it a find. It turned into one of my favorite places to grab mexican in city. Pretty much everything on the menu is delicious. The service is great and the wait time for food is pretty quick. Make sure try the green chile stew and their burritos.
author: Ajay K.

description:
I've lived around the corner from Green Chile for two years now (through their move to their new location) and I give them two stars only because every once in a while, I have an extremely tasty burrito there. But it's only two because of the many, many, many experiences I have had there where I have waited forever for a burrito I even called in to order ahead of time and it takes more than 30 minutes even when the place isn't that packed. It's a bit crazy actually, and it seems that even though they moved to a larger location, their cooking line has remained the same size and capacity. 

The other thing is the food. Like I said, every once in a while there is a truly amazing burrito that comes off that line. But it's hit or miss... many times their chicken or pork is really dry (and I'm glad they use organic sustainably raised stuff, another reason for 2 and not 1 star), and often the ingredients are bland or not even what I asked for. Is New Mexican food just wimpy Mexican food? When I ask for hot, I want some heat. Oh, and their salads? I got one a week ago with some supermarket pre-shredded cheese blend, canned beans and dry chicken cubes on the side. Trader Joe's does better.

So in summation, this place has awesome stuff going for it: location, atmosphere, mason jars, organic ingredients, cool staff. But it needs to live up to its hype: make good food and make it consistently! and if you're doing take-out, make it ready when you say it will be! Why do I keep going back? That mythical delicious burrito stays in my mind as I walk my dog past its doors each day, just like the mythical wave stays in my mind as I paddle out into absolute crap. It has so much promise, and it is local and it is responsible so I will always choose it over, say, Chipotle. But for reliability, honesty and fun, I'll be headed to the Papa(lote) much more often.
author: Sean G.

description:
Inviting, reasonably-priced, decent New Mex cuisine = three stars.  The fourth star is for the out-of-this-world fact that I can now walk just a few blocks to get a humungus mug of spicy Mexican hot chocolate, instead of having to wait for some special occasion, when The Husband stirs up a special pot of dark chocolate/ milk/ sugar/ cinnamon/ eggs/ vanilla/ chili powder to help make me feel super-blessed.  ¡Sabrosa!

GCK's stuff is seriously as good as homemade.  I'll definitely be back for this, and 110% recommend it to other chocolate lovers!  (Now, if only the desserts were in the same spot, that would be perfection!)
author: E R.

description:
Better again!!  Yeah!!  Maybe they read my reviews.  Probably not.  But maybe.  I read the Yelp reviews for my restaurant like it's my job... oh wait... it is...

Anyway, they seem to have pulled their act together, as my last lunch there was super yummy.  Thanks, Green Chili Kitchen...
author: Jennifer P.

description:
If it's been more than 3 days between my visits, my friends start asking me what's going on.

Awesome burritos every time. Friends visiting from New Mexico said this place is legit because of the "Christmas" option on the menu. (Both red and green chile). Either way, I wouldn't care because this place serves up some bomb nomnom.
author: Anthony C.

description: Such a nice, low - key restaurant. It's a little chilly inside, but the delicious New Mexican food warms you up nicely. Very neighborly & welcoming.
author: Pat K.

description: Great New Mexican fare! I was in San Francisco for a few days last weekend and came upon the Green Chile Kitchen through the WHERE book in our hotel room of all places. We were actually thinking of getting a burrito in the Mission, but I love New Mexican cuisine and we decided to try this instead. Glad we did; I loved the laid back vibe and the food was excellent. It came out steaming hot, which is always a pleasure. It was busy, but not packed for a midday Sunday. I got the savory pork sopapillas with Christmas sauce and my dad went for the green chile roasted pork burrito. Both were well seasoned, fresh, and tasted great. I went for the mild, but I probably should have gone with hot because I do like some kick to the sauces.
author: Mary N.

description:
Was super psyched to try the Green Chile Kitchen after coming across it on yelp last week.  We decided tonight was THE night.

We found the joint nestled in a quiet residential neighborhood full of cute Victorians.  When we walked in, my mouth started watering immediately from the warm aroma of chile and rotisserie chicken, it smelled absolutely delicious in there.  The place was full of promise - no seating to be found anywhere, a decent sized line, definitely the mark of an excellent restaurant.

Here's the drill - you order at the counter, pick up your own cutlery and cold water, find an empty seat w/ your number and wait patiently while they bring out your food.  

I ordered the veggie nachos, and S.B ordered the veggie burrito w/ chili tofu and green chile sauce.  After waiting about 15 minutes our food arrived looking and smelling fantastic.

In regards to the nachos, I love all of the ingredients - roasted zucchini, mushrooms, onions, real melted cheese, pico de gallo, refried beans, and guacamole over tortilla chips.  When I took my first bite, the little voice in my brain immediately sounded the warning alarm - "Houston, we have a problem..."  I was unpleasantly surprised by some very stale torilla chips.  I'm not talking about one or two stale chips, I'm talking about the whole plate - totally inedibly, and utterly stale!  I had to literally choke them down.  WHAT...THE...F*CK...!!?  Inexcusable.

S.B.'s burrito was no better, it was completely bland.  I understand tofu is bland, but the rice, beans and chile sauce literally had no salt at all.  

If it were just the nachos with the problem, I might have concluded that this was an off day, but the burrito too?  A big damn bummer.
author: Burrito M.

description:
Always good!  Every once in a while I realize that I have not been here in a while and I ask myself the same questions every time...why not?

The food here is fresh and always quick, the people are great and they have Negro Modelo on draft, can't beat it.
author: Nicholas S.

description:
Oh so amazing- a tad on the pricy side, but I think it's worth it.  Good Veggie options, and insanely good carnivore options.  Even special desserts- haven't tried them yet but they look delightful. 

Much better experience since they moved to their new larger space.
author: Candace B.

description: So I finally went to the new location on Baker St. The food is still 5 stars! The downside: the new space, furniture and general ambiance have knocked GCK down a star for me. It's starting to feel like a chain. The intimate, authentic feeling is a lot less prevalent than in the old location. Also, the addition of a wine/ espresso bar seems silly compared to the way the old restaurant looked/felt. The service has also gone down. It was always kinda DIY at the old location but there is hardly any staff around and the new place is 3 times as big. I'm definitely still a fan but it's not one of my very favorite restaurants anymore.
author: Veronica J.

description: Yum Yum! Was taken here by a friend and was a bit hesitant because I'm not a big fan of  mexican food. Can't eat too much of it often and its high in fat/calories. When I saw the menu and reviews I was so happy to try this place out! Not only do they have great mexican food, they have a variety of vegetarian options and its healthy! I opted for the vegetarian tacos (w/ tofu) and surprisingly it was delicious. Ive came back twice already and plan on coming here more often when craving mexican! The watermelon fresca is quite delicious too!
author: Colette P.

description:
Went to this place right after the street sweepers finished cleaning Alamo Square after the crazes called the Bay2Breakers came through.  So can you imagine the lines and chaos of drunks? But we were hungry so what were our options; starve or eat so we got on line. It went by quick and found a table enough for 7, we found friends straggling along the route overcome with the madness. Food tends to calm the nerves so we ate together and really enjoyed our meal. 

The food here is above average. We all had something different, the perks of going out with a group you get to try lots of food; everyone was satisfied.  I mean it's Mexican, how can you get it wrong, right? Wrong, lots of places do, I haven't been able to pin point what those places lack, but whatever it is this place definitely makes up for. 

We had:
hard shell chicken taco plate
pork burrito
verde stew
enchilladas
chicken burrito
nachos
author: Tamz O.

description:
My pal introduced me to the Green Chile Kitchen. I had never been to the old location, but I assure you the new place is cute, has tons of menu options and is reasonable priced. I went in for dinner on a Thursday and we barley got a seat!

The red sangria was the most disappointing part of the meal. I felt it was pretty watered down and the fruit definitely not soaked in brandy or anything special. It was however cheap. I would rather pay a couple dollars more for more pizzaz!

The nachos were good and I enjoyed the guacamole and sour cream on top.

Everything however was spicy. I don't like spicy food, so it was hard to find something to order. Putting the sauce on the side is fine, but I wish they carried a milder green sauce.  The crispy tacos had good flavor and definitely were made to order.
author: Natalie N.

description: Interior is wonderful and inviting.  I ordered the pork burrito and my wife ordered the chicken burrito.  I was disappointed with the pork: chewy and grisly are not good combinations.  The burrito otherwise was good - good beans and guac.  I don't see myself rushing back.
author: Joel G.

description:
So, I am searching for a few of my friends on Yelp and I come across my friend of 20+ years from Texas who happens to live in San Francisco.  He only had 5 reviews, so I decided to see what he took the time to write about.  In the list, I found the Green Chile Kitchen with a 4-star rating.  Since I know he knows Mexican food, and we used to eat it together in Texas regularly, I trusted his opinion.

Ouch.  I thought about giving it 3 stars for a minute becase the food wasn't bad, but then I remember the almost $40 tab...2 stars!

So, I went with my friend from Dallas, who was also craving some Mexican food today.  I told him about our mutual friend's review and we were excited.  We found the place easily and got parking within a block on the first pass.  Everything was fine.

When we walked in, the place was small but nice and had a few empty booths and tables.  There were two people at the cash register ordering so we got in line behind them and began looking at the menu.  We quickly decided to share a small order of nachos.  I wanted the chicken enchiladas, and my friend wanted the steak tacos.  We each got a bottled soft drink.  When the total came to just under $40, I was a bit surprised but shrugged it off thinking that the food was going to be really special.

We sat down with our number and waited.  First, the nachos were delivered to the table.  We both dug in!  What a disappointment.  My best description would be dorito chips with some refried beans, microwave-melted cheese, sour cream and guacamole.  Not good.

Then, the main courses came out.  While they were better than the nachos, the beef was chewy in the tacos and the enchiladas were edible but not really enjoyable.  I didn't like the chicken.  Overall, I would not recommend this place, unless you like overpaying for bad, cheap Mexican food.
author: Ryan W.

description:
I'm not an expert on New Mexican cuisine, but I liked some of the items we tried quite a bit. As countless others have noted, it gets very crowded and seems pretty family-friendly - or, noisy. You order at the counter and the food can be brought out to you, but I'd probably get it to go next time. The atmosphere isn't BAD and the music's nice, but it gets a bit chaotic.

Anyway, more importantly, the food: it's pretty solid. The rotisserie chicken was surprisingly good. Normally I'm pretty bored by this type of dish, but it was actually cooked to perfection, yielding a nice crispy skin and juicy meat. The rice was good and the tortillas (both corn and especially flour) were outstanding. The pinto beans were quite plain and bland, I thought, but not bad. I had the pozole, which I liked a lot - there was abundant hominy and nice chunks of chicken. I was surprised to find that I didn't like the green chile stew, which I had expected to be a stand-out. The pork was succulent but I found the stew to be too soupy and acidic. I had a bite of the enchiladas and was not too impressed - they seemed a bit bland. We also had the tamales appetizer - very good masa and tasty meat, although not quite enough meat for me. Anyway, I'd definitely come back and get the chicken, pozole, and maybe try a few other things.
author: Lisa K.

description:
My dinner last night was actually more of a 3* dinner, but since I've had pretty great meals there 2 or 3 times in the past, I decided to go ahead and round it up to 4*.

All the veggies seem to be very fresh, and I really like the fact that they have free-range chicken and hormone-free beef (even though I don't eat the stuff).

In the past we've gotten the grilled burritos (super yummy!) and the nachos (also yummy). We haven't been wowed by their quesadillas, very little food for the dollar.

I'd say their grilled burritos are 5*. I could have just shared that with my husband last night (with the "hot" green chile sauce, which wasn't actually all that spicy) and been satisfied, but we also decided to try out the tamale plate, with one cheese tamale (for me, the vegetarian) and one pork tamale (for him, the carnivore). That's where the restaurant lost a couple of stars. The tamales were both just kind of blah. Mine seemed to be undercooked. I think that's why my stomach was a little off later that night, the undercooked masa. It also had kind of a sour taste, I'm not sure if that was the cheese or the salsa or what, but it was a weird, unappetizing flavor.

The service is friendly, and the new location is much bigger which is nice. The sound really bounces off the walls though, so it gets pretty loud. It was also pretty cold in there, also probably because of the cavernous space. Maybe they could do something about that?
author: Gael T.

description:
Santa left a gift certificate to Green Chile Kitchen in my stocking this Christmas.  That Santa is a smart guy.  I suspect he may have consorted with a certain "father" who may or may not have been treated to this excellent cuisine after helping a certain "daughter"  assemble a bookshelf at her apartment across the street.  

The veggie quesadilla is scrumptious, stuffed mushrooms and potatoes.  They have perfect size breakfast burritos and platters, and $4 mimosas on the weekends.   Keep in mind this is not authentic Mexican food, nor are they claiming to be.  This New Mexican cuisine is healthy and fresh with true southwest zip.  All the ingredients  are organic and fresh; the salsas are unique and flavorful.  

GCK has a huge rotisserie and you can pick up an entire Fulton Valley chicken to-go!  They also happen to carry 3 more of my favorite things (which have NOTHING to do with the food or with one another):  wine by the bottle, Kumbucha Synergy and Ciao Bella Gelato.

During the day, Green Chile appears to be just a neighborhood coffee shop or breakfast joint.  After nightfall it could pass for bistro with its Christmas lights cascading down the windows and the flicker of table candles.  4 Stars for the "order at the counter, take your number and bumble for a good seat"-kind-of-dining system-- but the rustic furnishings (including using Mason jars as water glasses) creates great ambiance for dining in.
author: Kerry D.

description: I had a cold at least three times last fall/winter and I had to go get the green chile pork stew every time. It's spicy enough to clear out my nose plus it's hearty and has so much flavor that it even tastes good with a cold. Don't get me wrong, I eat it when I'm healthy as well, but it's definitely become my new chicken noodle soup... so yummy. It will leave you full and warm and oh so satisfied.  I'm only taking off one star because of some inconsistencies I've noticed lately. At least two of the many times I've ordered this stew, it tasted different and not so good.. almost like they added chicken broth or something sweet to it. Not good. If I love a dish this much, I want it -no, I need it-  to be the same every time.  The enchiladas are also great. You don't walk away feeling greasy and guilty like other latin food restaurants.
author: Jillian R.

description:
I have been craving tacos badly and I had to find a place that was not in the mission that served amazing tacos. Lo and behold, my friend suggested this place to me and it was glorious!

I got the soft taco plate with steak and it was to die for. Great portions, it was more than what I had expected.

If you expect pure mexican tacos, this isn't the place. It's more of an Americanized version but well worth it. 

I also got the Posole stew, it was definitely an interesting combination, it could have been a bit hotter (temperature wise), but I still enjoyed it. 

Good place, good vibes, good food.

Parking may be hard to find, but well worth it!
author: Carissa E.

description: We came in here for a late night dinner. We ordered the queso green chili dip and a carnitas burrito christmas style and a glass of wine and water. First off the total came to $32 dollars. The queso dip comes and well it's not very good, very bland and meh at best. We doctored it up with some hot sauce from the table. The burrito comes and is very nicely presented. It comes with a small salad and rice. The rice is super bland and pretty tasteless and the salad is some shredded lettuce with no dressing (I'm getting it's decoration). The burrito is quite good, the pork is really good, the beans are nicely seasoned.  I am surprised of how bland things were given it's the Green Chili Kitchen. We ordered the food spicy and it wasn't spicy. Overall it's a good place, expensive for what they are dishing up.
author: Jill T.

description:
I swear the staff here just keeps getting ruder and ruder each time we come in.  It's a really big disappointment because we used to just love this place so much!

The latest was when I asked for black beans on the nachos and got refried.  We didn't say anything until we started eating the burrito and ALSO got refried.  I went up to the kitchen counter to say something and they just looked at me with blank stares and said OK and were just SO rude.  The girl at the register was super nice but I'm hugely disappointed with the rudeness of those making the food!
author: Rachel S.

description: They have the best enchiladas I've ever had. Make sure to get the one with the green chili sauce...think it's called the Sante Fe or something. Not expensive, but not cheap. Def in the starting rotation - once a week
author: Douglas S.

description:
Could be better, could be worse, could probably be more appropriately located in Pac. Heights or the Marina. Kinda looks like they're going for a: "semi-classy and food beyond burritos" Mexican place (disclaimer: I waited outside with the dog, so I only really peaked in).

The burrito tasted fresh, and I enjoyed the crispy rather than greasy tortilla. However, after being asked over the phone whether I wanted green or red chili and spicy or mild, disappointment came over me like a wave when the "spicy green chili" appeared neither green nor spicy. Sigh.

Outside seating seems nice, although it's on Fulton, so you may taint your foods with a mouthful of car exhaust.
author: jack p.

description:
The food is better than a 3, you can really tell that its fresh and organic, but....

It too expensive, $16 with tip for nachos and a diet coke, ouch.

I have had the chicken burrito and the steak nachos and I found the flavors to be a little homogeneous,   They ran together some and it was bland out of the gate.  I like spicy food, and this was certainly not.  I know, I can add my own hot sauce, but I still think that the flavors lacked a certain punch.

Love the feel of the place and the communal table.  The staff is easy on the eyes, just saying..
author: Ken p.

description: Sorry GCK, you are not up to this New Mexican transplant's standards, you're bland over priced and don't listen very well! Why in holy heck would two kids 9 and under want an adult sized taco plate??  the ambiance doesn't even equate to any experience I hoped to have.  The sopas had a nice crunch, but NM cuisine would never dream of serving an al fresco soft taco with NO CHEESE.  I'll save my money and order my chile direct from Bueno without your twist!  I make it WAY better at home.
author: AS N.

description:
I met the owner, Trevor, at SFO airport and he gave me his business card when I told him I was from Santa Fe. 
I had family in town from NM and we decided to try out the food. Wow! What an unexpected treat! We had a party of eight and with much skepticism we ordered our chili rellanos, The food was very authentic and very tasty. I ordered the hotter chili, and it was just right, not overwhelming like it can get, but just right!
The service is semi-self-serve, we ordered at the counter and the food was brought to our table.
It is the best New Mexican food in San Francisco!
author: Jamie S.

description:
Originally from New Mexico and this place reminds me why we have the best food back home. Totally digg this place - I've tried several things on their menu and everything has been top notch.

Affordable too.

5 stars!
author: Rastko S.

description: Deeeelicious!  I live right up the street and would come here a lot more often if it weren't so pricey (it's not THAT bad, but you'll drop $10-$12 on just the entree alone). Haven't had a chance to try everything yet, but anything with grilled vegetables is delicious!! Also, during the holidays they had this delicious Beet Red Margarita drink... SO tasty!
author: Katie W.

description:
Absolutely delicious! 

Neiman Ranch Beef just melts in your mouth...Fresh ingredients! I had the 3 soft tacos which were served with Spanish rice and sauteed zucchini and squash with corn. I can't think if the name but it comes with all the dinners. I left off the salsa and onion, but added white cheese and Avocado. I want another plate right now just thinking about it! $15 dollars for food and drink combined. I also hear they have $2 Pacifico every day! 

So freaking good! That is Fresh Mex!
author: Courtney M.

description: Good vibe. Food was fast and very tasty! Service was friendly & inviting (not very structured when it came to ordering process). Good find :-)
author: Kat M.

description: Took my best friend here for dinner last week and it was DE-lish!  We started with the pork stew and guacamole and chips. For dinner we both had the flat, blue corn, chicken enchilada.  It was hard to decide on my dinner entree because everything on the menu looks good.  They have a decent wine selection.  They have recently started carrying Eight Arms Cellars brand which I love.  All of the folks working here are very friendly.  The ambiance is big and open and the prices reasonable.  Afterward we strolled down the street and grabbed a couple of slices of pie to go from their sister cafe Chile Pies. YUM! Go there now!
author: PictureGirl F.

description:
This is not Mexican food it is New Mexican food which might account for the lack of flavor?

One thing they really have going for them though is the extensive breakfast menu with vegetarian options, which is served until 2pm on the weekend. 
I get the soyrizo breakfast burrito when I'm in a hangover induced jam, without the red or green chili though because I don't think either one is very good. 
I read one review that said they might fare better in the Marina and I think that is probably pretty accurate.
author: Linz H.

description: This is my favorite place to eat! The food is excellent (order the mexican burrito plate or one of the salads - you won't be disappointed). The atmosphere is casual and I like that this is a place you can go, order at the bar and just sit wherever you like. It has a nice ambiance. They could, however, dim the lights a little more at night.. They were pretty bright when I went. The water is self serve with small mason jars which I thought was a nice touch. All in all a great place to dine alone, with friends or on a date.
author: Shayna B.

description:
I love love love this place!  Living two blocks from this place makes it hard not to come here ALL the time.  It's probably one of my favorite places to eat at in my hood.  The food is always consistently fresh and service is always friendly.

It's been getting pretty popular since its opening over a couple years ago so gets very crowded at times.  So I take it to go when that happens.  If you take it to go, I would suggest calling ahead cause the ordering line moves veeeeerrry slowly when it's busy.

Some of my favs are the new mexican chicken enchiladas, the stew, the nachos and the roasted pork burrito!  Oh and brunch is fantastic too, the breakfast burritos are yummers!
author: Susan P.

description:
Visited SF and tried this place.  I was excited for New Mexican food, but this wasn't it by a long shot!  First of all, how can you even call your restaurant "New Mexican" and not serve sopapillas?  

I got a burrito for about $8, and it was really small especially at that price.  So small, in fact, that the tortilla was folded several times underneath; this made it look bigger, but was disappointing when half of the burrito is just tortilla!  I saw that they had a junior burrito, which made me wonder if it was Taco Bell size.

Got the "spicy" green chile sauce, which was mild at best.  Have these people ever been to NM?  I got a chicken alfredo pasta in ABQ with spicier green chile than this!  My gf also tried the green chile stew, which had no meat in it.  It was just a slightly chunky liquid broth.  Maybe we read the menu wrong (seriously, we might have!).

They were also blasting some tunes that didn't sound like anything I heard in NM.  The decor just didn't work, like they started but never quite finished.  Luminarias and Virgin of Guadalupe were up, but then nothing else really.

Nice try at NM, but please try harder.
author: Matt C.

description:
I don't even get some of these reviews, talking about it being expensive. Come on people, they're doing a service, have to be rent, supporting local and organic as well.

Anyhow, I tried them for the first time today, went with the Chicken Burrito (it's Fulton Valley, or if you get beef it's Niman Ranch). Served with the usual ingredients, but I found their green chile sauce to be perfectly spiced.

You get blue corn tortillas as well, with a choice of some gourmet salsas, not all in all a bad deal.

For those who live in the neighborhood, they also have a small but good selection of inexpensive organic wines, easy to pick up on your way home or to a friend's place.

Also for take out, you can buy a whole or half Fulton Valley roasted chicken, that comes with mashed potatoes, yummy instant meal!

They also served breakfast, starting at 9am, and I hear their breakfast burrito is a pretty solid way to start your day.
author: Nish N.

description: What a cute place. I went to New Mexico recently and have been pining for this food. I LOVE that they have Niman Ranch meats. I ordered the blue corn tortilla ground beef thing-a-ma-jiggy, and it was very yummy. But, I asked for spicy and my food wasn't hot at all. Also, I woke up w/ indigestion. I wish and I miss sopaipillas. Where are thou sopaipilla?
author: Andrew K.

description:
Since moving to San Francisco from the east coast, I've tasted a LOT of delicious Mexican food, but Green Chile Kitchen served THE BEST steak quesadilla I have ever tasted, hands down.

Their ingredients are so fresh - the soft tortilla, melted cheeses and pico de gallo were top notch.  I would definitely recommend adding their delicious guacamole to whatever you order (of course, all true Californians already know that!).

The service is friendly and quick, the interior has a casual modern feel.  This is officially my new favorite lunch place in NOPA.
author: Laura W.

description:
UPDATE: 08/29/07; Four stars
We came back last week and sat in the restaurant and had their "plates". They were very good. I had the cheese tamales. My husband had the chicken enchilada. But the favorite of the night was the combo plate, and the favorite of the combos was the taco! Great food. We'll be back! 

___________________________
Old review: 
3.5 stars. 

I didn't realize that this place was semi-fancy, sit down Mexican food. We ordered take out Wednesday night, right before watching the 2 hour season finale of LOST. (Which by the way was MUCH better than the season finale of Heroes.)

They have paper menus at the counter in the back where you order, and also a chalkboard of specials for that night. I ordered a chicken burrito with red chili sauce and a veggie burrito with red chili sauce. 

The orders come out slower than your neighborhood Mexican joint, and came with blue corn chips and green salsa, which tasted kinda sweet. 

The burritos themselves tasted "clean", if you know what I mean. Not your typical, greasy Mexican food, which I expected. The red chili sauce was spicy, but of course, I could have used more spice, I'm Korean. We're spicy like that. 

Up at the front counter, they've got pints of Ciao Bella gelato and natural sodas. I need to go back one of these days and have a sit down meal and try one of their "plates". 

$14.00: two burritos, tax and tip.
author: Caroline C.

description:
The food, wow!  It is a highfalutin, yuppified taqueria for sure.  Don't eat here if you're too cool to accept a gentrified vibe nor if you're short on coin for the day.   This is the nicest "order at the counter" format restaurant I've seen, with trendy stoneware plates and bowls, fancy wines and beverages you'd find at a Whole Foods Market.   

Inspired by the flavors of the state of New Mexico, this is definitely not old Mexico!  The salsa and chile sauce flavors are exceptionally tasty and the mashed chunky (in a good way) potatoes come infused with slightly spicy green chiles, yummy.  Tortillas look like they're purchased locally, but they steam each one fresh on a griddle so their texture is just right.  Their ingredients all seem really fresh and claim to be organic and locally grown.  The meat offerings are very tasty...lean, slow cooked and tender.  

The staff is friendly, helpful and they build your plate fresh to order right in front of you, giving opportunity to customize your meal to your preferences.  

Like many urban neighborhoods, there seem to be more cars than parking, so they claim to offer curbside pickup if you want to eat at home and call in your order from their online menu.
author: P H I L H.

description:
Slow roasted rotisserie Chicken with green chile rub or the herb citrus rub, mmmm!!!!!!!!  They also use farmer's market organic veggies, Niman Ranch pork and have ciao bella gelato for desert.  Call it yuppie, call it qualtiy, but whatevas, it taste damn good! 

Anyplace that offers curbside pickup, where they will bring the food out to you is quality service and a nice touch of convenience, mmmmmm!!!!!!!!
author: Aaron I.

description:
What a great place to wake up in the afternoon to re-ring in the 2009 year again. $3 mimosas to celebrate the New Year, you can't go wrong! I thought coming here at 1:30PM would allow me to beat the lunch crowd. WRONG.Everyone else had the same idea...wake up late, hungover, extremely hungry, and craving for a big burrito. This place was packed and there were no empty seats to be found, so we took our orders To Go. 

- New Mexican Chicken Burrito Plate, Green chile, mild, and "Super" (cheese, guac, and sour cream for $1 more): This huge, hot and wet burrito hit the spot, but after a few minutes and half gone, I had enough. Way too much for a little girl like me to handle. =D There were large chicken pieces, very flavorful, too much re-fried beans, green chile was a good complement, but I wished I had salsa in my burrito or more on the side. The rice on the side was on the hard side, the salad that came with my burrito consisted of chopped up plain romaine with a little bit (equivalent to a tiny spoonful) of salsa. 

I had a taste of the Blue Corn Flat Enchilada (Chicken) and it was not as good as my burrito plate. There was flavor, it was a little spicy, but nothing really stood out. I think I came on their off day and it didn't help much  with the massive hungover new years crowd today. My BF claims this place is the best, but after a taste of my burrito, he said it tasted different. Maybe I'll have to give this place another try on a regular non-holiday day. 

P.S. They have a variety of drinks (organic Odwalla like drinks, natural soda (in many flavors: grape, orange, cola, etc), Izze, pelligrino, and many others). There were Just Desserts chocolate cakes and cookie dough. I also saw an ice cream chest with Ciao Bella pints and individual sized cups. I was so tempted, but it was too early today. Now I am regretting my decision of not getting any afterward, because I can't seem to stop burping burrito flavored burps, ugh.

Tip: Call in for your order. I ended up waiting 30 minutes for my To Go order. I wish I called in and took my sweet time to walk over to this place to pick it up.
author: Tracy T.

description: Had take out from there and it was   The steak salad is flavorful and delicious without any dressing.  The tamales are Oh-My-God-Good.  The pork has just the right amount of spiciness.  The kids had the citrus rubbed chicken and gobbled it up.  Would love to go back and eat there.
author: krystin k.

description:
Work has been kind of brutal and my stupid commute is finally getting to me.  My neck, my back, my neck and my back.  Where's that from?

After a long week, I was cranky, achy, kind of hungry and my mind was wandering in many directions.  I guess that's what happens when hysteria, boredom and too many obligations come together with no attention span.  

Before heading to a night of all karaoke, all the time, we grabbed a bite at Green Chile Kitchen.  I had walked by many times and heard it was good from the fancy eater but was never motivated enough to go in.  We got there before the line got crazy, ordered the 1/4 green chile rubbed rotisserie chicken and the posole and snagged the last available booth.

The chicken was good and came with salad, rice, beans, tortillas and salsa.  I'd happily get it again but more than Iikely, I'd stick with the posole.  It was full of spices, hominy, chicken and some vegetables and reminded me of Mexico last Mexican Independence Day.  Definitely the perfect hangover food.  They have a vegetarian version, too.

Eating delicious food in a casual environment while watching an adult drink out of a Capri Sun-like juice container got me back to a place where I remembered that I have it pretty damn good.  And my new go to song is:  "What Have You Done for Me Lately" by Miss Jackson.
author: Seong P.

description:
Trendoids do Mexican, Mexicans Absent 

Had the much esteemed super dooper pork stew. 9 bucks. Big whoop. If you bought it on 24th street, it would be 4 bucks, would taste better, and they wouldn't be so stingy with the tortillas.

3 oz of pork in the stew costing maybe $1.25. The rest of your 9 bucks go for peppers and atmosphere. Nice windows. 

I have no idea how they do it in NM.  I only care if it tastes good. 

The place is stuffed to the gunwales with the same kinds of young hipster parents who drive Morris cars, have friends with ear disks, neck tats, and work for Wal Mart labs. These are the same people who make fashion statements by paying 17.50 American for a peach at Whole Foods. PT Barnum knew these people well. 

Dead giveaway: no Hispanics behind the counter [although in the kitchen], and none in the house eating the fare. The Emperor has no Sombrero.
author: john d.

description:
Green Chile kitchen is consistently good.  

RESTAURANT 
Much nicer (bigger) now that they moved to a new location.  There is plenty of seating and overall a pretty relaxed vibe.  Not to chaotic, not too loud.  

THE CROWD
Folks are always nice -- but I have to say, you're playing with fire some week nights if you think you're going to go here and sit down to eat if it's an early-ish dinner.  On many nights, if you go here any time before 7:30 you're really likely to run into a ton of parents with small kids under 5.  Like, a lot of them.  If you don't mind the running and screaming, it's not a problem.   Look, it's not a fine dining restaurant, so I can't expect more -- but want to mention it for completeness.

THE FOOD
Their food is tex-mex, not mexican, which is a really nice change in this city.  They do some really decent stacked enchiladas, tamales, etc.  Their burritos are okay, but if you get chicken, just know from the start that they use rotisserie chicken which makes for a very different flavor for a burrito (and a slightly greasier burrito in some cases).   For those that are more health-conscious, there is the "naked burrito" option -- basically, a burrito in a bowl (so you can skip the tortilla).

It's definitely worth a shot, especially if you've not had tex-mex...even though this is probably "good tex-mex for california" rather than superb tex-mex.
author: michael l.

description:
This place is in the old Cafe Neon space and it's light years ahead of what Cafe Neon was. It's one block from my house, and I stand in front of it nearly every morning to catch a 5 Fulton bus, but today was my first day inside since they moved up the block. 

They did wonderful things with the interior of the space. They also have a great menu. I had the breakfast tacos and my wife had the breakfast burrito. Everything was great, from the tacos to the pinto beans to the posole. In fact, the posole was so good that I might just get a bowl of that next time I go. 

I forsee many nights of takeout from this place.
author: Kellie P.

description:
My new favorite: breakfast burrito with vegetarian soyrizo, without red/green chile (because it makes a wet-style burrito and also too spicy for me). 

Available Monday-Friday 8am-12pm and Saturday & Sunday 9am-2pm.
author: Ileana H.

description:
Thanks to fellow Yelpers for another great find. Went to Farolito for lunch yesterday, kinda late, and my girlfriend wanted Mexican anyway. What was I to do? There was no way I could kill another burrito, I was somewhat hungry, and then there would be the aftermath to come this AM.

So I looked it up. I needed to not drive back to the Mission and I wanted it a little different. And along pops up Green Chile Kitchen. 

I almost pulled the plug on the venture because of the parking situation over there, but hey, that's not their fault. I can almost say, though, that the parking pains were worth it.

I wanted Nachos, but she ordered a combo plate for me instead; tamale,enchilada and taco. All delicious, but I'm deducting a star because it was look warm. I will definitely come back a lot, and potentially revise the review. 

Damn though, those nachos looked amazing.
author: Jason R.

description:
Good in a "I will never go to Mexico because it's dirty" way. Like, for white people who have Taco Tuesday and call the Mexican people they know "hispanics."

I guess they're allowed because it's "new Mexican" cuisine instead of "Mexican Food,' which I assume is their validation for a $10 burrito. 

Ultimately, this shit is good in a "I CAN believe it's not Mexican" way. The salsa is bomb, the atmosphere is pleasant, and I feel comfortable taking my mom here when she visits from Marin.
author: Kelly Kate W.

description:
Dudes!  What is wrong with you people?  This place totally owns. Ok, it's pricey for a burrito, but you're paying a buck or two more than elsewhere in the 'hood and getting MUCH BETTER QUALITY INGREDIENTS.  I'm notoriously cheap, yet even I think this is worth it.  

IANAH*, but this is the kind of food that makes hippies cream their pants and with good reason.  It's a familiar basic concept: burritos and tacos (they also do rotisserie chickens, but no comment on that yet).  They have two sauces: red, green, ( and xmas for both ).  The red has a great smoky flavor.  Nothing here is blazing hot, but they serve hot pepper sauce out of bottles if you want to add kick.  The meat is Niman Ranch quality and the veggies fare equally as fresh and yummy.  Blue corn chips on the side is also an upgrade in my book.

The decorum of the place makes for a great vibe.  This might become my regular coffee shop hangout too:  High ceilings, exposed brick, large windows overlooking baker & fulton.  Unlike your average taqueria, you can sit down without worrying that everything you touch will mire you with sticky residue.  Grab a bay guardian or SF weekly from just outside and chill out.  

Next time I go back, I'm trying their south american drinking chocolate...

Finally in the 'hood we can say, "Houston, we have burritos".

*(I am not a hippy)
author: Eric X.

description:
Finally, someone brought some good green chile to the city.  I've been driving by the place for several months now and I've finally made it in and tried the food. Parking sucks in the area, but I've been there twice in three days...a regular has been born. 

I'm officially a fan of their Fulton Valley chicken burrito, which comes with your choice of refried or black beans, and red or green chile salsa (SPICY GREEN CHILE, please). The burrito is BIG and comes with salsa and blue corn chips. (If you run out like I do, they'll give you another helping.) The service is great and the prices are good ($7 for my burrito). And, more importantly, the salsas are delicious. I took my husband there today for lunch and he (being the Colorado transplant that he is) ordered a bowl of the green chile stew. It smelled incredible and was pretty damn good. 

They're open for breakfast so one of these days,  I'll have to partake in some green chile breakfast loveliness. For now, I'm just happy that they're here in the city and close to where I live. :)
author: Marie M.

description:
It's not the Mission like everyone says, but damn those jalapeno mashed potatoes make me happy.
And it's all organic.
And they don't skimp on portions.
And beer is cheap. They serve beer AND wine!
It's great for friends, dates and families.
