The steak burrito is definitely a must have. It's not the cheapest, but it's worth it. 

It's not a gut bomb, so if youre looking for an "after too many margaritas and mayhem meal", this ain't your place. It's fresh, quaint and just so damn tasty. Their guac is chunky and flavorful. Their meats have character, but aren't too intensely spicy. Although I do like me some spicy beef....

You can even get half a rotisserie chicken if you think you can handle it. Is your belly ready for the jalapeno jelly?
author: Jessica P.

description:
I'm from New Mexico. And let me just say, there really isn't anything in the world like New Mexico green chile. And there's nowhere else to get it but New Mexico. Don't say canned -- canned just doesn't cut it for me. I actually sneaked across the California border once with a 40-lb bag of fresh green chile in the back of my car. The smell was surely gonna give me away at the agricultural stop, but it was my lucky day and they just waved me by! A few other times I've driven back from New Mexico with a cooler full of frozen, fresh roasted. But as the years go by, it gets harder to get my ass back to NM. And ordering it by mail costs more than driving there. 

I'm happy to say, Green Chile Kitchen scratches my itch. I think they get theirs frozen, Bueno brand genuine NM chile, shipped in no doubt at great expense. And frankly, I appreciate it. 

Their green chile chicken enchilada plate was loaded with the aforementioned green gold. I ordered mine hot, and while it wasn't the hottest chile I've ever had, it did make my nose run a little. Ah, the nostalgia! 

I should digress a moment to mention the other serious nostalgia this place holds for me. I lived in the Western Addition for 10 years, until I was pried from my rent-controlled apartment by an owner move-in eviction. Driving around for 20 minutes looking for parking near Green Chile Kitchen reminded me why I'm so much happier now that I've moved to Oakland. Parking in this neighborhood SUCKS!

Back to the food: I had a little taste of the red chile, and really, mine is so much better. Too bad I'm not for hire. Also, I vastly prefer my own posole. So I guess I will just be coming here for a fix of the green stuff. If only they'd also make sopaipillas...
author: Max A.

description:
I'm conflicted on this place.  The nachos were outstanding.  They were the kind of nachos I make for myself - blue corn tortilla chips, fresh tomatoes, and grilled vegetables, with real cheese, and lots of fresh guac piled high.  Jen had the choose 5 salad (you get to choose 5 ingredients)  It was good, but a disappointing in its size.  For a large salad, it was more of a small.  When it came out, I ordered the house salad to add to it to give it some body.   

The most painful part of the experience is how slow the line to the one register moves - the line was at least 15-20 minutes long the whole time we were there.  And if you're going to have more than one drink, you should order both the first time around.  I read the entire Guardian while Jen waited in line for our second drink.  The food is great, but 40 minutes of waiting in line (20 minutes for the first order, and 20 minutes for the second drink) isn't fun. 

Great food.  Nonexistent service.
author: Mac W.

description:
This is one of my go to lunch spots.  Yes I'm a bit of a mission burrito fanatic but this place is a completely different experience. 

I love love love their green chile served with a perfectly warmed tortilla with sour cream on top.  Oh my god it's sooo good.  GET IT!  

Also their super carne asada taco is awesome.  The steak is cut into big juicy cubes.    

Plus they have Just Deserts and Ciao Bella and they use organic ingredients.

Just went for their breakfast burrito.  Holy ^%$&$ sooo good.  I got mine with steak and it comes topped with chile and a side of sour cream and salsa.  The BEST in the city.  

Love this place!
author: Lulu M.

description:
This great little eatery offers fresh, tasty New Mexican style food.  Without a doubt, the red/green chile salsas are the star here.  They make for a very unique burrito, as do putting the guac and sour cream on top of the burrito instead of inside.  I'm also a big fan of the house special, green chile stew with chunks of pork.  The salads are standard, kind of "Pluto's" style.  

Pair any of the above with a Blue Sky soda, and you'll be enjoying heavenly burps for hours.

UPDATE (6/26/06):  The breakfast burrito is outstanding.  I had mine with the mild green chile salsa and guac/sour cream on top.  The potatoes and eggs inside the burrito are cooked to perfection, and  the flavors all come together very nicely.  Expertly prepared.

UPDATE (1/19/07):  I'm baffled by some of the reviews that criticize this place for not serving authentic Mexican food.  It doesn't hold itself out to be a Mexican restaurant, you nitwits.  Did you even glance at the menu? The food is New Mexican-inspired, meaning from the state of New Mexico.  Comprende?

Ranting aside, I recently tried the NEW MEXICAN homestyle chicken enchilada plate and the vegetarian green chile stew.  Both were awesome.
author: Leon R.

description:
When you move to a new city, you have to go around and find where to get the best of your favorite foods.

When I lived in Boston, one of my favorite taquerias, Boca Grande, had this Posole that I would crave. The pork. The hominy. The cilantro. Squeeze of lime with tortilla chips on the side. Yum!

It's been four years, and I have found my fairly comparable Posole at Green Chile Kitchen. Of course I have to admit, I didn't look that hard either. I just thought somehow I would come across it at some Mexican place.... I mean, there are certainly plenty in SF! But alas, I hadn't. So today I typed in Posole in Yelp and up came Green Chile Kitchen.

Although Green Chile Kitchen makes their Posole with chicken instead of pork slightly spicy, tender chicken.. it had great flavor and was extremely satisfying. It even came with cute little mini tortillas... 

**** Food Story Number 2****

I have a rather interesting relationship with tamales. I never really loved them, but rather I loved the concept. In my mind, how can a corn-meal concoction stuffed with meat or cheese, then steamed in its own husk not be absolutely delicious? The concept of it alone gives me a food orgasm. Perhaps that goes for a lot of porn fantasies.. seems like fun, but if you were to put it into practice, not so much. Everywhere I go, I order tamales. I then say "why did I get this tamale.. i don't even like tamales." ...It's because of the concept. I guess tamales is one of those foods that, if it's only okay, it's not worth eating, but when it's good, it is awesomely orgasmically good.

Green Chile Kitchen fulfilled my tamale orgasm - FINALLY! I ordered a tamale with cheese and it was moist, fluffy, flavorful. They put a chile in there so it gave it a mild heat, which always helps... with cheese oozing out. 

Okay, sorry. TMI.
author: Bonnie H.

description:
I would like to live here, please.

the food is delicious and of excellent quality - all the way down to the rice. and if you didn't think tortillas could be worthy of being called out in a Yelp review, you should definitely go here to eat.

my only issue is they typically get to-go orders wrong - so check your order before you leave / pay.  i've never gotten a correct order, but to be honest, once i've eaten what i went home with, i've always been so satisfied it didn't really bother me that much.  

great space, great food. and kombucha on tap.
author: Courtney B.

description: Thanks green chile kitchen I feel like I'm back in the land of enchantment. You have truly made my year!!
author: Shawn P.

description:
-- I'm starting to suspect some of the Yelp sponsored reviews (people paid by Yelp who post reviews)... !?!?!?!

Anyway...

BUMMER!!!

::Food:: - Stingy on the Chile
Laaaaaaaaaaame!  The big deal about this place is the Green Chile's!  They fly them out and freeze dry them and have aliens harvest them from New Mexico and such... BUT THEY HARDLY USE ANY IN THE DISHES!!!  In my quesadilla, there were maybe a spoon full of tiny chopped chillies!  You don't even know they are there unless you pick one tiny bit out of the stack just to see how it tastes.  So what is the point???????????!!!!!!!!!!

I had some bomb ass green chile action in Albuquerque.  Those people put in plenty of green chile.  So tasty!  It makes the meal!  And THAT is the point.  THAT'S how it's done... but not here!  Here it's like... "lets make a big deal out of the chile's and then save money by serving hardly any."  : - ?

::Atmo::
Business lunch friendly.  Not what I look for in this sort of place though.

::Presentation::
Looks good on the plate, all be it kind of tiny for the price.

::Price::
10 bucks for a dang quesadilla?  Uhhh... say what now???

::Final::
I won't be back.  For green chile goodness in SF, I say NEXT!!
author: Dan M.

description:
This is an ideal combination of New Mexican food done California style.  New Mexican food is usually made with lard but the Green Chile Kitchen cut out the traditional lard and uses high quality ingredients.  The Californian influence provides the free range meats and organic veggies.  

The owner lived in Santa Fe for a while and decided to bring New Mexico back to San Francisco.  The Green Chile is actually flown in from New Mexico, I think they get it from Hatch.  I noticed people on Yelp complaining about the beef being stewed rather then grilled. This cafe does not have a hood in the kitchen so they can not grill meat, instead they use methods like the rotisserie or stew things.  I think they've done a great job of providing a variety of choices given the limits of the kitchen.  

I grew up in New Mexico and have always had a love affair with my Green Chile (a Anaheim looking pepper grown in Southern NM).  The most authentic dish I've had at the Green Chile Kitchen is their Blue Corn Chicken Enchilada, delicious!  My other favorites are not quite as authentic but the stewed Burrito is delicious, the taco's are tasty and the Green Chile Stew is perfect for a rainy day.
author: Ann M.

description:
It's good but not my top choice for a burrito. 

I like the chips & the breakfast burritos, but I'm not too wild about the rest of the menu. Come here for breakfast, skip the rest.
author: linda t.

description:
A great neighborhood spot. I'm not down with the fact that they charge a dollar extra if you want to get an additional Chile sauce... seems a bit high to me. But, it's mitigated by the fact that they ALWAYS have $2 Pacificos! 

My recommendations are as follows (formal, aren't I?): 
   - Super Nachos. These aren't the nachos you remember from your childhood. No Velveeta or other processed cheese foods here. It's not a tall heaping pile of chips, but each triangular tortilla receives individual attention in the way of tender chicken, whole beans, cheese, sour cream, guac and chile of your choice. 
   - Green Chile Quesadilla. Again, not an average quesadilla. There's red onion, corn and green chile to make it super-tasty.
   - Tamale Appetizer with a Cup of Chile Verde. Tamales were a little cold when they brought them out, but still delicious flavor-wise. I like adding the stew to round out the meal.

Late diners beware, they do close at 9pm every night of the week. For me, Green Chile Kitchen fits under the category of "Easy, Sit-Down, Fulfilling Dinner for About 10 Bucks." A nice addition to Fulton Street.
author: Erin M.

description:
Pretty Solid food!
It's super clean- The Place and the Food.  If you're looking for the dirty low down taco truck Mex, this isn't the place.  The food oozes healthiness(in the Mexican Food Realm that is).  And the Prices are great!!

Food-My Favs include the Steak Burrito,Chicken Burrito, and Chicken Enchilada.  They use Niman Ranch Steak(which melts tenderness in your mouth).  The chicken(really healthy white meat.  So a bit dry)  But really good!  All in all the food is clean and healthy.  

Price- Really cheap if you don't get the add ons.  Steak Burrito is about 6-7 bucks.  Chicken burrito is about 5-6 bucks.  It adds up when they get you with the Christmas version, sour cream, guac, etc...  With the Christmas, they just throw on Red and Green salsa.  

Pros- 2 buck Pacifico's any time!
Good decor.  Super casual and clean.  

Cons- Parking sucks.  Always a line during eating hours.  Seating is first come first serve, you're on your own with that.
author: Chase F.

description:
***2nd UPDATE: WARNING!!! GUARD YOUR CREDIT CARDS!!!!***************
I went into the new location for take-out on November 5th hoping to find that things had changed with the change in space. Not only did it take 30 minutes to receive the most overpriced skimpy salad with the most bland piece of chicken on top in all history , but...when I was scanning my credit card bill this morning, I found that even though I signed off for $13.03 they charged me for $155.03!!!  That's right folks - they stole $142 from me. Green Chile Kitchen = #FAIL

***1st UPDATE*************************************************************
So...After writing this review I got a message from (who I believe is) the owner of Green Chile Kitchen, Trevor Logan.  He wrote to apologize for my experience at his restaurant.  He insisted that he's usually "a naturally friendly and nice person" and that as a long time NOPA resident he "would never, ever want anyone to not feel welcome."  He seemed genuinely mortified and sorry so...I went back in.  Maybe I just caught him on a couple bad days.  We all have those, right?

He wasn't there, but I decided to give it a go anyway because the young lady behind the counter looked up and smiled as I walked in the door and greeted me in very welcoming manner.  She made sure I knew to let her know as soon as I was ready to order and continued working on another person's order.  When I was ready she came over cheerfully and took my order. She was helpful and even made a suggestion that sounded very yummy.  Then it was wait while she completed the other guys order and made mine.  

Once again the burrito was ample as was the wait.  I used to sling burritos out in Iowa (yup - burritos are EVERYWHERE) and it never took me that long - and I was making some damn fine burritos, let me tell you!  

I got it to go. Went home and settled down.  Despite asking her to make the burrito super hot (I believe I told her to make it burn my mouth, tears come to the eyes, HOT, HOT, HOT, so fiery a lesser woman would want to die, it's so hot") it was bland, bland, bland. The sad thing is, I don't think she left out the sauce, I just think it wasn't anything special. She had given me one of those little containers of hot sauce, but it wasn't enough to get me through the whole burrito.  Luckily for me I was at home and could raid my own stash of hot sauce.

Sigh. After Trevor's sincere apology and the young lady's friendly demeanor I was all ready to rave, but alas I can not.  I will bump up from 1 to 2 stars, though because customer service was great this time. Will I go back?  Maybe, but I'm going to have to try something else on the menu other than the veggie burrito.  Papalote - you're still getting my business for your veggie soyrizzo burrito - Now that's SSSSSSSSSSSpicy! 

***ORIGINAL REVIEW***************************************************
I've gone in twice now. Both times the guy behind the counter (who I think is the owner) was abrupt and rather rude. I understand he has a business to run, but a smile doesn't hurt you and it helps the customer feel welcome so that they want to return. I was hoping he was just having a bad day the first time I went in, but I guess he really could care less about being friendly to his customers.  

The burritos were standard Americanized fare and it took a lot longer to make than one would expect. I'd much rather go to Papalote. The service is relatively quick at Papalote and while they're always busy they are also always friendly and the food is super yummy and much more reasonably priced. Sorry Green Chili Kitchen, but my heart still belongs to Papalote.
**************************************************************************
author: Lisa A.

description:
I can never say the name with out being dislexic...Green Chile Chicken, Green Kitchen Chicken... Grile Chicken Kitchen... nevertheless, the food here is fantastic! Very homemade taste and feel, plus a bottle of delicious organic chardonnay is $10! 

It can get really busy, so we went early and got a seat right away. We got 2 huge plates of food and a bottle of wine and got outta there barely over $30. 

Only thing that sucked: we ordered take out, and they gave us one teeny lil' container of rice and beans (together), barely two bites each. But the food was still gooood. Rotisserie chicken = yum!
author: Alexa S.

description:
Best burrito I've had in the city so far. Granted, I've only lived here for 7 months and haven't explored the Mission taquerias as much as I want so that might change (I still haven't found that ABSOLUTELY INCREDIBLE burrito yet). Like other reviewers have noted, this is NEW Mexican food. 

Don't get scared away by the spiciness of the chiles, it's really not that bad. All in all, it's a great concept to make everything so chile-oriented. Extremely high quality of ingredients, which lead to great burritos. Great chips too, love the mason jars, and I especially love the ambiance.

Unlike most taquerias, it's actually a place where you might stay and chill/talk with a friend after you finish your meal, it's a great place to go and hang out. I love the high ceilings, dim light, and good music (seriously, have you ever heard Radiohead or Wilco while getting a burrito somewhere?)
author: Mark A.

description:
It has been a while since my first visit, but I liked the place so wanted to leave a review.  I used a green zebra coupon to check this place out.  I must have tried three different dishes, all were good.  Staff was really nice too and didn't mind at all that I used a coupon.

I'm looking to go back soon, maybe even tonight - which is what made me write the review. 

Note to business owners: If you offer a coupon in green zebra, don't be an ass when someone uses said coupon.  I've been to more than one place where they sneered at me when I showed them the coupon.  Hey, if it wasn't for the coupon, I wouldn't have tried the place.  And if you are an ass, I won't return.
author: Josh L.

description:
"Saying there's too many children is like saying there's too many flowers!"  Except instead of children, substitute "burritos."  And instead of flowers, say "unicorns."  Because unicorns are infinitely cooler than flowers, right?  Unicorns are kickass.   I think I've made my point: burritos are delicious.

So on that note, Green Chile Kitchen was a welcome addition to the 'hood when it first opened last year.  I've been in, and the burritos are consistently good.  At about $7 a pop, you're definitely not getting a deal- but you can take solace in the fact that the ingredients are fresh and the chips are crunchy.  

(The above?  That's what happens when you try to write reviews on five hours of sleep, while watching TLC shows about giant families).
author: Jess T.

description: Not your typical dirty taqueria. They use Fulton Valley chicken - support your local organic chickens! Parking is horrible but once you're settled in, the food is worth it. Cheap, huge portions, delicious. JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
TASTY!  Great quality food.  Love everything from their New Mexico Burrito Plate to the Build your own salad.  And who doesn't love $2 Pacificos???  

The only downside is there is limited seating.   On days  when my husband and i don't have the "fight" in us to wait and then hurry to grab a table we settle on something else.  And oh those coveted three booths.....Off hours seating isn't nearly as bad.
author: Claire M.

description: I thoroughly enjoyed my 1/4 chicken and my husband really enjoyed his unconventional tortilla cheeseburger! Will definitely be back for more
author: Dana S.

description:
hmmm

if you make corn tortillas there, why do you not make chips out of those tortillas?

And how hard can it be to make nachos?  I order nachos, with jalapenos... 

and I get corn chips, with beans and cheese heated up, with cold jalapenos on top?  huh?  I asked them to make it with heated up jalapenos, so they grilled the jalapenos, let the nachos get cold, and then put the grilled jalapenos on top.  Huh?  

The Queso is really quite good, even though the chips taste store bought and not fresh....

the guacamole does not taste as if it is made fresh daily.

I keep exploring this place since its the closes resteraunt to my house, and in theory, mexican is my favorite kind of food.

There small breakfast burrito is pretty good.... Dont ever order there breakfast tacos though.  be warned.
author: dyl c.

description: Really, really good. Fresh, wholesome mexican food. All carryout packaging is compostable.
author: Joby P.

description: Just had the nicest experience at Green Chili Kitchen!  Thanks to Mark the manager for making it so!  Had the Tamale Plate and it was perfect!
author: michael a.

description: I had a to go salad from here a while back and it was good.  It was tasty.  But the fact that  have tried to eat there about 4 times and each time either parking was not going to happen or we were told it would take over an hour to get a table, really keeps me from rating this place more stars.  The food is good but not worth the intense hype in my opinion.  Plus the vibe here is very hipster, which is a bit annoying.
author: Nilu r.

description:
my fiancee and i stumbled upon this place while on a walk in the west add.  he is from CO, where green chile is famously delicious, and was excited to finally come across a place that might make a similar green chile.

we walked in, placed our order and took a seat near the window.  the food was okay but not as spicy as we like.  it is a cute restaurant but the food is not nearly as authentic as it could be.  think of it as fancy southwestern.
author: Carmel U.

description:
Found this place from positive reviews on Yelp on my way home from a job interview.  

Was in severe need of one decent beer and some spicy Mexican after getting grilled for 6 hours.  

Came in around 4pm and there was only one other group in the place besides me...always makes me a little nervous trying new places with few people around.  In any case, I had nothing to worry about.  

I had a chicken burrito with red chili sauce and was really impressed.  Chicken was moist and the burrito had some decent weight to it.  Got a racer 5 from an attentive bartender and the food was up in less than 5 minutes.  In all seriousness it was the best mexican since moving to san  francisco (save the taco carts in the mission after an evening out).  Served with excellent fresh tortilla chips and salsa...

Service was good but just know that it's counter ordering / delivery to your table rather than a waiter.

Will definitely be coming back in the new future.
author: Ian M.

description:
I went here on Saturday with some friends before heading out for a fun early-Halloween night. I had been craving something spicy but not greasy (read: no Pancho Villa) and this sounded like it would do the trick. 

The place itself was perfect.....a friendly, neighborhoody place with a warm vibe from the counter staff and the other patrons. The desert southwest influences could be seen throughout the food--from the hominy in my posole to the use of actual green chilis in the queso.  The food was reasonably priced...for two people the bill was just over $25. 

The caveat to a five-star rating? The fact that I had to take two buses to get there from my Nob Hill apt.
author: Jenn G.

description:
In my world "Burrito" is the 6th food group so obviously I have high expectations for anything wrapped in a tortilla. I had the Soy -chorizzo and red sauce, I should've had the chicken (duh it's a rotisserie) and green sauce (duh its in the name). Bite Queen in full effect! 
Because of my bad ordering ...2 stars, because of my BF's burrito... 4 stars. Average = 3 stars.... & its a cute neighborhood place
author: LaLaLolita D.

description:
I don't like Mexican food.

Actually no I do like Mexican food.  I just don't like beans, sour cream, dishes that are very spicy and I am uber picky about guacamole.  Yes I am a bona fide gringo and proud of it.

So because I am so picky about 3/4 of what you would find on a Mexican menu, it's just easier to say I don't like Mexican food.

But for Green Chile I will make an exception.  I'm so glad my roommate took me here.  After going to the Fly for the umpteenth time, we felt we might be in need of a change of scenery.  When she suggested Mexican I was kinda like uhhhh.... well I'm not terribly hungry so if it is a bust then that's fine.  But the surprise was a pleasant one.  

I LOVE the tacos.  The quesadilla is good too.  I haven't had a salad there or the breakfast burrito but once I do I will be able to give a well rounded review of this place since I will have eaten everything on the menu that I am willing to pay for.  

I just wish it was a little bigger.  Everytime I've been there (twice) I feel like i need to bum rush for a table it is so crowded.  But I guess that is the curse of being good.
author: Alexis B.

description:
Love this little place...I have to agree with others that it isn't somewhere you want to go if you want huge, cheap burritos...
Everything is organic and they cook it right in front of you.  I ordered the 1/2 rotisserie Fulton valley chicken w/ salad which comes with salsa & tortillas.  It took awhile b/c they were in the process of cooking the chicken...so I got it very fresh! Their citrus dressing is great.  If you like whole foods style food you'll definitely enjoy dining here.  I want to try their burritos and salads next time I go.
author: Jaki B.

description: Mmmmm my breakfast burrito and Blue Bottle coffee were SO GOOD!
author: lori w.

description: I'd been wanting to try the Green Chile Kitchen since moving to the Bay Area a few months back. Having lived in New Mexico for awhile I am addicted to green chile. And while the food is decent overall it is less than satisfying when it comes to fixing the New Mexican food craving--I imagine something akin to methadone for a heroin addict. I had the stuffed sopapillas which didn't quite hit the mark, and the lack of courtesy sopapillas to swap up the food with was disappointing.  The number system was quaint in a Disney sort of way, as that is how a lot of restaurants operate in Albuquerque. I have to agree with the review that said GCK is more Santa Fe than Albuquerque. The best part of this place is the green chile, which is tough to mess up, and left the reminder of why New Mexican food is great.  Will I go back? Do I recommend it? I guess it all depends on how how bad the jonze for green chile is.
author: Pablo A.

description: I love Green Chile Kitchen! It's casual and kid friendly -perfect on nights you don't want to cook. I always get the soft tacos and my husband loves the homestyle enchilada plate.
author: Cee B.

description:
Just as I was getting bummed about having to go all the way to the Mission to get my burrito fix, I finally tried out Green Chile. Boy was I missing out, it took me six months to walk two blocks to try this joint out. 

Mouthwatering goodness is how I would describe that beautiful chicken burrito. They use Fulton Valley roasted chicken, and you can choose red or green (or both!) chile on top of it. They also have $2 pacificos. 

The ambiance is lovely inside, although it sometimes takes awhile to get a table. For then I get to annihilate my burrito in the privacy of my home...
author: Kara S.

description:
Best burrito in San Francisco...possibly the world.

This place is awesome. 

I will now  serenade you Green Chili Kitchen....or GCK as I call you when we are alone. 

"When I'm feeling blue, all I have to do, is take a look at you." 

Yes, oh yes. GCK I would make love to your grilled ground beef Niman ranch burrito is she were a woman and I was not married. 

Get it with sauce on the inside, not wet, black beans, cheese and rice and you have a very very special burrito. Wink Wink. 

My wife who is half mexican and knows her mexican food says, you can always tell how good a mexican food place is by their rice. Great rice. Great Pozole aka the Mexican Viagra. 

My brother and I eat here all the time. They also have amazing roasted Fulton chickens which you can buy whole or to go. I could go on and on. The tacos are excellent as well. GCK I love you. Yes that is right I dropped an L Bomb.
author: D M.

description:
So after an emergency at work led me to closing the store when I otherwise had a sun filled day off, my bosses brought a beer by for me and offered to bring me a burrito from this new place they had heard about that specialized in New Mexican fare. 

Awesome. Dinner on my bosses tab. I continue to work, alone, subtly drinking my Red Stripe behind the counter when a strange french man in his 40's comes in and begins to harass me. I won't go into detail but I was seconds away from dialing the cops when he ceased asking me things like if I was alone, and what my name was, the quickest fake name I could come to was Melissa, and the bastard finally leaves. I'm now freaked out, exhausted and slightly sad my day is ending in such a way and am pleased that the highlight will be the burrito the bosses promised. All I can do to not feel freaked out is hope that they get here quickly, with the food.

This burrito DID NOT make up for the weird day my Saturday had become. I took it home with me and ate it alone thinking, why does this taste familiar? And then it clicked. It tastes like food my grandma makes when she, whom is not Mexican nor New- Mexican but learned how to cook AMAZING Mexican food from her mother-in-law, is too tired to cook. Rice, beans some meat tomatoes. Only seasoning, maybe salt. 

So disappointed. A horrible end to my horrible evening. I ate the whole thing reluctantly because I wanted to like it, it was free dammit. The rice was a weird texture, green chili's in the burrito a great idea but didn't stand out or say anything spectacular or stellar to my taste buds. The meat was of course the best thing in the whole compilation. I wondered if plates would be better, enchiladas etc. But this morning find out from the boss that even the plate she ordered was lame.

Wonderful idea this place is, horrible execution. As a native San Franciscan, of part Mexican decent who was just searching for some comfort food after a VERY odd day, a tear came to my eyes. I should have just heated a tortilla directly on the burner of my gas stove, made some frijoles and called it a night.
author: Niki M.

description:
3 1/2 Stars

Green Chile Kitchen is like your "good-time girlfiend" - fresh, sassy, spicy, and just a little pricey.   

The free wi-fi saved me when I moved just around the corner until my DSL was hooked up.  I ate here pretty much every day for 2 weeks so I know the menu well.   

The ingredients are fresh and mostly organic/locally grown - big plus.  I highly recommend the chicken chile stew - it's really savory without being too salty, the quesadillas, and the made to order salads (get the chicken on top).   To echo other yelpers - do not go here for the burrito.  It's like going to Gary Danko for a burger. 

DO order the chocolate chip cookies - they're really small for the price, but oh so worth it!  Yum.

I had to dock them a full star for their inability to answer the phone for  a pick-up order.  I have tried 8 times to call in an order and they have only answered the phone 3 times.   

TIP:  If you plan on eating in the restaurant or waiting long for your pick-up - especially in the winter when the door is closed - plan to smell like food afterward as the ventilation is iffy.
author: Kristin S.

description:
my boyfriend seems to think that I work for Green Chili. that's because I literally go there about 4 times a week ... breakfast, lunch, dinner [especially breakfast!] - matters not. I love the food.

I love the fact that they use only Niman Ranch and Fulton Valley meats. I love that Pacificos are only $2 ALL THE TIME. I love the salsas. a great place for the veggies amongst us, too.

I especially love the breakfast bowl [think: whole beans, salsa roja, add a little chicken - simply the best fuel for my day!!]

if you're looking for a giganto-burrito, probably not the place to try, but if you want good, fresh, clean food you can eat in one sitting, I give you GCK.
author: Rachel W.

description: I am not familiar with New Mexican "inspired" cuisine hence I cannot say much to that but I've grown up on the range of Latin foods available in SF.  I've only been here a couple of times and think the food is really good.  The burritos are grilled giving it a crispy texture on the exterior and the green chile is, to me, incredibly delicious!   If you are eating in don't go for an intimate chat it's too loud.  It's also a little pricey.  The wait-time is horrendous especially if you want something to go; they have got to re-think their prep cook support as there are just two people stepping over each other to plate everything!  I can't wait to go back on a day when it is not so full...
author: Kristi J.

description:
- food: quality, spicy food
- atmosphere: casual, can be loud
- staff: unremarkable
- price: "Mexican-grill" price point

additional info:
- the guacamole was good
author: J. B.

description:
After seeing a review on the KQED show "Check Please"....the entire family went here on Memorial Day to check it out.

I had the Green Chili Stew, which was highly recommended on the KQED show.  I wasn't disappointed.  Very good green chili in my view.  Others were very pleased with the tacos they ordered.  I ended up getting to try both a chicken and pork taco.  They were very good.  We also had the guacamole starter, which was very nice.  And a basket of Sopaipillas (sp?)  to conclude the meal.  They were some Chili honey on the table....in the sopaipillas it was excellent.

Is a drive for us from the lower peninsula....but was fun, and we will be back.
author: K F.

description: Tasty Mexican food that has been slightly watered down for the NOPA neighborhood.  I had the chicken nachos, which was really good.  The chicken is really tender.
author: C L.

description: I loved the burger here, wow it's new and at the very bottom of the dinner menu. Who would have thought that  a Mexican place would serve such a delicious burger! It has two smaller patties with cheese in between the patties and green chile on top of it all and it is wrapped in a tortilla. Damn, it was good and spicy! And the organic fries I got were just as spicy and good, sprinkled with cumin and oregano and chili flakes. All went perfect with my $2 Pacifico!
author: Chris D.

description: Green Chile is one of the most inconsistent restaurants around and I am appalled by their customer service. Two weeks ago I had a delicious vegetarian burrito bowl and was excited to come back again for the same thing. After I ordered, I was brought the wrong dish so I sent it back. Not that big of a deal - mistakes happen. After waiting 15 minutes for the right order, they finally brought me a bowl with a pile of black beans, a pile of rice, and dry tofu with no seasoning or sauce/salsa whatsoever. The same thing happened another time I went here where they brought me the wrong dish, I sent it back, and then they brought me the wrong dish AGAIN. At this point I was frustrated, since I have gotten this dish many times and know this is not what it looks like. I went up front and asked the chef to add the sauce that usually comes on it. He looked dumbfounded and plopped some pico de gallo on the uncooked tofu so I would go away... Then I asked to speak with the main chef. I explained the situation - that I'm a regular customer and this is not what the dish normally looks like. He seemed confused as well but said he would bring me something better. (Keep in mind the person I was eating with was completely done eating at this point). Finally he brought out a bowl with overcooked tofu and an orange (?) sauce. I'm a regular customer and go there for a specific dish, so when I inconsistently get the dish I actually ordered, it's frustrating and I'll probably stop going here. I would normally give Green Chile 4 stars but after this happening multiple times + the terrible customer service, I have to give it 1 star.
author: Molly S.

description:
New Mexican Inspired Food. 
Ok.. let me just say this .. if you miss New Mexican food this is the closest thing I've found so far. I took one bite of the green chile chicken stew and felt like I was on the Plaza at the Plaza Cafe. Now .. if they can copy the Christmas Burritos of Tomasita's I'll be in heaven. You can even call ahead and have food brought to the car. 415-614-9411

...also not to be picky... but I've read some of the reviews below and all I can say "If the food isn't what you "thought" it was going to be ... it's because it's authentic to New Mexican cuisine.  The chile is going to be runny because it's mostly the chiles .. it's not Tex Mex .. the burritos will be gooey .. that's a New Mexican Burrito ...  the Green Hatch Chiles are subtle... it's more about the flavor than "the heat."    It's just a little different in New Mexico.
author: Kevin-John B.

description:
I live across the street and was SO excited to have a new affordable restaurant in the 'hood.  I went there with a date, we both ordered the green stew, and both came down with food poisoning that night.  Granted this was literally the 3rd day they were open, and my roommates eat there almost every night, but I thought I'd share my experience.
It took another 2 years for me to get the sack to go again, and when I did I wasn't disappointed.  It's a bit on the pricey side (for me, though maybe not for what they offer) but the quality is good and I know they are mindful of organics and customer service and all the good stuff restaurants should be aware of.
2 years ago they would have gotten 0 stars, but after my return visit and the constant patronage of everyone else in my household, they have been partially redeemed.
author: D C.

description: 3.5 stars rounded up to 4.  The atmosphere is great...really nice friendly vibe.  The menu is interesting...some nice dishes.  The prices, ok.  Good pricing on their bottles of wine which means it's a great place to hang and enjoy a bottle, but per glass pricing not as good.......6 bucks for a glass or 12 for the bottle?  Strange.  I am a lover of  tamales so that is what i ordered even though that is a bit dull.   i thought theirs might be something special but alas, no.  I could not even tell the chicken from the pork.  The red sauce was served in a tiny cup to pour on yourself..  It was good and spicy...but i was surprised at how little they gave me.  Tamales were moist and fresh tasting but nothing different or unusual.  Beans good. rice decent.  All in all,  a pretty nice place and we were happy with our dinner.
author: Rita D.

description:
I came here for a working dinner with my bosses. They picked the place. 

Although I had to talk and eat at the same time, my tastebuds were literally exploding. We ordered the green chili fries as we walked in and saw them bringing some out. I had the green chili stew. So good! Just the right amount of spicy.

Everything that came out of the kitchen looked delicious and like many many reviewers have said, this is NEW MEXICAN food. They are also using organic meats which is a real bonus.

I left there craving the food and thinking about the next time I can get in there for some more.

They also have beer and wine. I ordered Sangria. It was good, LOTS of ice, little sangria, little fruit, but tasty.

This is an order at the counter then sit down kind of place but it's very clean and friendly.
author: Ste B.

description:
Solid Southwestern style food that also happens to be located right next door to my new favorite nail salon. The nice thing about the Southwestern angle is that the food tends to be healthier than straight up Mexican food.

I had the vegetarian green chili. It was really tasty, though I thought a bit too brothy for chili. I think chili should be thick enough to be scooped up with a tortilla, no other implements needed. In this case, I had to do some spoon maneuvering to facilitate the tortilla scoopage. The tortilla was thick and warm and a great accompaniment to the chili.

The taco menu looked pretty good as well. They have quite a few vegetarian options so I know I'll back for round two, probably next time my nails need some TLC.
author: Angie R.

description:
Anyone who wrote a negative review obviously didn't have the breakfast burrito.

I eat here almost every week and I've never gotten anything else because seriously, what's better than a great breakfast burrito?

The hot green chile sauce isn't really that hot, but it's delicious.
author: Leah C.

description:
Hmmm. I really wanted to like this place as I am a huge fan of Santa Fe food. I just got home from eating the chicken enchilada plate and while it was tasty, it was also sort of mealy and weird, and the red sauce wasn't all deep and haunting like I want a red sauce to be, and the chips were overly foo foo.

I really like the staff and the interior a lot, and they had $2 Pacificos, so I'll probably go back, but it's not that exciting, foodwise.
author: sarah l.

description:
Having been reared in N.M., I easily developed, how do you say
"an addiction," to that festive little pepper. Green chile is one of the few things you can add to anything savory to take it from good to "wow!" Breakfast , lunch, dinner on pizza or  even sushi; I could eat it everyday. The perfect cure for what ails you (especially hangovers). 
When we heard of Gck, we were skeptical. Green chile and niman ranch together under one roof- F*&% yes!!
On my first visit, the owner and I made the NM connection and he gave me a box of bueno sopapilla batter! Sweet! I've never learned  to make sopapillas, but I'll try (if any of you yelpers know how and want to teach me, i'd be so down). 
An extra star for organics and high quality meats (I hardly eat meat so when I do, it's got to be healthy).
author: Sandrita R.

description:
I was reading yelp reviews the other day, and came across the many reviews of Green Chile that sang the praises of the breakfast burritos there.  Those reviews, of course, got stuck in my head all day and all night.  That night, I got together with some old friends from school for some poker, and drunkenly talked about breakfast burritos ALL NIGHT LONG.  I didn't realize this, of course, until the next day when my girlfriend told me that I wouldn't shut up about breakfast burritos all night. 

I woke up with a bit of a hangover the next day, but I wasn't going to be denied.  We headed over to Green Chile around noon, a little bit worried that they might no longer be serving breakfast.  The place was pretty busy, which is always a good sign, and I was SOOOO happy to see the sign that said they served breakfast burritos until 2!  

I ordered their breakfast burrito with chorizo and "Christmas" (red and green sauce) on top.  The burrito itself was tasty, but the eggs were not that hot in some parts of the burrito.  They were fluffy but obviously were sitting in a tray for awhile before they were put into the burrito.  The red and green sauces were also good, but could have been a little spicier.  However, I forgot that having sauce on the burrito meant that I couldn't pick it up with my hands and devour it like I would most breakfast burritos -- next time, I'll get the sauce on the side.  

I probably hyped the burrito a little too much in my head (and to my friends), but it was still very good.  I will definitely try it again, maybe next time I'm hungover.
author: Pilan C.

description: Expensive burritos but very solid. great neighborhood spot that is always a solid option when  you don't want to cook.
author: Dave C.

description:
Great food, and as another yelper stated, it was the smell that grabbed my attention and caused me to stop my walk for some food. I've been back four times since.

The food is great, the menu is simple, not bad on prices, super service, and they have one of the greatest drink selections in the area. Organic if that's your thing, Pacifico beer is always below happy hour price, and many natural sodas and wines. Plus, the place is very clean!

Meats are free-range too!
author: Ben L.

description:
3.5 starts

I actually eat here all the time since it opened. The only item i really like is the breakfast burrito but everything else on the menu is just alright. The only reason I keep dinning here is because it's around the corner from my house and it's a nice change from Mexican food once in awhile.
author: Rolo A.

description:
LOVE!

My friend and I foolishly decided to get hungry around 9 p.m. on a Friday night without reservations in the Divis area. Whoops. But lo and behold, just a few blocks away, is Green Chile Kitchen! With seating! A miracle in SF, I must say.

I'm a vegetarian so I can only speak to the veggie options, but they are fabulous. Prices are very reasonable for San Francisco (seriously, a burrito and chips for $5? I've paid more at a Mission taqueria!) though I'm told the meat options get a little pricey (guess it's that fancy-schmancy organic meat).

The veggie burrito was fabulous and enough for two meals. Soft taco plate was delish -- you can mix and match. I wasn't a fan of the tofu (something about the sauce) but I tried a few bean ones and was thoroughly impressed. Plus they have $2 beer (I want to say Pacifico) and you really can't beat that.

I love this place -- cute cozy little restaurant, great food, great prices and tucked far enough off Divis that you won't be battling the crowds for a seat, even on a weekend.
author: Kate Z.

description:
This place has saved us from starvation after a long day at work with nothing in the fridge to look forward to.  We usually call ahead for takeout as we're heading home to order the 1/2 chicken dinner (herb citrus) with the mixed green salad.  The dinner also comes with rice, beans, tortillas and salsa and just one order is enough for the two of us (what a deal!).  

I haven't tried the burritos here (I have other places for that) but if you are in the market for a great and inexpensive chicken dinner with a New Mexican flavor, stop by Green Chile Kitchen!  Oh, and a very family-friendly place...another plus!
author: Abby N.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in SF. It is moderately priced and the food is great. I have yet to find better tamales in the city!
author: Montana G.

description:
Finally! A southwestern restaurant in San Francisco! They said it didn't exist...amazingly, one such place does. While it's not nearly great enough or comprehensive to satisfy the urges of a southwestern foodie, Green Chile Kitchen does a great job "repping" new mexico in an honest fashion. The food here is really down-home kitchen food, not done up, bobbly flay-style explorations in chile-based flavors. Which is fine.

I had the blue corn enchilada with chorizo and it was really great. The ingredients all seemed fresh, and the big thing is that you need to "add christmas", as the menu says. "Adding Christmas" means covering your plate with half roja and verde chile sauce. This is a must-do for anything you order here, because chiles are the whole point! 

Anyways, it was greatly enjoyable, great residential location, great for breakfast or lunch or dinner. Basically just great. They have honest tea, mexican coke, and spicy hot chocolate too.
author: Tolga E.

description: I have been there for breakfast and lunch countless times, only to leave with nothing but love for this place. So I went for dinner the other night with a friend and ordered the crispy tacos. The guacamole, refried beans and rice were still of the same genius ilk, but the chicken had absolutely no flavor, not like the roasted chicken, which is stupendous. Maybe it was the wrong thing to get? Or have they just started this new flavorless chicken thing? Hmmmmmm....
author: Alissa P.

description:
I had the signature stew.  I forget what made it so signature.  It was fresh tasting though and the ambiance is nice and comfortable.  Kind of like eating at home except they don't have TV dinner trays.  I would have liked bigger portions for the money or at least some cornbread with that stew.  
I want to go back and try the rotisserie chicken.  Looked and smelled great.  More to come...

Second visit -

I had the enchiladas verdes this time.  I met one of the owners and she gave me a "sneak preview."  The enhiladas were very tasty.  I enjoyed them very much but I did think the portions were a bit small.  Maybe small in the "I'm an american and like to eat like a pig" sense. Again, I didn't have the chicken and watched my company scarf it down never taking a second to even wipe the chicken grease from their faces.  Next time, and there will be a next time...
author: J P.

description: We had a few things here in order to get a full spectrum. The chips and guac were ok simple is always best and that's what it was. The enchilada combo plate was next. The taco was mediocre at best and was super dry. The tamale was ok however the meat or the masa could use some chili powder to give it something more and make it not so plain. I really feel like the blue corn was a great idea however it's a fine line when using this type of masa. Maybe it's because I have made hundreds of tamales every x-mas with my family my entire life that I just expect a little more then what was on my plate. The enchiladas were the clear favorite on the plate as I felt this was well executed with the right amount of sauce and cheese. They are done New Mexico style so the tortillas are laid flat and stacked with ingredients vs rolled. The star of the show was the chicken hominy soup. This was a well executed dish even though a little fresh cilantro would of knocked it out of the ball park. It didn't have a lot of spice but the flavor was good enough for me.
author: Eisa m.

description:
This is my go-to place in NoPa (I feel stupid just using that term).  Nice seating, polite if somewhat spacey cashier, speedy service, and food that sticks out for not tasting like every other burrito shack in SF.  A little more expensive than Papalote, but the ingredients are better and the portions more substantial (the $10 enchilada meal leftovers are good for a full lunch the next day).  The last two times I went there were some loud and annoying kids -- hopefully that trend won't continue.

UPDATE
Down to three stars because of the cheap Papalote tacos and the kids.  Screaming, yelling, crying kids everywhere.  Can't they go to Cafe Neon or something?
author: S P.

description:
I LOVE Green Chile Kitchen. Its right down the street from my house and anytime I walk by it I start salivating.
The food is delicious and the people are super friendly. True its a little pricey but I talked to the owner one day and found out that its because they support organic farms. I'll pay a little extra for better quality any day.
If you havent checked this place out, do it. You wont be sorry. My favorite is the super chicken burrito. Get both the red and green sauce on it. Delicious! 
Now I'm hungry.
author: Heather L.

description:
So I'm not a fan of this place.  I'd heard great things about the food, but last week a couple friends and I got take out.  We ordered a lot from the menu, so I feel we sampled a pretty good selection of what this place has to offer- unfortunately none of us liked our meals.  I've had better Mexican food at burrito dives throughout the city.  I found the food kinda bland- despite the promise of new Mexican chili's in our dishes.  I won't be going back, and the most annoying thing besides the bad meal was that it reared it's UGLY head in the bathroom the next day.  Two letters- P U.

:-(
author: AJ L.

description: Super nachos, posole, burgers, breakfast naked burritos and home made Kombucha on tap.  They serve brown rice that they grow their own.  Good stuff.  Oh flan is very milky and silky as well.
author: Miyako U.

description: I love that there's a delicious restaurant less than 30 seconds from my front door. Had the pork quesadillas the other day and they were super yummy! Had some friends visit from back east and they loved it so much they wanted to eat here everyday!
author: Liz A.

description:
Holy moley this place is fucking delicious. The blonde cashier girl with funky glasses was super helpful and nice to me. She recommended the the flat enchiladas and they were PERFECTION. 

I blame her for my new addiction!
author: Natasha T.

description:
First off - this is not a place to get a burrito. Maybe a breakfast burrito, but not a Mission-stylee burrito, per se. 

This IS a spot to get yourself a healthy salad and a bowl of green chile or posole. I've tasted green chile from New Mexico (Frontier Restaurant serves it ALL NIGHT LONG), and I've been to Hatch, New Mexico and left with the scent of green chiles seeping from my pores. But that sort of green chile is the decadant, fatty sort, and Green Chile kitchen tends to cook up California-fied versions of the classic.

I typically order a salad and a cup of the chile. The chile is served with a dollop of sour cream and a warm tortilla. The salad is crisp and garnished with cucumber, tomato and shredded carrots. While sometimes the service is annoyingly slow, the chile is tasty (though, if you're from New Mexico, you may find it a faint replica of the original) and the owners are really friendly. Also, the atmosphere here is clean and inviting - they serve both beer and wine, as well as organic sodas and Mexican Jarritas, and they also offer lovely jarfuls of ice water, real silverware and everything is served on tasteful Heath ceramics. 

So this place ends up somewhere between a restaurant and a take out sort of joint, and somewhere between a healthy California eating spot and a New Mexican outpost. Friday nights, there tend to be tons of families and lots of kids. Either way, when sitting at the bar in front of the window, there's a nice view of its Western Addition neighborhood, and on a sunny day, it's nice to take your chile outside and sit at one of the tables in the sun while reading the paper. 

I'd say this is a good place for the 'hood, though not worth a trek by any means.

Note: I don't know who M.S. is, but the above photos of Green Chile Kitchen are actually mine. Sort of funny to find them here.
author: Chrissy L.

description:
I would say this place was pretty good, but then I walked away not stuffed and somehow spent a good amount of money.  That knocks it down a star for me.

Otherwise, the enchiladas, which is more or less how I judge a mexican food place (unless it is a burrito place, obviously), were pretty tasty.  The nacho plate was pretty tasty too, but nothing was amazing.  I like the vibe in there though.  I'll go back occasionally.

Just an update: habanero salsa is pretty spectacular.
author: Amit M.

description:
Oh Green Chile Kitchen!

I live very close to this place.  Their number is in my phone and sometimes our relationship feels a little dangerous.

I have gravitated more to the nacho side of things.  I used to go for the burritos, as I love burritos in general, however I found that sometimes the quality of their burritos was inconsistent.  However, the nachos have never disappointed.  I stand by them.
author: jessica o.

description: Enjoyed the calabicitas (zucchini, summer squash) which had some heat to it and accompanied my chicken and Mexican style rice.  The seats aren't the most comfortable, but an interesting, funky setting..
author: Susan N.

description:
I lived in New Mexico for close to five years, and I dearly love New Mexican food.  Green Chile Kitchen however, is an insult to New Mexican food.

And it's right there in the name: Green Chile.  I simply can't eat the canned green chile they serve here (I don't care if Bueno brand green chile comes from Hatch, it's still ruined by whatever they do to it before shipping).  It's disgusting, like snot. Tasteless green slime.

I had really high hopes for this place but if they can't get some fresh roasted green chiles instead of this slimy mess called Bueno I'm not going back.

It's like going to an Italian place where they serve Ragú or Chef Boyardee.
author: Sean M.

description:
I LOVE GREEN CHILE!
Quality of product is something Green Chile takes very seriously. I've never had anything be less than fresh and tasty. New Mexican cuisine done right! They lose a star because it is a bit pricey and sometimes very slow. But when I'm in the mood for some beans and rice and Niman Ranch Pork and Chicken I'll pay and wait. They've become a staple for me, at least twice a week, and a handful of other locals too. Check it out, you won't be disappointed!
author: Ishmael C.

description:
SO tasty!
Blue Corn Flat Enchiladas, Christmas, refried beans - to go. DELICIOUS! I am torn on which chile sauce I prefer, both so deep in flavor.
author: Janine L.

description: Yum! I am a HUGE fan of Southwestern Mexican food....so much so that I actually stopped in Hatch, NM to get chiles on a road trip across the US. Needless to say, I was psyched to try a place that uses green chiles with wild abandon! I am pretty shocked to hear that people think this place is expensive -- for the quality of food you're getting, fresh ingredients (and the atmosphere, which is LOT nicer than most take-out places...you can actually sit and hang out here) this food is a total steal. Not to mention the $2 Pacificos. I've had dinner a few times here, but I absolutely must come back to try the Huevos Rancheros for breakfast.
author: Britt M.

description: I don't know why I keep coming, hoping to be wowed, but I think this was the last time. There's nothing actually wrong with the place. Other folks like it fine. But everything on the menu reminds me of chicken soup. It's all overcooked zucchini, watery tacos, and unremarkable spices. The roast pork is good, but it floats in a stew of boiled to death veggies. You find yourself praying for a bite with pork in it. Plus, everything is overpriced. 8 bucks for a bowl of guacamole and chips? Please! Call me crazy, but I recommend Little Chihuahua, the neighborhood's other Mexican place. It actually tastes Mexican.
author: Ted N.

description: I was treated to a yummy chicken posole brunch.  I enjoyed the posole and thought it might have had a bit more chicken and toppings to be my favorite posole.  I also enjoyed a delicious ginger lime aid.  I would come to this restaurant again.
author: Naida E.

description: I love Green Chile Kitchen! The food is fresh, organic, and delicious! The breakfast burritos are amazing, and it's obvious that they only use the freshest ingredients. This place is a "must" when visiting the city.
author: Brandie B.

description:
Ever since Whole Foods switched to the "make your own burrito" bar, I've been looking for a place that serves up the grubbin mexican food I crave, using organic veggies and quality meat. 

Last night I got the salad with meat, like they do it at Pluto's, but paid twice as much. Don't care, it's in my hood and the gucamole was delish. Burritos are goodbut not the biggest super burrito you ever saw. (Baby-sized burritos are so 90s any way!)

Pretty good service, they have beer and wine, and the ambiance is nice. Four stars are for the food and my gratitude that the restaurant options might finally be expanding in the panhandle!
author: Gretchen T.

description: My beautiful NM girlfriend gives this an authentic 5 stars.
author: Peter B.

description:
My first thought:  Did Rick Bayless open a burrito shop?

When I first walked in, I thought this place was going to be another cookie-cutter place like Chipotle... This isn't your Mission burrito joint to be sure, but I was impressed by their big helpings and various foodie options. Mighty Leaf teas and Dagoba chocolate? muy bien!
author: Richie K.

description:
I came here with a big group of people for the Burrito Brotherhood (a burrito eating club one of our friends started).

I had the green chile roasted pork burrito plate. It was quite tasty! A burrito with potatoes and cheese? That wins me over. The plate came with a side of rice and calabacitas - sauteed zucchini, yellow squash, corn & green chile. I also tried the super nachos with Niman Ranch steak that someone in the group ordered. Yum!

I liked that they used glass canning jars for water glasses. Quite rustic but charming. The people who ring you up are friendly as well. I hear their breakfast burrito is good. I hope to try that sometime. I definitely recommend this place.
author: Helena H.

description:
The steak burrito I had was not bad, but not particularly good either. 

What really lowers the score for Green Chile Kitchen is that I've never waited so long for a mediocre burrito.  In fact, I've never waited even a tenth as long for even a good burrito.  Not ever.  I think they'll be waiting roughly as long for me to return to this place -- forever.
author: Richard R.

description:
I used to literally live across the street...so close i could pick up their wifi from my pad. Now that I've moved downtown I definitely don't get there as much as i should...especially since i probably used to go there once or twice a week. 

In general - yes the prices are a lil steep for the impecunious college student however their food is just generally so out of this world incredible its worth it. Definitely have to recommend their Chicken Tamales or Posole. If you're a vegetarian....the tofu soft tacos are soooo filling and yummy. I'm also a big fan of places where the staff recognizes and acknowledges their regulars. I've definitely been given a free drink every now and then plus one time when I showed up right as they were closing they gave me some free flan. 

You can probably get some cheaper (and slightly more authentic) Mexican food down in the Mission...but if you want amazing food thats well worth the price, homey environment, chill staff, free wifi and delicious spicy hot chocolate thats the size of a household pet...GCK is def the place.
author: Tam G.

description:
First off, I'd move to New Mexico for the food.  So how excited was I to learn that Green Chile Kitchen was in my hood?  Man, this food is good.  And even better, it tastes authentic.  I had the blue corn enchiladas with Christmas (both red and green chile sauce).  All of a sudden I was back in Taos, living the dream.  Unbelievably tasty, GREAT flavor.  Both my friend and I agreed that Christmas is the way to go, since the green chile is unbelievably good, and the red, while not better than the green, serves as a good balancing factor.  (That might not have made any sense, sorry)

The setup is a little weird though; you wait in line and place your order, then someone delivers the food to your table.  That was a little confusing the first time, but no worries.  Once you get it, you GET IT.  

Love it, and I'll be back for sure.
author: Jessica H.

description:
I've had the burritos at dinnertime, which didn't really impress me - I'd rather go to Papalote or La Taqueria if I want a burrito.

However, the nachos are pretty good - and the breakfast burritos are huge and so good.

I'll keep trying them - maybe at some point, I will like their burritos.
author: Carly P.

description:
This is a really nice little place.

Consider it New Mexico cuisine.  I was impressed with the menu selection, and started things off with trusty tamales.  Red chile, of course.  That was great, as was the salad and rice that came with it.  

It's a small restaurant that has a charming ambiance about it.  The staff was friendly, the establishment clean, and service quick.  

Plus, I finally learned what it means to "chrismas" a meal.

I'll be back.
author: Charles R.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE.   I frequent this gourmet burrito land because it's right across the street from my house, which is awesome for me.  The food is ALWAYS good and the staff is really nice.

Their food is fresh, diverse, and I've never had anything I didn't like.

I totally recommend the posole, nachos, or any burrito with chicken in it because their chicken is damn good.  Their new location is awesome as it is LARGE and they serve beer now!  woohoo!

They also get brownie points for having ciao bella ice cream.  Green Chile Kitchen can do no wrong.

If you're reading this GCK, I love you, will you marry me?
author: Alexandra A.

description:
The thing to try here is the green chile pork stew.  Incredible... with a spicy kick.
I've also had the burrito and while it wasn't bad, you could get something equally good elsewhere.
Go for the Green Chile Stew.  it's still organic :)
author: Suzanne G.

description: I've been a fan of this place since I moved to the block, but the service always tended to be a bit slow.  Well it looks like they finally have taken care of that issue, as I was in and out of here with a burrito to go in about 5 minutes last night.  The food was great as always.  Keep up the great work guys, you're a great addition to the neighborhood!
author: Joshua W.

description: Great place to have fresh and delicious food . Not only that the place is great to hangout with friends .
author: Yasser A.

description:
I live down the street so I really really really want to love this place. I like it, but a few things - 

1) They mess my order up most of the time. Today, they put rice in the burrito. Last time they gave me a regular tortilla when I asked for whole wheat. Nothing terrible, but it's annoying.
2) It takes way too long - I was told 10 minutes for my burrito today and it took more than 20!

Ingredients are quality, price point is reasonable, space is nice and open and it seems like they treat their employees well.
author: Lindsay T.

description:
Keep in mind, this isn't a taqueria.

Everything is organic, a lot of the ingredients are locally grown, and the meats are from Fulton Valley or Niman Ranch.

Try the steak burrito or the chicken enchilada plate...yummy.
author: Michelle V.

description:
Dear GCK, I love your food, and it's great you have upgraded to the larger new location but... you gotta do something about the heat. The new location is cold cold and very drafty. Every time I have been there, I have eaten with my coat on. Not a very comfortable dining environment. I think also, because the room is so cold, my food has been consistently luke warm, unless it was a burrito. So sad cause I really like my food hot.

Heat is better the heat is better!!!! yyaaaaayyy!!
author: Miranda B.

description:
Never again.  Jumbo mama texting at the register semi-interested. 
I get a thimbleful of sour cream and guacamole while jumbo heaps it on her plate and proceeds to chow down and lick her sausage fingers behind the counter.   Who owns this joint?
author: Victor J.

description: This review should really be a 3.5 - mainly because of the scattered and very slow service.  My friends and I ordered dinner for takeout and started wondering what was going on when we didn't get it within 35 minutes.  We inquired what was going on, and initially they thought they had lost the order.  Then it turned out they didn't lose it, but they did forget it was for takeout.  By then we were so hungry we just decided to eat there.  They comp'd us a bottle of wine and guacamole so that helped ease the pain.  The food itself was great - very tasty and while not as good as actual New Mexican, it's the best I've had in SF.  I had the blue corn enchiladas, and my friends had the soft tacos and the rotisserie chicken.  All delicious.  If the wait wasn't so long, I'd go back in a heartbeat.  The place did seem to empty out after 8, though . . .
author: B. Y.

description:
Let's just say that if this restaurant was located in Santa Fe or Albuquerque it wouldn't be in business for long.

My boyfriend and I have been excited to try this place for some time as we're both huge fans of green chiles and southwestern food in general. We ordered the veggie burrito with christmas sauce and the veggie green chile stew. 

The stew was pretty decent but it was lukewarm and the small size wasn't worth the price. The burrito was mostly filled with rice and was lukewarm as well. I was really hoping the red and green chile sauce would be enough to make up for the lame burrito, but I've had better sauce from a jar.

If this place was in my neighborhood I would maybe go back for the chile stew if I had a sudden craving for it, but since it's not in my hood, I won't be going back anytime soon.
author: .'antigone' ..

description:
There is something you must know before you're allowed to eat here: this is not Mexican food.  It's also not "new" Mexican food.  It's New Mexican food, as in "the state with Santa Fe in it," and it's not trying to be Mexican because it's a different thing altogether.  Green chile, blue corn, pork, hominy corn, made into stews and enchiladas and tamales.  Delicious and rare outside NM.

We had the chicken enchiladas and green chile stew - both authentic and very good.  Chase it with Blue Sky soda (from Santa Fe) and it almost feels like home.

GCK gets four stars for great food, and one star for being here and not one thousand miles away.  When I go back it will be morning, and I'll be eating that breakfast burrito I've been dreaming about.

P.S.  Don't go looking for sopaipillas, as there's no deep fryer.  :(
author: Brett W.

description:
If you have ever been to Tomasita's in Santa Fe, NM then DO NOT BOTHER GOING HERE. If you have lived in New Mexico and miss tender burritos packed with beans and swimming in a spicy vegetal gravy of savory green chile, then I repeat: don't bother.

Because what you get is a soupy concoction of soggy tortilla wrapped around cheese and beans, covered in cheese, and surrounded by cheese. Even if you order extra green chile and NO CHEESE, they will still serve you a tortilla log in a greasy pool of cheese.

The search continues.
author: Chris P.

description:
Meh - it's doable. I'd go if someone else wanted to. It's more than I'd like to pay and their cheese is weird. Otherwise tasty though. 
Their coffee is not very strong either. :-(
author: Elsa E.

description: Good Mexican restaurant. I like the ambiance. Food comes out and it is super hot so wait so you don't burn your mouth ha ha. The people who take your order are super nice. I expected a taqueria style restaurant but it is more of a sit down. Apparently they have a pie shop next door also that has good reviews. When I come here again, I need to make sure they don't put the green sauce on top of the burritos so if you don't like your burrito wet style ask for it without sauce on top.
author: Darius A.

description:
This spot is not what it could be.

1. up until the other day, my girlfriend and i simply called this spot "the mexican place," becuase we never knew what the name was... because its too hard to find! (bad sign, logo small, hard to read, bad placement, etc.)

2.  as soon as you walk in, after noticing how nice and cozy it feels, you will then notcie that there is no signage allowing you to see the menu and order. instead you will have try an find the paper menu located somewhere near the cash register. which becomes more problematic when there is a line.

3. they have a nice open kitchen with a glass window, but it is obscured by a large shelf for wine. taht could easily be somewhere else.

4. they offer red salsa or green salsa for free with your burrito, however if you order "X-mas" (as my girlfriend did), you have to pay an extra dollar for the same amount of... Salsa!!! 

5. they have wireless internet for free... but you would never know.

6. they have a kick ass breakfast burrito, but it is only offered on the weekends!!! wtf? 

7. they have an icecream vending machine near the counter, but they dont offer a breakfast burrito on weekdays!!! 

Anyway, I think the food is solid. The place looks and feels good. The staff is ok (kind of cold sometimes). I will no doubt go there again, although probably not on a weekday and probably not as frequently as I will go to Ziyrab fo Med, or Thai Place II for spicy eggplant chicken, or even the corner store for sandwich!!

****

UPDATE: Respect to the owner for writing me about my review. He sounds like he is working hard at beefing up this location and making it the best it can be. For the record I have returned to this spot and I did order the breakfast burritto... on the weekend!
author: nate m.

description:
I'd give the place another quarter star over my last review if I could. The new(ish) location is better organized than when it first opened. The food is a bit more interesting too and good as always. The soups/stews are nice to have over the conventional burrito places (yum). And it still feels like a neighborhood joint.

Since it is a sit-down place (order at the counter and they bring to your table) I personally think the interior could be improved a bit. It can get noisy and finding a seat is sometimes hard - the intimacy of the old location is missing. With such a large space it feels a bit too cavernous and dark.

I think the one quick improvement? More chips and a salsa bar to fine tune your dining experience.
author: Dave P.

description:
High quality ingredients, veggie options, tasty food and several choices for beer = good times.  Bonus points for sangria.

Tried the green chile chicken enchilada.  Nicely spiced with a mild kick and there was a great salsa bar with a good selection available to add.

Chips and salsa to begin.  The sangria was just what I needed after a day of hiking.  I was slightly skeptical before I tried it as I thought with all the fancily sourced ingredients that the food wouldn't be interesting or that the spices would be toned down.  

Luckily for us, Green Chile Kitchen is the real deal.
author: Aaron T.

description: authentic. chips and salsa were bomb. freakin delicious
author: Daniel S.

description:
True New Mexican...Love the ambiance and the food.. It has New Mexican decorations that are not in your face mixed with a San Franciscan elegance.

Having lived in New Mexico for 7 years before moving to California, I had missed New Mexican food sooo much especially after being disappointed at "no chile" Mexican food establishments.  This place is great... The green chile tastes as good as fresh Hatch chile. The red was not worth mentioning much but will give it  a second chance in a breakfast burrito next time...
author: Lokum W.

description:
the ambiance is nice, but a little dark for my taste and doesnt mesh well with the order first, then find your seat with order number in hand.  my salad was prepared very quickly, while my friends taco duo hadnt arrived practically 15 or 20 minutes after mine.  finally we asked the employee at the cash register if her order had been lost.  he admitted to not giving her a number and just letting it go... NOT cool.  the tacos finally arrived and they werent very satisfactory.  my salad was very delicious.  TexMex, not mexican, so dont go looking for authenticity.  and their mango mimosa was pretty delicious as well.  

so good salad and good mango mimosa brought this horrible review up one star... barely
author: elizabeth r.

description:
I'm afraid I'll need to say ditto to Lisa A's initial experience at Green Chile Kitchen:

"I've gone in twice now. Both times the guy behind the counter (who I think is the owner) was abrupt and rather rude. I understand he has a business to run, but a smile doesn't hurt you and it helps the customer feel welcome so that they want to return. I was hoping he was just having a bad day the first time I went in, but I guess he really could care less about being friendly to his customers.  ...

The burritos were standard Americanized fare and it took a lot longer to make than one would expect. I'd much rather go to Papalote. The service is relatively quick at Papalote and while they're always busy they are also always friendly and the food is super yummy and much more reasonably priced. Sorry Green Chili Kitchen, but my heart still belongs to Papalote."

I'm not sure Trevor really meant it when he emailed Lisa after her review was posted to say he really cares about his customers.

Today, my husband, son and I went to GCK. We had been looking forward to trying it ever since it opened in our neighborhood. When we first walked in, we walked up to the counter and were blatantly ignored for 2 or 3 minutes. Try staring at the second hand on your clock for this long while holding a hungry 3-year-old. If you haven't done it, trust me, it's a long time. All the while, three employees stood right in front of us, continuing their personal conversation.  Apparently, they don't need or want the business.

Yes, I could have interrupted them, but I could not have possibly enjoyed my meal at this point.

So we left. My 3-year-old's eyes welled up with tears outside on the sidewalk. Cafe Neon anyone? They're always attentive. And efficient. (At this point, even Papalote was too far.)

Unfortunately, I will not be experiencing what my fellow reviewers tout as some good food.
author: Lucy M.

description: Looks kinda tex-mex-y from the outside, but great, reasonably priced legit Mexican food. Try the salsa sampler!
author: George W.

description: I went there for the first time last week and I loved it! The food. The vibe. Everything.  I definitely recommend it if you are in the area. I'm definitely coming back more often!
author: Kassandra L.

description: A friend of mine told me that we needed to try this place so we took a late lunch and headed over there. the place was full but not crowded and service was reasonably fast. Food was excellent! We had the beef nachos and split a chicken quesadilla. The nachos were ordered spicy but they were not that hot so i would not worry about ordering it spicy here.  Portion are big enough to share too.
author: joseph c.

description:
Started eating at the restaurant which I definitely reccomend. Not only are the burritos better with the sauce on top, but they have 2 dollar Pacificos ALL the time. 

2 dollar Pacifico??? What is not to love about that.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Green chile/cheese tamales = Amazing.  uh-maze-ang.  AhhhmaiiizeeeING!
They remind me of the true Southwestern tamales I used to get in Tucson.

Ask for refried beans on the side vs. black beans because they are kick-ass.
They also do fabulous salsas and guac.  

Yeah, the prices are higher than the corner taqueria, but I am down to pay a little extra for fulton valley chicken and sustainable ingredients that taste like this.
author: Heather P.

description:
Green Chili Kitchen is one of the best--and most underrated--brunch spots in SF, especially for those of us living on the West Side. Christmas lights, wooden tables, and funky, vibrant serving dishes give it a homey feel, and low prices complete the laid-back vibe. 

Their fresh and healthy approach comes through in every recipe.
