I love to order a breakfast burrito--fluffy eggs, fried potatoes, Niman Ranch bacon, and cheese, garnished with mind-blowing salsa--with a mimosa or a mug of organic, spicy hot chocolate. Although their regular burritos can't really compete with Mission District offerings, they, too, are made from great quality ingredients.
author: Karin H.

description:
I was in an incredibly pissy mood prior to walking into this happy little place. I'd been stuck in stupid traffic and had to pee for over an hour then had to try and park on Divisidero.

The cute blonde behind the counter said the magic words "yes, we have a bathroom" and I was already stoked. Was even more stoked when my yummy blue corn tacos came out a few minutes later. Totally and completely pleased a short while later when I finished them. Nummy nummy in da tummy.

Kind of a yuppified southwestern place with black beans and green chile on the menu but it was really tasty, affordable food in a pleasant little place.

Kinda funny that the girl behind the counter was white, while the cooks were all hispanic.
author: Christine K.

description:
Dear GCK,

Thank you for existing, dear GCK, thank you for your delectable rotisserie chicken, paired with your TDF black beans and rice, some sort of vegetable thing that I cannot pronounce but that I love to eat, and  fresh hot tortilla's to roll it all up in.
Thank you too, darling GCK, for dinner last night, lunch today, and the delicious chicken stock bubbling away on my stove, all for the bargain basement price of $18.56.
Till we meet again,

your devoted yelp fan
author: Ellen S.

description: Amazing amazing amazing. Just like new Mexican green chili. The chicken is perfect. Order with extra green chili obvi. The new location is perfect with tons of seating.
author: Andrew Christian C.

description: I grew up in New Mexico.  I know my red and green.  This place straight up kicks ass.  Recommend the blue flour enchiladas with red - will set you free.
author: Amy B.

description:
This place ROCKS!!!  I love New Mexican cuisine, and Green Chile Kitchen definitely does it right.  Yum! The atmosphere is really nice, and I found the service to be totally fine.

And Holy SH**, you people who are complaining about it being expensive?!?!   You think $11 for a huge, delicious, filling entree is expensive??!  OK, cheapskates, time for you to move back in with your parents.
author: Holly P.

description:
A bit expensive, it is true.
But, reluctant burrito-eater that I am, even *I* want to try one of the Niman Ranch beef burritos at this place.  
While they have yet to put up some of the finishing touches, the decor is nice and the service friendly.  I'll be back, especially for the yummy guacamole! 
It's good to note that this place isn't open on Mondays so they may be out of some of your favorites if you're dining late on Sunday night.  The flipside to that is you may just get an extra cookie with your spicy hot chocolate dessert.
author: Ky W.

description: Great food but they can never get my order right. Simple things like no green chili inside the burrito. Pork tamales when I ordered chicken. Happened about 4 times. You can't tell if the order is correct until you get home. Like I'm gonna open my tamale to check if its chicken. Very pricey as well. You can buy their green chili sauce and make your own burritos : )
author: Melody K.

description: I love their nachos, but a little overpriced for my taste. I appreciate that the ingredients are fresh and its evident in the flavor.
author: Moises T.

description:
This is probably the closest restaurant to my house and I don't come here nearly enough considering.  I'm going to give it 5 stars even though today it was slightly under.  I normally order the Super Nachos (green sauce) with chicken, but today I wasn't as hungry so I went with a quesadilla.  The first problem I had was that it was rolled up, almost like a "quesarito" or something.  It was overly crispy and terribly difficult to eat as the cheese was pouring out both sides.  The flavor was still good though, like everything here.

The burritos and nachos are much better, and the service is always spot on.  I love the mason jars for water and the casual but classy ambiance.  It can be difficult to find a seat at times but takeout is always a great option.
author: Cole I.

description: My wife and I live nearby, and frequent Green Chile and love it, but I wanted to post about a really good customer service experience.  We usually order take out burritos, and mostly the chicken with spicy green chile.  After picking them up and heading home, my wife discovered that her's didn't have any chicken in it.  I called over and spoke with mike (I think that's his name).  No sooner had I explained the problem than he asked if I lived nearby and offered to run the correct burrito over.  Didn't see that one coming.  he was on our doorstep in less than 5 minutes.  I love when you encounter that just-correct-it kind of service.  Thanks and we'll see you soon!
author: Brian S.

description:
This used to be one of my favorite spots in the City. Good enchiladas, burritos, authentic New Mexican chile, good vibes. 

However, my last two visits were incredibly disappointing. I waited 40 minutes for a burrito and the place wasn't that busy. Everybody standing around waiting for someone to take charge. The burrito itself was lackluster and a absolute ripoff for ten bucks. The cincher was the complete lack of chile. I mean really! New Mexican food is all about the chile. All I tasted was sour cream. 

Better step up your game Green Chile Kitchen!!
author: Dave G.

description:
I'm totally a fan.

I've only been here once so far. And it was for breakfast at 9:30am on a Sunday so keep that in mind as you read the rest.

I woke up and biked to this joint, with a joint, to meet some friends for breakfast. I've never been, but I'm so glad I now know about this place. The breakfast burrito with chicken, smothered in red sauce, was SO F'ing GOOD...i finished the entire thing. I had a cup of coffee too with agave syrup. All of it was yummy. 

I'm sure lunch and dinner are good there, but I'll probably go for their breakfast burritos exclusively. Dunno why, that's just how I roll. :)
author: Matthew M.

description:
Green Chile Fan Club!!
this place is everything it's Yelped up to be :)
I am partial to the grilled burritos, though the nachos are spectacular, as is the posole, & everything else I've tried here, honestly.. the salads are sumptuous as well! their citrus dressing is great ~ This place is gourmet & uber flavorful while still retaining its authenticity. I used to live around the corner & ate there several times a week... It is still mos def worth the walk!!
plus,Trevor is an absolute doll!
author: Miss W.

description: Perhaps we ordered the wrong items (him--the steak burrito and me the veggie chili) but our food was bland and lacking flavor. The flour tortillas seemed straight out of the grocery store (however the corn tortillas are handmade). In conclusion, we probably will not be returning to green chile and regret not going to nopalito (it was a close second for the night). My boyfriend is rushing home to slap My roommate who recommended this spot:-)
author: Amanda K.

description:
After having several good experiences at this restaurant, my last trip there has left a bad taste in my mouth. An hour wait for a burrito and a cup of soup!!! 

I must say that I cannot recommend this place to anyone anymore.
author: peter h.

description:
This is a nice little restaurant tucked away two blocks away from Divisadero. The food is Southwestern-style -- it's not the stuff you'd actually be eating in Albuquerque or Santa Fe, but it's tasty in its own right.

As the place gets busier, the speed of your order slows down. They aren't really geared to handle a flood of patrons, which happens once or twice a week. On those days, your burrito will be later. Tasty, but late.

The people who work there are very nice and personable. Then again, we live in the neighborhood, so that may be why. I've always felt well looked-after, in any case.
author: Linda V.

description: It doesn't  get much better than this place! I live in the neighborhood and this is one of my favorite restaurants in the area. Always really friendly staff, and really great food!
author: Martin V.

description: great food, service is lackluster. cheer up folks! you have a great product!
author: Penguin P.

description:
This is a neat little place.  They have great southwestern brunch options (breakfast burritos, scrambled egg bowl, tacos, etc) and it is all very fresh.  On sunny days they have some highly coveted outdoor seats, but if you can get them it is an excellent way to eat on a weekend morning/afternoon. 
Also, if you are feeling in the mood they have some reasonably priced mimosas that go rather well with a breakfast burrito.
author: Kristin S.

description: Fresh food, tasty, consistent, clean, welcoming.  I really like this place and will keep going back.  I have tried the burritos, enchiladas, quesadillas, and a few other dishes.  I haven't ever been disappointed.
author: Russ S.

description:
Went here for brunch and was pleasantly surprised at how much I liked the food. My review isn't getting five stars because I haven't eaten there for dinner. 

I ordered a Jr. burrito, which is perfect for a person who has somewhat of an appetite but doesn't feel like being passed out all day due to a food coma. I ordered my chili mild and my husband's hot. His wasn't too hot, but I preferred mine as I could still taste my food without needing water after every bite. I'm not a baby about eating spicy foods either; I typically prefer spice. Just not this time. 

I will definitely go back.
author: Hilary A.

description: This place is solid. I have never had a bad meal here and always leave feeling like I spent my money well. On the other hand, it doesn't completely blow me away. Regardless, I have been here many times for a decent meal. Sundays seem the time to go but they move people through quickly so you don't have to wait more than 15 minutes, usually. I think I am more excited about trying the Chile Pies and Ice Cream shop that they opened up where the old Green Chile used to be located. That place has awesome written all over it.
author: Jessica P.

description:
The veggie green chile soup was the perfect rainy-day lunch.  Chiles, not too many pintos, potatoes, and corn.  I would definitely get this again.  Also had the veggie quesadilla w/ potatoes, onions, mushrooms, zucchini.  It was perfectly crisp/soft which is great, but nothing exciting.  

The chips...eh - packaged thin blue corn.  The roasted red salsa is the best, the green yucky, and the guac sub-par.  As a queso afficianado from the midwest, this did not do it for me.  It was chalky cheddar.   

Service was super-friendly, but the meal was a little pricey at $30, with 2 mexi-beers.  I'll be back to try more stuff.
author: Kimberly C.

description: Its really close to where I live so I usually order a take-out dinner on my way back from work and pick it up. I usually get a steak burrito, which I like way better than anything from Tacqueria Cancun or Maya in SOMA. Its fairly decent for a casual sit-in too, and head down to the Green Chile Pie 1 block down for an excellent dessert right after!
author: Abhinav S.

description:
This eatery is a welcome addition to the North Panhandle neighborhood, especially with the demise of the oft-criticized Tango 20! burrito place further down Fulton. While the prices suggest gentification more than the food does, the chicken, burritos, and salads are tasty. The staff asked us how are food was and seemed genuinely interested (to the point of nervousness) about whether we enjoyed the food.

The food is good and the location is very convenient, serving a neighborhood that should have twice as many places to eat as it does.
author: Timothy O.

description:
It was a rainy day when I came across this place. I looked at the menu and was attracted immediately by the various herbs and flavors used in their different dishes. You can tell that a lot of thought was put into making each menu item unique from all the others. It also looked clean and nicely decorated inside.

I got the three tacos special and tried pork, beef, and chicken. I got the extra "super" add-ons (cheese, guac, sour cream). The staff is very attentive and friendly.

I have had many Mexican meals throughout Arizona and Southern California. Some of the best new Mexican restaurants in Arizona charge a lot for a meal of this quality. This unique New Mexican flavor has been hard to find in Northern California. The prices are very reasonable and I may be making more trips up to San Francisco from the south bay just to eat at this place again. Maybe I'll try one of their bottles of organic wine.

There is something I love about stumbling across a restaurant that becomes one of my favorites. The charm of the food quality, decorations, menu, and service all make me feel like this kitchen was waiting for me and that I was their new favorite customer!

Shouldn't every restaurant make you feel this way?
author: Tomas P.

description:
We stumbled across this place a few weeks back and were very pleasantly surprised! Extremely yummy, not too expensive, and definitely different from anything else I've had. The Calabacitas (squash and corn) and cheesy chili potatoes were extremely yummy--so much so that I hoarded mine and didn't want to share. The portions were also pretty generous and heavy on meat--my taco was probably 85% steak. 

Can't wait to go back for more!
author: Liz K.

description:
Great fresh n quick Mex.  The flavors are all so clean and bright.  Probably not for people looking for heavy monster burritos like in the Mission.  GC's obviously more focused on quality, organic ingredients and have portions that fill you up but aren't over the top.

I got the vegetarian burrito with roasted squash and guacomole inside. It was covered with green chiles, red hot salsa and a dollop of sour cream, w/ blue corn tortilla chips.  Yum.  My friend got the simmered pork burrito which had chunks of Niman Ranch pork that tasted like meat fresh from the butcher, not the shredded stuff that's been in the warmer all day. Served with roasted squash, rice, red sauce and sour cream.  Totally satisfying.

The space is bright and airy with natural wood and high ceilings.  And a little 'market corner' where you can pick up some organic wine, chips, beer and sauces.
author: Melanie C.

description:
3 and a half stars.

I dig that it's all organic but I've found the food to be just okay.  Generally pretty bland and I think by now I've sampled most of the menu.  Not worth going out of your way for but if you're a neighbourhoodie like me it does the trick.
author: Rachel N.

description:
Nice clean Mexican restaurant with lots to choose from on the menu. Good atmosphere to sit and enjoy a meal and good conversation. The only menu items I have tried are the burrito, tamales, summer taco salad, and rotisserie chicken. Burrito was OK (prefer Papalote - cheaper and tastier), tamale was above average, salad was OK, and the chicken was OK ($$). But since this place is only a block away and is a good place to sit and eat AND they have $2 Pacifico's all day every day I'll have to give this place 4 stars. I was originally just going to give 3 stars but you get 4 for selling my favorite beer for only $2!!

The only pitfall is that it's a little pricier than normal Mexican restaurant but they use the organic good stuff so i guess it's not that bad. Just go in there and enjoy a $2 Pacifico! Enjoy!

Did I mention they have $2 Pacifico's?
author: David C.

description:
I love the quiet neighborhoody ambiance about the place.  Stars abound for the dim lighting and the simple decor.

I came here when it first open a long time ago and had a burrito I remember loving.  It's been awhile, since I'm usualy lazy and usually do not like leaving my house for dinner, although it's only a mere 3 blocks away.

The boyfriend and I hit up Green Chile Kitchen last night and while all I had was a quesadilla...it was awesome.

Extra stars just for the fact that they're open pretty late for a neighborhood joint.
author: Jen I.

description: Came here on a Monday night and it was extremely crowded. I was surprised that it was so popping for a Monday night. Anyhow, we managed to get seats at the bar. We ordered the green chile enchiladas, the flight of salsa, chicken soft tacos, and a cup of green chile soup and a jug of sangria. Everything was pretty good and flavorful. The salsas were delicious, each one had a very different and distinct flavor, there was a habenero one which was extremely spicy. The only things I wasn't extremely impressed by were the tacos and enchiladas, I thought the tacos were tasty but a little dry. The enchiladas definitely needed more sauce. They let you order extra green chile sauce on the side, which we probably should have done.  The sangria was really good and I would definitely order it again. We wanted to dry the beet red margarita, but they had run out. Hopefully next time we can try it out. The staff is really friendly and helpful. They're more than willing to give suggestions on what to order. Overall, for Mexican food this wasn't my favorite place but I would  come here again. I think I have a high expectation for Mexican food, since it is my favorite. Still, flavorful food and a good ambience. Afterwards we went and got some frozen treats from Chile Pie, which is right next door.
author: Neha H.

description:
After watching the seriously talented dancers at the SF Ethnic Dance Festival, we were famished! Especially since it was 4pm and the last time we ate was 10am. Passing by this neighborhood restaurant, we decided to stop in and give it a try. 

I am seriously glad we did. The place was fairly empty but filled up with locals by the time we left. The staff was friendly and helpful but not overbearing. I couldn't make up my mind between the salad and the salmon fish tacos (Yes, salmon! I had the same thought....where is the white fish?) The staff recommended the salmon tacos and they were AWESOME!! 

I have to admit, I had a hard time eating them all, especially after finishing off a bowl of the delicious chips and 3 dipping sauces with more salt than should be legal (my sodium count for the month). My date had the chicken enchiladas with the Verde sauce and damn near licked the plate clean. 

This was a perfect unexpected place for dinner after a relaxing afternoon. If you are ever in the neighborhood, give it a try. With reasonable prices and the ability to park in NOPA, plus an ATM around the corner, how could you go wrong?
author: Island G.

description: Mmm nom, nom nom nom....this place hits you in the face with roasted chicken as soon as you enter! It's intoxicating! We were tehre for caffeine, but came back an hour later for second breakfast. The breakfast tacos and burritos are outstanding, with fresh, local and organic everything. Oh yea! The tacos came with rice, beans and what they refer to as a 'side of pozole' which is really more of a cock tease of pozole. It leaves you wanting more. Nice, friendly staff and an open and airy set up make this a great place for early afternoon. Oh crap - tons of organic wines and sangria as well - even some from Mendo!
author: Colleen B.

description:
Green Chile Kitchen was one of the first restaurants I ate at when I moved to SF 4 years ago. The owner Trevor was also the cashier, and it was in the old location. A lot has changed since then (also why they dropped a star, because it used to be so much more personable and more time and attention went into everything), but the heart of the place is still the same. 

If you're going to eat here, definitely either get a burrito or nachos; everything else is a little overpriced. The meat is great quality, the portions are huge, and worth it. Definitely a home away from home for me.
author: D S.

description: I have been here twice, eaten once.  The first time I took in the atmosphere, second time the food.  I quickly fell in love with the "Mother Mary" theme and how open and big it is, great for big groups.  The food looked and tasted amazing.  It was not taqueria traditional, but it wasn't too Americanized either.  I was not impressed with the taco or the enchilada, but I was fully impressed by the nachos (their price was reasonable too).  They were generously loaded and flavorful.  I also tried their sweet potato tamale, it was very interesting and worth trying if you like sweet potatoes.  The most unique part about their food was the blue corn that was used in some of their dishes, it was visually interesting.  Negative notes on the enchilada...it seemed to be like a soft taco you eat with a fork, I personally like enchiladas to be more like a casserole, clearly baked in the sauce.  Their tea infused sangria was also noteworthy, not super sweet and refreshing, creative spin on sangria.  Overall I am a fan, and look forward to eating here again.
author: Veronica D.

description:
3 1/2 STARS

After getting over the slightly-high prices for "taqueria" food, I found everything to be pretty good.  But the thing is - this ain't taqueria food, it's US southwestern!  

Definitely new to southwestern food, so I enjoyed trying a few new things, like their signature green chile chilli.  My dining partner had a couple of tacos and the excellent guacamole.  There seemed to be a few other items that I'd like to try in the future, including the salads and the high-end hot chocolate for desert.  The bottle beer prices were slightly high, though they had some on special (and it was nice that they had beer at all). 

And I really like that fact that they try to get their ingredients from local and organic sources, and I'm willing to pay more for the food just based on that fact.  The staff was pleasant and the atmosphere was laid back, nice colors.  The restaurant is still pretty new so they've got some organizational things to work out.. like making it clear where to order the food, arrangement of the tables, etc. but those are minor complaints. 

In short, nothing spectacular, but definitely a good addition to the neighborhood.  I'll be sure to try it again in the next few weeks to see how they evolve.

UPDATE: Have the spicy hot chocolate for dessert!
author: Eric H.

description:
It's really very simple.  The.  Best.  Breakfast.  Burritos.  In.  The.  City. 

Get them to go if you want the chile on the inside.

Nachos are pretty good too.
author: Tim K.

description:
Until last week, I have never been here. Now, I am a complete fan of the food. 

For me, Mexican food is very hit or miss. While I really LOVE Mexican food, if its done wrong, it can be too heavy, too greasy, not enough grease to hit the spot, or just a miss. So everytime I go into a new Mexican restaurant I haven't tried, I go in with the hesitation, or fear that the food won't hit the spot completely. Combine that with the initial thought that this was going to be a taqueria of some sorts, which around the south bay are a dime a dozen, you may or may not be completely excited to eat.

Man, I was wrong to go into this place with that perception. The food is awesome, actually, let me say that it was amazing. A lot of reviews have said that all the food has just the right amount of ingriedients - and I have to completely agree. And the best part, not only did the food hit the spot, it did not make me feel heavy or guilty...two common feelings that plague you when you eat at a Mexican joint.

So, what do you come for? The steak burrito with the green chile. It is just AWESOME. Throw in the $2 bottle of pacifico and you have yourself a great meal (BTW the beer is $2 all the time!). Another plus, the food is decently priced and you get a good amount.

For all you fans of great food, this is definitely a place to stop by and check out. You will most likely, become a fan and begin to crave the steak burrito bowl with green chile. And yes, maybe even a bottle of pacifico.
author: Brian D.

description:
Yum! This is by far one of my favorites in the city. As I usually put it, it's non-greasy, non-lardy, but oh-so-delicious Mexican food (or New Mexican if you want to get picky). 

The food is incredibly fresh. My favorite is the tamales and their soup is fantastic too. The chicken dinner is unbelievable too and if you're not in the mood for traditional Mexican, it's the perfect choice (definitely get the mashed potato side dish). The prices are reasonable too. 

Unfortunately, I can only give them 4 stars. I've tried their breakfast burritos twice now and they made me nauseous both times. All of my friends love them though so it might just be my picky stomach. 

The place can get pretty crowded though, so I usually grab it to-go. One of the perks is curbside pick up. You can call ahead and then wait outside in your car and they bring it out (yes, I'm THAT lazy).
author: Lauren B.

description:
Just had the breakfast burrito with charizo. Plenty of meat and perfect size for breakfast or lunch.
The place is clean, and the line to order goes fast. Parking sucks, but that's expected.
author: Justin M.

description:
Two dollar pacifico everyday! 

So our living room window looks directly into the Green Chile Kitchen... that might be one reason we go there often.  But the cheap beer and delicious southwest food keep us coming back.

Everytime I take our dogs for a walk, they try with all their might to walk through the open door, drawn by the yummy smell of rotisserie chickens wafting out to greet us.

The half chicken meal is alot of food for the money. The hubby and I can share it.  Nachos are good but a little expensive for what you get, in my opinion.  Overall, I love it.

The staff rocks too.
author: Melissa J.

description:
My trainer sent me here stating that he had the awesomest taco salad EVER.  It's Sunday, just finished playing with the dog, feeling like Mexican done anew for lunch.  I'm in the hood, there's parking, so I go in.

There's some Kombucha in the fridge, which I grab in anticipation of the start of tomorrow's day.  Reasonable wait for this taco salad. 

I get home, set to devour.  I started with the guacamole, which was not thrilling.  Moved onto this oh-so delish taco salad AND...underwhelming.  

However, I did witness a fine-looking blue taco plate that someone else got delivered to their table while I waited.  I may go back for those...
author: Tamar D.

description:
The closest thing to a New Mexican Restaurant you'll get to.
I love Green Chili, ill smother it in anything.  they're  Pasole is great, and the Burritos are cool, But if you tried Frontier in Albuquerque, New Mexico you will prolly feel the same way I do.  But ya This place rocks, just real expensive. Nice area with a lot of cool peeps.
But if your ever on camanche or juan tabo road in Alb,New Mexico you will find a lot of good foods.
author: Myron P.

description:
i grew up on a horse ranch in new mexico, so i had to try this place. they know what theyre doing! 

my fav is the green chile bowl, with chicken added

prices are reasonable, especially if you split a dish with a friend!

i now take anyone who hasnt experienced NM green chile, to see how different it is from any other mexican variants! 

soooooo savory!
author: Kelsey W.

description: Veggie queasadilla...I will be back again for you....and and you too, Sangria. Yum! So glad I stumbled upon this little gem!
author: Colleen M.

description: If you've ever been to New Mexico and had the green or red chile sauces, you know it's next to impossible to find that here.  Not anymore!  This place was amazing.  It's not pricey, food is served quickly and it's GOOD.  I could have used another helping of both red and green chile sauce on my enchilada though. And they have sopapillas at night.   I'll be back!
author: suzanne l.

description:
the chicken soup is ridiculously delicious. 

It has huge chunks of chicken and I could drink the broth with a straw. The small is pretty small, so I would suggest getting the larger size (I eat a lot though).  It also comes with a tortilla. 

Also, it's on the spicy side.
author: Josie A.

description: I love green chile kitchen.  Their steak is phenomenal.    Only a four star because it's a tad pricey for what it is.  That said, I keep going.
author: J D.

description:
I've had the chicken stew and a chicken burrito- both were quality but I found the burrito more flavorful- got it with green chile. It's great that they use Niman Ranch, etc, and they have upscale healthy options such as Ciao Bella ice cream (ok not that healthy) and kombucha and other drinks. Also, the house wine is decent and affordable.
I tried to call ahead with my order but they put me on hold forever so I gave up- seemed they put me on hold to tie up the lines to avoid calls because they were understaffed. In that case, they should just state they're not taking call-in orders... I resented being kept waiting. But I'll still go back if I'm in the neighborhood and have time.
author: Kate A.

description: This might sound silly, but I think this place is GREAT (if not a little pricey. But hey, I think Papalote charges up the wazoo for Mexican, too. I come from San Jose, where a delicious burrito should never needs to cost more than 8 bucks. For a super.) EXCEPT for the green and red chile (ironic, I know). I have a friend from New Mexico who gives me legit green chile, and the stuff from this restaurant pales in comparison (and tastes pretty much like watery, salty, tomato skins). So, I just order things that come without out (Hellllllo, crispy tacos) or ask not to have it put on. But if you don't want to take my word for it, just get it on the side. It'll keep your food from getting prematurely soggy anyway.
author: Andria M.

description: That was quite possibly the best chicken taco I've ever had!  And the guacamole and chips were great too!  I'll definitely come back again.
author: Jason F.

description:
Green Chili Kitchen might as well be called Vegas Burrito. Your chances of getting a stellar vs. awful burrito are roughly equivalent. When it's stellar, highlights are the shredded pork super burrito with remarkable guacamole. When it's awful, it's signified by egregious errors such as running out of black beans.

(NOTE to Owner/Head-buyer/head chef: You're a burrito place. Black beans in your burritos are integral to your business model. Please plan accordingly.) 

Additionally, disorganization tends to reign supreme here. The line/ordering set up changes more than Puff Daddy's name, the divvying-up of employee tasks appears to be governed by musical-chairs and I've often found myself a block out the door before I'm run down by an out-of-breath employee explaining that he gave me the wrong take-out order.     

Bottomline: Green Chile is new, so clearly a few kinks are still being ironed out. Potential is staggering. However, at the moment a burrito at Green Chili is like betting the house on red at the Bellagio roulette table --- you're either going to win big or feel like a jackass.
author: Tom C.

description:
Never been to New Mexico.
Don't know what posole is.
And what's 'christmas' salsa?

But!

GCK rocks.  The block.  

$2 pacificos.  Niman ranch pork, beef,  and fulton farm chicken.  I didn't think it'd make that big of a difference...but it does.  But don't get the burritos.  Get the tacos or the 1/4 chicken plate.

Also, try the Habanero salsa if you're feeling adventerous.
author: Tan H.

description:
Ok, so this spot is in my hood and I've been here no less than half a million times.  So check it...

New Mexican food with a Californian flare (Read: organic chicken, Neiman Ranch beef).  Burritos are nice and sizable.  Beef.  Good!  Their rotisserie chickens are decent, albeit a tad underseasoned, and a 1/4 chicken meal might still leave you hungry.  What?!  I eat a lot!

This spot is good if you live in the hood and are craving healthy Mexican.  Equally good as takeout or to bring a book and eat there.  Nice, soothing decor.

As much as I love to see a local spot like this survive, I do have to make a point about the jerk-off behind the counter, whom I suspect is one of the owners.  EVERYTIME I have come in (see above for the exact number), he is rude.  Crack a smile, man.  I've made jokes, I've smiled, I've engaged him - the guy makes me work waay too hard for a chance to see his pearly whites.

Lastly, food prep takes waay too long, especially for a glorified Mexican joint.  Their assembly line is neither efficient nor ergonomic for the worker.  So, pick up a Guardian from the corner and be prepared to wait...
author: Adrian L.

description:
Awesome for burritos/nachos, and also for more serious dinners like blue corn enchiladas or rotisserie chicken w/ fab sides (like green chile and cheddar mashed potatoes - yum!).  Green Chile Kitchen uses super-fresh ingredients, and only Fulton Valley chicken and Niman Ranch beef and pork.  They always have $2 bottles of Pacifica, and they also have some nice California and world wines, if you prefer.  Ciao Bella gelato for dessert.  MMMMMmmmm!  

It's a cozy, friendly neighborhood place with a casual but warm ambience.  I'm so happy it's in my neighborhood!
author: Jes H.

description:
This place rocks...great brunch, great lunch, great diner and great prices...it's just really great!  

Everything is VERY fresh and healthy.  Real important when you're watching the curves...
author: Lisa Kim J.

description:
If you're hungry - really hungry - and love all things breakfast you need to come here and have a breakfast burrito. 

It will blow your mind. And make your morning.
author: Madeline N.

description:
I have been eating at Green Chile Kitchen for a while and I feel like it has gone down a little recently.  My biggest complaint is that when I order something to go, when I arrive, there is a line in front of me.  I can see that my order is just sitting there, getting soggy, while people are chatting with the cashier and figuring out what to order.  I have had a few too many soggy meals from GCK because of this, thus I have taken a little bit of a break from there.  

However, when the food is piping hot and fresh, it is quite delicious.  The ingredients taste fresh and not greasy and very satisfying.  Try eating there and you will be safe.  Also, their wine is pretty good with the food.
author: Lauren H.

description:
Things aren't working out for me with this place.  Over three times now I have asked for and paid extra for white meat when I get my 1/4 chicken and I get home to discovered that they have ripped me off again.  A drumstick and thigh is not a quarter white meat.

I wish I could recommend this place.
author: Patricia A.

description:
A little white-washed I guess?  Sounds too much like the name of that fast food joint... what is that.. Green Burrito?

Anyway I was happily shocked that my food was good!  Yummy burritos smothered in sauce.  They have breakfast-y things too.

It's in walking distance and it's affordable.  They are nice and there is plenty of seating.  YAY!
author: Aaron W.

description:
Food was good, I ordered the taco plate and liked the chicken and the beef versions, but not the pork so much. I think the husband got enchliadas and was happy.

Yes people (thank you Kerrinski S.), it's food from New Mexico which is one of our 50 states, not nuevo mexican cuisine.  Some people never travel....

Big plus - I love that they serve all of their food on Heath ceramics.  Supporting and showcasing another local company is what makes this a 4 star restaurant for me with 3.5 star food. 

But I'll be sure to try that green chile stew next time.
author: Amy C.

description:
Hmm. I have wanted to try this place for a long time and finally made it there...

Started with the nachos, which were ok... they were a little soupy and they were the kind of nachos where a lot of chips had been layered and then toppings were on the top layer. I don't like that bc I'm a slow eater so that means I get stuck with the plain soggy chips at the bottom. Equal nachos for all!!

Moved onto the combo plate (the one with 3 diff items) in veggie form. The cheese quesadilla was pretty good. The "hot" green chile sauce was not very hot at all. I realize this varies with the batch of green chiles, but maybe if there isn't a hot batch that week, we can call it something else? I'm just saying.

The taco with tofu was pretty good - I can't really say bc I only had 1 bite of it, but I think the boy liked it. The rice & beans were average (nothing special, but fine). 

Had to bring the cheese tamale home, but I don't have the highest expectations.

Overall, it was a nice place to try, but the food was bland and the green chile factor wasn't as a big a draw as I had hoped.
author: Shal J.

description:
Hey all. It's not very often you find a totally craveable place like this little gem. And I love that it's off the beaten trail so it's got that good neighborhoody feel. Even though I'm actually invading the neighborhood to visit.

I usually eat in 'cause the atmosphere is almost as delicious as the green sauce. And the prices are awesome, well worth what you're getting. 

Oh, and can you say $2 Pacifico? or Niman Ranch beef in the breakfast burrito? But more than anything I can not get enough of the sauces!
author: Abby B.

description: Green Chili Kitchen serves a hybrid burrito which is partly inspired by the Mission style, but also heavily influenced by New Mexican cooking. They use organic/natural ingredients and Niman Ranch beef and pork. The NM inflection comes in the form of the addition of red or green chili sauce in the burrito. They serve a burrito which is my favorite of all time consisting of seasoned ground beef, refried beans, cheese, guacamole, sour cream, rice and green chili sauce. They import their green chilis from NM. And they grill their burritos, too. Their burritos perfectly meld all those components into a gooey, tasty amalgamation of pure bliss. On top of that, they make the most amazingly flavorful and fiery habanero salsa that when added to the mix only raises the stakes to orgasmic.
author: Brian J.

description: Wow!! I only wish I lived in San Francisco so I could eat at this place all the time. The food is absolutely delicious! Authentic New Mexican food at at its best, trust me you don't want to miss out on this place.I can agree with negative reviewers that the prices are a little high but the quality of chiles (red/ green) and meat are better than most places around town. You get what you pay for. The service is also very quick and helpful. There is a tall blonde girl that assisted me, she took ample time (despite the morning rush) to help me decide on the perfect breakfast item. I ordered the breakfast burrito and my friend ordered the healthy breakfast bowl- both totally delicious and healthy! This place also has yummy mimosas and sangria. Love it! Next time I'm in the bay you can find me here.
author: Sara L.

description: Robyn and I stepped out for a late lunch on a Monday afternoon. She's a local and I'm the foreigner, hailing from Los Angeles. It was a sunny day in San Francisco and the big widows played well for our afternoon meal as we soaked in the light sipping on our  Pellegrino. Robyn got the Posole Stew topped w/ cilantro & onion served w/ corn tortillas & lime squeeze and we shared a side of guacamole chips that was fresh and delicious. Service was prompt and polite. I dug into their new Chile Relleno plate with vigor. As I savored the food I realized that this was "New Mexico's" cuisine, not truly Mexican. But closer to Mexican than Tex-Mex. I really enjoyed the chili rellenos and part of the experience was the New Mexican "Hatch" chilis they were made of. Earlier, Robyn suggested that I should try both red and green sauce on the chili rellenos. I did, and the verdict is thumbs up on the red sauce, being that it has a rounder and more savory flavor than the green sauce. But I'm not generally a fan of green sauces, nonetheless, it's one of the better green sauces I've eaten. The beans were excellent and it played well with the dish. IThe beans was a natural when blending it with the corn chips, sour cream and guacamole. The friend rice was truly above average, being a bit more moist and flavorful than most fair. We left full and full of chatter from an remarkable meal on a sunny San Francisco afternoon.
author: Billy B.

description: Loved the food and the atmosphere.  Took my friend from Colorado who's obsessed with CO-style green chile and she loved it!  Said it was the same flavor, only a different consistency.  Love all the vegetarian and healthy options!
author: Audrey L.

description: I live in the neighborhood - this is a place I always suggest if I need to meet someone over lunch. I like the deco and the atmosphere, and the food is pretty good. Not spectacular, not super cheap, not super expensive, not super flavorful, not super unhealthy, not super healthy. You get the drift. I like the green chile stew and the kombucha on tap, the tacos are pretty good, the burritos sauced with chile are OK but somehow are missing on flavor inside (maybe the beans are cooked plain or something). Generally, nice for a casual bite out or lunch, and it really wouldn't kill the cashiers to smile once in a while. I always feel like awkwardly smiling an extra time or telling a joke when I get a death stare from them.
author: emmeli p.

description:
This was the first place I went to using my Green Zebra savings book for 2009 (buy one entree and get the second 1/2 off). Relax, I just got the book like a week ago at Appel and Frank for free so it's not like I was sitting on it until year's end.
I had been to the old location and it was perfectly fine. Now that they've moved up but still on the same block, it forces me to walk an extra 50 paces. John S. doesn't like this but I'm glad he's willing to trek the extra block for amazingly good food.
I love their Jarritos (especially grapefruit) and the Colombian Gorge selection of smoothies. This is the third place that I've seen carry my favorite Mango Cogo smoothie (the others are Faletti's and Berkeley Bowl).
GCK's nachos and tamales are delicious and it's decently priced as well. I love how you get options; lots and lots of options! Sour cream, avocado, black/refried/pinto beans, red/green salsa, mild or hot. All of these options JUST FOR ONE APPETIZER of nachos. I can never go wrong with a burrito here either. Come to think of it....I should come here more often.
author: Alyssa G.

description: I visited family in New Mexico last month & fell in love w/their hot chile.  I haven't been able to find ANYTHING close to their chile, here in CA.  I found Green Chile Kitchen online & decided to give them a try.  I LOVE their sopapillas yum & the red chile honey, oh ya!  You have a choice of mild or hot green chile.  The hot was delicious, finally I made my taste buds happy.  The red chile was good but, not hot.  I will definately be back.  The servers were friendly & even gave me a bottle of their honey after asking if I could buy a bottle.  Thanks!
author: Debra P.

description:
We only tried the posole and a green enchilada plate - so I will only rate those 2 items...when my cousin tried my posole, he said "its good but its missing something...yes, I said...it's missing PORK!
OK, I love that GCK is making a healthy version of a traditional mexican dish, but it's just not the same. I have roots in New Mexico and the chile is a little on the wimpy side.  I asked where they got their chile - the green is actually Hatch chile but grown in California - the red chile comes from a powder.  Red chile sauce made from the powder form is just not as rich as the puree made from the dried pods - just made a batch at home this weekend, thick, rich, and hot!
I would go back to GCK only if I were in the 'hood.
Thanks.
author: Deborah M.

description:
Since this place has opened up, I can't stop eating there. At reasonable prices, the food they offer gives a upscale take on my favorite type of food without going over the top. Their blue corn tortilla chips with the simple, yet sufficient, selection of salsa adds as a great side to my favorite: THE CHICKEN SUPER BURRITO: CHRISTMAS STYLE.

The employees are extremely nice and helpful, but the service is very slow. I've seen some improvements recently, with he addition of a computerized ordering system, but even during the smallest of rushes, they seem understaffed. Hasn't stopped me yet, though!
author: Joe G.

description:
Updated October 22, 2007***

Green Chile Kitchen has a formula that really works. There is no table service so you don't have to worry about cranky waiters. You order your food at the counter and then they bring it out to you. They have burritos, tacos, rotisserie chicken, and more. All the meat is organic and free range. It's listed as Mexican and I've heard it described as Santa Fe but be careful if you call it Tex-Mex. I don't know what to call it but yummy.

I just ate a half of a chicken with herbed citrus rub, roasted potatoes with cheese, and a green salad. I could have eaten a whole bowl of just that delicious, crispy chicken skin but that might have been gross. Now I'm in food coma. Oh my. When I snap out of it I'll rewrite this review in a more eloquent manner. For now it shall just be, "Hunter like meat. Meat good."

OK, so this wasn't one of my best reviews but doggonit, people like me... I think.

***
Now that I have an iPhone (yes ladies, I have an iPhone) I can yelp  
immediately from the restaurant I'm eating at and if they have wifi I  
can upload my review right away. Boy do I feel like a geek. No wonder  
I'm still single. And if you don't already feel sorry for me, how's  
this? The last two places I went to I was completely alone. I'm not  
just talking about going by myself, I was the only person in the  
place. Read my Madrone review.

So anyway, the update. Finally GCK has breakfast burritos. They even  
have a sign out front that says, "Finally Breakfast Burritos." I had a  
super with chorizo. Great way to fill your belly early on the morning  
and go back home for a nap. No need to sign a waiting list out front.  
No scrambling for a table either. You get your food right away because  
you are the only person in the restaurant. The sun shines through the  
window and halfway across your table. Little Maria comes in looking  
for her mom and the counter guy tells HER what salsa is for. Your food  
settles in your stomach and then you go to Central Coffee for an  
espresso. There will be people there so you won't be alone.
author: Hunter G.

description:
Food is pretty good, but you will wait for it- even at slow times. 
The staff can be inattentive and definitely focused on themselves, rather than the customers. 

I do appreciate the organic ingredients, and the made to order dishes, but it really can take 20 minutes for a burrito.
author: teriaki b.

description: my love affair with green chili kitchen started a couple years ago with the pork stew (order extra to bring home and serve over scrambled eggs for sunday brunch!) then it turned into a mission to try all the pies ...the green chili apple is still #1 for me. and then, theres the citrus habanero salsa...tangy SPICY and delish.  i love this place.
author: Randy S.

description:
I just recently moved into an apartment a block away from Green Chile Kitchen and after a week of living in the neighborhood, I was already considered a "regular." Yes, the girl at the register actually said "I won't tell you about our specials because I know you're a regular."  Am I flattered that she remembered me, or is this becoming an obsession? 

This place has the best chicken. I don't know what it is, but even the chicken on the salads is amazing. For a good time, try the chicken with the smoky/spicy red sauce. They have great Sangria, a kick-ass breakfast burrito, cheap beer specials, a super friendly staff, and always give you lots of chips on the side when you take your food to go. Plus, the place is super comfy with tables of all sizes (even a big communal table), and they have these huge sliding windows that they keep open on warm nights.
author: Kristy K.

description: I dont know what happened when I went/rated previously, but now think its great. So there.
author: tara s.

description:
This place is pretty good. But I grew up in San Diego and the got-daym yummiest tacos and burritos don't come from a sit down restauraunt staffed with well coiffed middle class chicks. They come from some hole in the wall with a slight to moderate risk of food poisoning. But they'll make your mouth think its having an orgasm. 

Plus its cheap.

So i'm pretty hard to please when it comes to tacos and burritos at a fine family establishment. The food here is pretty good, relatively well priced, and carries almost zero risk of e coli, salmonella, or those other fun flavors that leave you in the bathroom for hours on end.

But honestly its all about the posole.

MMMMM POSOLE!!!

I think its a little over priced. I mean who wants to pay $7 for wet food? But its definitely worth it if youre a) hungover b)sick with a cold c) ballin' and not concerned about the price tag.

Whatever you wanna do, just eat it. This shit is yummy all the time. 

They also make mean soyrizo breakfast burrito with potatoes in it. Damn Gina! I'm telling you, a couple snaps of chong, a comfy sofa, one of those breakfast burritos and I swear to jeebus it will cure even the nastiest of hangovers. 

Plus I live like a block away, so when I'm all hungover and look like I got dragged by a truck for mile or two, I call in an order, they have that shit ready in the time it takes to find my debit card, throw on a hoodie and stunna shades, brush my teeth, and drag my ass over there. Sweet deal.
author: Steph-a-saurus, Grr. J.

description: This place is good, but not great.  The food is always very fresh and the staff is very nice.  My husband and I live in the neighborhood and our only other option for mexican style food is Tortilla Heights (awful).  We eat here every couple weeks and have tried several menu options.  I did not really like the enchilada, but love all of the salads.  The steak salad is the best.  My husband really like the steak quesadillas and the burritos.  If you live in the neighborhood, it's a must try.  If not, don't waste the drive.
author: Cyndi S.

description: As someone who grew up in New Mexico (505!), I was very excited to find a New Mexican restaurant just blocks from my place.  And it's pretty legit.  It's not exactly what you find in Albuquerque, but the food is good and it has a very cool SF spin to it.  I recommend breakfast/brunch.
author: Robby N.

description: I've become a bit obsessed with this place recently. It's a cozy yet spacious corner restaurant with a self-seating setup (equals cheaper), Heath ceramic dishes (awesome choice), great drinks on tap and a delicious menu that is largely organic (all meat, beans and rice are organic/local). The pasole soup is perfect on a cold day and the burrito and enchiladas are super yummy and filling yet never greasy.
author: Sara W.

description:
I was led to this place based on a friend's recommendation. I went here with a group of 4 and we were not disappointed.  It's a very casual place.  you just go in, look at hte menu, walk up to the counter, oder, sit and they bring your food to you.  I got the blue corn enchilada plate christmas style, because I wanted to taste both the red and green chile.  It was very good.  It's not a favorite, but i wouldnt mind eating it again.  My friends opted for burritos and quesadillas which they said was very good as well.  i think what i like most about this place is that they are you typical mexican taqueria.  they offer a lot of different things on their menu.  they also have mimosas which were great! each plate was ranged between $7-$15 depending on what you ordered.  not a lot of items were over $10. I would also hold on the dessert and save it for their sister restaurant which happens to be a on the other end of the block (Chile, Pies, and Ice cream).  They have very good desserts.

It's not a place id go all the time, but defintely a recommended place to eat if youre around the area, Parking is dreadful around this area, so be prepared to either walk or cirle the streets for a bit.
author: Roxanne E.

description:
Tsk tsk tsk.  Waking up this morning I thought: mmm, breakfast burrito...  Looked up GCK and found they were both open early AND had vegan options for a breakfast burrito!  Yay.  My dude and I ordered 2 burritos, a side of chips and guac and one cup o' coffee.  "$30?!!!?"  we both asked when the guy gave us our total?  He tells me that the guacamole is $7.95!!!!!!  When he realizes I just wanted a side he lowers it to $2.50 plus a buck for chips...  As opposed to what?  An entire plate of guacamole?
     $25 later we sit down still a little perplexed.  My dude grabs the receipt from the register when the attendant wasn't looking because he didn't give it to us.  Turns out he charged us both for meat breakfast burritos($9 each) even though mine was vegan and had neither eggs, cheese, nor meat in it.  That's what I get for asking for tofu instead.  These aren't the type of burritos that leave you with leftovers either.  Also, my coffee was $2 for one pre-brewed mug he filled behind the counter.  No refills.
      I left feeling sadly bamboozled.  For $25 I could have bought enough groceries to make breakfast for myself and my 5 roommates.  This place is just another ridiculous, unauthentic money pit for the yuppies that live in N.O.P.oorA.llowed.
author: Haley A.

description: I came here a few days ago for lunch. I got a steak quesadilla which was pretty yummy and came with some blue corn tortilla chips. The food was a little bit slow coming out, but, I didn't mind too much, since I wasn't in a rush. The food was a bit pricey. I think single tacos were $3.50 each and my quesadilla was $6 or $7. I could see myself coming back here, especially since I live super close by it, but if I didn't live so close, I'm not sure if it would warrant a special trip.
author: Paige C.

description:
I'm a local and hop over here about once every two weeks. We had New Mexican food in my hometown growing up, and I've been to New Mexico several times. I wouldn't say this is the best take on New Mexican but it definitely scratches that itch when I have the hankering. 

Breakfast burritos are stellar and I'm also a big fan of the blue corn crispy tacos. I would recommend the nachos except that the chips have been consistently stale both times I ordered. But I'm thrilled it's in the neighborhood and take friends there pretty regularly.
author: Seth W.

description:
If you are looking for clean, fresh, organic, and tasty mexican food - eat here! 

Great atmosphere serving eco-friendly food, I recommend this place! 

had a half chicken entree, and nacho plate, both were delish. 

Support Local!
author: AA B.

description:
greenchilekitchen- 
I had the beef taco. It was made with Neiman Ranch beef. Unfortunately, it didn't taste like Neiman. Although I had the good-for-you feeling that I was eating better quality beef, I didn't get the full benefit of eating it freshly grilled. The beef was pre cooked and in a broth, tasted like chipped beef or beef stew meat. If I went to a steak house featuring Neiman Ranch steaks, then I wouldn't want them to cook my steak before I arrived. Anyway, the taco had a nice red chile with an earthy flavor to it, along with lettuce. I gave the taco 3 out of 5. The 3 was a stretch. The green salsa in the little cup was too acidic. I was so disappointed given the idea behind the name (greenchilekitchen). 

Here is what I really like about the place. They have rotisserie chicken, although it wasn't spinning, I'll go back to try it with a glass of fine wine, since they have a nice selection. Did I mention that I really like the decor? It's very very inviting and I want to stay there for hours. Oh yeah, they have wireless internet. No way! Way! The customers are nice; it feels like I'm shopping at TJ's, Berkeley Bowl or Whole Foods.
author: Miguel V.

description:
Friendly folk, fresh food, fairly frugal - Fine!

Actually it is quite a nice place - only gripe - no waiters - its that California thing again!  But the food is fresh and tastey.

Note if you ask for 'hot' when offered the choice of hot or mild - don't expect it to be "hot".  I didn't ask for super hot nor do I know if they even have that - but hot - aint!
author: Stephen M.

description:
This place is surprisingly good.   On Sunday's they have a breakfast taco that is healthy and delicious.  I got it "super" style with extra Chiles.   All the ingredients are fresh and there are a few tables outside for sunny days. 

I am nat sure I would really categorize this as a restaurant, but more of a burrito shop.   Prices are a little high, but the food is good, and the location is convenient for me.  

In summary: Good breakfast place on the weekend if you want a breakfast burrito or tacos.    A little pricey.  Can't speak for their other burritos or dinner menu.
author: Jim Z.

description:
I ate here once, I'd have eaten there more due to convenience but the food just wasn't all that. Its yet another dripping-wet-hipster-taco place, just like Papalote up the street.

They also didn't pay attention to my order very well because I got cheese on one of my items and I told them "I am allergic to dairy, no cheese/creme/etc please".
author: Tom S.

description:
I was excited when Green Chile Kitchen opened, and more so as time goes on.  I believe that any true fan of the taqueria craves useful (translate "delicious") variety, and GCK delivers.   Kinda a variation of an old saying "Every Jew needs two delis - one to love, and one to hate."

High quality ingredients and emphasis on chiles really comes through across the menu.  I've had pretty much everything and been happy.  Shout outs to roasted chicken, enchiladas, chile verde, and my fave, the green chile stew (either veggie or pork).

The main dining room is nice, and they have outside tables.
author: Stefan A.

description: Honestly, I don't know what the big deal is about this place. My fiance raved about it - so we went and I was in the mood for nachos and ordered that.  The beans were out of a can and the chips tasted blahhhhh.  He told me that you order the burrito in that place so that's what I got the second time I was there.  More blahhhh when I ordered that.  The chicken was good but it didn't have much flavor or any flavor at all. I was expecting perhaps some fireroasted New Mexico chiles or corn salsa or something and got none of that.  I get that it's organic but organic doesn't necessarily mean bland.  This is hardly Southwest cuisine and I don't understand why it's so popular.  I guess the local hipsters think it's green so they bombard it to be seen.  It's mediocre and nothing like I'd get in New Mexico and not even half as good as a taco truck.  I won't go there again.
author: Tanya H.

description: Went here after work one day for takeout.  Had a horrible time finding parking.  The food was ok, will probably venture to many other mexican restaurants before returning.
author: Karie M.

description: The chicken burrito is my favorite.  I like it so much it is almost impossible for me to order anything else on the menu.   Yum.  Love the new digs too.  Price range is not cheap, but not out of place.
author: Deborah T.

description: My boyfriend is from New Mexico, and since we moved to SF 2 years ago we haven't been able to find good New Mexican food - until tonight. I don't know how we didn't discover this place sooner. OH MY GOD. The food is perfect. Every single thing we had blew us away. The best thing is how you can vegetarianize almost every dish. I had the vegetarian green chili stew, which was a treat b/c it's usually impossible to find green chili stew without pork. We also had appetizer nachos, and guacamole, which was really fresh with the right amount of lime. Pacificos are $2. My one complaint about this place is I wish they had table servers, at least for dinner. It's so nice and cozy inside, but very awkward to stand in line and order at the counter. Counter service just doesn't match the warm, intimate feel of the place. But that's a small hangup. I'm psyched to go back for breakfast burritos now.
author: Erin R.

description:
So sad to give a bad review.... I used to love this place, but I keep finding bits of meat in my vegetarian food. 

Not cool. They've managed to mess up my food over 50% of the time, and I've eaten here quite frequently.

Although I hear their meat is great, I'd rather not be tricked into eating it.
author: T. C.

description: One of my favorite restaurants. My only wish is that it was bigger because it gets crazy packed. I take visitors from out of town here because I know they always deliver. I'm told be native New Mexicans that their green chili is legit, and I believe it, because it tastes amazing.
author: Jeremy F.

description:
OK, let's get real here.  First of all, the prices are offensive. Second, other than the breakfast burrito (for $12), the portions are small.  Third, they have messed up, and over charged me two consecutive times.   Both times I called  them out on it, and  they acted like it was not a big deal..but did give me back my money.  

The crispy chicken tacos have good flavor, but they are tiny_so order more than you normally would. And if you opt to take them home to eat, they will guaranteed be soggy and fall apart, so I reccommend eating them there.  The best reason to eat here imo, is for the rotisserie chicken dinners.  They are a great deal, and travel home well.  I prefer the chile rub over the citrus.  But both are delicious.  Also, the green chile is very good.
author: Jessica B.

description: I have to rescind my original review a little bit on this place.  Having ate here two times since, the food has seemingly become much more bland.  It's good but not great.  Not sure if I'll go back again.
author: Brian H.

description: I'd probably give 3.5 stars, since the food was good but I'm not yet a fan... Our order was confused multiple times - first we got chicken when we'd asked for a vegetarian posole, no guacamole with the order though we paid extra for it, and one of the appetizers never showed up (it turned out that it hadn't been put down in the order in the first place). While my blue corn enchiladas were good, the egg portions were too bland really. I'd be happy to go back there for brunch some day, but my first experience was less than perfect.
author: Neha K.

description: Very disappointed. First of all service was horrible, this was my first time here and the young man was not very friendly even though I informed him it was my first time here. I ordered the flat enchilada with red chili sauce and pork which also had a scrambled egg in the middle? Really!! No fried eggs here. Cheese was barely melted and they were greedy with the red chili sauce which was quite tasty. Came with a tiny cup of what they refer to as green chili stew, horrible. Ordered an order if Sopapillas which were excellent however they were pricey, order of 4 @ $5. This is not a place to come if your looking for that real New Mexico taste- way over priced.
author: Dolores S.

description:
Popped into Green Chile on Saturday morning for a hangover burrito. Had the steak with red chili sauce. Off the hook!! 

And the girl working the register wearing the Dickies was super cute!!

I will be back!!
author: Dave U.

description: This is a great neighborhood spot. Get the Pork Stew - yum - and expect to wait for a table.
author: Paul O.

description:
I have championed GCK for a long time, but after three consecutive, disappointing meals, I have to take back some stars.

While the decor and equipment seem to keep improving, the food quality has slipped, as have the attitudes of the people who make and serve the food. It's well on it's way to becoming just another taqueria.

As any New Mexican can tell you, a burrito is a plate of CHILE with some beans wrapped in a tortilla at the center of it. I realize this might be hard to understand and expensive to implement, but keep trying...
author: Jabe N.

description:
The enchiladas and tacos were good although my food always got cold really fast (I only ordered to go).

The owner, Trevor, yelp-mailed me 1 year ago and asked me to try the place again. I was a little put-off at that time because he assumed I hadn't lived in the area long enough to know that Green Chile Kitchen came before Papalote. Six months after his email, I went back and tried it and liked it. I had made it a regular place, but on my last day living in the neighborhood my tired husband and I went there for take out. We stood in line for 30 minutes and then waited for our food for 30 minutes. We only got our food at that point because I asked about it and the cashier practically threw it at me. I rarely take 1 hour to eat even when I go somewhere for a sit down meal.

Trevor, I don't know if you are still the owner of Green Chile. If you are, don't bother emailing me again. I will NOT change my review.
author: Mandy K.

description:
Green Chile Kitchen gets 5 stars because:
  It is a block from my house
  They do carry out (call in-carry out)
  They have ample vegetarian options
  Their decor balances restaurant feel and taqueria very nicely
  The owner and staff are always friendly and helpful
  They have breakfast burritos (and maybe ONE day they will serve them ALL day)
  Their veggie taco plate was fantabulous and hit the spot
  Their burritos are good (Now, the burritos are in no way the BESt in the city or anything like that; they're just good, packed, fresh burritos)
  They have $2 Pacificos ALL THE TIME
  They have good amount of seating
  They have a good selection of beverages
author: Christine G.

description:
I have some friends from Texas who are always talking about breakfast tacos (and bitching about how you can't get them in SF). Well, compadres, I've found your breakfast tacos. 

Jonesin for some bacon and eggs, I hopped on over this morning. I was alone and didn't really want a full-on sit down experience, but wanted some quality fare. GCK only uses high quality ingredients which I believe are all local (Niman Ranch, for one). The salsas are fantastic- not some store-bought version from a jar. But back to the tacos. 

The eggs were light and fluffy, the pico de gallo crisp and the tortillas, well, corny. Having had 'authentic' bfast tacos not too long ago in Austin, I have to say these were just as good- just in a higher-quality way (i.e. not the down-and-dirty kind from Texas). Buen provecho.
author: Billy L.

description:
I lived in New Mexico for 10 years and I have missed green chile since I left 5 years ago. This IS the ONLY place you can get it outside of New Mex and it is very very good. My favorite is the green chile stew with chicken.

However minus a star because the size of the stew (especially to go) is just too small. Also, they need to have a separate line for to go customers. I have yet to see the curbside pick up work.

The food is the BOMB!!
author: Kara S.

description:
This place is really good. The owner takes the time to source very high quality products and really cares that what he is doing is authentic. I have eated here several times. The posole is wonderful as is the chicken. I also enjoyed the burrito that I got and I hear the their breakfest burritos are great; I'm just never in the area for breakfast so I can't confirm.

I also like the high ceilings and the airy nature of the place. I look forward to going back again and trying something else.
author: sarah k.

description: My best new restaurant find in a while. It's clear they take care in every aspect of their dishes...even their refried beans are from scratch. All the vegetables exude freshess. Delicious, elegant food prepared with finesse. And a very good value for the $$.
author: Allen C.

description: I love this place. The green chile stew is to die for! It is a little spicy so watch out. They have a lot of vegetarian options, which is important because many of my friends are vegetarians and it is always nice to take them to a place where they can choose between more than one or two things. The people working there are very nice. Many of them remember my name even though I've only been there a had full of times. Sure it costs a little more than a tacoria in the mission, but it's WAY nicer! Their ingredients are top quality, most of it is organic. They have nice bottles of wine sold for practically the same price as it is in the store, they have soju cocktails, and home made Kombucha tea on tap! Tell me that is not worth paying $8 for your burrito instead of $6.50.
author: Jena M.

description: Heard about this place years ago and saw a Blackboard Eats deal and decided to pull the trigger. I have been to New Mexico (last time I follow a top 10 places to live tip from Forbes and will gladly take my rent controlled apartment over living over there), which is famous for green chiles and sopapillas.  This place is cute and crowded!  Relatively easy to find parking. You order and then sit down. Glad we got our own table (sorry fellow SFers...not into sharing tables) and they bring it out. Had the Carne Asoboda (spelling is totally off but nothing else really comes close to that on the menu so you will know what I am talking about) as its slow cooked pork in a stew if red chilis. Not spicy,wet or greasy. Comes with rice,beans, salad, grilled corn off the cob, and a tortilla. Basically a burrito not put together but I really enjoy eating my food like that. I wish I had added sour cream but the meat was super tasty and lean. Then I ordered the sopapillas and poured honey on them. They are deep fried triangles of joy. Every culture has a fried dough delicacy and they were yummy. More deep fried and less doughy than what I had in New Mexico but overall pretty good (fried dough usually is).  Like the casual atmosphere and would go back with friends. It got crowded. Went at 8:30 on a Friday night and by the time I left there were people still lining up to order and most tables were just packed.
author: Deal G.

description:
maybe i just came by on the wrong day, but this place is extremely overrated. 
the staff was really nice, though and their green chile stew was great and actually spicy, but that's probably the only thing i would go back for. we were so excited for the flat enchiladas, but they were cold! the rice was hard, like it had been sitting out all day, too. I am also a firm believer that all mexican and new mexican food should be reasonably priced. we paid over $20 for just a bowl of soup and the enchilada plate. that wouldn't happen in new mexico. 
super disappointing, we were looking forward to eating here bc of all the yelp reviews. 
chili pies (their dessert place) down the street is pretty awesome!
author: Courtney J.

description:
It's been awhile since I ate here, but I remember quite a bit about it. 
I loved how they use mason jars instead of cups. I may be a bit biased since I like mason jars in general, but they were so unique. 
I got a burrito (carne asada?) and I remember that chile honey was on every table and that it complemented the flavors of my burrito. I'm not sure if that's how I was supposed to eat it, but it was delicious that way. The burrito was served unconventionally drizzled with a green chile sauce that required a knife and fork to eat it. It was rather irritating, to be honest. I want to eat my burrito like a burrito! Also, I think the tortilla was too large because it was all bunched together on one side. My burrito was a snugly wrapped bundle, but the excess of tortilla was a bit of a turn off. 
I really liked the aesthetic details of the restaurant; the sleek dark gray/black square plates were a nice touch, the lights were slightly dimmed and like I said before, they used mason jars. Overall, a very nice restaurant, but it almost seems to value visuals over functionality.
author: Reb R.

description:
Bumped into this place on a lazy Sunday afternoon walk back from Golden Gate park.  Cool decor, with mason jars for self service water, some nice wooden tables and a little counter that looks out over the street.

Saw the chickens on the Rotisserie and had to try the chicken burrito.  Very fresh and tasty!
author: Steve H.

description: Good food at a good price. We will definitely be back. My wife had the taco salad and I had the chicken burrito with the red chile, both of which were excellent. Would have earned a 5 star review if the burrito had been a bit bigger as it looked like it used a 10" tortilla rather than a 12".
author: Chris S.

description: My boyfriend and I came here for lunch the other day, when the weather was gorgeous.  We ordered the vegetarian burritos, just $5.50 each, sweet deal!  They have outdoor seating which we appreciated.  My Brazilian boyfriend hates fatty mexican food, greasy rice and lard added into the beans- so he was very pleased with the light healthy fare we received at Green Chile Kitchen.  I wasn't a fan of the sauce covering the burrito, thats the star subtraction.  We will be back :0)
author: Liz Y.

description: Being from Santa Fe but not trying to sound like a snob, I gotta say this place skimps on chile like no other .... and when I went up to get more xmas chile for my single rice and bean burrito, they charged me almost an extra 5 bucks..... I had a sub-par vegan burrito that cost me 14 dollars before I even tipped.... ridiculous.... even more ridiculous; bit into a piece of animal flesh in it afterwords and had to walk out..... a lot of you may laugh, but I don't think this is funny..... its actually f'in gross and shows that things are clearly insanitary on their hot bar in the kitchen..... I haven't eaten meat in over a decade and a half and i wasn't trying to start with the crappy boiled kind either.... given this place many chances to not skimp me on chile but its what they do here.... the animal flesh was the final straw........ never going back and neither should you if you are a vegetarian..... if you need green chile thats the real deal (4 diff spice levels) and less than half the price, buy 10 pounds of the stuff on ebay and they'll deliver it frozen to your door for only 5 or 10 bucks more (about 45ish dollars) than what 5 pounds of frozen costs at green chile kitchen(35ish dollars.... This place wouldn't last a month in northern new mexico with the amount of chile they give you and their lame system of ordering at the counter and having to wait in line again after you decide you want a drink or a sopapilla halfway through your meal? wtf is that?!!! the lady at the counter is like a zombie trapped in a human shell too....  click and paste for new mexican deluxeties anywhere you want them and save yourself the trouble of going to this place...........         http://stores.ebay.com/SOUTHWEST-FLAVORS-AND-SPICES?_trksid=p2047675.l2563
author: Rob D.

description:
I went in earlier today with my boyfriend. He's New Mexican and likes to have a taste of what home tastes like every once in awhile. We have eaten here a few times. 

the food here is never the best compared to actual New Mexican food nor is the Hot or Mild Christmas sauce. The hot sauce is just like the mild. No difference. 

The girl at the register with a pierced nose took our order. When we first walked in we didn't even get a proper greeting. The girl spoke so lightly  that we could barely hear what she was saying and i had to lean over to hear her and respond. My boyfriend asked for a black cherry blue sky drink and i asked for the blue sky lemon lime drink. She told my boyfriend sorry we don't have black cherry as a blue sky but have some other kind of black drink(holding up a IZZIE ) . I told her no its the black cherry blue sky. She then proceeded to tell me and my boyfriend that he had apparently told her a IZZIE. Which, a. boyfriend hates IZZIE's and b. she had the nerve to tell us what he had apparently said. I heard him say Blue Sky and he knew what he said as well. 

That was just the first part of our awful service. Especially with this being a restaurant and the first person you have contact with is the counter person, one would think she would be nicer to a customer and not correct them. 

The second part, after we paid she gave off a sigh of  "you were rude." I asked her what was wrong and she proceeded to tell me how she felt like my boyfriend and i didn't acknowledge her. EXCUSE ME!!! since when does staff tell me people that they don''t feel like they are getting enough attention. ? I told her i have worked in customer service for the past 8 years and i have never once ever treated a customer the way she treated both of us nor gave so much nasty attention. I told her well you might want to get attention from someone else, because in Customer service you don't always get attention you deserve. I know first hand. I have had better service at McDonald's. 

I was just appalled that this girl would dare make me feel a guilty person for not giving HER enough Attention. Who does that nor what management would want someone like this on their floor.

I tried to go online and contact Management however there is no location to email owner nor management as to issues that have occurred. I guess its because they don't want to know the truth about how their staff treats customers

Be aware staff is extremely RUDE. 
Food is Eh. Green Chile is not HOT (if its called hot or Mild)

And Sopapillas aren't available until after 5pm. That's ridiculous. People in NEW MEXICO eat them at all hours of the day and if you are  going to be having a name like the GREENCHILEKITCHEN and sell NEw MExican food you should have at least the sopapillas be available at all hours of the day.  People eat them like bread and butter before a meal. 



WON'T be returning any time soon, nor recommend this place to anybody.!!!!
author: Sara J.

description:
Came here for breakfast and am excited to come back for more.

Good home-cooking kind of meal.  Nothing fancy, just a comfortable place to grab a cup of coffee(or beer) and a plate of good food.
Here is what home cookin' is to me:
1) Not overwhelmingly or underwhelmingly spiced
2) Served in hearty, but not HUGE portions
3) Uses simple, fresh ingredients
4) Not greasy or too rich

Green Chile Kitchen feels like home cooking, even if you didn't grow up in New Mexico you'll feel like you had.  

I had the blue corn flat enchilada plate (vegetarian version)....tortillas were fresh, filling was simple yet delicious, and the sauce (red) was not too hot not too mild with a subtle smoky flavor.

Added bonus:  Love the stoneware plates, bowls, and mugs.   Feels solid with a good amount of heft in your hands, and seems to add just the right amount of "grit" to your meal!
author: aekta s.

description:
I used to live only a few blocks from this place and would go once in awhile to get a burrito or a bowl of posole.  Now that I have moved out of walking distance, I hardly go, but yesterday night my boyfriend and I stopped in before going to a show at the Independent, and the food was as good as (or better) than I remember.
