We got a bowl of posole, a 1/4 chicken dinner, and 2 sodas for about $20.  Our plates were completely clean and our stomachs streched to capacity when we left.  Both of us were very satisfied with our dinner and will definitely be back.
author: Gami G.

description:
IF YOU WANT TO SEE AND TASTE HOW REAL AUTHENTIC GREEN CHILE IS SUPPOSED TO TASTE IN SAN FRANCISCO, GO TO JUST FOR YOU CAFE AND GET THEIRS.  

I lived in NM for 8 years and have harvested and prepared green chile almost every fall while there.  I even have my NM friends bring and ship me green chile so I can keep it in my freezer year 'round.  I was really excited about Green Chile Kitchen being able to offer New Mexican food with green chile.  I kept my expectations low and that was a good thing.  It's pretty pricey for what it is.  The service is okay.  The chile is Bueno Green chile, the kind you find in the frozen section in NM, and most New Mexicans will scoff at it, somewhat deservedly, because it just doesn't have the same flavor as others.  But as a far away business I can see why this is one of their most viable sourcing options.  But after going to Just for You Cafe the other day, I can honestly say when I need my green chile fix, I'm going there, NOT "Green Chile Kitchen".  Green Chile Cafe-you are kind of messing up.  If you want o see how green chile is really suposed to be, like in NM, go to Just For You Cafe and try theirs, and get a clue.  Any fool can get Bueno chile, toss it on some mediocre NM recipes, and charge 30% more than the average mex-new mex fare is worth for the gimmick.

After deciding GCK was a bit of a let down for a NM palate, I  took my girlfriend down the street to their sister-business  for a pie-shake.  While there I saw Frito Pie on the menu.  I love frito pie and it's pretty hard to mess up.  After shelling out a ridiculous amount of money ($8+) for what is a fast-junk-convenience food in NM and should be priced accordingly, I received a little frito pie that DIDNT HAVE ANY CHILE ON IT.  It's a NM dish.  New Mexicans put green or red chile on everything, and I don't think I've ever had a frito pie in NM without either red or green on it.  thanks, but I could have cut open a bag of fritos, dropped some plain beans, lettuce onion and tomato and cheese on it at home for about $2.  Which is what Ill be doing next time.

A+ for offering it.  D+ for pulling it off.  D- for charging so much.  F- for no chile on my frito pie.  D for the chile in general.  Shame on you for being so lazy by offering out of the freezer Bueno green chile, not doing much if anything to it, and charging up the ass for it.
author: Uuri K.

description:
this is the great little no frills yet fresh and healthy take out or sit down place everyone wants around the corner from home.  tex mex food gets a bad rap - bad mexican food with a bunch of green peppers thrown in comes to mind - so most of the bad rap seems well deserved, in my opinion, blame it on the fast food chain restaurants for the negative stereotypes.  But green chile has helped me see that tex mex food can be great, like when it means one of your sides will be grilled chunks of fresh zuchini.  if you're turned off from tex mex from the general lack of spice, you can quickly self correct with the tapatio at every table.  each of the certified organic meats taste great. chicken tastes like chicken, beef like beef. and the pork is lean yet delicious.  the burritos are satisfying, making up in quality ingredients what you think you lost in size until you actually finish one and you realize all the places preaching gargantuan sizes are lying and you really do not need a burrito bigger than your head to feel satisfied.  skip the tamales but do get their soft tacos.  

the space is cozy, by which i mean it does a good job of being small and consistently packed without making you feel crowded.  and they manage to be a great value (order at the register, take a number to your seat) while you still feel like you're out and dining.  which gets extra pluses from me.  and i actually like the fact that it is really in a neighborhood, on a residential corner.  the short walk down to divis or up to the haight for post dinner drinks will prove really key if you took my advice and  finished that burrito.

p.s. i have never had red wine with mexican food before.  but i could not think of a reason not to try it when they have a bottle of red for 10 bucks.  seriously 10 bucks for a bottle. scoff if you want to consider yourself a wine snob, but it was good enough that we ended up getting 2.
author: Nikki F.

description: Given that there are only a few restaurants in my neighborhood, I eat here far more than I would choose too. There is nothing New Mexican about it, other than a hint of green chili on the chicken rub and a bit of green chili in the mashed potatoes.  The food is just ok. Nothing to rave about. The chicken is really good- I will give them that. Their prices are ridiculous and I can not even begin to imagine what made them price things the way they did. It is always busy here, again, not many places in the neighborhood. And parking, forget it. It's residential and there is not much turnover.
author: Kim K.

description: The change of location for Green Chile Kitchen (GCK) is the best thing that could of happened to this authentic organic Mexican restaurant located in Alamo Square area. Looking for a casual yet comforting ambiance, GCK is your place! EVERYTHING is delicious here, including the all-star breakfast burritos that are the perfect cure to a killer hangover. This has quickly become a favorite w/ my group of friends and is always crowded but there's plenty of seating. The taco salad is fresh with ingredients and has the best California avocados. Whether your a neighborhood regular or just a visitor to the neighborhood, this is MUST-HAVE!
author: Jamie D.

description: Everything was solid and good. I like the new space much more than the old. We tried the posole and a pork burrito. It was tasty and filling. They have good beers on tap, which was a surprising bonus. However, if you're in the mood for a burrito in that neighborhood, I would walk down to Little Chihuahua  instead.
author: m t.

description: Been there twice now, first time had the vegi burrito; seems healthy but not allot going on inside.  Second time had tamale plate chicken and cheese;  more soggy then I would like a tamale to be but tasted pretty good.  I really want to like this place more then I do.
author: John C.

description:
We love Mexican food and we also focus on eating healthy and typically the two don't meet.  The food at most Mexican restaurants and taquerias is far too salty and fatty.  But as food trends continue to evolve and there are more and more restaurants popping up offering healthier, organic and sustainable food choices, yesterday I decided to do a search for "healthy Mexican restaurants in San Francisco" and Green Chile Kitchen appeared in the results.  It was in the ideal location as it's on my way home and I wanted take-out.  Then I looked at their online menu and it seemed to be exactly what I had hoped for. Organic ingredients and tasty sounding dishes.  Lots of great choices.
I placed my order to go, and everything was so good, exceeded our expectations.  Large portions, big chunks of white meat only organic chicken, light but delicious sauces and flavors.  And all just lightly salted. Loved the blue corn tortillas!
They have a side order called Calabacitas....lightly grilled or sauteed squashes and corn.  A great big side dish of veggies!
They were very busy so be prepared to wait a little bit.  But busy means they'll stick around so while I'd prefer a shorter wait (I was there about 15-20 minutes), I'd rather see that they stay in business.  They also plan to add online ordering soon, so that should help the process.
Green Chile Kitchen is our new go-to place for Mexican!
author: m b.

description: Green Chile Kitchen has the best chicken ever.  It's so delicious.  It's juicy and flavorful, and sometimes, I run by just to pick up a side of it to put on salads.  Their burritos are also delicious, but huge!  I recommend eating burritos on site; taking them home takes something away from the burrito eating experience.
author: Carrie A.

description:
I've had two dining experiences here since the move to McAllister St.  

#1: Tamale platter was excellent.

#2: Chose to make my own salad.  You get salad and several add-ins.  What a rip.  Literally got like a teaspoon of each add in, for a $10-12 (can't remember) salad.

Overall, I used to think this place was pricey but that was ok because the ingredients are so quality and fresh.  Now, starting to think it's just pricey.
author: Martine D.

description:
I really liked the feel of the place. A lot of natural light and the wooden window frames, tables and chairs give the place a relaxed homey feel. Nice place to unwind and chow after a hectic day. 

I came here for one reason: sopaipillas. As far as I can tell on yelp this is the only place in San Francisco and San Jose that sells real sopaipillas on a regular basis. They are dessert from New Mexico, consisting of pieces of puffy fried dough served with honey. 

Service was friendly enough but a bit slow - I waited fifteen minutes for 2 orders of sopaipillas. Turns out that they'd been fried and sitting in the kitchen until I asked the server if they were ready. 

Also, at over a buck apiece, they're a bit pricey, but oh so, so  so good. Thin, flaky, perfectly golden, perfectly puffed, and the server even offered some honey to take home with me. 

I like the atmosphere enough to come back - and the food people around me were eating looked helllla good. 

Finding parking can be a pain.
author: Polly F.

description: I love New Mexico and its food, and not just because of Breaking Bad. My pal & I bellied up to the bar & were served beer tastes while we waited for our food. The servers were super friendly and the food was all delicious! I agree with the writer who called out the sopapillas for some help -- I prefer mine doughier -- but what a great addition to San Francisco's options for casual food!
author: E H.

description:
My husband and I go there at least once a week.  We love the crew that is working there and the food is RADICAL.

Yeah, we can't get enough and we think we are lucky to live two blocks away.  If you want a super tasty, filling breakfast or lunch burrito give it a try.  The posole is great too!
author: Christine S.

description:
This place is tasty and above all, has some really nice people. I like breakfast here better than dinner, but I'm not that picky as they both taste pretty darn good.

I love that I can walk here, but more importantly, I love the fact that the service is pretty darn good considering you order at the counter.

...and the posole can seriously cure you of any cold or flu with one big bowl!
author: Sarah G.

description: Perhaps not the best place to go for a regular ole run of the mill burrito, but still hella fancy. Green Chile Kitchen's best option is definitely the breakfast burrito though, if'n you're not vegan. Oh god so good. They also serve unsweetened yerba mate tea, and that makes me happy more than anything.
author: Bier S.

description:
Let me start by saying I lived in Colorado for a few years, and my wifes family lives in Santa Fe, so I know what green chile/New Mexico style Mexican cuisine should be. This ain't it.

What a dissapointment. I guess after reading the reviews I wasn't expecting a whole lot, but was hoping for more than I got. I ordered the Pork something or other burrito which I have to say was the worst burrito I've had maybe, ever. I can't believe a restaurant in SF would serve pork like that. Not at ALL tender, yet still overcooked. It seemed like they just threw some pieces of pork and cooked it real quick. Terrible. There was also very little inside the burrito, just a lot of tortilla. Also, potatoes in a burrito? Really? I made the mistake of getting it Christmas style (1/2 red 1/2 green chile) which also ended up costing an extra $1. I say it was a mistake because the green chile was actually decent, but they already barely put enough on and then the other half was what was supposed to be red chile, but sure looked (and tasted) like canned enchilada sauce to me. I think this place just thinks that because they are serving green chile they can forget about the rest? Oh well. The sopapillas were decent, as was the sangria. Definitely won't be back. Bummer
author: Jeff S.

description: Really authentic New Mexican food, I don't think there's anything else quite like it in SF.   The green chile wasn't as thick as I was hoping for, but the incredible flavor made up for it.  We also had enchiladas, which were really interesting and delicious.  Love the open atmosphere and neighborhood vibe.
author: Leah S.

description:
I just came back from the GCK after having, without a doubt, the best breakfast burrito I have ever had.  Just delicious.  The perfectly cooked eggs, the chorizo mixed with a fantastic blend of spices, the salsa verde splashed delightfully on top, all wrapped in love within the warm, chewy flour tortilla.

I'll be back.
author: Timothy C.

description: I love this place! My boyfriend can quench his craving for beer, sour cream and cheese, and I can order a bright and fresh salad with kombucha from the tap?  I'm in! Love the new location.
author: Danielle M.

description:
Came here for a late lunch on Saturday and, since I was being "good", I had the posole with huge chunks of roasted chicken which really hit the spot.  My friend had the steak burrito which looked yummy, even though I don't eat red meat.  Atmosphere is also very warm and cozy.

I can't wait to come back and try one of the breakfast burritos!
author: Michelle E.

description: This place has good food, but both times I've been there they've somehow messed up my order.  I didn't mind the first time because it was near closing and they left the dressing on my salad when I asked for it on the side.  The next time I was there three of my friends and I got the same salad and only one of us asked for chicken on it- they ended up putting on all of them!  Come on, it's not that hard to leave chicken off a salad that doesn't normally come with it. The burrito I had was okay but I'd rather go to papalote down the block.
author: Karen B.

description:
What is that old saying, fool me once, shame on you; fool me twice, shame on me. Well what do you know, I have now been fooled twice three months apart from each other. I am so bummed out. Let me just say for 10.90$ I feel like I should be able to expect to get what I want in my burrito. I have twice ordered super burritos WITHOUT rice and received it. Do they need to translate rice to arroz or do I need to open my burrito "to go" in the restaurant and bite into it so that I know I am getting what I paid for. 
The exuberant prices can be explained with the territory, as there are many USF students(=$$$) and middle class families with appetites and the wallet to match. For this reason I cannot bash on the prices. Unfortunately burrito joints in this vicinity have taken advantage of the high socioeconomic status of its most prevalent residents and I am not one of them (I know, I know, the recession...). 
Don't worry, I will solve my dissonance via this blog and by not ever going back. I hope someone is reading this and takes my advice. There is such a nasty taste that one is left with when not getting what they were unsure of paying for in the first place. Good luck my fellow blog readers...
author: Erronious M.

description:
Nachos are my favorite junk food and Green Chile has some of THE best nachos I've ever had. I ordered the appetizer size and it was enough to fill me up for dinner.

I was eying our neighbor's plates...there portions were huge and looked delicious...I wanted to steal a bite!

Definitely a delicious and affordable place to eat out when you want some good home cooked mexican food.
author: Sarah G.

description: Of all the burritos I tasted in San Fran, this was hands down my favorite.  Get it Christmas with Guac and Cheese - you can't go wrong.  We used to come here before night class at USF and get burritos and beers. They also have amazing breakfast burritos.   Great ingredients, no table service - get a number and good luck finding a table. come off peak for less hectic experience.  Also right outside the 5 stop.
author: Lucy A.

description: This is a great neighborhood place, however I agree with other comments regarding price.  My biggest issue the amount of protein they put into their burrito's, given the price it seems to have been reduced over time.  Everyone knows that the rice and beans have very low cost.  I hope they will start putting more "meat" into their burritos if they are charging those kind of prices. Quality of food is good, but protein portions are inadequate.
author: Crater H.

description: Not a fan. I guess I misunderstood that our meals did not come with chips. What kind of Mexican food place doesn't offer chips? Besides the fact the asian lady wasn't too nice about it. I won't be back!
author: Maliny S.

description:
I really wanted to give this place more stars, but can't. The food itself was completely eclipsed by the time it took to prepare. 

Went here alone one Saturday morning not too long ago. Drawn in by the menu and the scent that drifted down the street. Nice, I thought. I honestly couldn't have been any hungrier. Place was somewhat busy, by which I mean that there were people already eating. Not sure how many orders were ahead of mine, but in the end there were some five-odd diners in there when i finally got my food. 

Tell you the truth, I can't remember what I ate. It took so friggin' long to get. Seriously took more or less a half hour to get my food.  What gives?  

Maybe instead of hanging out in the dining room and blah-blah-blah'ing about your recent trip to Europe and what a drag Basel was you should get behind the counter and start working some pans. 

To be fair, when someone's eathing alone time slows to a c-r-a-w-l, but I had just gone to the bank down the street and had my time-dated receipt. The food took more than a half hour. 

Sign in the window says something along the lines of "breakfast served 9-2". I'd recommend you get there at nine if you're thinking of brunch/lunch. I can't imagine the wait when they're busy.
author: scott l.

description:
I really enjoyed this restaurant, so did my boyfriend who is the pickiest eater on the planet.

My sister moved to Albuquerque, NM about a year ago and the two times I've been to visit I could not get enough of the New Mexican food. Everything is super spicy and smothered with New Mexico chiles (red or green).

Now, I wondered if a New Mexican restaurant in San Francisco could do justice to this amazing food... I just have to say that I found Green Chile Kitchen to be amazing. And the food actually reminded me of a restaurant in Albuquerque, called El Patio.

Most places in NM give you giant portions, but this place has the food but in a portion that just filled me up, so I didn't overeat. I acutally liked the portion size a lot.

The chiles, which I get cravings for and are very hard to find in CA were just as good as most that you find in NM!

This place made me sosososo happy that I can get my chile fix and not have to fly all the way to ABQ. YAY!
author: Debbie C.

description:
So happy with this place. Great food, and one of the few that serves good calabacitas. 

Went last night, and was given the wrong burrito as part of a to go order. Made it outside and the young man ran out after us to tell us he had put in a chicken burrito rather than a vegetarian burrito. Was super happy he came out after us, and took care of it, rather than me having to return. Great service!
author: Jonathan B.

description:
I went on a dairy detox for no good reason recently, and found myself with a insatiable craving for mexican. of course, my usual mexican concoction consists of cheese enchiladas with extra cheese and a side of cheese, so this was going to be a hard craving to satisfy. 
but i found this place, and its one spot i can get my jones satisfied for delish mexican, even without the cheese. 

sometimes i dream at night about the posole. 

the wait staff has mood swings, but if you're in a decent mood, the food will overcome all that. however, i went the other day and was not in a good mood, so the fact that the counter chick got pretty diva when i asked her nicely for some soup bowls for my leftover posole, (she was all, "i just got here. i'll have to ...uh...go DIG for them if you really want)  made the aftertaste of the previously delicious chicken tacos turn into the taste of duckbuttoles and immediately ruined my lunch. 

But other than that, its a great place for a beer in the sun and some yum.
author: jesse s.

description:
It's pathetic, but I have to admit that I plan my weekends around the Green Chile Kitchen's breakfast burritos. I steadfastly refuse to leave my hood until I've walked the 1 block that separates my apartment from this mecca of breakfast burritos. 

Yes, they are THAT good. Seriously.
author: Tom A.

description: The burritos here are sooooo good! The best burritos I've had in SF since I moved here. Breakfast burrito = super soft tortilla filled with just the right ratio of eggs, potatoes, cheese, and soyrizo (or whatever meat you want)...then topped with warm red or green sauce. Yowza! I got tofu tacos once and they tasted like nothing. I'll stick to the burritos from now on.
author: Emily S.

description: They moved to a new location last year which is great because there is usually always room to sit. I have had their burritos, their nachos, and their salads. I have been pleased with them. I think it is a little overpriced, hence the 4 stars.
author: Victoria L.

description: Love the new location. Much more spacious. Food is great and the key is the $2 Pacifico. I tend to order off the a-la carte menu and keep my meal under $10 (incld the Pacifico). Everything I have had has been fresh and tasty. Thanks GCK!
author: Heather M.

description: Every time I go here I have trouble picking what I want...and it's not cause there's nothing good on the menu. For dinner, I usually end up with the 1/4 chicken all white meat dinner. It comes with Fulton Valley rotisserie chicken, rice, beans, mashed potatoes and tortillas for $9.50. Seriously good. Salads, enchiladas, and burritos are also great and generously portioned, and Pacifico is always $2.
author: Seth B.

description: The food here is awesome and for some reason they need help with their service.  While they are very nice they are too busy for the amount of people they have working there and are not efficient.  I called yesterday to place an order for pick up and the phone rang and rang and rang and rang and rang and rang and then when i showed up to order I had to wait 25 minutes for my order after waiting in line for 15 minutes so essentially it took 40 minutes for me to order and get my food.  they need a better system to handle how busy they are.
author: Rebecca A.

description:
Maybe i should be more generous, as the wait staff were pleasant enough and there was nothing actually bad about the food, but the problem was simply that both the posole and the green chile stew tasted almost the same, the only serious difference being the hominy in the posole.

I'd have been much happier if i hadn't known what a real posole and a real Chile Verde were supposed to taste like.
author: Matte G.

description: It's definitely worth a try-- the green and red chiles are excellent... overall, though, the food just lacks the deep intense flavor (high fat, cheese, etc) of authentic new mexican food.  good guacamole, though.
author: James K.

description: Randomly checked on the reviews for my favorite restaurant in the city and am shocked (shocked, I tell you!) by the small number of negative reviews.  Holy moly, what is wrong with you people?  Some dude mentioned it's dirty - WTF?  This is the cleanest Mexican (or New Mexican) place you are going to find anywhere, anytime, anyhow.  Seriously, I moved here just about a year ago from NYC and this was one of the first places I had the pleasure of dining.  Unlike the myriad of other overhyped, underwhelming restaurants in the city (can you hear me Nopa?), this place rocks every single time.  The freshest ingredients, nicest people and tastiest food.  I have never, ever been disappointed with a meal and sometimes wake up in a puddle of drool dreaming about their burritos.  To top it all off, they carry Blue Sky soda.
author: Chris V.

description: Just don't come here looking for a Mission burrito.  It's different:  Blue tortilla chips and small mason jars as water glasses.  I also wasn't expecting to use utensils to eat a super burrito, but with guac, sour cream, and chiles scooped on top, I had no other choice.  Turns out, it's all New Mexican inspired.  Prices are comparable to other Mexican establishments that tout the use of fresh, organic ingredients--not dirt cheap, but certainly not unreasonable.  Be sure to check out their killer breakfast burrito; it's only served on weekends.
author: Marsha Z.

description: The breakfast burritos are the bomb especially when satisfying the grease craving after a night of boozing. The habinaro salsa is super hot and delicious. The new location is great, much larger, with a nice big community table. The chicken dinners are also a great deal and yummy as well. At times it can be pretty crowded, so call in your take out order to avoid a wait.
author: Nathan J.

description: While the food here is good - It is so expensive bc of all the organic stuff you are paying for. Not only that but the people who work there are a little retarded and not very nice.
author: Jessica L.

description: Got some take out here recently.  I was in a healthy mood, so I decided to go with a salad.  For $8 you get to choose 5 toppings and the dressing choices are really delicious sounding.  I went with the chile lime vinaigrette which was a LOT spicier than I imagined.  But, it was still good nonetheless.  The space is really cute AND they have $2 Pacificas all the time.  Not too shabby.  Will def be back to check out the other menu items.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Just tried this brand new burrito shop for the first time tonight.  I walked the two blocks from my house a bit apprehensive after reading some of the Yelps and fresh off the disaster that was Tango 20!, yet with high hopes and nervous titillation, for I am a burrito addict.  I'm understandably anxious for a decent taqueria to arrive in this area, a neighborhood literally starved for decent food options.  Well, I was pleasantly satisfied with the product here: definitely a bit expensive and a little on the small side, but its quality ingredients, including Niman Ranch stewed beef, New Mexican green chiles and a nice avocado tomatillo sauce, help to pull off a very tasty and unique southwestern-style burrito.  Don't come here when you're looking for a ginormous Mission-style zeppelin to sate your ravenous hunger, but instead when you are prepared to try something a little different and you shall find happiness my sons and daughters.

Update: Went again last night. I think I might become addicted to this place (or any other decent burrito place near my house) The size was substantially larger this time, more along the lines of a Mission behemoth, but squatty and fat.  Pretty good stuff.

Update: Tried the green chile stew the other night.  It was a little runny for my taste. Will stick with burritos from now on.
author: Rick H.

description: Terrible, terrible service! When I went in there, they forgot my order, and after a while I realized it and told them, the wait staff did NOT make it a priority to make my food, and I ended up waiting 10 more minutes.  Then, when my food had still not come, I asked for my money back and the boy working gave me such attitude and told another worker, "you can deal with this."  I was HORRIFIED by the way they treated their customers, and I live in the NOPA neighborhood.  In addition to having terrible workers, their food is not very good and extremely overpriced!  I just think people don't know what good Mexican food is and that it doesn't have to cost you much. I will NEVER eat here again after the way their workers treated me.
author: Jenna W.

description: Being from new mexico I was a bit skeptical about "new mexican inspired" food. However since I had been craving green chile stew I had to try it out. Im glad I did , the stew is spot on. The burritos are big and the green chile chicken enchiladas are good. Not exactly what Im used to but better than nothing. !
author: Jerry M.

description: Soild flavorful tex mex!  My neighborhood go to for weeknights when I don't want to cook.  I love the grains and greens salad, and add tofu.  Burritto's are always good as well.
author: Lauren M.

description: some of the best mexican food i have ever had! i am already looking forward to my next west coast visit to eat here. the atmosphere isn't the best though - the lights are too romantically dim for it to be casual. the app order of guac is amazing, as are the chips that come with it. it's a small portion which is probably for the best because otherwise i would not have saved any room for my delicious meal. i had the hard shelled beef tacos which i highly recommend - comes with rice and beans (hold the sour cream, please!) as well as the standard tomato pieces and lettuce shreddings. perfectly portioned. no complaints!!!
author: Lori K.

description:
I would LOVE to give this place 5 starts and if I didnt have such a high standard i would have given it 5 stars already.  I finally took the whole family in.  After their first few bites, my 10 yr old and my husband looked at me like I had done something wrong.  I asked them if something was wrong with their food and didn't like it.  Umm, not quite.  They actually accused me of keeping this place a secret from them.  (thank Yelp, that I had proof that I was planning to bring them here but nobody listened to me).  They really liked it because they got their enchiladas the way they like them.  There are different ways to make enchiladas.  This place serves them up the two main ways you can get them.  Rolled and baked in a pan like a casserole or rolled and then cheesed and sauced and placed under a broiler until the cheese melts so that the tortillas keep their shape.  That's how the men in my family like them but when I cook I make them the way I like them--tortillas get soft and mushy.

My 8 yr old had issues with the tortillas and the sopapillas.  This kid knows his carbs.  He is right though, it is hard to get good corn tortillas around here.  The ones here are too chewy.  It makes me think it has something to do with the masa/flour ratio that is being used.  Then the dough to the sopapillas could use some lemon juice, vinegar or baking soda to lighten up the batter.  It is suppose to be as "light as a cloud" so that it really puffs up into little pillows.  Also, when they are deep fried, you've gotta give them the space to puff up.  That's why they are called sopapillas.    

We all plan to return.
author: Mary A.

description: Had a lovely Sunday brunch here.  No problems with parking (perhaps that's in the evening?), and lots of space at 11am on a Sunday.  The chile sauces were delicious, as was the guac and the spiced hot chocolate.  My friends said the meat was excellent.  I was a little let down by the vegetarian options.  There are lots of them, which is nice, but they all essentially consist of removing the meat from meat-based options --  which basically leaves you with a lot of rice and cheese.  Having said that, I didn't try the chile rellenos dishes, so I shall give that a go next time.
author: Sarah B.

description: A good neighborhood place for a simple, clean lunch or dinner in a nice, laidback environment. The burritos are* different from those at Papalote or the Mission, but it's a good different! They use only organic chicken and beef. I could taste* the chickenness of the chicken in my burrito ($6.95) -- which is a pleasant surprise. It's not drowned in marinade or sauce. I like being able to taste my meat, esp. since these days it's easy to forget what chicken and beef really taste like. I also like the green chile pork stew and their decent selection of interesting juices, spritzers, and organic wines. The food's certainly not KICK-ASS tasty, but it's NOT tasteless. It tastes natural and healthy. Good hot chocolate with* free cookie ($3.95). Four stars instead of five b/c the portions can stand to be a little bigger and the menu can get a bit boring after going there a few times.
author: Sumi Y.

description: This is NOT Mexican food or Tex Mex. This is wonderful Southwestern food. Their posole and green chile stew are as good if not better than what I used to have in New Mexico and I say better because of the quality of ingredients that go into their food from Fulton Valley Chicken to Niman Ranch Pork and Beef.
author: Claudia O.

description:
employees: friendly enough.

food: pretty good but not amazing. the veggie burrito i got was good but they didn't put the sour cream inside. the menu said it came with chips and salsa...i got 6 stale chips and a salsa that clearly came from a jar.

price: a little much for what it is. i'd be down to pay $7 for a burrito if there was a little more to it.

service: i waited 25 minutes for a veggie burrito. weeeak.

i won't be back unless they step up their game big time. :)
author: Abby R.

description: Great burrito, but seriously $12?  Other than the price I have not complaints.  Try the breakfast burrito too (ya, it's also $12)
author: Shawn H.

description: I used to come here a lot, and though the food is good, they screw up the order about fifty percent of the time. I pay for things I don't get and I'm so tired of it. So from now on all of my business will go elsewhere. Putting things in a bag shouldn't be this hard.
author: brant f.

description: When I got married, my husband feared he would never have the pleasure of eating a burrito with his wife.  Thanks to Green Chile, he can!  It's naked (in a bowl, no tortilla) and other discerning modifications, but we enjoy going here regularly.  I love supporting local businesses especially ones that care for the welfare of people, animals plants, the planet and our environment.  Bravo Trevor!  Business is so good that they moved to a bigger location. The manager has been there for years and is always really nice.  They will get 5 stars when they add brown rice.  Not having it seems out of sync with what they're about.  I have brought many people here over the years, even our picky daughter, and everyone loves it.  I love Santa Fe, and am thrilled it's flavors are here in SF.
author: S. K.

description: I really love this place...so casual but still has some energy to it.  The food is really good and can easily please anyone.
author: Ila L.

description: Whenever super nachos are offered on any menu, you must always get them. Why would you want rice, beans, even mashed potatoes on the side of your rotisserie chicken when you can have nachos? Everything I tried was good, especially the posole. Since it's in Aaron's hood and he intro'ed me to the place, I think I can safely say Green Chile Kitchen, mmmmmmmmmm!!!!!
author: Mimi L.

description: Great food and horrifically bad service about sums up Green Chile Kitchen. I walked in at 12:15 pm and the register was completely unmanned. Prospective customers were confused and the prep cooks who saw what was going on just stared lazily past us without telling the cashier to get the heck out front. During the lunch rush? Seriously?! They are also slow as molasses at filling orders and habitually screw up uncomplicated requests. The only reason I even bother to return to GCK is that I really, really love the food, even if it is regularly served with a side of incompetence. They use quality product - organic vegetables, Fulton Farms chicken, Niman Ranch beef, brown rice (at a Southwestern restaurant!) - and the housemade chile sauces are fabulous. It's comfort food that I can also feel good about putting into my body. Here's hoping the ownership reads this review and starts hiring some more, ahem, motivated waitstaff.
author: Heather F.

description: I'm kind of less impressed with Green Chile every time I go. I've had the nachos (too dry!), tamales (not amazing, but my favorite thing here. Good flavors on a generously portioned plate), chips (not salty enough for me, but I appreciate the blue corn tortillas - Yummy!), guacamole (not too bad), wet burritos (good and smoky, but not what I look for when I personally get a burrito craving). The atmosphere is nice, and it's a good place to go with friends. Overall, an okay place to grab a bite.
author: Andria M.

description: If you are a fan of New Mexican cuisine like I am then this is the place for you. I had the classic green chili enchiladas which brought back memories of Santa Fe. I cannot wait to go back. The reason I am giving it four instead of five stars is because they do not take reservations or offer full table service. You have to get there early, stand in line to order your food at the counter, and  somehow snag a table. The line can be really long because word is out that this place is good. Other than than it being crowded, loud, and having to wait in line to order food and get a table, the service is friendly and our food was ready quickly after it was ordered.
author: bonnie b.

description: Green Chile Kitchen is a block from my house and I LOVE it. I am so happy that they use sustainable, non-antibiotic meats. The steak burrito is delicious and I get it 'naked' without the tortilla and it's even better. The rotisserie chicken dinner is also wonderful and I just tried their tacos with ground beef and was super impressed. Check it out!!
author: Lucey M.

description: I have only come for the breakfast menu but really enjoy it! the breakfast chicken tacos are awesome and really filling. I'm a big fan of their outdoor seating when its available and the indoor vibe is laid back and homey. You order at the counter and prices are average from brunch, around $8.
author: Barbara C.

description: this is the first review I will have written and I am so glad it is for green chile kitchen. I was having a hard time deciding where to put my punches in first... and this place seems extremely appropriate to start. Now, I am not one to gush about burritos. As a San Franciscan I defiantly have had more then my fill. When I first went to green chile I was practically dragged down the street by my boyfriend and force fed a vegetarian burrito. given the yuppie vibes, I wanted no part of this gringo place. And the line situation is really confusing. (Everyone seems to be confused and don't know that they order then pay.)  BUT... it was amazing. I now crave it all the time. and if you live in the area it is just the thing for a night close to home.
author: alexis g.

description:
green chile kitchen has the best grilled chicken in the city. i'm serious. whether you get a whole meal or just a chicken burrito, you will not be disappointed with the flavor. the fulton valley chicken is always tender and features subtle touches of spice and chile flavor. i don't even live in NOPA anymore, but find myself going back for this hidden gem.

here are some tips to help out your dining experience:

- the chicken comes with different flavor rubs. try them out if you're feeling adventurous.
- this place is rather small and can get packed with families with young kids (probably because of the natural ingredients). i always call ahead and get my food to go in order to avoid the screaming babies. i rarely have to deal with kids in the city and i like to keep it that way.
- the breakfast burritos are also excellent here. soyrizo anyone?
author: Maveric V.

description:
While the food is reminiscent of the style of Mexican food you find in New Mexico, don't be fooled.  This is not a local neighborhood spot.  This is a cash cow.  The chili you get is in a tiny little container.  If you want more, it's an extra cost unlike the awesome salsa bars where you can load up anywhere else.  My husband ordered the $11 for 2 hard taco platter.  The menu state for $3 extra you could a third taco, but  since we usually find 2 tacos (in the Mission) to be way more than sufficient, he decided on 2.  But believe me, he was really considering 3.    They tasted great, but were the size of a quarter.  He was still hungry since he only ate 2 quarter sized tacos and didn't want to fill up on rice and beans and went to the front to request a 3rd taco for the $3.  Mind you, we spent $30 at an order at the counter Mexican restaurant with food that tastes no better than Pancho Villla or La Taqueria in the Mission on two quarter sized tacos and 1 count, 1 enchilada (my order) and some rice and beans.  They said that they could not give him the extra taco for the $3 and would have to charge him $4.35.

What?  We will be heading out to the Mission for our next venture into tacos.  If you want some tacos here, make sure to bring a lot of money.
author: Aurora H.

description: this place is awesome! the food is so fresh and I love the staff. There's a couple tables outside which is great when the weather is nice.
author: Kandace K.

description: I was debating over two or three stars for this review.  I think the food is good.  They probably have the freshest tortillas I have ever had, but the portions seemed very small for the price.  We got two cups of green chile pork stew, two enchilada plates, and two sodas.  The cost was $45.  There are just so many great taquerias in town that are half the price for twice the amount of food.
author: Russell C.

description: I love rotisserie chicken. I love when it is juicy, flavorful and falls apart at the touch of your fingers (yes, I am a picker). There should be no need for a knife when eating r.c. If you're looking for a r.c. option beyond Safeway, Andronicos, Falletti's, Costco, etc - try this cute little place with a Mexican flare. I've only tried their r.c. once - along with pork tamales, guacamole and sauted veggies - and I'm definitely willing to give it another try. Perhaps, I'll eat in next time. The nice part of about taking out was how I was able to order as I was leaving work, pay over the phone, cab over to the not-so-busy corner of Fulton and Baker, run in and run out (with food in tow). Nice, quick, yummy and a feeling of "gourmet-ness."
author: Deann M.

description:
3 stars from my boyfriend who loves their quesadilla (i just butchered the spelling didn't I?) and -1 star from me.

my guy really likes this place, it's in our neighborhood, it's good quality food and for someone that eats chicken, it's pretty darn good. No mission burrito.....but still great for the neighborhood.

I on the other hand have quite a different experience with this place. I think it's got great decor, I love that something like this is in the neighborhood and the people that work there are very nice and helpful and attentive. I totally want to support this small business but......

1) I got food poisoning the first few months they opened from the veggie burrito. 24hrs of throwing up. And it was everything I ate there.

Because of this experience, I could never go back. My body would get sick at the idea of it, even when i would stop in for a drink to go. So after year(s)? of convincing, my guy says "c'mon that was so long ago.... try it again, you'll like it."

So we go in, I decide to get the blue corn cheese enchiladas. I'm excited, it smells good and then I go to cut my enchilada's and I need a fucking axe to cut through the tortilla. I don't know if blue corn is suppose to be this tough, but it was ridiculous and it just felt undercooked. I mean, you can't really get melted cheese and sauce wrong so the tortilla is really where its at to pull it all together. So to make the best of it I start mixing my rice with the cheese and sauce instead...... the rice was from the bottom of the pan and I about crack a tooth chomping on gristly rice. FUN! 

the chocolate chip cookies are good (if they had been warm). I later found out they bake their chocolate chip cookies IN THE ROTISSERIE!!!! So vegetarians, be warned!!!!
author: K B.

description: One of the best breakfast burritos I have had. Thank god I have a default place to eat when I'm not sure what I want. There's always something I'm in the mood for.
author: Cory G.

description: Beautiful place and fantastic pie.  Best pie in the city.  I had the lemon buttermilk.  He had the apple/chile/cheese a la mode.
author: Kathy R.

description: Great food. A neighborhood gem. Unfortunately, they were very rude about letting us know they were closing in three minutes when we ordered. Half way through our meal, they were spraying tables and stacking chairs. Please note: it was only 9p.
author: Laura B.

description: Excellent place.  Often, I am dismayed by the fact that if I am in the mood for a burrito, I must subject myself to a run-down, Mission-style Taqueria joint.  Green Chile Kitchen, however... This is a NICE place.  I can sit down in there, and FEEL GOOD about it!  It's clean, it's got properly-dimmed lights, and the food is really excellent.  It's a proper SIT-DOWN burrito.  And that's great.  We need that here.  I will DEFINITELY be going back.
author: Eric H.

description: Very disappointed.  We had found information on this restaurant while researching places to eat while in San Francisco.  We couldn't believe our luck when we found this restaurant that 'specialized' in New Mexican food.  Being a native from New Mexico, it is always great to find these rare gems and we have never been disappointed in other cities in which we've found restaurants that serve authentic New Mexican food ( i.e Carlitos in Las Vegas, NV).  So we were quite excited to find this place.  Boy did we get let down!  We walked in and saw that it was an order at the counter type of restaurant, which was fine, nothing wrong with that. The crew seemed to be too busy texting and watching TV to be of any help with recommendations or actually even taking our order.  We finally ordered.  I ordered a burrito, Christmas style and my daughter ordered the stuffed sopapillas and an order of sopapillas.  The food took a long time to be ready and when it came it did not look very appealing. We assumed it was the chef that served us and told us that utensils were 'over there'.  So we got up and got utensils.  The food was lukewarm; the flavors of both the red and the green chile were not authentic tasting at all.   But worst of all my burrito actually tasted like it had been microwaved and was possibly not made that day.  The rice seemed old and clumped together and the beans were not fresh either.  The only exception was the sopapillas, which seemed to be the only thing made to order.  What topped off our wonderful (read sarcasm) experience at this restaurant was the staff.  What I believed to be the owner was scolding a worker in front of the restaurant in front of guests, the rest of the staff was hanging around the bar watching television and visiting with each other.  Not once were we checked on or served in any way. Our expectations were high for the food and it was sad to be as disappointed as we were hoping to have this be our go to place when in San Francisco but unfortunately we will probably never go back.  I am actually embarrassed to think that this food is considered a representation of New Mexican cuisine.
author: Monica R.

description: Sunday brunch is excellent (if you like New Mexico fare) and perfect for curing that hangover.  Bowl of Posole and I was ready to rock.  It does get crowded though so get there early and for god sake, eat your food and move on.  There's limited seating.
author: Corey V.

description: went a few times to be sure since its in my hood. expensive for average food that you stand in line for. beautiful interior. all in all, too many other good options nearby to go back.
author: Brian D.

description: This place is really good but only if you eat in.  Get your burrito super and they put all the stuff on top of your burrito and it is soooo good.  To go, not so much.
author: Reggie G.

description: Everything is amazing at the Green Chile Kitchen. It's definitely one of my favorite spots in the city. A couple of pointers- 1. watch how much you order- it can $ add up fast. 2. Make sure you mention that you want NO avocado on your taco (if you are allergic). 3. Be prepared to wait around for a seat or take it to go. And then get ready to eat some yummy down home food!
author: Michelle K.

description: having lived in the land of green chilie (Santa Fe [Tesuque to be exact]), I really don't see what all the hype is about this place! They do skimp on the green chilies in their dishes. And when I asked for Christmas they looked at me like I was crazy (that's red and green chilie together). While I can detect that o-so familiar and intoxicating flavor of green chilies in the food, it's underwhelming at best. It's certainly no Tecolote, Pasquals or Plaza Restaurant. When in Santa Fe these places are a MUST. Be sure and ask for Christmas to get the full spectrum of dynamic chilie flavor.
author: ashton c.

description: One of my favorite places in San Francisco. Awesome environment and excellent food that always tastes so fresh. The burritos are delicious as is their taco salad. It can be a little on the pricey side, but totally worth it. They also offer an interesting selection of alcoholic beverages like sangria. So good!
author: Kayleigh M.

description: OK i finally had what I think I should have gotten months ago, the CHICKEN DINNER.  This is the sort of meal I have been looking for - half a chicken, beans, rice, great salsa and a few tortillas for like $12.  PERFECT post-ride or -volleyball meal.  Can't believe it took me this long to figure it out.  Duh.
author: Matt S.

description: On an empty stomach and with a fresh twenty burning a hole in my pocket, I decided to grab a taco plate at Green Chile kitchen with some friends. Wow! This place is perfect for a casual dinner among friends. It is not loud and the food comes out quick. I decided to upgrade to the combo plate. Best decision of the day. Got the Chicken Tamale, Enchillada and Taco. The Taco's here are loaded with meat. Not a big fan of the green sauces and chili's but overall meal was delicious. This was a nice little ending to my day.
author: John S.

description:
it's not every day a piece of metal gets lodged in your burrito, but yesterday was my lucky day.  somewhere, nestled in between the avocado, and chicken was a strange, almost stringy object- that after a few seconds of chewing, and a few more spent contemplating the chances of having eaten a chicken bone, i spat, and found something entirely un-burrito like, let alone organic and poultry in my meal.  

apparently one of the scouring pads left a little souvenir, and the shock must have made me stupid, because i didn't move for a few minutes.  i was unable to register the phenomenon of having something NOT chicken in my mouth, and flinched at the sound of my boyfriend's suggestion to bring my burrito "surprise" to the kitchen, and to get another.  

so i did, hand out stretched, and thrusted forward to one of the staff cooking, like a kid who had just made a macaroni necklace.  i pointed to the metal thingy.  see here where the silver shines against the green guacamole smeared on my napkin, yeah, gac spit and scary metal shit, very weird.  anyway- that thing, it came from this hole i dug deep within this burrito log.     

okay, no quite so cute, it went more like, um guys, i found this in my food.  and they were like, um sorry.  and i was like, um ok.  puzzled, they took my damp napkin, the food, and apologized again.  the burrito maker looks defensive, the server apologetic and confused.

i go back to my seat, eat my boyfriend's blue tortilla chips to quell my ever so quail heart, and before you can spell Green Chile, Ian, the server dude walks over to us, and without a word places a full, cash refund of our entire meal on the table.  apologies.

then the defensive cook, comes out with my fresh burrito, apologies too, and all is glorious with the world again.  

i eat at Green Chile about once a month, and each time it warms my pigeon soul.  they have organic meats, and it's a bit pricy for mexican, but i don't feel lardy, and don't fart after, which is worth it's weight in beans.

considering the prompt response, and Ian's [the staff dude's] humbled admission of guilt, i will continue to brave many more burritos from this establishment.

i recommend the taco plate though.
author: Carolyn H.

description: I wish I ate here. But, I only strolled in to try the 4 buck mimosa. It was tangy and refreshing. The burritos looked huge and smelled delicious and I would have tried one had I not had dinner reservations already. I could tell that the food would have been great when I saw someone pulling the chickens out of the rotisserie and it filled the restaurant with a heavenly aroma.  Bonus points for donating a portion of burrito sales to charity on the day I went.
author: Michelle P.

description:
super fulton valley burrito, steak niman ranch burrito, tamale plate, posole, a beer, and hot chocolate.

...

yes.  
we were hungry.  

the masa was delicious.  the posole was good too.  

will definitely try the breakfast menu if i ever make it to the area in the morning.
author: Ting A.

description: I'm not from New Mexico, but I've been there a coupla times, & the Green Chile Kitchen does Green Chile RIGHT. Their super chicken burrito is addictive, & they have a nice selection of natural sodas to choose from (each different one I try seeminly more delicious than the last). The staff are friendly & chatty, & just my luck, it so happens to be four blocks from my house. Highly recommended if you're in the Panhandle & on the hunt for a high quality NEW Mexican style burrito.
author: Pete J.

description: Just got back from Santa Fe and was needing my fix of all things New Mex. Then I realized my fave local spot IS New Mex cuisine and it's dang good. I love the local vibe and the super friendly service. It's one step above feeling like a taqueria, which is refreshing in this city. Cheap beer and some Christmas (red and green chili) style anything and I'm one happy girl.
author: Kylie S.

description: It's right next to my house, and the smell makes me want a burrito every time I get home. I've eaten here several times and found their New Mexican inspired food way better than actual New Mexican food in New Mexico. The ingredients are fresh and they often have good deals on breakfast burritos. Come by here if you're in the neighborhood, it's not too pricey and it has pretty fast food turnaround.
author: Alex S.

description: Having lived in New Mexico for 9 years, we've been yearning for some good New Mexican food, so we had high hopes for Green Chile Kitchen. It didn't disappoint. We all had burritos, which were delicious. The ingredients were really good quality and portion size was good. The biggest disappointment is that we were there at 3 in the afternoon, and they don't start serving sopaipillas until 5 PM.
author: Katie B.

description: Great spot for take out dinner. The rotisserie chicken was very tasty. Minus one star because they packed the take out bag so full that all of the house made salsas that I purchased went flying off the top of my takeout boxes and smashed open on the ground.
author: Kay T.

description:
Went there last night with my husband and a friend, who lived in NM for years. He really likes the place. I did enjoy dinner and the $2 beer! The cost for 2 people was $28, which is very good becasue of the $2 beers. 

The food is good but no amazing! I think if I was in the hood, I would stop by again.
author: Loree K.

description:
3.5 stars
not sure what people are talking about with yuppie this and expensive that.  this is no mission burrito joint, but for a neighborhood eatery the prices are reasonable, the atmosphere is unpretentious, and the food is good (although i feel it could use a little more flavor at times).  the staff is friendly and you've got to give props for their efforts to use quality ingredients.  ask them for a side of the carrot-based habanero sauce, nowhere as hot as marie sharp's but it's good stuff.
author: Alfredo I.

description: What a treat! I can't tell you the countless times I've driven past this place and said to myself, "I should really check it out". Well, I regret it took so long to go in because I think I've found my new obssssion! I knew I wanted to save room for dessert so I went light with their Beet Salad with Chicken & Avo. Delicious! But the mouthwatering part came after we walked down the block to its sister, "Chili Pies" and order the Mexican Chocolate Pecan apiece with Three Twins Maple Walnut Icecream. Holy cow! I've already made plans to go with friends on Tuesday!!!
author: Peta B.

description: Fresh but bland Mexican food in a slightly hip setting.  Uncommon beer and wine choices, some interesting-sounding combo plates, but even their "hot" chile sauce wouldn't discomfort a baby's palate. Prices are a buck or two more than I'd have expected. Basically you can get better and cheaper in the Mission and other places in town, but for a local place it's comfy and serves decent quality food.
author: tw s.

description: Kick ass chile verde stew with a generous dollop of sour cream.  Watch out for the spice cuz it will make you sweat.  I would have liked a couple of corn tortillas on the side instead of the one flour tortilla that was served with it but I still recommed giving this place a try.  Plus they use organic veggies and the meat they serve is high quality.  And yes the mason jars made me smile.
author: Erin L.

description: I had a friend tell me about this place, she ate here all the time, cause she lived around the corner from here. She said it was a little bit expensive, so I put off eating here for a while. I shouldn't have waited so long. Green Chile is only 4 blocks from my apt., and the food is great. Green Chile uses niman ranch meat so I can understand way it's a little more then your average mexican joint.
author: Noah K.

description:
Green Chile is one of my favorite mexican restaurants in the City. It's New Mexican style Mexican cuisine, which I'm told makes a difference. In any case, it's delicious. They hold the title of "Best Breakfast Burrito EVAR!" Which is true. So go get one, with green sauce and bacon. 
Other than breakfast, they have a huge menu with many different options, such as layered enchiladas, burritos, stews, salads and tamales. I'm probably leaving something out. They use Niman Ranch beef and pork and Fulton Valley chicken, and use local ingredients whenever they can. They also have rotisserie chickens, so on a lazy night you can come by and get 1/4, 1/2 or whole chicken with either their green chile or citrus rub. 
They have two sauces. One is green, one is red. The red is ok, but it has a seriously smokey flavor. Maybe you like that, but I think the green is the best. You can get the green spicier, too. 
I can't recommend these guys enough. I love them.
author: Steffany F.

description:
three stars.  i wanted to give it more, based on a friend's rave reviews and based on their use of local, organic ingredients.  however, as i have found to sometimes be the case, the local, organic ingredients were high-quality but not-high-enough flavor.  

if i lived in the neighborhood, i would probably come here from time to time, as the steak burrito was tasty.  it's just not worth the 15 minute walk it took me to get there.  and if i am going to walk that 15 minutes, i'm going to papalote, which is about two blocks down on fulton and masonic.

sorry, green chile kitchen, i wanted to love you, but you were too bland.
author: Kirsten F.

description: I really like this place.  Its near my boyfriend's house and I've eaten here and gotten it to go.  I think both times I got tamales and they're really good.  The staff is really friendly.  And the restaurant is nice and clean with lots of seating (most of the time.)  They also have beer and other yummy juices.  It is on the more expensive side (for Mexican).  But I know I'll be back again.
author: Angela S.

description: i grew up in northern new mexico, with my spanish-ancestors living in the sante fe area and  making green chile dishes for 400 years, and i can clearly say this restaurant is the real thing.  Almost as good as my mom's and grandmother's cooking.  If you like authentic new mexican food, at reasonable prices, go here without hesitation.
author: joe r.

description: The food at this place is fantastic and the service is good. The breakfast burrito is out of this world good! And I love the cheap beer and kid's menu for the little ones.
author: Emilia D.

description: Merry Christmas to me!  Bring on the christmas salsa is what I say.  Not only is the chicken organic, but its slow roasted, non fatty, juicy goodness tastes great in a super burrito which always kills my super hangover!  And now, are you sitting down, they have Nachos.  Until this plate of heaven arrived, I used to think Kezar's had the best nachos.  They now pale in comparison.  Move over bacon...
author: Amy H.

description: Really like this place. High quality ingredients, really good value for the price, and I can't get enough of their red salsa.   Nice place to grab something good to eat. I do, however, have two complaints-- their phone service is pretty awful; they're not very friendly, almost curt, and they nearly always mess up my phone order.  Which brings me to my second complaint-- I usually order the chips and salsa, and about 50% of the time, I get a big sack of chip-bits, and a teensy container of that glorious salsa.  Seriously, if their salsa and crispy tacos and pozole weren't so damn good, I'd probably give them two stars.
author: Jill N.

description: Finally got to check this place out tonight. Such a great gem hidden in this residential neighborhood! Amazing, fresh food that is not your typical Mexican by any means. Highly recommend the red beet Margarita's! Lots of options for everyone- meat to vegan- and full of great flavor. Our kiddos loved it too.
author: Sara G.

description: I love you Green Chile, but you've been slipping. I haven't visited in a while, but when I did, I was expecting an amazing burrito. What I got was something mediocre. Please fully grill those burritos! I will patiently wait because it's better than the disappointment you feel when the cheese is completely not melted.
author: Faye P.

description: This spot is a real gem! Freakin delicious food, and $2 pacificos! BOOYAH! I love the tacos - steak, tofu, and chicken are all delicious, and the dinners come with MORE than enough rice & beans. I had a tamale the last time I went in, and man that shiz is delish! Also, the 'best of everything veggie' salad is large and satisfying. but beware the spicy chipotle lime vinaigrette dressing - it actually is pretty spicy!
author: S B.

description: This place reminds me of a cross between San Antonio tex mex and the chiles my grandma used to cook from New Mexico. A lot of the flavors are smokey and sweet. The beans are a bit bland, but if you just add one of the salsas your good to go. My bi-monthly dinner consists of the green chile enchiladas and a Butte Creek Pils. Butte Creek is a local brewery, hailing out of Chico where I spent five years of my life drinking this magic in a bottle. It pairs great with the stew as well. The nachos are filled with a large amount of toppings and definitely worth sharing with the table. I like to go midweek early evening when it's not as busy.
author: monika l.

description:
UPDATE: I feel kind of mean for my less-than-stellar review because the owner sent me a super sweet note offering to refund my hot chocolate and explaining why they put the sauce on top (apparently that's how they do it in New Mexico.)  I am touched.  Also, I'm living in England now, where they don't have burritos.  I would give ANYTHING for a proper burrito right now.  So, I'm upgrading this place to 3 stars for sincerity of business practice, which you don't see very often these days.

I had high expectations, so I was somewhat disappointed by this place.  I had the much-anticipated Niman Ranch burrito.  The ingredients were fresh and delicious, but they put the guac and sour cream on top of the burrito, turning it into a fork-and-knife ordeal, which is a big no-no for me.  The green chile sauce was kind of tasteless, and the salsa they served with the chips tasted more like marinara sauce than salsa.  Still, it was a decent burrito.  If I had stopped there, this place would have gotten 3 or possibly 4 stars.
But no, dessert fiend that I am, I had to order the Mexican hot chocolate.  It's not on the menu, but I could see the jar of chocolate behind the counter, so I ordered it.  They charged me $5.62 for a cup of hot chocolate!  Granted, it came with a cookie, which was tasty.  But the hot chocolate was definitely not worth it.  Boo.
author: Molly C.

description: Well, they get 4 stars because the food is great and reasonable priced, the staff is cute, they serve wine & beer and they are walking distance from my house.  The reason for the 5th star?  Curbside pickup for take-out orders.  Even better you charge it over the phone and they'll even cross the street to bring it to your car!  I think this is a wonderful service to offer in a city where parking tickets are easy to come by and legitimate parking is NOT.  Thanks Green Chile Kitchen for your wonderful salads and service!
author: V T.

description: I don't know why but I felt like Naachos the night we went to Green Chile Kitchen. Everyone else got something unique....burrito in a bowl, etc. but I just felt like Nachos and I'm glad i did.  I haven't ordered them since the kids were little and they're now grown adults. The nachos here were supreme, with very tender, juicy chicken layered in with the usual toppings but the guacamole was spicy, chunky and flavorful. The place had a steady stream of customers that all seemed to be served and waited on at a steady pace. I'll be back!
author: P G.

description: Dude. I will drag my ass all the way out from Glen Park (and circle for a half hour) to feast on New Mexican green chile stew any day of the week.  For you geography-challenged people out there, New Mexico is a state in the Southwestern U.S. with a distinct cuisine derived from but unlike Mexican food. Stop comparing GCK to your divey burrito joint in the Mission!  Order the chicken enchiladas - Christmas style - or the aforementioned stew (especially on a foggy night).  It isn't Duran's or Tomasita's, but only because SF couldn't handle that anyway.
author: Kerrinski S.

description: I live around the corner. Conveniently delicious. I love their super chicken burritos. They're huge too so for 6 bucks, I get lunch and dinner! I would call first for take-out. Sometimes there's a line out the door. Service is a tad bit slow but if the food's good...the food's good. It is what it is.
author: Jacinta H.

description: My sister lives in New Mexico so I have a soft spot for anything that's got green chili on it.  I LOVED my breakfast taco.  The food was really good and the coffee was awesome!  I was impressed with the size of everything and it was pretty inexpensive.  I'll be back to this neighborhood gem!!
author: Erin K.

description: Pretty much everything here is really good the nachos are HUUUGGEEE, and i usually get the steak quesadilla which has a bunch of stuff in it not just cheese and meat. I think it way better than papalote just a tiny bit more expensive. All the ingredients just seem to be really quality and fresh with a lot of organic local meats as well.
author: Matthew R.

description: My friends from New Mexico tell me that this isn't really authentic (note the "inspired" tagline), but when the cravings for green chile something kick in, I usually find myself here. The roast chicken is also pretty yummy, and I can't think of anywhere else one can have green chile mashed potatoes. Added bonus: beer, wine and tons of dessert options to satisfy my sweet tooth.
author: Suepattra M.

description: This restaurant has very quickly become our favorite weekend brunch/dinner place.  The people are friendly and real, they have amazing sustainable meat, kombucha on tap, organic and vegan beer and wine, great coffee, and the best take on New Mexican food I've experienced in the Bay Area.  The owners' love for New Mexico comes out exquisitely in the earthy, colorful decor and the cozy environment that it creates.  The wood bar is beautiful, the many windows and high ceilings have an expansive effect so that one can feel cozy and at same time not cramped- a rare combination in the San Francisco food scene.  There are booths, community tables, a little bit of outside seating for dog lovers, and a kid's style bar in front of the windows. It actually does a remarkable job of feeling like a family place without isolating people who are just there for a beer or even on a date. My partner and I have a friend who lived in the mountains near Albuquerque and is an expert on good New Mexican food.  He came into town to visit recently.  We took him to Green Chile Kitchen and he asked to go back the very next morning- very impressed.  I whole-heartedly recommend this place.  If you have ever been to New Mexico and have fallen in love with the marvelous green Chile the way I have; or just want something different but great quality, sustainable, tasty food is your compass; Green Chile is as good as it gets.
author: yebuny j.

description: I had the special of the day which was tamales.  They were good, not the best I've ever had (those were from a roadside shack in Arizona), but decent.  We started with the queso, good as well.  I love how clean this place is, how everything is fresh and lots of healthy and organic items.  Not your average taqueria, and definitely better than any of the food I had in New Mexico.
author: Sarah M.

description:
This place is awesome in so many ways that it's hard to know where to begin.  For one, they use super high quality ingredients that make for fantastic food quality.  For another, they have a pretty vast selection of wines and beers.  On top of that, the whole feel of the place is upscale, but also very relaxed and casual.  If you're in the mood for tasty mexican, with a great atmosphere to boot, then this is just the place.

I had the "Christmas" cheese tamales - you can't go wrong.
author: Patrick P.

description: the crispy taco is filled with a ton of flavorful meat but it doesn't taste any better than a taco bell taco. the nachos were okay. i think the idea of "new mexican" isn't for me. you could tell the ingredients were good and everything tasted kind of healthy, but i think i'll stick to greasy taqueria tacos/nachos. $16 for nachos and a single taco is not okay.
author: Regina C.

description:
I've been here once and I really want to go back. This is strange because I usually don't go for Americanized Mexican food but I guess this is New Mexican food. To compare it to traditional Mexican food would be unfair. 

I had the New Mexican chicken enchilada and it was delicious but very different than a traditional enchilada. The tortillas are layered between cheese, sauce, and roasted chicken (local, range-fed) before being baked to an ideal consistency. I ordered mine with red sauce but they offer green sauce or "Christmas" (both red and green).

The chips and salsa were also great. I asked for an extra hot sauce and they actually have a wonderful habanero salsa -- this is truly a rarity at such non-traditional, yuppie Mexican places.
author: Aaron S.

description: This place was satisfying however, not the best.  I will definitely give them another try in hopes to be a little bit more impressed.  The beans and rice were a little bit salty.  I ordered the chile and cheese tamales and it was just alright.  I am not sure if it was steamed in the husk for long enough because the masa was soggy.  I live down the street so I think I will give them another shot, but I will order something different.  I do like the fact that their are many different options for vegetarians, like myself.
author: Dominique T.

description: Green chile in San Francisco! Who would have thought. Takes me back to good times in Las Cruces. Jump in people. It's as good as it gets here. Had the blue corn cheese enchiladas, green chile of course, and got green chile stew to take home. Portions are sufficient. Try the blonde beer. Great atmosphere, simple yet neat and open. Buen comida!!! Viva chile verde!
author: Martin Z.

description:
Having lived in SF and eaten every variation on "the Mission burrito" for more than 17 years, I've never found it easy to call a winner... until now. The steak burrito at Green Chile Kitchen is THE WINNER, at least in that category. Every element is a refinement of the lardy and lower grade ingredients found in many burrito shops (for example, Niman Ranch beef). Also their salsas are freaking incredible. and... THE SIMMERED PORK BURRITO PLATE. mmmmmgggggghhhhh. Informal seating and layout great for kids, a nice addition to the hood. 

I know some people will stick to their favorite shop because they like the particular brand of lard used in their burrito, or because they like to remember their first date with their boyfriend, but I suggest you honestly put religion aside and judge Green Chile based on QUALITY rather than tradition... 

Anyway, for me, this is now the very first place to take out-of-towners. After calibrating your meter at Green Chile, theres always time to stop by Castilito, Pancho Villa, Papalote, Balazo, Zona Rosa or whatever.
author: d p.

description: This is my go-to place.  Whenever I want a good meal guaranteed, I can count on Green Chile Kitchen.  I haven't had a meal here that I did not like and their wine is great as well.  My only hope is that somehow they can magically expand for more seating.
author: Monique L.

description:
New Mexican green chiles and I had a short lived fling in December of 2000. I've been trying to find them in California ever since, in sauce, salsa, over beans, with tortillas or potatoes, on burgers, at the breakfast table, you know what I mean if you've had them before. Every time I get my hopes up, I'm let down. 
Green Chile Kitchen didn't really live up to my N.M. experiences, but that's ok, it wasn't a bad meal. 
The green chile stew could use some more meat in it and was lacking the richness that pervades N.M. green chile dishes. The meat was tender, just not enough of it. After trying the plato de aperitivos, I would recommend going with the green chile queso, a warm cheesy chile dip that's good spread on everything. The quac was good, but wasn't spicy enough, and the salsa were pretty good. I appreciate that G.C.K. is using natural meats. The quarter chicken dinner came with a large salad and salsa. The chicken was tender and had a typical rotisserie style flavor. 
Didn't really find anything to rave about, but the people were nice, the space is clean and pleasant, the prices are very reasonable (except for making you pay for salsa), and if it was in my hood, I might hit it up once in a while. I do wish that they would provide some spicy options on their menu. Lots of people say that NM green chile isn't about the spice, but many dishes I tried in the SW had a healthy burn to them. Oh yeah, stop using the  tortilla steamer, it yields rubbery tortillas. Somewhere in the 2.5 to 3 star range.
author: Candice L.

description: Mmmm, Christmas sauce. No, not the creepy mystery kind your uncle brought to dinner, a combination of green and red ranchero styles sauces, found here! First of all, Green Chile is using high quality meat ingredients, and telling the consumer where it comes from. That alone deserves the four stars!! On top of the phenomenon, the food is quite tasty. I sampled some nachos that were the best outside of home made I've had in quite some time. The burrito was a little bland (even though I got it super styles), but everything tasted fresh. Their tamales weren't half bad either. The interior of the space is rather small, kind of dark, and pretty cold on days like the one I experienced (rainy, early evening).
author: Shannon F.

description: The tortilla on my enchilada was so dry and hard, the knife couldn't cut thru it.   Really no reason to go here when Little Chihuahua is so close by.
author: Joshua S.

description:
Nearly good enough to be a 4, but not quite.
Green Chile is an order-at-the-counter, get a number, and take a seat sort of place.  They also have some surprisingly nice wine.  Kind of an unusual combination.
An important thing to know is that if there's a large line at the register when you get there, you might want to go elsewhere unless you don't mind sitting around for a long time (like half an hour) waiting for your burrito.
If there isn't a long line, though, the food is pretty tasty, .  It's the closest thing to authentic New Mexican-style that I've had yet around here.  Burrito tortillas are steamed, but then the entire thing is grilled after it's finished.  Unfortunately, the grill isn't used for much else, so you don't get the delicious extra flavor the grill at your usual taqueria will contribute to a grilled tortilla.  The Niman Ranch steak in my burrito was on the tough side, which was too bad.
Tacos and tamales are excellent though.  The green chile stew was relatively unremarkable.
author: Don H.

description: I love curbside delivery service! So nice not to have to find parking when you're solo. Got the posole the other night and it was pretty good. Interested in trying more items. With the convenience of curbside delivery I definitely will. :-)
author: Sarah R.

description: This place has really good food it is sort of pricey though, I forgot if all of the stuff they use is local or organic, even if it local it should be slightly cheaper because local food cost less!
author: Janet Z.

description: Being a native New Mexican I was excited to have Green Chile Kitchen open in my neighborhood.  I wasn't disappointed and the place keeps getting better.  Great green chile stew with chicken, breakfast burritos, salads and the only good sopapillas I've ever had outside of the Land of Enchantment.
author: C S.

description: I have been going to this place since it opened in the other location.  I am always excited to go there for there ground beef burritos and tacos.  Since it got to the larger location service has definitely been slower and the meat not as generous but I still go back.  So I guess that means I always enjoy my meal.
author: nicole k.

description:
One of my daughters lives close enough to walk to this place, so we frequent Green Chile Kitchen fairly regularly.  It is a treat!

Breakfast burritos and tamales with champagne or mimosas on Saturday or Sunday are a great way to start the day!  Everything is very fresh and delicious.
